Traffic wardens are employed in a growing number of areas to help the
police in dealing with the problems created by parked vehicles and in the
control and regulation of traffic. In specially designated areas traffic wardens
issue fixed penalty tickets which give motorists who have committed certain
parking offences an option to pay their fine to the clerk of the appropriate
court instead of having their cases tried. A county or county borough council
(or by agreement a police authority) may also employ school-crossing patrols.
Every police officer in Great Britain is an independent holder of a public
office. His powers as a constable, whether conferred by statute or by common
law, are exercised by virtue of his office; he is not a servant of the police
authority. Chief officers of police in England and Wales have a vicarious
liability for any wrongful act committed by their subordinates in the
performance of their functions as constables.
The many and varied functions of a police officer as a constable range from
the protection of persons and property, road or street patrolling and traffic
control to criminal investigation and the apprehension of offenders.
All police forces have their own criminal investigation departments, and
many have other specialised departments, including motor patrols, river police
(in districts which include long stretches of navigable waterway), a mounted
branch (for maintaining order and safety in large crowds), and police dogs.
During recent years a number of common services have been provided by
the central government departments for the benefit of all forces; they
supplement those provided by the police authorities for their own use and
by communal arrangements made between the forces themselves. The most
important of these services are: training services, which in England and Wales
provide ten residential training centres and a central police college and in
Scotland a central police college with courses of recruit training and higher
training; a forensic science service in England and Wales which provides
nine laboratories (in addition to the Metropolitan Police Laboratory) for the
use of regional groups of forces; regional wireless services and wireless depots,
which in England and Wales supply and maintain wireless equipment for the
police; and central and provincial criminal records which are available to all
forces. Regional crime squads, consisting of teams of experienced detectives
from several forces, are employed to investigate major crimes involving
inquiries in more than one police area. Arrangements are also made for
everyday assistance by one force to another.
The Home Office Police Research and Planning Branch, headed by one of
Her Majesty’s Inspectors of Constabulary and staffed by senior police officers
and scientists, is charged with the planning of police methods, the develop¬
ment of new equipment and the study of new techniques throughout Great
Britain. Its current programme covers various aspects of criminal investigation,
traffic policing, establishments (force strengths), recruitment and wastage in
the Service, vehicle replacement, the evaluation of equipment requirements,
and the application of computers to police work. A considerable amount of
the work in which the Branch is engaged involves the use of operational
research techniques.
Services provided by the Metropolitan Police Force for other forces include
(1) the publication of the Police Gazette,1 which contains particulars of people
1 The Scottish Criminal Record Office in Glasgow is responsible for the publication
of the Scottish Police Gazette.

wanted for crime and details of stolen property, and is supplied without
charge to the police forces of the United Kingdom and to certain other Com¬
monwealth and foreign forces; (2) the organisation and control of the special
branch of the criminal investigation department at New Scotland Yard,
whose duties include the physical protection of royalty, some ministers, and
distinguished foreign visitors; and (3) the carrying out of extradition orders
made by the courts. The Metropolitan Police Force is also available, on
request, to assist any other police force in England and Wales in criminal
investigations. Similarly, the services of the Fraud Squad, run jointly by
the Metropolitan Police Force and the City of London Police, are available
throughout Great Britain for the investigation of serious company frauds.
The National Central Bureau, which handles the business of the International
Criminal Police Organisation (Interpol) on behalf of Great Britain and the
British dependencies, is part of the Metropolitan Police Force. For certain
of these services, the Metropolitan Police Force receives an additional
Exchequer grant.
The Royal Ulster Constabulary comes under the direction of the Inspector
General, who is responsible to the Minister of Home Affairs. It undertakes
the policing of the whole of Northern Ireland, its cost being borne by the
Northern Ireland Exchequer.
The strength of the Royal Ulster Constabulary is approximately 3,000. The
Inspector General has, under his immediate command, a deputy inspector
general, a commissioner for the City of Belfast, and a county inspector for
each of the six counties. The area is further sub-divided into districts, each
district coming under a district inspector and each sub-district under a head
constable or a sergeant. Conditions of service and pay follow closely on the
lines of the police service in Great Britain, and the general duties pertaining
to the various ranks are much the same. Although the more senior ranks bear
different titles, the ranks of head constable, sergeant and constable are broadly
equivalent to the three junior ranks in the police service of Great Britain.
The Ulster Special Constabulary, which may assist the Royal Ulster
Constabulary on special occasions, also comes under the direction of the
Inspector General. In the main, this force is a part-time body of some 10,500
part-time members with a small nucleus (no) of full-time personnel for
organisation and training purposes.
4 Defence
Policy and
Commitments
Costs
Peace-keeping
and
Disarmament
Britain’s security depends above all on the prevention of war in Europe, and
for this reason Britain makes a substantial contribution to the forces of the
North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO). In addition, Britain has a
political and economic interest in the stability of the world outside Europe,
and accordingly retains a capacity to contribute to the maintenance of peace
where this can usefully be done by British forces. Britain belongs to the
Central Treaty Organisation (CENTO) and the South East Asia Treaty
Organisation (SEATO), which involves certain defence responsibilities in the
Middle and Far East; has defence obligations under various bilateral and
multilateral agreements; and is ultimately responsible for the defence and
internal security of British dependencies overseas.
Information about defence policy and the armed forces is provided by the
Government in an annual Statement on the Defence Estimates. In 1967, the
usual statement (Cmnd. 3203) issued in February was followed in July by a
Supplementary Statement on Defence Policy (Cmnd. 3357) marking the end of a
three-year major policy review. Defence policy can never be static; this chapter
describes the position in July 1967.
It is Britain’s policy not to undertake major operations of war except in
co-operation with allies; not to attempt to maintain defence facilities in an
independent country against its wishes; and to make military commitments to
other countries dependent on receiving in time the facilities necessary to
ensure that such military support is effective. Outside Europe Britain aims to
foster developments which will enable the local peoples to live at peace without
the presence of external forces. Defence policy provides for closely integrated,
well-equipped and trained, highly-mobile regular forces, including a strategic
reserve maintained in Britain and able to move rapidly by air to any part of
the world.
In order to keep defence costs within the country’s resources, the British
Government has carried out a major review of defence policy resulting in
decisions which are expected to keep the future annual cost of defence below
£2,000 million at 1964 prices. The defence estimates for 1967-68 of £2,205
million were equivalent, at 1964 prices, to £1,927 million.
Foreign exchange costs arising from the stationing of British troops abroad,
including those in Germany, were estimated at £293 million in 1966-67, thus
constituting, as in previous years, a heavy burden upon Britain’s balance of
payments. It is aimed to achieve, by the end of 1967-68, an annual rate of net
overseas expenditure about £75 million below that estimated for 1966-67,
without allowing for any further reductions in expenditure on British forces
in Germany that may be arranged. Foreign exchange costs in Germany for
1967-68 will be covered by offset arrangements to the extent of some 90 per
cent.
The British Government believes that, in the long term, the security of all
countries would be best assured by developing systems of arms control and
disarmament and by strengthening the peace-keeping capacities of the
United Nations, and is working to achieve these ends. Britain has signed,
112
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Service
Management
Service
Organisation
and strongly supports, the 1963 ban on nuclear tests in the atmosphere,
under water and in outer space, and the treaty agreed in 1967 excluding
weapons of mass destruction from outer space and reserving celestial bodies
for peaceful uses.
PLANNING AND CONTROL
Supreme responsibility for national defence rests with the Prime Minister
and the Cabinet, under the ultimate control of Parliament. Defence problems
and their implications for foreign and economic policy are dealt with on
the Cabinet’s behalf by the Committee on Defence and Oversea Policy,
under the chairmanship of the Prime Minister. The formulation of defence
policy is the responsibility of the Secretary of State for Defence (see
P- 52).
Command and administration of the armed forces is vested in the Defence
Council, under the chairmanship of the Secretary of State. The members of
the Defence Council are the two Ministers of Defence, the three Parliamentary
Under-Secretaries of State, the Chief of the Defence Staff and the Chiefs of
Staff, the Chief Adviser (Projects), who is professional head of the Ministry
of Defence scientific staff, and the Permanent Under-Secretary of State.
The Defence Council deals mainly with major defence policy. The
principal military advisers to the Government are the members of the
Chiefs of Staff Committee, which comprises the Chief of the Defence Staff
as chairman and the Chiefs of Staff of the three Services. The Com¬
mittee is responsible to the Government for professional advice on
strategy and military operations and on the military implications of defence
policy.
The management of the three Services is delegated to Admiralty, Army and
Air Force Boards of the Defence Council, of each of which the Secretary of
State is chairman, although the appropriate Parliamentary Under-Secretary
of State normally acts for him. Unified control of policy and management has
made possible further rationalisation of Service administration and operation
and improving the work of the whole structure of defence organisation is
continuing.
The Royal Navy has nine specialist branches: Seaman, Communications,
Engineering, Fleet Air Arm, Electrical, Supply and Secretariat, Medical,
Shipwrights and the Regulating Branch.
The Corps of the Royal Marines, which is part of the Royal Navy, is a body
of men trained for service on sea or land. Its official existence dates from
1664. The present-day functions of the corps are: to provide personnel for
Commandos; to provide crews for minor landing craft and certain other
parties required for amphibious assault; and to supply for Her Majesty’s ships
detachments which take part in the routine duties, including guard duty, and
provide emergency landing parties.
The Army is organised into some 30 arms and services which include the
Household Cavalry, the Royal Armoured Corps (the historic Cavalry Regi¬
ments and the Royal Tank Regiment), the Royal Regiment of Artillery, the
Corps of Royal Engineers, the Royal Corps of Signals (which provides land

Women’s

and wireless communications), the five regiments of Foot Guards (the Brigade
of Guards), the Infantry of the Line (to be regrouped into divisions), the Army
Air Corps (which operates light aircraft on reconnaissance and undertakes
aerial observations and liaison work), the Royal Corps of Transport (which
operates all types of logistic vehicles from locomotives to aircraft), the Royal
Army Medical Corps, the Royal Army Ordnance Corps (responsible for most
equipment and stores), and the Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers
(responsible for most repairs).
The specialist branches of the Royal Air Force are the eight Home
Commands (see below).
The three women’s services, the Women’s Royal Naval Service (WRNS), the
Women’s Royal Army Corps (WRAC) and the Women’s Royal Air Force
(WRAF), are integral parts of the Navy, Army and Air Force respectively.
Servicewomen serve alongside servicemen in Britain and overseas. Nursing
services are provided by Queen Alexandra’s Royal Naval Nursing Service,
Queen Alexandra’s Royal Army Nursing Corps and Princess Mary’s Royal
Air Force Nursing Service.
Operational control of the Forces in the Persian Gulf and Far East is exercised
through Unified Command Headquarters in Bahrain (seep. 116) and Singapore
respectively by a single commander, who may belong to any one of the three
Services; he is supported by an inter-Service staff co-ordinated by a Chief
of Staff. These arrangements are one of the most important features of the
increasing unity of the Services.
The structure of the home commands is being radically altered in order
to bring the bulk of combat forces in Britain under a single major front-line
command in each Service. Meanwhile the home and overseas commands of
the Services are:
Portsmouth, Plymouth, Scotland (Rosyth) and Northern Ireland, and the
Commander-in-Chief, Western Fleet. British naval forces in the North
Atlantic and Mediterranean area are assigned to NATO. Naval command in
the Middle East rests with the Flag Officer, Middle East, and in the Far East
with the Commander, Far East Fleet. Smaller naval forces operate under the
Senior Naval Officer, West Indies Station.
Eastern, Northern, Northern Ireland, Scottish, Southern and Western
Commands. The British Army of the Rhine (BAOR, assigned to NATO);
Gibraltar; Malta; Near East Land Forces; Land Forces Gulf; and Far East
Land Forces. In April 1968 all field force formations and units in Britain,
apart from those earmarked for assignment to NATO or employed on
public duties and training, are to be brought under a new Army Strategic
Command.
Bomber, Fighter, Coastal, Transport (from August 1967, Air Support
Command), Flying Training, Technical Training, Maintenance and Signals
Commands; Royal Air Force, Germany (Second Tactical Air Force, assigned
to NATO); Near East Air Force; Air Forces, Middle East; Far East Air
Force. From April 1968, Bomber and Fighter Commands will be merged
into a new Strike Command. Flying Training and Technical Training
Commands are to be amalgamated into a single Training Command from
1st June 1968.

Entrants to the non-commissioned ranks of the three Services are given
basic training, and further training is given during the course of their careers.
Young servicemen have the opportunity to read for the General Certificate of
Education ‘O’ level (see pp. 158-9). Trade and technical training, though
primarily designed for Service purposes, leads in many cases to nationally
recognised qualifications; completion of many Service trade or technical
courses followed by experience is recognised by trade unions as a qualification
for membership by men who have left the Services.
Commissions may be granted for short, medium or long terms. Promotion
from the non-commissioned ranks is possible in all three Services. In the
Royal Navy and the Army the normal method of entry is through cadetship
in the Britannia Royal Naval College, Dartmouth, or the Royal Military
Academy, Sandhurst. This is followed by specialist training which may include
degree courses. The RAF trains cadets for long-term commissions at the
RAF College, Cranwell, Lincolnshire, but the majority of entrants to the
flying and executive branches take Direct Entry Commissions (of medium
length). There is special provision in all three Services for the entry of men
with appropriate qualifications including doctors, dentists and other
graduates. A Royal Defence Academy is being set up to provide higher educa¬
tion for men from all three Services. It will comprise a Royal Defence College
together with the three existing Service technical colleges.
Selected officers of all three Services who have had previous staff training or
have been to the Royal Naval Staff College, Greenwich (London), the Army
Staff College at Camberley (Surrey), or the Royal Air Force Staff Colleges at
Bracknell (Berkshire) or Andover (Hampshire) go to the Joint Services Staff
College at Chesham (Buckinghamshire), where particular attention is paid to
the inter-Service aspects of staff work. A few specially selected and more
senior officers from the Services, the Civil Service, and from other Common¬
wealth countries are sent to the Imperial Defence College in London.
Considerable training is done through joint-Service and inter-allied exercises,
on which increasing emphasis is being placed. Inter-allied exercises take
place under the auspices of the three regional alliances.

RESERVE AND

forces

ii5
The Regular Reserve consists of various categories of former full-time officers
and ratings liable to recall in emergency. The Voluntary Reserves comprise
the Royal Marine Reserve (with its associated women’s reserve) and the
Royal Marine Forces Volunteer Reserve, and carry out part-time training.
The Royal Naval Auxiliary Service, a civilian organisation composed of
men and women volunteers, is responsible in time of war for minewatching
duties around the coast and the waterways, and other duties.
Men who have completed the Colour portion of their service with the Regular
Army are retained on the Regular Reserve to complete a total engagement of
12 years; as such they are liable to recall to the Colours. Thereafter they are
transferred to the Long Term Reserve (LTR) where they remain until the age
of 45 and are liable to recall in an emergency.
The Territorial and Army Volunteer Reserve (T & AVR) comprises
categories I and II (the ‘Volunteers’), category III (the ‘Territorials’) and
section IV. Category I, together with individual volunteers from the Regular
Reserve and T & AVR II, is known as the Special Army Volunteer Reserve
(‘Ever Readies’), liable to be called out at any time at the discretion of the
Secretary of State for Defence. T & AVR I and II are liable for service with
the Regular Army when warlike operations are in preparation or progress.
T & AVR III is liable for recall for home defence only. T & AVR IV consists
of miscellaneous reservists not included in the other categories.
The Regular Reserve consists of former full-time officers and airmen, of whom
a few are detailed for specific tasks in emergency and the remainder have a
statutory liability for recall. The Royal Auxiliary Air Force, consisting of
three maritime headquarter units controlled by Coastal Command, and the
Royal Air Force Volunteer Reserve are liable for part-time training and for
recall in an emergency. Auxiliary formations include the mainly civilian
Royal Observer Corps and the 18 University Air Squadrons (for information
about the Combined Cadet Force, see p. 174). The present strength of the
Royal Observer Corps is some 18,000 men and women whose principal task
would be the measuring and reporting of radioactivity in the event of nuclear
attack.
DEPLOYMENT
In January 1967 British and locally enlisted troops were deployed roughly as
follows:
Britain, 243,300; European continent, 63,460 (nearly all in Germany);
Mediterranean and Near East, 20,300; Middle and Far East, 72,650
(including Gurkhas); and elsewhere, 43,290 (mostly Royal Navy at sea).
Britain’s deployment of forces is summarised below:
Frigates, submarines and coastal minesweepers carry out training, trials and
fishery protection, and ships of all classes spend periods at home for refitting. All
ships at home have NATO commitments in the Channel or Eastern Atlantic.
The Army Strategic Reserve and certain other front line units and skeleton
headquarters are kept in readiness. There are also training and logistic units.
Air Force units are V-bomber, reconnaissance and tanker forces of Bomber
Command; air-defence forces of Fighter Command; strategic and tactical
transport and ground-attack squadrons of Transport Command; maritime
n6
Germany
Contribution
to NATO
Mediterranean
and Middle
East
Far East
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
reconnaissance squadrons of Coastal Command and squadrons of the Royal
Air Force Regiment.
Britain has stationed in the Federal Republic of Germany an army corps of
three divisions—the British Army of the Rhine (BAOR)—with associated
troops and a tactical air force including light bomber, reconnaissance and
air-defence squadrons; also fighter reconnaissance aircraft and support
helicopters and a brigade in Berlin (which the NATO powers have agreed to
treat as part of the Atlantic Treaty area): giving a total force of some 63,000.
BAOR equipment includes, as tactical nuclear weapons, the Honest John
free-flight missile and the 8-inch howitzer.
Britain’s contribution to NATO includes the strategic nuclear V-bomber
force, all Fighter Command and nearly all Coastal Command, over three-
quarters of the Royal Navy’s operational and reserve fleets and all British
forces in Germany. The V-bomber force, in its strategic role, will be replaced
by the Polaris force (see pp. 117-8) as it becomes operational.
Facilities for a depot ship for United States Polaris submarines are provided
by Britain at Holy Loch on the Firth of Clyde, Scotland, while the Ballistic
Missile Early Warning Station built at Fylingdales Moor, Yorkshire, under
an Anglo-American agreement of i960 completes a chain of such stations
formed with Thule (Greenland) and Clear (Alaska).
Britain contributes toward the defence infra-structure of the CENTO area,
provides various military training facilities and keeps an RAF bomber force
in Cyprus for the defence of the region. Britain also supplies at its own expense
about 1,000 men for the United Nations Force in Cyprus (more than one-fifth
of the total) and provides logistic support for the force. Certain forces are
stationed in Malta under bilateral arrangements and there is a small garrison
in Gibraltar.
Destroyers, frigates and minesweepers are deployed in the Mediterranean
and are supplemented from time to time by other major naval units.
Middle East land forces numbered about 11,500 at the beginning of 1967,
mostly stationed in Aden and Bahrain. The Aden garrison is being run down
and is to be withdrawn as South Arabia becomes independent in 1968.
Forces in the Persian Gulf will be slightly increased.
Royal Navy frigates and coastal minesweepers have been operating in the
Persian Gulf and Aden area. A Royal Marine Commando was based in Aden
during 1967. East of Suez one aircraft carrier, one commando ship and one
assault ship have been operating as needed between the Far and Middle East
theatres.
Royal Air Force units stationed in Aden during 1967 included ground-
attack, fighter reconnaissance, tactical transport and maritime reconnaissance
aircraft, helicopters and a field squadron of the RAF Regiment. Units in
Bahrain and Sharjah comprised ground-attack aircraft, tactical transport and
communications aircraft.
In the SEATO area, Britain provides training facilities and, in particular, has
built an airfield in Thailand with the help of Australia and New Zealand.
In addition to ships mentioned in Middle East section above, there are many
destroyers (some with guided missiles), frigates, submarines, coastal mine¬
sweepers and support ships; two Royal Marine Commandos and two Royal
Marine special boat sections; and ships of the Royal Australian and Royal
New Zealand Navies, attached to the Fleet.

The Far East Air Force includes light bomber squadrons; reconnaissance
aircraft; air-defence forces, including guided missiles; ground-attack and
medium- and short-range tactical transport squadrons; Royal Air Force
Regiment squadrons; and units of the Royal Australian Air Force and Royal
New Zealand Air Force.
Singapore provides bases for all three Services.
With the end of Indonesia’s campaign of ‘confrontation’ all British troops
were withdrawn from Eastern Malaysia and by the end of April 1967 troops
in Far East Command had been reduced to about 30,000. In October 1967
there is to begin a two-year run down of the Brigade of Gurkhas from 14,000 to
10,000 men.-A small garrison of Gurkhas is stationed in Brunei. A substantial
garrison, including a Gurkha brigade, remains in Hong Kong.
A small naval force, normally of frigates and sometimes carrying a Royal
Marine detachment, is stationed in the Caribbean and South Atlantic. There
is a small garrison in British Honduras. HMS Protector operates in the Falkland
Islands and Dependencies and the Antarctic during the period of the southern
summer.
Royal Navy submarines are based in Canada and Australia to assist in
anti-submarine training for the Royal Canadian and Royal Australian Navies.
COMBAT FORCES
Combat forces can be divided into six major groups, according to their functions
and corresponding equipment, as described below.
The nuclear strategic forces are the medium bomber force (V-bombers) of
Royal Air Force Bomber Command (together with their headquarters, bases
and control and support facilities), which are being progressively replaced by
the Polaris Fleet of the Royal Navy as it becomes operational. Their cost in
1967-68 is estimated at £104 million. Their role is to contribute to the
strategic nuclear deterrent forces of the West. To achieve this, the nuclear
forces must be seen to be able to inflict an unacceptable degree of damage upon
an aggressor.
Britain has assigned its strategic nuclear force to NATO, and has played a
leading role in discussions intended to devise means of ensuring that decisions
concerning the use of nuclear weapons by the Alliance be taken in accordance
with the wishes and interests of the Alliance as a whole.
The V-bomber force comprises Victor Bz squadrons and Vulcan Bz squadrons,
equipped with either Blue Steel stand-off bombs or free-fall weapons.
The effectiveness of the force has been increased by progressive improvements
to electronic equipment and nuclear weapons, and greater fuel capacity. A pro¬
portion of the force is always kept at readiness. In addition to their nuclear
strike role, V-bombers can carry conventional weapons and, in an emergency,
can be deployed rapidly for operations in other theatres.
The first Polaris submarines, Resolution and Renown, have been launched,
and Resolution will become operational during 1968. The force will ultimately
consist of four submarines, two of which will always be on patrol at a time.
Each submarine will carry 16 long-range missiles. Construction of the
submarine base on the Gareloch (north of the Clyde estuary) should be
completed in 1968. When the Polaris submarines come into service they will

take over the strategic role of the V-bombers, which will then be used to
supplement the FmK aircraft (see p. 121) in the strike role.
The European theatre ground forces consist of the BAOR and an independent
brigade in Berlin. Their role is to deter aggression in all its forms and to
fight if deterrence fails, in co-operation with NATO allies. Their cost in
1967-68 is estimated at £184 million.
The Chieftain main battle tank is succeeding the Centurion, and Conqueror has
been withdrawn from service. It incorporates many new features in protection
and mobility. Two armoured car regiments are equipped with the Vigilant
anti-tank guided weapon mounted on the Ferret scout car. Swing fire, a long-
range, guided, anti-tank weapon, will be introduced into certain units during
1968. The field artillery supporting the general war ground forces have received
several new weapons, including the British Abbot self-propelled 105 mm. gun
(which has good cross-country mobility, range, fire power and protection for
its crew) and the American self-propelled 155 mm. Mi09 and 175 mm. Mi07
guns. Missile regiments equipped with the Honest John free-flight rocket and
the 8-inch howitzer provide surface-to-surface tactical nuclear support for the
ground forces. The new tracked armoured personnel carrier is increasing the
mobility and protection of the infantry, who are also being provided with
improved chemical and nuclear defensive equipment. Carl Gustav anti-tank
weapons have been made available to infantry sections. A semi-automatic
multi-channel trunk system for communications in the combat area is being
introduced in BAOR.
The naval general purpose combat forces are the ships of the Fleet1 II other than
the Polaris submarines; the Fleet Air Arm (aircraft carriers, naval aircraft,
air personnel and shore naval air establishments); the Royal Marine Com¬
mandos ; and support ships and overseas bases, dockyards and supply depots.
Their role is to help to keep the peace and to protect and further trade and
other British interests; in an emergency to be ready to safeguard the use of
the sea and to support the Army; and to make an effective contribution to
the forces of NATO, CENTO and SEATO. Their cost in 1967-68 is estimated
at ^291 million.
The two commando ships HMS Albion and HMS Bulwark, the two assault
ships HMS Fearless and HMS Intrepid, and the Royal Marine Commandos
are the amphibious forces. Commando ships are equipped with Wessex Mark 5
helicopters and landing craft. In the commando troop-carrying role, the
Wessex is armed with the SS 11, a French anti-tank guided missile. The
United States Sioux helicopters are coming into service.
Assault ships are also equipped to operate helicopters. A Landing Force
Headquarters can exercise command control from the ship until it takes up
position ashore. The ships can land troops with supporting arms and transport
and the landing craft, operating from a dock space at the stern of the ship, can
unload tanks, vehicles, equipment and stores across open beaches.
The aircraft carriers HMS Ark Royal and HMS Eagle are to continue in
service until the middle 1970s, while it is planned to phase out HMS Victorious
I In 1967 the following ships of the Fleet were operational, preparing for service, or
engaged on trials and training: 3 aircraft carriers, 2 commando ships, 2 assault ships,
6 guided-missile destroyers, 14 other destroyers, 51 frigates, 37 submarines, 56 mine¬
sweepers, and an ice patrol ship. In addition the following were in reserve or undergoing
long refit, conversion, etc.: 2 aircraft carriers, 3 cruisers, 2 destroyers, 20 frigates,
II submarines and 31 minesweepers.
DEFENCE
Ir9
in 1969 and HMS Hermes in 1971. The carriers are equipped with the angled
tiight deck, the steam catapult, the automatic aircraft positioning device for the
catapult and the projector sight (all British inventions), and the ‘Audio’ landing
aid. HMS Eagle also has Action Data Automation (ADA) giving command
and control facilities in advance of any system at present known. The main
strike and fighter strength is provided by the Buccaneer and Sea Vixen aircraft
both fitted with the United States Bullpup air-to-surface guided missile. The
Buccaneer Mark 2 is a long-range low-level strike aircraft with an advanced
weapon system. The Sea Vixen Mark 2 carries air-to-air missiles Firestreak
f°r use against high-flying and supersonic targets. Eventually
the United States Phantom, powered by Rolls-Royce Spey engines, will
replace the Sea Vixen, and the first unit of Phantoms will be formed during
1968. The Whirlwind Mark 9 helicopter is in service for search and rescue
duties and the Wessex Mark 1 and the Wasp for anti-submarine work.
The still more advanced Wessex Mark 3 helicopter, with radar equipment,
is being introduced and in the slightly longer term is to be replaced by an
anti-submarine helicopter of yet greater capacity, a British-built and British-
engined version of the Sikorsky SH-3D (Sea King).
Eventually the Royal Navy, and the Army, will rely on Royal Air Force
land-based aircraft for support. Ships from frigate upwards will be
equipped with helicopters capable of reconnaissance and attack on ships and
submarines.
Nuclear power propulsion has revolutionised the submarine, enabling it
to operate submerged for prolonged periods at sustained high speed. Apart
from the Polaris submarines three other nuclear-powered submarines are now
in service (Dreadnought, Valiant and Warspite) and wih eventually be joined
by three more. Thirteen Oberon class submarines, the most advanced con¬
ventional-powered submarines in the world, are now in service. They are
armed with a new type of homing torpedo, backed by a complex fire system.
Other operational submarines include eight of the Porpoise class.
The Tiger class cruisers have fully automatic armament and the latest
control equipment. 1 hey are being converted to carry anti-submarine
helicopters. Destroyers and frigates, which constitute the largest part of the
Fleet, are the main surface protection against submarines and against enemy
surface and air forces. Of eight County class guided-missile destroyers planned
for the Navy, six are in commission, two of them are already equipped with the
Seaslug Mark 2 surface-to-air missile and ADA. All the ships carry a Wessex
helicopter. A new, more powerful guided-missile ship is on order—the Type 82
destroyer—to be equipped with the surface-to-air guided weapon Seadart,
the Ikara anti-submarine weapon and new Anglo-Netherlands radar. Leander
class frigates have advanced anti-submarine equipment including variable-
depth and medium-range sonar and mortars; both they and the Tribal class
frigates can carry Wasp anti-submarine helicopters.
Support-ships replenish the Fleet and offer it maintenance and repair
facilities. They include submarine depot ships (equipped with workshops
and plant to support a squadron or more of submarines), a heavy repair and
maintenance ship and mine counter-measures support ships, all manned by
naval personnel. Ships of the Royal Fleet Auxiliary Service provide afloat
logistic support such as fuel, food, ammunition, stores and spare gear. These
ships fly the Blue Ensign and are manned by Merchant Navy officers and
seamen. The dockyards at Portsmouth, Devonport, Chatham and Rosyth
provide the Navy with major supplies and repair facilities in Britain. Singapore
and Gibraltar are the main dockyards overseas.

Army general purpose combat forces consist mainly of the ground forces
deployed outside Europe; the Strategic Reserve; and other front line units
in Britain. Their cost in 1967-68 is estimated at £185 million.
The Strategic Reserve consists of two infantry brigades and one parachute
brigade with armoured car, artillery and engineer support. It is capable of
undertaking operations ranging from internal security and counter-insurgency
to limited war and is available to support BAOR in the event of general war.
It is completely air-portable. In addition special Air Service troops are highly
specialised forces which can act independently and react quickly to unforeseen
contingencies.
The introduction of the light-weight rifle and light-weight sleeping equipment
and rations in the Far East has helped to lessen the infantryman’s load; a new
manpack radio has been issued. Other equipment includes the remotely
controlled anti-personnel mine, the radio homing beacon and the Green Archer
mortar locator. The General Purpose Machine Gun is replacing the Vickers
and the Bren in infantry battalions. Equipment to improve the Army’s ability
to fight by night is being issued. Mobility is being increased by improved
engineer equipment that enhance the Army’s power to cross natural and
artificial barriers and by deployment of the Stalwart high-mobility load-
carrier. Following trials of hovercraft by the Joint Service Hovercraft Unit
in the Far East, the Army has formed a Hovercraft Unit, equipped with four
Westland hovercraft modified for military use. The introduction of the Sioux
helicopter has greatly increased the Army’s power of reconnaissance. Scout
helicopters are used to carry patrols, casualties and urgently needed stores,
and as airborne command posts. The Canadian fixed-wing light aircraft
Beaver is used for liaison purposes. The faster and more advanced Landing
Ship Logistic (LSL) is superseding the Landing Ship Tank (LST) for support
operations.
The Royal Air Force combat forces comprise all the front-line formations
and units except the V-bomber, transport and tanker forces. They fall into
five main categories: air defence, ground attack and fighter reconnaissance;
light bomber and tactical reconnaissance; maritime reconnaissance; head¬
quarters; and general support, including the Royal Air Force Regiment,
which is responsible for protecting bases. Their cost in 1967-68 is estimated
at ^237 million.
Fighter squadrons are equipped with Lightning Mark 3 and Mark 6 supersonic
aircraft, which carry Firestreak or Red Top air-to-air missiles and can be
refuelled in flight. The Lightning is fitted with a computer to aid bomber
interception. In the long term, the Lightning’s successor will be the Phantom.
Air defence is also the function of the Bloodhound Mark 2 surface-to-air missile.
Air defence squadrons are controlled by ground radars. New military radars
and centralised data-handling equipment are being installed in Britain as part
of the integrated plans for air defence and national air traffic control. Overseas,
new transportable radars are supplementing static radar. The ballistic missile
early warning station at Fylingdales (see p. 116) would provide warning of a
missile attack on Britain and so enable V-bombers to be alerted and despatched.
It also detects, tracks and identifies objects in orbit.
The Hunter EGA 9 ground attack and short-range Army support aircraft
is being replaced by the Phantom in 1968 and the British-PII2J vertical take-oft
and landing aircraft (the Harrier), the first such aircraft in the world to enter
squadron service, during 1970-71. Later, a strike version of the Anglo-French

Jaguar light-strike and trainer aircraft will release Phantoms to replace the
Lightnings. Overseas fighter-reconnaissance squadrons are equipped with
Hunter FRio aircraft.
Light bomber forces are assigned to NATO in a primary role of nuclear
strike, but they can also use conventional weapons to meet Britain’s require¬
ments outside the NATO area. Squadrons are also declared to CENTO and
SEATO. 1 hey are equipped with Canberra aircraft, some of which are armed
with AS1130 missiles. These forces will be replaced partly by the F111K and
partly by medium bombers transferred from the nuclear strategic role.
Reconnaissance forces comprise the Canberra PRy and Victor Mark 2
aircraft. Maritime-reconnaissance squadrons in Britain are equipped with
Shackleton Mark 2 and Mark 3 aircraft and squadrons overseas with the
Shackleton Mark 2. In addition to their reconnaissance functions they can also
be used for attacking surface ships and submarines, and as transport aircraft to
supplement Transport Command. The Shackleton Mark 3 is being modernised
and the Mark 2 replaced by the HS801 (the first all-turbo-jet maritime
reconnaissance aircraft) from 1969-70.
Air mobility forces are made up of the strategic and tactical transport forces,
tanker aircraft to refuel combat aircraft in flight, and communications aircraft.
Their cost in 1967-68 is estimated at £140 million.
The strategic transport force at present consists of Britannia and Comet
Mark 4 aircraft, while the Comet Mark 2 has been withdrawn. The Belfast and
VC 10 are being introduced. Tactical transports are the United States
Hercules (which is replacing the Hastings and Beverley aircraft) and the
Argosy. The short-range tactical transports are the Pioneer and Twin Pioneer
aircraft and the Belvedere, Whirlwind and Wessex helicopters. The Andover
Mark 1 short-range military freighter is now in service. The Victor tanker
aircraft can refuel two or three aircraft at the same time. The Basset (Beagle
B 206) and Andover C Mark 2 aircraft are used for communications.
WEAPONS AND EQUIPMENT
Responsibility for the supply of aircraft, guided weapons, nuclear weapons
and certain radar and other electronic equipment has been taken over by the
Ministry of Technology from the former Ministry of Aviation. The Ministry
of Defence is responsible for the procurement of other weapons, stores and
equipment. Total expenditure on research and development for 1967-68 was
estimated at £260 million.
A substantial part of the equipment used by the Services is developed and
produced in Britain, some by private industry on a contract basis and some
by the Royal Ordnance Factories, the Royal Dockyards and other establish¬
ments operated by the Ministry of Technology and the Ministry of Defence.
Production of nuclear warheads is undertaken by the Atomic Energy
Authority (see p. 210) under contract with the Ministry of Technology. In
some cases—particularly where development costs would be dispropor¬
tionately high—aircraft, weapons and other equipment are bought from
overseas. Conversely, British defence equipment has been adopted by allied
and friendly nations: for example, the United States, the Federal Republic of
Germany, Denmark and Sweden are using the British 105 mm. tank gun, and
122
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Research and
Development
Establishments
Nuclear-
Powered
Submarines
Missile Testing
Nuclear
Weapons
British early warning radar equipment has been adopted by several countries
and by NATO.
Britain also undertakes manufacture in collaboration with other countries.
The United States Bullpup short-range air-to-surface guided weapon is in
service with the Royal Navy and is being manufactured in Europe under a
NATO international agency.
Other collaborative projects in progress are: with France, the Jaguar light
strike and trainer aircraft, the Martel stand-off air-to-surface guided missile
and an air-portable helicopter (SA 330) for the RAF, a light helicopter (SA 340)
for the Army, and a utility helicopter (WG 13) for the Royal Navy; with
Canada and the Federal Republic of Germany, a reconnaissance drone; with
the Netherlands, a surveillance radar; and with Australia, the long-range
anti-submarine Ikara system.
Britain is participating in the United States Interim Defence Communica¬
tions Satellite Project (IDCSP) and a memorandum of understanding has been
signed under which Britain is acquiring an operational satellite communica¬
tions system, functioning initially through two satellites providing communi¬
cations for the area between Britain and Australia.
Research and development are undertaken at a number of specialised
establishments. Among the most important are: the Royal Aircraft Estab¬
lishments, Farnborough and Bedford; the Royal Radar Establishment,
Malvern; and the Aeroplane and Armament Experimental Establishment,
Boscombe Down, Wiltshire. The Navy Department’s two research
establishments carry out research on ships, maritime equipment and weapons
and also on certain kinds of electronic equipment on behalf of all three
Services. They are at Portsdown (near Portsmouth), where the design and
development of ship-borne gunnery and guided-missile systems are carried
out, and at Portland (Dorset), where all aspects of work on underwater
detection are co-ordinated with work on underwater weapons. Research
establishments controlled by the Army Department include the Royal
Armament Research and Development Establishment, Sevenoaks, Kent; and
the Fighting Vehicles Research and Development Establishment, Chobham,
Surrey.
Much experimental work has been carried out by the Navy and the Atomic
Energy Authority on nuclear-propelled submarines (see p. 119), and a nuclear
submarine power unit prototype is in operation at Dounreay (see p. 211). The
Royal Naval College, Greenwich, has a low-power training reactor which
provides facilities for basic education in nuclear engineering and research.
Guided missiles are tested at the Ministry of Technology’s research establish¬
ments, and guided and ballistic missiles at the Woomera range set up in
Australia under the Joint United Kingdom/Australia Guided Weapon Project.
Service firing trials of air-to-air and surface-to-air missiles are carried out at
Aberporth and at the Army gunnery range in Anglesey; a range for testing
surface-to-surface missiles has been set up on South Uist in the Hebrides.
Research into nuclear weapons began in Britain during the second world
war. It was continued, as an allied project, in the United States where the
first atomic bomb was produced. After a subsequent period of independent
development in both countries, collaboration was resumed in 1958, when an
agreement was concluded which made possible the exchange of information
on the design and manufacture of nuclear weapons. This was supplemented
by a further agreement in May 1959, which contained provisions to enable
DEFENCE
123
Britain to buy from the United States component parts of atomic weapons
and weapons systems other than actual warheads, and to make possible the
exchange of nuclear materials between the two countries.
Britain s present nuclear programme is based on an agreement of 1963
under which Britain buys from the United States a number of Polaris missiles,
to be fitted with British nuclear warheads, for submarines to be built largely
by Britain.
USE OF MANPOWER AND RESOURCES
Defence policy provides for a force of about 400,000 professional servicemen
consisting entirely of regular volunteers with the highest possible proportion
in effective combat units, backed by an approximately equal number of
civilians. Tables 7 and 8 and diagrams on p. 124 show the active strengths of
the three Services at 1st April 1967 and estimated for 1st April 1968, the
allocation of expenditure allowed for in the Defence Estimates for 1967—68
between government departments, and the estimated use of this expenditure
and of both military and civilian personnel according to defence functions
irrespective of departmental and Service divisions.

HOME DEFENCE
Expenditure and other information on home defence is given in the annual
Statement on the Defence Estimates. In 1967-68 home defence expenditure
by civil departments (including part of the cost of the Territorials, see p. 115)
was estimated at £20 million.
Civil defence forms an integral part of the country’s defence plan. Following
a nuclear attack there would be enormous and immediate devastation: there
would nevertheless be millions of survivors in need of help. The civil defence
programme is designed to ensure as many survivors as possible and to safe¬
guard their well-being by making the best use of essential supplies and services
after an attack.
The United Kingdom Warning and Monitoring Organisation exists to warn
the public of the threat of air attack and fall-out. Warning would be given by
sirens and other devices from 18,000 points throughout the United Kingdom
and by BBC broadcasts. Information about nuclear bursts and radioactive
fall-out would be collected by the Royal Observer Corps. The Organisation
would also provide civil and military authorities in the United Kingdom (and
neighbouring NATO countries) with a scientific appreciation of the predicted
path and probable intensity of fall-out.
A scheme has been drawn up for the voluntary dispersal from the larger towns
of up to about 45 per cent of the population, mainly mothers and children,
disabled, aged and infirm people.
It would be impossible to provide protection by shelter within any area of
complete devastation caused by nuclear explosion, and beyond the country’s
resources to provide specially constructed underground shelters all over the
country as a protection against blast, heat and fall-out. Nevertheless, protective
shelter against some of the effects of nuclear explosions could be provided
relatively simply for most households and advice on this is given in civil
defence publications.
Plans have been made for safeguarding essential supplies of food, electricity,
gas and water and for maintaining the functioning of ports, shipping and rail¬
ways. Provision is also being made for stockpiling, storing and distributing
oil and emergency medical supplies. Special attention is being given to
safeguarding telephone communications and broadcasting.
Civil defence planning in Britain is the responsibility of a number of ministers
each of whom undertakes the duties which, in war time, would represent a
natural extension of his peace-time functions. The central Government has
enlisted the assistance of local government authorities, of industry and
commerce and of public bodies of many kinds, including voluntary organisa¬
tions such as the Voluntary Aid Societies and the Women’s Royal Voluntary
Service, for the local execution of the plans.
In England and Wales the Home Secretary co-ordinates the work of
government departments in home defence planning and supervises the civil
defence activities of the police and fire services, the Civil Defence Corps
and the Industrial Civil Defence Service. Other government departments have
direct responsibility for the civil defence applications of the services which
they control; for example, the Ministry of Health is responsible for the hospital
and first-aid services (including the National Hospital Service Reserve) and
the Post Office for telecommunications.
126
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Regional
Organisation
The Civil
Defence
Services
The Fire
Service
In Scotland the Scottish Home and Health Department deals with questions
corresponding to those dealt with by the Home Office in England and
Wales, and is responsible for such matters as the hospital and first-aid
services.
In Northern Ireland responsibility for civil defence matters lies with the
Ministry of Home Affairs, which may arrange for other departments to
undertake some functions on its behalf.
Co-ordination of government activity in war time would be undertaken in
the nine civil defence regions in England by Regional Commissioners, who
would assume full responsibility if control by the central Government were
disrupted. Similar arrangements would apply in Scotland and Wales.
Northern Ireland would be under one central control.
In England and Wales the regions are divided into two or more sub-regions
in each of which the main government departments, the police, fire service
and public utilities would be represented, so that effective government
would continue if communications with the regional headquarters were cut
off. Below sub-regional level, control is based on administrative counties and
county boroughs and, within counties, on county districts. The purpose of
this system of control is to direct life-saving operations after attack and to
provide a framework of civil administration to marshal and co-ordinate the
use of available resources to the best advantage for the continued survival of
the community.
Civilian volunteers in Great Britain undertake regular training in peace time
in the following services.
The Civil Defence Corps, following reorganisation, is expected to have an
active strength of about 75,000-80,000 members, who must undertake one
year’s part-time training. The Corps is recruited and organised by local
authorities. Its role is to help the local authorities to man the ‘control system’
(the system of government in emergency) and to provide limited numbers of
specialists to assist in organising first aid and welfare operations. On comple¬
tion of active service members pass to a reserve.
The Industrial Civil Defence Service (106,230 members in October 1967)
has been formed in the larger industrial and commercial establishments and
is trained in the same way as the Civil Defence Corps.
The Auxiliary Fire Service (13,932 members in March 1967) would reinforce
the regular Fire Service in war time (see below). Auxiliary firemen are trained
by officers and men of the regular brigades. In addition, both regular and
auxiliary firemen receive special training in emergency fire-fighting.
The National Hospital Service Reserve (69,335 members in March 1967),
limited at present to trained nurses and people willing to be trained as nursing
auxiliaries, reinforces the National Hospital Service in England and Wales.
In Scotland there is also an ambulance section of the reserve.
In Northern Ireland there are three main services: the Civil Defence
Corps; the Auxiliary Fire and Reserve Services; and the Hospital Service
Reserve.
In time of war the fire brigades maintained by local authorities would be
brought under central control and formed into a National Fire Service, which
would be expanded by the mobilisation of such members of the Auxiliary
Fire Service as were available for whole-time service.

127
1 he police would continue to be responsible for the prevention of crime, for
the maintenance of law and order and for the control of essential service routes.
They are also likely to have duties in connection with dispersal, care of the
homeless and other specialised civil defence tasks. In all these duties they
would have the aid of the Special Constabulary.
The Secretary of State for Defence plans the part to be played by the armed
forces in home defence. In addition the military home defence force of
between 20,000 and 30,000 men (T & AYR III, the Territorials, see p. 115)
will supplement military units in the United Kingdom, assist the police in
the maintenance of law and order, and act in support of the civil authorities
in the event of a general war.
5 Social Welfare
STATE AND VOLUNTARY SERVICES
In Britain the State is now responsible, through either central or local govern¬
ment, for a range of services covering family allowances, social insurance,
help for war victims, financial assistance when required, health and welfare
services for mothers and young children, the sick, mentally disordered,
elderly and handicapped and for families in difficulties of various kinds, and
the care of children lacking a normal home life (all described in this chapter);
and for education (see Chapter 6) and housing (see Chapter 7). Public
authorities in the United Kingdom are spending over £7,000 million a year
on this range of services; that is, over £130 a year per head of the population.
Voluntary organisations, especially the Churches, were the pioneers of
nearly all the social services. They provided schools, hospitals, clinics,
dispensaries, and social and recreational clubs before these were provided by
the State. They made themselves responsible for the welfare of the very
young and the very old, the homeless and the handicapped. Gradually the
State accepted the primary responsibility for the major services, supplementing
the voluntary services and developing a comprehensive structure that ensured
a minimum standard of living and well-being for all citizens.
State and voluntary social services are now complementary and co-operative.
The State may work through voluntary agencies specially adapted to serve
particular needs and ensures that necessary standards are maintained. The
officers of central and local government, in carrying out their duties, co-operate
with the workers of many voluntary social service societies, while the resi¬
dential provision made by the State and by local authorities for the care of
the chronic sick and the aged is supplemented by voluntary homes of various
types. Most of the sick and elderly receive State pensions or benefits.
The Charity Commission, a government department, gives free advice to
trustees of charities, making schemes to modify their purposes or facilitate
their administration when necessary; it maintains central and local registers
of charities which are open to public inspection; and it works to promote
co-operation between charities and State services.
Voluntary
Organisations
The number of voluntary charitable societies and institutions in Britain
runs into thousands; they range from national organisations to small individual
local groups. Most organisations, however,- are members of larger associations
or are represented on local or national co-ordinating councils or committees.
Some are chiefly concerned with giving personal service, others in the
formation of public opinion and exchange of information.
Organisations concerned with personal and family problems and mis¬
fortunes include the voluntary family casework agencies, of which the Family
Welfare Association, working mainly in London, is the best known; marriage
guidance centres affiliated to the National Marriage Guidance Council; and
the Family Service Units.
Voluntary service to the sick and disabled in general is given by the British
Red Cross, the St. John Ambulance Brigade and the St. Andrew’s Ambulance
Association, but a number of societies exist to help sufferers from particular
disabilities, such as the Royal National Institute for the Blind, the Royal
SOCIAL WELFARE
129
Social Workers
Immigration
and Welfare
National Institute for the Deaf, the National Association for Mental Health,
the constituent members of the Central Council for the Disabled and their
Scottish equivalents.
Bodies working on a national scale whose work is specifically religious in
inspiration include the Salvation Army, the Church Army, Toe H, the
Committee on Social Service of the Church of Scotland, the Church of
England Children’s Society, the Church of England Council for Social Work,
the Young Men’s Christian Association, the Young Women’s Christian
Association, the Society of Friends, the Crusade of Rescue, the Society of
St. Vincent de Paul, the Catholic Marriage Advisory Council and the Jewish
Welfare Board.
A wide range of voluntary personal service is given by the Women’s Royal
Voluntary Service, which gives help in every kind of practical difficulty,
brings ‘meals on wheels’ to housebound invalids and old people, provides
flatlets and residential clubs for the elderly, helps with family problems and
assists in hospitals and clinics, as well as doing relief work in emergencies.
A central link between voluntary organisations and official bodies concerned
with social welfare is provided in England and Wales by the National Council
of Social Service, which brings together most of the principal voluntary
agencies for consultation and joint action, either as a whole or in groups of
those concerned with particular aspects, such as youth work or old people’s
welfare. There are also the Scottish Council of Social Service and the Northern
Ireland Council of Social Service, which perform similar functions. It was the
National Council of Social Service which set up the Citizens’ Advice Bureaux,
of which there are now over 450 in Great Britain. The primary role of the
bureaux is to give explanation and advice to the citizen who is in doubt about
his rights or who does not know about the State or voluntary services which
could help him.
While the voluntary worker giving full-time or part-time service has done
pioneer work in many of Britain’s social services and continues to play an
essential part, social services of all kinds increasingly depend for their operation
chiefly on the professional social worker, that is, the full-time salaried worker
trained in the principles and technique of social work. Training for many
forms of social work consists of a basic university degree, diploma or certificate
course in social science followed by a university course in applied social
studies or specialised training for a particular service. The latter is sometimes
organised by the profession concerned. The Council for Training in Social
Work also promotes the training, in the first instance, of workers in the local
authority health and welfare services and similar services run by voluntary
bodies. Full-time courses lasting two years, now being provided by 21
colleges of further education, lead to the Council’s Certificate in Social Work.
Voluntary organisations were the pioneers in the employment and training
of social workers, but local authorities now employ increasing numbers of
trained social workers, for example, in child care, youth work, medical social
work, psychiatric social work, and the probation service.
Since the 1950s many people have entered Britain from Commonwealth
countries in Asia, Africa and the West Indies to take up employment, some
with the intention of returning home when they have acquired savings or
additional skills but many coming to settle permanently with their families;
others bring their families over later. Immigrants from the Commonwealth
and their families now comprise about two per cent of the total population.
130
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The Home Office is responsible for co-ordinating Government action
designed to help Commonwealth immigrants to settle in Britain and to deal
with a number of social problems which have arisen.
In 1965 the Prime Minister appointed the National Committee for
Commonwealth Immigrants under the chairmanship of the Archbishop of
Canterbury with the aims of promoting and co-ordinating on a national basis
voluntary efforts directed towards the integration of Commonwealth immi¬
grants into the community.
The Race Relations Act 1965 introduced legal sanctions against certain
discriminatory behaviour. It provides for local conciliation committees to
enquire into complaints of racial discrimination in places of public resort1 and
to try to settle differences. The Race Relations Board, established under the
Act, examines cases where conciliation is not achieved and, if necessary, reports
to the Law Officers who may then take proceedings in the civil courts.
SOCIAL SECURITY
National insurance, industrial injuries insurance, family allowances and
supplementary benefits together with (in a special category) war pensions
constitute a comprehensive system of social security in the United Kingdom.
The Ministry of Social Security administers these services in Great Britain
and within the Ministry the Supplementary Benefits Commission is responsible
for the system of supplementary benefits. In Northern Ireland the first four of
these schemes are administered by the Ministry of Health and Social Services
which contains the Supplementary Benefits Commission for Northern Ireland.
Pensions and welfare services for war pensioners and their dependants are
the responsibility of the Ministry of Social Security throughout the United
Kingdom. Appeals relating to claims for insurance benefits, family allowances
or war pensions, or to applications for supplementary benefit, are decided not
by the Ministries but by independent authorities.
Although the development of public provision for social security in Britain
can be traced back for several centuries (the Poor Relief Act of 1601 may be
regarded as specially important in England and Wales), the modern system
of comprehensive provision is a creation of the twentieth century. Non¬
contributory old age pensions were introduced in 1908, and the first con¬
tributory pensions for old people, widows and orphans in 1926. A contributory
National Health Insurance Scheme was begun in 1912, and in the same year
a scheme of unemployment insurance was introduced which in 1920 was
extended to cover the great majority of employees. By the beginning of
the second world war social security provision in Britain was among the
best in the world, but lacked co-ordination because of its piece-meal develop¬
ment, and not everyone came within its scope. In the immediate post-war
years a series of Acts introduced the present comprehensive system, which
became fully operative on 5th July 1948. Adjustments have been made by a
number of subsequent Acts. Statutory provision for the war disabled goes
back to the end of the sixteenth century, but the main lines of the present
war pension provisions were laid down during the first world war.
Family allowances and national insurance benefits or allowances, other than
maternity, unemployment or sickness benefit, are included in the taxable
income on which income tax is assessed. On the other hand, various income
1 In July 1967 the Home Secretary announced the Government’s intention of widening
the scope of the Act to include discrimination in employment, housing, credit facilities
and insurance.

Reciprocity
FAMILY
ALLOWANCES
NATIONAL
INSURANCE
131
tax reliefs and exemptions are allowed on account of age or liability for the
support of dependants. War disablement pensions are not taxable.
The national insurance, industrial injuries and family allowances schemes of
Great Britain and those of Northern Ireland and the Isle of Man operate
as a single system. Reciprocal agreements on industrial injuries, family
allowances and most national insurance benefits are in operation with Belgium,
Denmark, Finland, the Federal Republic of Germany, Guernsey, Jersey,
Norway, Sweden and Yugoslavia. Agreements with France, Israel, Italy,
Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Switzerland and Turkey cover industrial
injuries and most national insurance benefits. With Australia and New Zealand
there are agreements on family allowances and most national insurance
benefits. An agreement with Cyprus covers all national insurance benefits
and one with the Irish Republic covers most national insurance benefits
and certain provisions on industrial injuries relating to seafarers. There is
a limited agreement with Canada. Northern Ireland and the Isle of Man are
also party to most of these agreements with other countries.
Family allowances are provided in Great Britain under the Family Allowances
Act 1965 (which consolidated the Acts of 1945-64), and in Northern Ireland
under its own legislation. About 6| million allowances are being paid in Great
Britain to nearly 4 million families with two or more children, and in Northern
Ireland to 124,000 families. An allowance is paid for each child other than the
first child below the age limits. The age limits are 15 years for children who
leave school at that age, 16 years for certain incapacitated children, and 19
for children who remain at school or are apprentices. The rate of the allowance
is 8s. a week for the second child below the age limits and 10s. a week for the
third and each subsequent child. These rates are to be increased by 7s. in
April 1968 (5s. of which will be paid for the fourth and subsequent children
in October 1967).
Family allowances are paid from the Exchequer and their object is to
benefit the family as a whole; they belong to the mother, but may be paid
either to the mother or to the father. There is no insurance qualification for
title to the allowances, but there are certain residence conditions.
The National Insurance Acts apply, in general, to everyone over minimum
school-leaving age living in Great Britain. There are similar schemes in
Northern Ireland and the Isle of Man. (The National Insurance Act 1965
consolidated the provisions of the National Insurance Acts 1946-64.)
The national insurance scheme provides benefits in specified contingencies
where contribution conditions have been fulfilled. The benefits are paid for
partly by insured persons’ contributions, partly by contributions of employers
in respect of their employees, and partly by a contribution made by the
Exchequer out of general taxation.
The original system was based on flat-rate contributions and benefits.
Contributions varied only with the sex and insurance class of the insured
person and benefits were at standard rates. (In both cases lower rates apply to
those under 18.) Two modifications were subsequently introduced to provide
additional earnings-related contributions and benefits. For retirement,
graduated contributions and pensions were introduced in 1961. For the first
six months of sickness, unemployment or widowhood the National Insurance
Act 1966 introduced a scheme for earnings-related supplements to the flat-rate
benefit and contributions.
132
Contributors
Contributions
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Contributors under the national insurance scheme are divided into three
classes:
Class i. Employed persons. Those who work for an employer under a
contract of service or are paid apprentices—over 23 million.
Class 2. Self-employed persons. Those in business on their own account
and others who are working for gain but do not work under the control
of an employer—nearly million.
Class 3. Non-employed persons. All those insured who are not in class 1
or class 2—nearly a quarter of a million.
This general classification is subject to certain modifications, made by
regulations, to meet special circumstances. Married women engaged only in
their own household duties are, in general, provided for by their husbands’
insurance and need not pay contributions. They can choose to pay contri¬
butions provided they were insured when they married. (Those who were
already married when the scheme began to operate on 5th July 1948 cannot
be insured in their own right unless they were then insured under the old
scheme and continued to pay contributions as non-employed persons or
unless they have since taken up paid work.) Employed married women may
choose whether to pay separate flat-rate contributions themselves (they must
pay graduated contributions) or to rely on the cover provided by their
husbands’ contributions, which make them eligible for maternity grant,
retirement pension at lower rate, widow’s benefit and death grant. Students
receiving full-time education and unpaid apprentices need not pay contribu¬
tions. Up to the age of 18, flat-rate contributions are credited to them. Over
that age they may, if they wish, pay as non-employed persons (class 3) and
thus safeguard entitlement to widow’s benefit and to retirement pension at
full rate. Self-employed and non-employed people whose income is not more
than ^312 (£260 until October 1967) a year can apply to be exempted from
liability to pay contributions. They too may pay as non-employed persons to
safeguard entitlement to pension.
An employed person ceases to be liable for national insurance contributions
at the age of 70 for men, 65 for women, or when he retires, or is deemed to
have retired, from regular employment after reaching minimum pension
age (65 for men, 60 for women), whichever is the earlier. If such a person
does any work as an employed person thereafter, he must pay an industrial
injuries contribution; the employer still has to pay his full share of the flat-rate
contribution.
Flat-rate contributions1 are paid by means of national insurance stamps bought
from a post office and fixed, for each contributor, to a single contribution card.
All three classes pay flat-rate contributions (see Table 9). The stamps for
class 1 contributors also include the employer’s redundancy contribution (to
help to provide for payments in certain circumstances to employees whose
work is terminated, see p. 436) and the selective employment tax paid by
employers (see p. 380); and for all contributors the National Health Service
contribution (which for convenience is pad with the national insurance
contribution although the two services are separately administered). It is the
employer’s responsibility in the first place to see that the class 1 contributions
are paid, but he can deduct the employees’ share from their wages. The

October 1967. The new rates are given in the following paragraphs.
