Other
Educational
Aid
State and
Voluntary
Partnership
Interchange schemes, under which teachers in Britain exchange posts for
a year with teachers overseas, include one with the United States and another
with Commonwealth countries, whereby each year over 100 British teachers
exchange posts with teachers from Canada, Australia and New Zealand.
Official exchange schemes also operate between Britain and several European
countries both for teachers and for temporary assistants’ posts for language
specialists.
Britain provides, on request, assistance to the developing countries in several
other ways, including the loan of educational experts for technical and
consultant services and specialist missions, through various educational
organisations and the Ministry of Overseas Development. For example, the
Centre for Educational Television Overseas (see p. 458) helps to advance the
education of adults and children in developing countries by means of
television, and the Oversea Visual Aids Centre in London gives advice to
teachers and others from overseas countries on all aspects of audio-visual aids.
Financial assistance is also given for building and equipping educational
institutions; recent examples include the £5 million grant for educational
development in Nigeria and the £1 million grant for the University of
Zambia.
YOUTH SERVICES
The object of youth services in Britain is to provide for the leisure-time
activities of young people in the 14 to 20 age group, and to offer them
opportunities—complementary to those of home, formal education and work
—for discovering and developing their personal resources, so that they may
be better equipped to be responsible members of the community. Membership
of youth organisations is voluntary and the facilities they offer are sufficiently
varied to appeal to every type of boy and girl.
Responsibility for youth services in Britain is shared by the education
departments, local education authorities, voluntary organisations and the
Churches. There is no attempt to impose uniformity or to create any national
youth organisation. A number of youth organisations have spontaneously
developed over the last century, mainly by voluntary effort. Government
encouragement in England and Wales dates from the 1930s. In 1939 the Youth
Service (as it is known in England and Wales) was created as a partnership
of voluntary organisations, local education authorities and central government.
The status of Youth Service as an essential part of the educational system of
Great Britain was confirmed by the Education Act 1944 and the Education
(Scotland) Act 1945; in Northern Ireland, youth welfare work is promoted
under the Education Act (Northern Ireland) 1947, and the Youth Welfare,
Physical Training and Recreation Act (Northern Ireland) 1962.
The education departments provide grants in aid of the administrative
and training work of some national voluntary youth organisations, towards the
expense of training full-time youth leaders and towards the cost of premises
and equipment of youth clubs provided by voluntary bodies.
Local education authorities co-operate with voluntary organisations in
their areas: most give some financial help and lend premises and equipment;
most also employ youth organisers to help in the promotion and encourage¬
ment of youth work. Where voluntary services are considered inadequate,
EDUCATION
173
local authorities themselves organise youth centres and clubs. Most local
authorities have appointed youth committees on which official and voluntary
bodies are represented.
In addition to grants received from the State and local authorities, voluntary
organisations may receive help for special projects from charitable trusts.
Most of the funds of the voluntary organisations are raised by their own
efforts.
Since i960 developments in the Youth Service have been greatly influenced
by the recommendations of a committee set up to examine the service, under
the chairmanship of the Countess of Albemarle (see Bibliography, p. 500).
On the advice of the Youth Service Development Council, formed as a result
of one of the committee’s recommendations, the Department of Education
and Science is making larger grants towards the headquarters expenses of
national voluntary youth organisations and special grants for voluntary
projects; it authorised a building programme for the period 1960-68 at an
estimated cost of ^27-5 million and co-operated with a local education
authority in designing an experimental club; and, to supplement existing
facilities, established a national training college at Leicester for youth leaders.
Local authorities’ contributions to the Youth Service have also increased;
their expenditure for 1966-67 was estimated at £6-8 million.
The Albemarle Committee’s inquiry extended only to England and Wales,
youth provision in Scotland having already been the subject of reports by
advisory bodies; but some of its main recommendations applied to Scotland,
while others reflected the existing Scottish position. The Standing Consultative
Council on Youth and Community Service has functions similar to those of
the Youth Service Development Council for England and Wales. Training in
youth leadership is available for full-time youth leaders and organisers. More
money is being made available from central funds to national voluntary
organisations in Scotland and, as in England and Wales, increased expenditure
on youth services by Scottish education authorities (estimated at £1 million
in 1966-67) is taken into account in calculating the Exchequer general grant.
The Youth and Sports Council for Northern Ireland encourages the
provision of facilities by voluntary and statutory bodies and advises the
Northern Ireland Ministry of Education. Grants are available for indoor and
outdoor amenities, for the training and salaries of youth leaders, and for
maintenance costs. Local education authorities also take an increasingly
active part in the youth service, both in running their own youth centres
and in co-operation with voluntary organisations.
The Voluntary The voluntary organisations vary greatly in character since nearly all of them
Organisations were formed to serve specific groups of young people; some of them provide
educational and religious activities as well as social and recreational pursuits
for their members, and all of them seek to inculcate high ideals of personal
conduct and service to the community.
Twenty-six national voluntary youth organisations with memberships
of at least 10,000 are constituent members of the Standing Conference of
National Voluntary Youth Organisations, a consultative body which takes
action only in the name of its member bodies and with their consent. A further
27 bodies are associate or observer members, for example, the Church of
England Youth Council, which represents about 273,000 young people who
are members of clubs sponsored by the Church of England. The corresponding
body in Scotland is the Scottish Standing Conference of Voluntary Youth
Organisations, in Northern Ireland the Standing Conference of Youth
174
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Organisations, and in Wales the Standing Conference for Wales of Voluntary
Youth Organisations. These major organisations have a total United Kingdom
membership of about 3 million young people under 21.
Among the youth organisations with a mainly religious origin and purpose
are the Young Men’s Christian Association (YMCA) and Young Women’s
Christian Association (YWCA), with about 52,000 and 18,000 members under
21 respectively; the Boys’ Brigade (150,000), the Church Lads’ Brigade
(12,000), the Girls’ Brigade (91,000), the Girls’ Friendly Society (19,000),
the Methodist Association of Youth Clubs (157,000), the Salvation Army
Youth Organisations (109,000), the Catholic Young Men’s Society of Great
Britain (15,000), the National Council for Catholic Youth Clubs (39,000),
the Young Christian Workers (18,000), the Grail (12,500), and the Association
for Jewish Youth (18,000).
The Scouts Association and Girl Guides Association have world-wide
affiliations; they are undenominational and non-political, and were founded
by Lord Baden-Powell in 1908 and 1910 to develop character and good
citizenship in boys and girls. Their total United Kingdom membership under
21 is about 489,000 scouts and 574,000 guides.
The National Association of Boy’ Clubs, with about 2,000 affiliated clubs
and 165,000 members, and the National Association of Youth Clubs, with
over 3,000 affiliated clubs and 262,000 members, are concerned mainly with
the 14 to 20 age-group. Each affiliated club has its own rules, but all aim at
giving young people opportunities to develop into mature members of
society. Representatives from clubs form local committees and these send
representatives to the national members’ councils.
The pre-Service organisations for boys (the Combined Cadet Force,
Army Cadet Force and Air Training Corps) combine social, educational and
physical development with training for possible entry into the armed forces;
their combined membership is about 125,000. The Combined Cadet Force
(CCF) contingents are based on schools in which education is continued to
the age of 17 or beyond. Training normally begins at 14 and the boys can
choose whether they will join the Royal Navy, Army or Royal Air Force
sections. The Army Cadet Force and the Air Training Corps are for boys in
schools that do not have CCF contingents or for those who have left school.
The Sea Cadet Corps, although not a pre-Service organisation, helps boys
who wish to make their career at sea; its membership is about 17,000. The
Girls’ Venture Corps, with about 6,400 members, formed in 1964 from the
Girls’ Training Corps and the Women’s Junior Air Corps, has an Air Wing
offering aviation courses.
The National Federation of Young Farmers’ Clubs in England and Wales
has about 34,000 members between 10 and 25 years old, the Scottish
Association of Young Farmers’ Clubs has about 7,500 and Northern Ireland
Young Farmer Clubs over 4,000 members: in addition to encouraging
interest in agriculture and appreciation of country life, the clubs provide
training in the arts of citizenship and develop ability to serve the community.
The Welsh League of Youth (Urdd Gobaith Cymru) has a membership
of about 43,000; its aim is the ‘development of Christian citizenship among
the youth of Wales’.
The Youth Hostels Associations in England and Wales, Scotland and
Northern Ireland have a network of hostels for walkers and cyclists, particu¬
larly intended for young people of limited means. They seek to promote
knowledge and love of the countryside, and are closely linked with each other
and with similar organisations in other countries.
EDUCATION I75
Adult organisations with youth sections include the British Red Cross
Society, St. John Ambulance Brigade and the political parties.
Other
Organisations
Concerned with
Youth Work
King George’s Jubilee Trust was established in 1935 by King George V, to
promote the welfare of the younger generation. Since its inauguration it has
disbursed nearly ^i-8 million to the headquarters of the principal voluntary
youth organisations and to many local projects, particularly those of an
experimental nature.
In 1967 about 114,000 young people between the ages of 14 and 20 took
part in the Duke of Edinburgh’s Award, which is a scheme operated by local
authorities, schools, youth organisations, industrial firms and other bodies,
and is designed as a challenge to boys and girls to reach certain standards of
achievement in three progressive stages in leisure-time activities. The scheme
for boys covers sections on public service, pursuits and interests, expeditions
and fitness. The scheme for girls is divided into sections on design for living,
interests, and adventure and service. A number of Commonwealth countries,
including Canada, Australia and New Zealand, now operate the scheme.
The Outward Bound Trust maintains in Great Britain five schools for boys
which offer 26-day character-building courses, based on adventure and
overcoming testing experiences. There is a similar school for girls, with
modified courses. About 5,000 boys and 850 girls take part each year. The
courses are mainly for boys and girls aged 16 to 19 years; but there are also
junior courses for boys and girls aged 14 to 16 and senior courses for young
people up to 25 years old.
The aims of the Central Council of Physical Recreation, the Scottish
Council of Physical Recreation and the National Playing Fields Association
bring them into touch with many youth organisations (see Chapter 19).
In addition to organisations on a nation-wide basis, there are a large
number of town, district or village social clubs run by voluntary groups for
general or particular purposes; photographic societies, folk dance, table
tennis or jazz clubs, for instance.
7 Planning and
Housing
TOWN AND COUNTRY PLANNING
Britain is one of the most densely populated areas in the world and it is
essential to plan land use for a satisfactory national distribution of employment
and population, to undertake a programme of urban renewal, to build new
towns and to preserve the amenities of the countryside.
From 1909 successive Acts of Parliament recognised the principle of the
planned use of land, but because the pattern of development over much of
the country had already hardened into large unplanned urban concentrations
the powers granted to planning authorities were inadequate for the task in hand.
The 20 years between the two world wars were decades of rapid social
and industrial change and of developments in industry, engineering, house¬
building, and motor transport; the population was increasing and becoming
more mobile; there was a widespread demand for improved standards of
accommodation and consequently a greater need for systematic planning than
had hitherto been required. At the beginning of the 1930s a major effort was
made to strengthen planning law and to extend the planning powers of central
and local authorities. This resulted in the Town and Country Planning Acts
of 1932 which remained the basis of planning law for 15 years.
Although inter-war planning legislation improved sanitary and environ¬
mental conditions and did something to preserve amenities, its general effect
was unsatisfactory mainly because it failed to deal adequately with the problems
involved in compensating property owners who stood to lose by the intro¬
duction of positive planning schemes. Local authorities often hesitated to
exercise their powers effectively for fear of being involved in financial liabilities
beyond their means, and as a result there was still much unregulated urban
development spreading over the countryside.
Renewed efforts to tackle these problems were made immediately before
and during the second world war. Between 1937 and 1942 three expert com¬
mittees were appointed to study and report upon (1) the unregulated growth
and spread of industry, (2) the restriction of planning by the financial and
administrative difficulties of compensation and betterment and (3) the
encroachment of urban development upon the countryside. After the second
world war other committees studied the question of new towns and national
parks.
Almost all the principal planning recommendations of these committees
have now been incorporated in Acts of Parliament. The major Acts relating
to town and country planning are: the Town and Country Planning Acts
1947 to 1963; the Town and Country Planning (Scotland) Acts 1947 to 1963;
the Land Commission Act 1967; the New Towns Acts 1946 to 1966; the
Town Development Act 1952; the Housing and Town Development (Scot¬
land) Act i957> tL® National Parks and Access to the Countryside Act 1949;
the Local Employment Acts i960 and 1963; the Control of Office and
Industrial Development Act 1965; the Industrial Development Act 1966;
and the Caravan Sites and Control of Development Act i960.
PLANNING AND HOUSING 177
Town and country planning in Northern Ireland is governed by the
Planning and Housing Act (Northern Ireland) 1931; the Planning (Interim
Development) Act (Northern Ireland) 1944; the Planning Acts Amendment
Act (Northern Ireland) 1944; the New Towns Act (Northern Ireland) 1965;
the Amenity Lands Act (Northern Ireland) 1965; and the Land Development
Values (Compensation) Act (Northern Ireland) 1965.
Planning in
Great Britain
Development Plans
Regional
Planning
The Town and Country Planning Act 1962 (which consolidated earlier
planning legislation in England and Wales), and the Town and Country
Planning (Scotland) Act 1947, are the principal Acts that govern the pattern
of land use in Great Britain. They provide for the co-ordination of planning
by means of development plans drawn up by local planning authorities and
approved by the Minister of Housing and Local Government, the Secretary
of State for Scotland or the Secretary of State for Wales; and they control
development by making it subject, generally, to the permission of a local
planning authority or of a central government department. They also give
extensive powers to public authorities to acquire and develop land for planning
purposes, and deal with questions of amenity, such as, the preservation of
buildings of special historic or architectural interest, and of trees and wood¬
lands, and the control of advertisement display. The Land Commission,
established in 1967, has wide powers to acquire, manage and dispose of land
for development, and to impose a levy on land transactions in order to recover
for the community a share of development value.
Under the Town and Country Planning Acts local planning authorities
(in England and Wales, the councils of counties and county boroughs, the
London authorities and, in some areas, joint planning boards; and in Scotland,
councils of counties and of large burghs, and the councils of the two small
burghs of St. Andrews and Thurso) are required to prepare and submit
development plans covering the whole of their areas to the appropriate
Ministers for their approval. Each development plan consists of a written
statement of intentions illustrated by maps describing the major projects in
the plan and is accompanied by a report giving the background to the plan
in terms of existing land use, communications and similar matters. Plans
normally cover a period of about 20 years; they must be reviewed at least once
in every five years, and may be extended and altered at any time so that they
are kept up to date. Local planning authorities control development in accor¬
dance with the development plans. Proposals for changes in their plans must
be advertised by the planning authorities and the ministers concerned must
consider objections and representations from the public. Usually a public
local inquiry has to be held before the proposals are decided.
In a White Paper (see Bibliography, p. 501) the Government has announced
its proposals for changing the form of development plans so that the Ministers
will be responsible for approving the physical planning strategy for each area
while the local planning authorities will assume responsibility for the detailed
implementation of official policy in the preparation and adoption of local
plans. Changes in the administration of development control and of planning
appeals are to be made to increase efficiency.
Machinery for planning on a regional basis has been set up by the Govern¬
ment (see p. 248). Studies showing the economic and social resources in
several regions have been made (see Bibliography, p. 506) and certain areas,
where land, communications and facilities are favourable, have been proposed
as places where development should be concentrated.
i7B
The Location
of Industry
New Towns
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Provisions relating to the location of industry and offices have been made in
the Town and Country Planning Acts, the Local Employment Acts, the
Control of Office and Industrial Development Act 1965, and the Industrial
Development Act 1966. General problems of industrial development are
dealt with jointly by a number of government departments, but the consent
of the local planning authority is, as a rule, required for any new industrial
building, any extension of a building or any change in the use of an existing
building. Financial incentives to encourage the location of industry in
particular areas have been made available by successive governments (see
p. 264). Special control of office building in and around London and in
Birmingham was instituted in 1965 and has since been extended to the whole
of south-east England and the Midlands.
The New Towns Act 1946 (now consolidated for England and Wales in the
New Towns Act 1965) gave the Minister of Housing and Local Government
and the Secretary of State for Scotland power to make an order designating
any area of land (which may include any existing town or other centre of
population) as the site of a new town; in 1965 the same power was given to the
Secretary of State for Wales. The appropriate minister must consult the local
authorities in the area about the proposal and an opportunity is given for
objections to be made by the public. Once the site has been designated, the
minister appoints a development corporation (consisting of a chairman, a
deputy chairman and up to seven other members) to be responsible for the
development of the new town.
The development corporations have powers in general (subject to the
consent of the appropriate minister) to acquire, by agreement or compulsory
purchase, land or property within the designated areas, or, in some cases,
land near to or outside those areas, and they may provide buildings, roads and
services essential for the development of the towns. Ministerial approval of
proposals for development, given after consultation with the local planning
authority, constitutes planning permission.
The capital cost of developing the new towns is advanced to the corporations
from public funds and is repayable over 60 years out of the income from
the property. The corporations submit annual reports (which include
copies of their audited accounts) to the ministers who lay them before
Parliament.
As each new town in England and Wales is substantially completed the
development corporation is dissolved and its assets and liabilities are handed
over to a Government appointed central agency—the Commission for New
Towns—which was set up in 1959. The Commission has taken over respon¬
sibility for the maintenance and management of land and property in
Crawley, Hatfield, Hemel Hempstead and Welwyn. No new towns central
authority has been proposed for Scotland, where new town development is at
a less advanced stage.
Twenty-four new towns have been, or are being, established in Great
Britain; nineteen in England and Wales and five in Scotland. Ten of the new
towns in England and Wales (Basildon and Harlow in Essex; Hatfield,
Hemel Hempstead, Stevenage, and Welwyn in Hertfordshire; Crawley in
Sussex; Bracknell in Berkshire; Milton Keynes in north Buckinghamshire; and
Peterborough in Huntingdonshire) are designed to help to relieve housing
problems in the Greater London area. Of the others, Corby in Northampton¬
shire, Aycliffe, Peterlee and Washington in Durham, and Cwmbran in Mon¬
mouthshire are serving the special needs of their areas; Skelmersdale in
PLANNING AND HOUSING
179
Lancashire and Runcorn in Cheshire are to meet the overspill needs of
Liverpool and north Merseyside; Redditch in Worcestershire and Dawley
in Shropshire will take population from Birmingham.
It is estimated that one million Londoners will need to be housed outside
London by 1981. In order to meet this need the Government is considering
plans for the large-scale expansion of Northampton, and Ipswich in Suffolk.
Other areas which are being studied for possible large-scale growth are the
Southampton-Portsmouth region in south Hampshire and around Ashford
in Kent.
To help in solving the housing problems in Manchester, Liverpool and
Birmingham proposals are under consideration for the expansion of
Warrington, for large-scale development in the Leyland-Chorley area of
Lancashire and in the Wellington-Oakengates area near Dawley. Newtown
in mid-Wales is to be developed to promote economic growth in the area.
Studies are also being made of the possibilities of development in the Dundee
and Tayside area and the regions of the Humber and the Severn rivers to
provide for a rapidly growing population.
The Scottish new towns (Cumbernauld in Dunbartonshire, East Kilbride
in Lanarkshire, Glenrothes in Fife, Irvine in Ayrshire, and Livingston in
West Lothian and Midlothian) are helping to house people from Glasgow.
Livingston and Irvine are also to be centres for industrial activity in the
central belt of Scotland.
The new towns represent a notable achievement in positive land use.
They are generally recognised as one of the most successful post-war experi¬
ments, both socially and industrially, and as a profitable long-term investment.
More than half a million people have moved into the new towns during the past
20 years and an extensive building and civil engineering programme has
provided houses, flats, factories, schools, shops, churches, health centres and
libraries as well as public buildings including the town hall and law courts.
Roads, water supplies, sewerage, gas and electricity, police, fire and bus
stations, postal, telegraph and telephone facilities have also been provided;
most of the towns are well equipped with parks and playing fields of various
kinds. All towns have become concerned with the increasingly high level of car
ownership of their inhabitants and are making more adequate provision for
parking and the segregation of pedestrians from motorists.
A number of the more developed towns are becoming regional centres
and, as the populations grow large enough to give the necessary support,
offices and hotels as well as full entertainment and recreational facilities such
as skating rinks, dance halls, bowling alleys, swimming pools, sports stadia,
golf courses and youth centres are gradually being provided.
Under the New Towns Act 1946 Parliament approved a fund of £50 million
to provide for advances to the development corporations for work on the
new towns. This fund was increased by subsequent Acts and now stands
at ^800 million; a total of over £505 million had been advanced to the
corporations by March 1967.
Town
Development
Schemes
The Town Development Act 1952 makes provision for the relief of congestion
in large industrial towns in England and Wales (such as London and
Birmingham) by encouraging the transfer of population from these areas to
places suitable for expansion where employment is provided. Schemes have
been approved for providing some 132,000 dwellings in this way, of which
about one-third have been completed or are under construction. Most of the
expanding towns, for example, Basingstoke in Hampshire, Thetford in
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
180
Norfolk, and Aylesbury in Buckinghamshire, are already well established;
further large-scale development is to take place at Swindon in Wiltshire.
The Housing and Town Development (Scotland) Act 1957 makes similar
provision for Scotland. Schemes have been approved for some 20,000
dwellings; about a quarter of these have been completed.
Urban The renewal and re-shaping of existing towns and cities is being undertaken
Renewal to meet the growth in population and the impact of more traffic. Glasgow,
for example, has started a programme of rebuilding 30 areas, housing nearly
a third of its population and accommodating much of the industry and
commerce of the city. The Buchanan report (see p. 348) which assessed the
conflicting demands of traffic and environmental standards has influenced
many authorities’ redevelopment plans. Special studies are being made in
Bath, Chester, Chichester and York to consider the particular difficulties of
preserving features of historic interest in ancient towns, in the face of com¬
mercial development and of the increase in motor traffic.
A centre for environmental studies has been set up by the Government to
advance education and research in the planning and design of the physical
environment.
Green Belts In order to restrict the further sprawl of large built-up areas, to prevent
adjacent towns merging into one another, and in some cases to preserve the
special character of a town and the amenities of the countryside, the policy
has been adopted of establishing ‘green belts’ around all or part of certain
urban areas. Green belts are areas which it is intended should be left per¬
manently open and where, in consequence, there is a proscription against new
development.
Preservation
and
Development
of Amenities
Responsibility for the preservation of the historic, scenic and architectural
beauties of Great Britain is vested mainly in the Minister of Housing and
Local Government, the Secretary of State for Scotland, the Secretary of
State for Wales, and the local planning authorities. Lists of buildings of
special architectural or historic interest are being compiled (covering 180,000
so far). The respective ministers (on the recommendation of the appropriate
Historic Buildings Council) are responsible for administering the grants
available for the repair and maintenance of buildings of outstanding historic
or architectural interest. Grants totalling over £6 million have been made
towards the cost of urgently needed repairs to over 1,200 historic buildings in
England, Scotland and Wales. Under the Civic Amenities Act 1967 local
authorities have powers to protect areas of special architectural or historic
interest in towns. The Ministry of Public Building and Works is responsible
for the maintenance of royal parks and palaces and (under the Ancient Monu¬
ments Acts) for the protection of ancient monuments of which over 700 of
the more important are in its care.
Under the Town and Country Planning Acts local planning authorities
have power, for example, to protect trees and woodlands by means of tree
preservation orders (some 5,000 of which are in force throughout Great
Britain), to prevent mineral workings becoming permanent eyesores by
attaching suitable conditions to planning permissions, and to restrict or
regulate the display of advertisements in the interests of amenity or public
safety. Local authorities are empowered, under the Clean Air Act 1956, to
declare ‘smoke control areas’, in which the emission of smoke from chimneys
constitutes an offence.

National Parks
and Access to
the Countryside
181
Voluntary amenity societies, wholly dependent upon the support of their
members, include: the Council for the Preservation of Rural England,
the Association for the Preservation of Rural Scotland and the Council for
the Preservation of Rural Wales; the Commons, Open Spaces and Footpaths
Preservation Society; the Ramblers’ Association; the Society for the Protection
of Ancient Buildings; the Georgian Society; the Pilgrim Trust; and the
Historic Churches Preservation Trust. The National Trust for England,
Wales and Northern Ireland, which was founded in 1895 and now has some
165,000 members, is (apart from the Crown and the Government) the largest
land-owner in the United Kingdom. It owns and protects from harmful
development 400,000 acres of land and some 190 historic buildings and
gardens for the benefit of the public—often acquired through gifts (some¬
times by arrangement with the Treasury in lieu of death duties, see p. 379).
With Government support it is at present engaged on a £2 million campaign,
Enterprise Neptune, to preserve 900 miles of coastline.
The National Trust for Scotland is an independent body founded in 1931.
It has about 31,000 members and has under its care some 70 properties,
covering in all about 70,000 acres.
The Civic Trust, financed through covenants from leading industrial
firms, was founded in 1957 to encourage high quality in architecture and
planning and to stimulate public interest in the protection of beauty in town
and country. It has, for example, produced plans for the redevelopment of
town centres and for a recreational area in the Lee Valley. The Trust makes
use of local initiative; it has separate sections in the north-east and north-west of
England and in Wales and Scotland and advises some 600 local civic societies.
The National Parks and Access to the Countryside Act 1949 provided that
selected areas of beautiful country in England and Wales should become
national parks, where the characteristic landscape would be safeguarded and
facilities for open-air recreation provided or improved.
A National Parks Commission was set up by the Act and given the job of
selecting these National Parks. Ten have been established: Northumberland,
the Lake District, the Yorkshire Dales, the North York Moors and the Peak
District in the north of England; Snowdonia, the Pembrokeshire Coast and
the Brecon Beacons in Wales; Exmoor and Dartmoor in the south-west of
England. They cover a total area of 5,258 square miles, or 9 per cent of the
total area of England and Wales. They have various forms of administration,
based on representation of the local planning authorities of the areas in
which they are situated, as well as members nominated by the Minister
of Housing and Local Government or by the Secretary of State for Wales.
The Commission also has power to designate other areas in England and
Wales as ‘areas of outstanding natural beauty’. By 1967, 21 such areas had
been designated covering some 3,700 square miles.
The land in these Parks and designated areas remains in private ownership,
but agreements or orders to secure additional public access may be made by
the local authorities. Steps are taken to preserve and enhance the natural
beauty of the landscape by high standards of development control, and by
positive measures attracting Government grants such as tree planting and
preservation, removal of eyesores and improvement of derelict land. In
National Parks, public enjoyment is promoted, for example, by the provision
of car parks and camping and caravan areas and the setting up of information
centres with the help of Government grants. All National Parks and some
designated areas have warden services.
182 BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Responsibility for making proposals for long-distance footpaths or bridle¬
ways also rests with the National Parks Commission; once the proposals are
approved by the Minister of Housing and Local Government or by the
Secretary of State for Wales, it is the responsibility of the local authorities to
give effect to them. Ten routes—in all, nearly 1,300 miles—had been approved
by 1967. Large stretches of these paths are already public rights of way; the
first long-distance footpath to be completed (the Pennine Way, which
stretches for some 250 miles) was opened in 1965. The establishment of
further routes is under discussion.
In a White Paper, Leisure in the Countryside {England and Wales) (see
Bibliography, p. 501), the Government proposes to set up a Countryside
Commission to replace and extend the work of the National Parks Commis¬
sion. The new body will be responsible for promoting public enjoyment of
the countryside generally. Measures envisaged include the creation of
country parks within easy reach of towns to meet the needs of motorists and to
relieve pressure on the National Parks; and the increased use of reservoirs,
canals and restored derelict land for leisure activities. Local authorities are
also surveying coastal areas under their responsibility to establish which parts
should be protected and used for recreational purposes and which are more
suitable for development.
Although there are no National Parks as such in Scotland, five large areas
have been designated as national park-direction areas. They are: Loch
Lomond—Trossachs; Glen Affric—Glen Cannich—Strath Farrar; Ben
Nevis—Glen Coe—Black Mount; the Cairngorms; and Loch Torridon—
Loch Maree—Little Loch Broom. In this way close supervision is maintained
over development in these areas and the local planning authorities concerned
must refer proposed developments to the Secretary of State for Scotland for
consideration.
It is also proposed to set up a Countryside Commission for Scotland under
the Countryside (Scotland) Bill 1967 to provide and develop facilities—
including country parks and long-distance routes—for recreational purposes
as well as to conserve and enhance the natural beauty of the countryside.
Forest Parks The Forestry Commission (see p. 337) has formed, and opened to the public,
seven Forest Parks in some of the finest country in Britain: Argyll, Glen Trool,
Glen More, and the Queen Elizabeth Forest Park in Scotland; the Forest
of Dean and the Wye valley woods on the borders of England and Wales;
Snowdonia in Wales; and the Border Forest Park (adjoining the Northumber¬
land National Park to the west) which includes forests on the borders of
Northumberland and Cumberland in England and of Roxburgh in Scotland.
The total area of the seven parks approaches half a million acres. Camping
facilities are provided in all the parks.
The historic New Forest, in Hampshire, although not a Forest Park, is
also open to the public.
Nature Responsibility for nature conservation is exercised by the Nature Conser-
Conservation vancy on behalf of the Natural Environment Research Council (see p. 212),
of which the Conservancy is a component body.
The Conservancy derives its powers in this field from its royal charter and
the National Parks and Access to the Countryside Act 1949, as amended by the
Science and Technology Act 1965.
The Conservancy conserves wild plants and animals and the environment
in which they live (see p. 213). In July 1967 there were 122 national nature
reserves in Great Britain, covering 256,400 acres. The largest (covering more

Thirteen forest nature reserves have also been set up; of these nine have
been created by agreement between the Forestry Commission and the Nature

The Council for Nature (established in 1958) is an independent voluntary
organisation of some 450 natural history and conservation societies concerned
with averting threats to wild life in Britain. It receives grants from the

Under the Planning and Housing Act (Northern Ireland) 1931 local authori¬
ties are empowered to prepare planning schemes for their areas in order to
secure proper sanitary conditions, amenity and convenience in the laying out
and use of the land.
The planning provisions of the 1931 Act are permissive, but the Planning
(Interim Development) Act (Northern Ireland) 1944 brought under planning
control all land not subject to a scheme under the 1931 Act and empowered
local authorities to secure more effective control of development until planning
schemes came into operation.
Under the 1944 Act authorities prepare outline advisory plans which
indicate broadly the proposals for their areas and provide a foundation for
more detailed plans. The outline plans also facilitate the control of develop¬
ment until planning schemes are completed. Where application is made to
an authority for permission to develop, the authority may grant the application
conditionally or unconditionally or may refuse it altogether. In the event of a
refusal or conditional approval, the applicant may appeal to the Ministry of
Development for Northern Ireland (the department primarily responsible)
or to an independent person appointed by the Ministry for the purpose. In
1964 a White Paper was published proposing radical changes in the admin¬
istration of planning in Northern Ireland (see Bibliography, p. 501). The
Government intends to set up a Central Development Office with
responsibility for regional and area plans while local authorities would
prepare ‘action’ plans for projects within their areas.
Planning in Northern Ireland entered a new phase with the publication
of Sir Robert Matthew’s Belfast Regional Survey and Plan, in 1964, and the
Report on Economic Development in Northern Ireland, in 1965. These reports
have led to a greater emphasis on regional planning and their general thesis
of preserving and enhancing Northern Ireland’s physical environment has
been accepted by the Government.
The Government and local authorities are co-operating in limiting the
growth of the Belfast urban area; a development plan is in preparation. The
New Towns Act (Northern Ireland) 1965 provides machinery for the develop¬
ment of new towns and for the major expansion of existing towns. Craigavon,
in County Armagh, is being developed as a new city; plans are also being
prepared for the expansion of a number of other key towns including Antrim,
Ballymena, Coleraine, Londonderry and Newry.
The Ministry of Development co-operates with the Ministry of Commerce
in the selection of industrial sites in order to secure the best possible use of the
land and to facilitate the efficient provision of housing and other services, espec¬
ially communications, in connection with industrial development (see p. 266).
The Amenity Lands Act (Northern Ireland) 1965 enables the Ministry of
Development to acquire or control areas of natural beauty or amenity; to

HOUSING
There are over 18 million dwellings in Britain: nearly 16 million in England
and Wales, 1,720,000 in Scotland and about 420,000 in Northern Ireland.
Over one house in four is owned by public authorities (in Scotland the figure
is almost one in two), nearly half are in owner occupation and most of the
remainder (mainly older houses) are rented from private landlords.
Between 1945 and March 1967 over 6 million new houses and flats were
built; one family in three now lives in a post-war dwelling. Most of the new
dwellings in Britain are houses (usually of two storeys); the remainder are
flats or maisonettes, mostly in blocks of from 2 to 20 storeys, although a few
blocks may be higher. High blocks are generally built in central urban areas
where they replace old, overcrowded dwellings. In the new towns and on
new housing estates they provide focal points and help planners to achieve
higher densities of population per acre where desirable, while still providing
open spaces.
Accommodation in a house designed for a family of four or five people
includes one or two living rooms, a kitchen, a bathroom and a water closet,
two or three bedrooms and a store. A typical 3-bedroom house built by a local
authority in England and Wales in 1966 had a superficial area of about 945
square feet and cost £2,782 to build.
Responsibility for formulating housing policy and supervising the housing
programme is borne by the Minister of Housing and Local Government in
England, by the Secretaries of State in Scotland and Wales and the Minister
of Development in Northern Ireland.
Local authorities are responsible for ensuring that the provision of housing
in their areas is adequate. In England and Wales and Northern Ireland the
local housing authorities are the councils of county boroughs, boroughs,
urban districts and rural districts, the Greater London Council, the London
borough councils and the Common Council of the City of London. In
Scotland all town and county councils are housing authorities. The actual
building of dwellings is undertaken by the local authorities (or by building
firms under contract to them) and by private builders, usually for sale to
owner-occupiers. In recent years about one-quarter of the dwellings built by
local authorities have been of the single bedroom type, suitable for old people.
The Government has set a target of building 500,000 dwellings a year in
Britain by 1970—half in the public sector1 and half in the private. Although
1 In addition to local authorities, this includes new town authorities, the Scottish
Special Housing Association, a statutory body established in 1937 to erect houses for
letting to supplement building by local authorities (it now owns about 63,500 houses
and by 1970 will be building at the rate of some 5,000 houses a year), and the Northern
Ireland Housing Trust set up in 1945 for a similar purpose which has built about a
quarter of Northern Ireland’s post-war houses.

Research and
Development
Industrialised
Building
Standards of
Building
185
the numbers of households and dwellings in Britain are roughly equal they are
unevenly distributed and there is a heavy demand for housing in the areas
of economic prosperity. There is also a continuing need for accommodation,
amounting to some 150,000 dwellings a year, for the growing number of
households as the population increases. In addition, it is estimated that about
3 million dwellings are required to replace slums and old houses which lack
essential amenities in industrial areas. A further y^o,ooo or so dwellings are
required to overcome shortages and provide a margin for mobility as well as
to replace losses due to redevelopment.
In two White Papers on the housing programme published in 1965, one
dealing primarily with England and Wales and the other with Scotland, the
Government said that the output of new housing in the public sector in
Britain should be expanded to about 250,000 by 1970, primarily to meet the
urgent need for low-rented accommodation in large towns.
Recognising also the increasing demand for dwellings for owner-occupation
the Government, in agreement with the builders and building societies, aims
at the provision of some 250,000 annually by 1970 in the private sector in
Britain. To ensure that a high priority is given to housebuilding by the
construction industries, control over less-essential building has been intro¬
duced. T. he Building Control Act 1966 provides for a licensing system
for certain commercial projects worth more than £100,000; an Order
has been made temporarily reducing the limit to £50,000. The Land
Commission (see p. 177) is helping to make land more readily available for
housebuilding.
Research into building techniques and into new methods of house construction
as well as into the needs of families, is carried out by the Research and
Development Groups of the Ministry of Housing and Local Government and
of the Scottish Development Department, the Building Research Station, the
architects departments of major local authorities and the research groups in
big constructional firms. All government building research and development
is co-ordinated by the Directorate-General of Research and Development at
the Ministry of Public Building and Works. The National Building Agency,
set up in 1964, gives technical advice on housebuilding, particularly the use
of industrialised methods (see p. 287). Ways of increasing productivity are
under study by economic development committees set up for the civil
engineering and building industries and by a committee of the Ministry of
Public Building and Works, which is concerned with small builders who
undertake the maintenance and improvement of existing houses where, for
example, prefabricated plumbing and bathroom units can be used.
The housing programme is putting heavy demands on the construction
industry. A number of local authorities work in consortia to make the best
use of industrialised systems (with standardised components) in their house¬
building programmes. The Government believes that by 1970 some 40 per
cent of housebuilding in the public sector should be by these methods, which
offer the advantages of rapid construction on the site, greater independence of
weather conditions, and the use of fewer skilled workers than traditional
building methods require.
Control of building standards is generally exercised through regulations made
by the central departments, which also give guidance on design and layout to
local authorities.
186 BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The Central Housing Advisory Committee, a statutory body, issues reports
on housing standards. For example, the Parker Morris report (see Bib 10-
graphy, p. 501) suggested standards that should be achieved in new dwellings ;
those relating to space and heating have been made mandatory for local
authority housing schemes. A study of standards at which older dwellings
should be maintained has been followed by a survey of the condition of such
dwellings in England and Wales (see Bibliography, p. 502). In Scotland basic
housing standards are laid down in the building regulations; a report on older
houses there was published in 1967 (see Bibliography, p. 502). For building
in the private sector the National House-Builders’ Registration Council sets
standards and enforces them by inspection and certification. Many building
societies and local authorities make a condition that they will lend money on
mortgage (see p. 187) only for dwellings built by house-builders registered
with this Council or built under professional supervision.
Housing
Finance
Local Authority
Building Costs,
Subsidies and
Rents
Private Purchase
The initial capital cost of houses built by or for local authorities is met by
raising loans; current expenditure, including loan repayment and interest on
loans, is met from rents supplemented by subsidies from the Exchequer and,
in some cases, from the rates (see p. 76). Local authorities may raise loans
for housing either on the open market or by borrowing from the Public Works
Loan Board (see p. 77). In Northern Ireland local authorities, the Housing
Trust and housing associations may borrow from the Government Loans
Fund. 11
Housing subsidies, at varying rates and for different purposes, have been
provided in Britain since 1919, when they were first introduced to enable
local authorities to build houses for letting at moderate rents. However, the
value of normal flat-rate subsidies has been eroded by rising building costs
and interest rates. A new kind of subsidy was introduced in the Housing
Subsidies Act 1967 which provides a basic subsidy equal to the difference
between the interest charge (at current borrowing rates) on a loan raised to
cover the approved capital cost of a dwelling and the charge if the loan had
borne interest at 4 per cent a year. For example, the basic subsidy payable on
a house costing £3,000, assuming a borrowing rate of per cent, would be
about £67 a year for 60 years. Supplementary subsidies are paid for high
building; to councils with insufficient resources to provide urgently needed
houses; for houses required in connection with a major transfer of industry,
for expensive sites; for precautions against subsidence; for building in certain
materials; and for overspill. Similar subsidies are paid in Scotland. In Northern
Ireland annual subsidies are paid to local authorities, the Northern Ireland
Housing Trust, new town development commissions and housing associations
and ‘lump-sum’ subsidies are paid to private people who build dwellings for
letting or owner-occupation.
In selecting tenants for council dwellings local authorities give preference
to families living in overcrowded or unsatisfactory conditions. Rents are
generally low in comparison with current building costs. About two-fifths of
the housing authorities in England and Wales operate rent-rebate schemes,
under which tenants with low incomes or with large families are able to claim
a reduction in the standard rent. In Scotland over one-third of councils
operate rebate schemes, although rents generally are lower than in England
and Wales. The Government is encouraging the expansion of such schemes.
Loans to enable people to buy their houses by a system of instalment purchase
are available from various sources, including building societies, insurance
companies, industrial and provident societies and local authorities. The local
PLANNING AND HOUSING
Housing
Corporation
Improvement
Grants and Loans
187
authorities are expected to concentrate their efforts primarily to helping
people with special housing needs who are unable to obtain loans from other
sources.
Building societies, of which there are about 600, are the most important of
these agencies. They do not build houses themselves but provide long-term
loans on the security of property bought for owner-occupation. Many are
now prepared to make advances of up to 95 per cent of the value of the houses
in certain cases. Loans are usually repayable over periods of up to 25 or even
30 years, by equal monthly instalments to cover capital and interest. A
scheme to help people with low incomes to buy their dwellings on mortgage
was introduced in the Housing Subsidies Act 1967 and is due to come into
effect in April 1968. Under the scheme borrowers will have the option of
either claiming income tax relief on interest payments on their loan (as at
present—a system which helps people who pay a high rate of tax more than
those who pay little or none), or receive through the lending agency a
Government subsidy, whichever they consider to be of the most financial
benefit to them. The subsidy will reduce the rate of interest they pay by up to
2 per cent, subject to a minimum remaining interest charge which in most
cases will be 4 per cent.
In England and Wales dwellings may be bought on freehold or leasehold
terms. This means roughly that a freeholder buys both the dwelling and the
land on which it stands (there are special provisions for flats), while the
purchaser of a building lease buys only the right to the use of the dwelling
for a stated period, and agrees to pay an annual ground rent to the owner of
the ground for the use of the land on which the dwelling stands; at the end
of the period the ground landlord regains the use of the land and the owner¬
ship of the dwelling on it. Under the Leasehold Reform Act 1967 lease¬
holders of an original long lease (more than 21 years) who have occupied a
house for at least five years may, with some exceptions, buy the freehold
compulsorily from the ground landlord at site value plus any development
value, or extend the lease for 50 years.
The Housing Act 1961 authorised Exchequer loans to approved non-profit-
making housing associations for the building of houses to let at unsubsidised
rents. This provision was increased and extended by the Housing Act 1964
under which a Housing Corporation was set up to stimulate the formation of
housing societies. Building societies advance to a housing society two-thirds
of the cost of each approved housing scheme, the Corporation providing the
remaining third. The housing societies build dwellings either to let at
unsubsidised rents or for co-ownership by a group of occupants. Co-owner¬
ship gives the occupants most of the advantages of house ownership at
a lower cost. The Corporation also has power to buy land for the housing
societies.
Private owners in England and Wales can obtain Exchequer assistance for
the improvement of houses or conversion of large houses or other buildings
for housing. Cash grants may be made by local authorities, with Exchequer
assistance, to people converting or improving existing buildings for housing
at a cost of over ^100 per dwelling. The grants may amount to half the cost,
with a maximum grant of £400 for each dwelling or £500 if a house of three
or more storeys is converted. Subsidies based on costs up to £2,000 were
authorised by the Housing Subsidies Act 1967 for housing associations in
England and Wales, which acquire, convert and improve dwellings for rent.
Housing associations in Scotland can also obtain grants.
188
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Local authorities are obliged to make ‘standard grants’ for the provision
in houses built before 1945 of a bath, wash basin, water closet, hot-water
supply and food store; these cash grants cover half the cost of the work,
subject, normally, to a maximum grant of j£i55 (£>35° certain circum¬
stances), or smaller sums if some of the five items already exist. Grants for the
provision of some of these facilities may be made where further improvement
is not practicable. Grants for improvements to houses owned by local
authorities are available from the Exchequer but on an annual basis over
20 years. The Acts under which these improvement grants are available are
the Housing (Financial Provisions) Act 1958, the House Purchase and Housing
Act 1959, and the Housing Acts 1961 and 1964. Over one million grants were
made between 1949 and March 1967.
Improvement grants and standard grants are also provided in Scotland and
Northern Ireland with, in addition, provision for accommodation for farmers,
agricultural workers and approved workers.
Local authorities also have power to make loans under the Housing Acts for
the acquisition, conversion, improvement, repair and alteration of houses.
Under the House Purchase and Housing Act 1959 they may make loans of up
to 100 per cent of the house’s value.
Control of Rents Rent control was originally introduced in 1915 as a temporary war-time
measure and successive Acts have varied its scope. Under the Rent Act 1957
there was a large measure of decontrol but the Rent Act 1965 re-introduced
control over most privately rented unfurnished dwellings—those of annual
rateable value up to £400 in London and fzoo elsewhere. Tenants have a
wide degree of security of tenure and the rent may be fixed on application
by landlord or tenant. Rents are determined by locally appointed rent officers
or, if the landlord or tenant objects to the rent determined by the rent officer,
by independent rent assessment committees appointed by the Minister
concerned. Once determined, the rent is not normally reviewed for at least
three years. For furnished premises under the rateable value limits a tenant
may go to a rent tribunal for determination of a reasonable rent and may be
given security of tenure for up to six months with a possibility of further
periods if the tribunal so decides. Eviction without a court order from fur¬
nished or unfurnished premises of any rateable value and harassment of
occupiers are criminal offences with severe penalties.
Measures of control and de-control also apply in Northern Ireland. In 1951
and 1956 legislation was passed which permitted prescribed increases in the
rent of certain controlled houses. The 195^ Act also released from control
houses with a net annual value of over £$0 (with certain safeguards) and
houses with a net annual value of over £26 of which the landlord was in
actual possession when the Act came into force, or of which he subsequently
obtained possession.
Slum Clearance About two million people have been rehoused since the mid-1950s as a result
of slum clearance programmes. It is expected that in about ten years’ time
the great majority of the housing authorities in Great Britain will have
succeeded in getting rid of all their present slums. In certain areas, however,
particularly the older industrial towns, including Birmingham, Glasgow,
Liverpool and Manchester, four of the biggest cities in the country, the
proportion of unfit houses is so high that clearance may take much longer.
Local authorities with major slum and overcrowding problems are being given
priority to clear their slums and to undertake major programmes of urban
renewal. Their housing programmes for the next few years have been doubled
PLANNING AND HOUSING
189
or trebled compared with recent years and the ministers are making more
building land available to them by the designation of new towns nearby.
Housing authorities are obliged to see that other accommodation exists,
or can be provided by them, for people displaced from slum clearance areas.
Where an unfit house is demolished by order of the local authority and the
owner retains his land, he normally receives no compensation. If the local
authorities acquire an unfit property in order to demolish it themselves and to
rebuild on the land, the normal basis of compensation is the market value
of the house as it stands or the value of the site after clearance, whichever
is the less. The slum clearance code provides for special payments for con¬
demned houses which have been wrell maintained. Additional payments may
also be made in certain cases to owner-occupiers and business occupiers.
8 The Churches
The Church of
England
Every person living in Britain possesses the right of religious freedom and
may manifest his faith in teaching, worship and observance without inter¬
ference from the community or the State. Churches and religious societies
of all kinds may own property, conduct schools, and propagate their beliefs
in speech and in writing.
Freedom of conscience in religious matters was achieved gradually from
the seventeenth century onwards; in many cases relaxation in the adminis¬
tration of laws discriminating against minority religious groups preceded the
repeal of the legislation concerned. Heresy ceased to be a civil offence with
the passing of the Ecclesiastical Jurisdiction Act 1677, and the Toleration
Act of 1688 granted freedom of worship to Protestant dissenters. In 1828
the repeal of the Test and Corporation Acts freed nonconformists from
political disabilities and made it possible for them to be appointed to public
offices; Roman Catholics gained political emancipation under the Roman
Catholic Relief Act 1829; the Jewish Relief Act 1858 enabled Jews to become
members of Parliament; while religious tests that had been imposed on
prospective students and members of the academic staff of the universities
of Oxford, Cambridge and Durham were successively abolished by Acts of
1854, 1856 and 1871. Nowadays, there is no religious or denominational bar
to the holding of public office, except in the case of the Lord Chancellor,
where there is some doubt whether existing statutory provisions would permit
this office to be held by a Roman Catholic.
In the services administered by the State, such as the armed forces, the
national hospitals and the prisons, the clergy of the established Church of
England or the Church of Scotland provide the principle ministrations and
are paid a salary by the State for this part of their work. Priests of the Roman
Catholic Church and ministers of other denominations may also be appointed
or specially called in as required. Voluntary schools (see p. 154) provided by
churches of any religious denomination may be wholly or partly maintained
from public funds.
There is no precisely accurate or uniform method of assessing the number
of adherents to the various churches in the United Kingdom, since no inquiries
are made about religious beliefs in population censuses or other official
returns, and each church adopts different criteria in counting its members.
The membership figures given in this chapter are therefore approximate.
The Church of England is the established church, and claims to be the
ancient catholic church of the land. At the Reformation in the sixteenth
century, it repudiated the supremacy of the Pope, but retained the historic
episcopate, and the creeds and sacraments upon which its doctrines are based;
therefore it claims to be both ‘catholic’ and ‘reformed’. Its form of worship
is embodied in the Book of Common Prayer, which was first compiled in 1549.
The Church is uniquely related to the Crown in that the Sovereign, who
must be a member of the Church of England, is called ‘Defender of the
Faith’ (a statutory title as protector of the Church) and promises on his or
her accession to uphold it. The coronation of the Sovereign is performed by
the Archbishop of Canterbury; prayers for the Sovereign and other members
THE CHURCHES
Church
Organisation and
Government
I9I
of the royal family are said in all the statutory services of the Church; Church
of England archbishops, bishops and deans are appointed by the Sovereign on
the advice of the Prime Minister1; and all clergymen take the oath of
allegiance to the Crown.
The Church is also linked with the State through the House of Lords,
in which the archbishops of Canterbury and York and 24 senior diocesan
bishops have seats (see p. 34). This makes it possible for the views of the
Church leaders to be expressed freely on any moral issue raised in connection
with the corporate conduct of the State as well as on specifically ecclesiastical
issues—a matter of particular significance in view of the fact that the clergy
of the Church of England (together with those of the Church of Scotland, the
Church of Ireland and the Roman Catholic Church) are legally disqualified
from sitting in the House of Commons.
The Church must obtain Parliament’s consent2 to change its form of
worship, as laid down in the authorised Book of Common Prayer; canons
(Church rules) cannot be made or amended without the consent of the Queen;
and the Measures of the Church Assembly (as distinct from its regulations)
also require parliamentary approval and the Royal Assent.
The Church of England is organised by geographical areas into two provinces
and 43 dioceses. The Province of Canterbury contains 29 dioceses and that
of York 14. Each diocese is subdivided into ecclesiastical parishes, of which
there are about 14,400 in all. The Archbishop of Canterbury is Primate of
All England and bishop of his own diocese of Canterbury; the Archbishop of
York is styled Primate of England and is bishop of his own diocese of York.
The baptised membership of the Church is about 27^ million, that is two-
thirds of the population born and resident in the two provinces but only about
35 per cent of this number is confirmed.
Spiritual authority in the Church rests with the bishops. The authoritative
bodies in matters of doctrine, belief and practice are the Convocations of
Canterbury and York, each presided over by its archbishop, and consisting
of an upper house of bishops, and a lower house of representatives of each
cathedral chapter, archdeacons and elected clergy. The Convocations meet
not oftener than three times a year.
The legislative and central administrative body of the Church is the
National Assembly of the Church of England, which is commonly called the
Church Assembly. It was set up in 1919 at the request of the two Convocations,
and was given power to legislate by measure by the Church of England
Assembly (Powers) Act 1919. It can discuss any matter connected with
the Church of England, but may not make any doctrinal statements, nor
infringe upon the rights of the Convocations. It consists of three houses:
bishops, clergy and laity. The first two houses are composed of the members
of the Convocations; the house of laity consists of men and women elected
every five years by the lay members of diocesan conferences, and the con¬
stitution allows for ten co-opted members.3 * * *
1 The Church Assembly has appointed a commission to consider what constitutional
modifications are desirable and practicable in the present relationship between Church
and State.
2 Consent has been obtained for the experimental use of alternative forms, if and when
authorised by the Church.
3 A reconstituted Church Assembly, which would take over the authority of the
Convocations of Canterbury and York and would bring the laity into closer contact
with the clergy in all church matters, has been proposed by a commission set up by the
Archbishops of Canterbury7 and York to work out a form of synodical government for
the Church of England.
