BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Film reviews appear regularly in the press and on sound and television
programmes and many organisations are interested in different aspects of
the film. There are numerous private film societies.
The development of the film as an art is promoted by the British Film
Institute, founded in 1933, which is financed partly by an Exchequer grant.
The Institute encourages the making and showing of good films. It also
administers the National Film Theatre in London and the National Film
Archive, runs an annual summer school, and maintains a film library from
which films may be hired, a library of books on the film and an information
service. It makes grants to the Federation of Film Societies, the University
Film Council and the Society for Education in Film and Television.
The National Film Archive contains over 18,000 films, including newsreels
and other miscellaneous items, besides scripts, art designs, posters and
about 500,000 photographic stills, selected to illustrate the history and the
art of the film and as significant social and historical records.
The National Film Theatre, on the south bank of the Thames, in London,
shows films of outstanding historical, artistic or technical interest; it holds
a unique position as a cinema offering regular programmes unrestricted by
commercial considerations or by the age or nationality of the films shown.
The British Film Institute is promoting the development of regional film
theatres on the lines of the National Film Theatre and makes grants towards
their capital costs.
The Society of Film and Television Arts, formed in 1958 by the amalgama¬
tion of the British Film Academy and the Guild of Television Producers and
Directors, has as its aim to improve the standard of film and television
production and to stimulate public appreciation of the arts.
The National Film Theatre organises an annual London Film Festival,
which includes films receiving their first showing as well as films which have
been successful in international competitive festivals. A council on which
leading British film organisations are represented organises a film festival as
part of the Edinburgh International Festival.
The Cinematograph Act 1952 (which came into force in January 1956)
provided for the making of regulations by the Home Secretary to protect
the health and welfare of children attending film shows. Cinemas which give
children’s shows require a special licence from the licensing authority, which
may impose conditions. There are about 900 children’s cinema clubs which
provide special programmes on Saturday mornings. An important contribu¬
tion to these programmes is made by the Children’s Film Foundation, which
produces and distributes entertainment films specially designed for children
and publishes at intervals a list of films particularly suitable for children and
for exhibition at children’s matinees. The Foundation is a non-profit-making
body set up by the British film industry in 1951 and, under the Cinematograph
Films Act 1957, it receives grants from the British Film Fund Agency.
10 The National
Economy
BACKGROUND
Britain ranks about 75^ in size among the countries of the world, with
about o-i8 per cent of the world’s land area. In population, approaching
2 per cent of the world’s inhabitants, it ranks tenth. In density of population
it is fourth: of the major countries, only Japan, Belgium and the Netherlands
are more crowded; and there are nine times as many people to the square
mile in the United Kingdom as in the United States. In terms of national
income per head it ranks appreciably below the United States and also below
Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Sweden and Switzerland, and about on a
par with France and the Federal Republic of Germany. In world trade, it
ranks third, accounting for nearly one-tenth of the total. It takes about a fifth
of the world’s exports of primary products, and provides about one-seventh of
the world’s exports of manufactured goods.
Britain, from its own soil, provides only about half of the food it needs,
and—apart from coal, low-grade iron ore and natural gas—it has few natural
resources; thus it is the world’s largest importer of such products as wheat,
meat, butter, fodder grains, citrus fruits, tea, tobacco, wool, and hard timber.
In return, it is one of the world’s largest exporters of aircraft, motor vehicles,
electrical equipment, chemicals, textiles and most types of machinery. No
other major country has such a small proportion of the working population
engaged in agriculture (less than 3^ per cent).
The United Kingdom is also the central banker of the sterling area, an
area with a quarter of the world’s population. Many countries outside the
sterling area use sterling in their international transactions, and it is the
currency in which about one-third of the world’s trade is conducted.
The Economy During the nineteenth century Britain secured a leading position as world
before 1939 manufacturer, merchant, carrier, banker, and investor and so was able
to support a rapidly increasing population at a rising standard of living.
During the period from 1870 to 1890 British industrial expansion had a
clear lead over that of other countries. Between 1890 and 1914 growing
industrial competition from Europe and North America began to make
itself felt, but its effects on Britain’s staple export industries, particularly
cotton textiles and coal, were offset by the general rise in world trade, by
the continued demand for British textiles from India and other eastern
countries, and by the continued high level of overseas investment.
The new problems confronting British industry and trade in the twentieth
century became apparent after the first world war. Textiles from India and
Japan, where labour was cheaper, established themselves firmly in the large
eastern markets, to a great extent replacing the more expensive and often
higher quality British products. The extension of the world demand for coal
was slowed down by the increasing use of oil, while coal from the newer
European mines competed keenly with British coal.
In the old-established branches of the vehicles and engineering group of
236
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Effects of
the Second
World War
The Post-war
Period
industries (for instance, locomotives and ships) world demand fell away a ter
a brief post-war boom, and Britain failed at first to gain a compensating share
of the expanding world trade in the new types of engineering products (for
example, vehicles and electrical goods). Most countries were tending towards
self-sufficiency, and some sought deliberately to protect nascent and even
established industries by tariffs and (later) quotas and exchange restrictions.
Income from overseas investments and a substantial improvement in the
terms of trade (the price of exports relative to the price of imports) cushioned
the effect of a fall in the volume of exports, and imports remained high.
The loss of export markets led, however, to a contraction of Britain’s staple
industries—coal, cotton, iron and steel, and the older branches of engineering.
The result was heavy unemployment, the general rate of which averaged
14 per cent of the working population in the years 1921-39, reaching a peak
of 22 per cent in 1932, when the slump in world trade was at its worst. In
districts relying mainly on one or other of the staple industries, the rate was
much higher.
After 1932 an improvement in the levels of production and employment
took place, stimulated by an increase in home investment which was aided
by the policy of cheap money, by some revival in world trade and, after 1935,
by the armament programme. The decade saw a strong expansion in the
vehicles, electrical, chemicals and aircraft industries, while the construction
of 3 million houses brought about a large growth in the building and ancillary
industries. By 1937 average real income per head was about 14 per cent
higher than in 1929.
The second world war is estimated to have run down British domestic
capital by about £3,000 million, through shipping losses, bomb damage, and
arrears of industrial maintenance and replacements. Some £1,000 million
worth of overseas investments were sold, nearly half in North America, and
new external debts of £3,000 million were accumulated. By 1944 exports had
fallen to less than one-third of their 1938 volume as a result of the war effort.
Economic conditions in the immediate post-war period led to many of the
war-time restrictions remaining in force. Holdings of gold and foreign
exchange had been greatly depleted to pay for the essential war-time supplies
from overseas, and the export trade had to be rebuilt. Thus, rationing and
other war-time controls could only be relaxed gradually with the expansion
of production and the progress of recovery, this process being largely
completed by about mid-1954. The abolition of quantitative restrictions on
imports, other than from the dollar area, was largely completed by 1955-
Exchange controls on transactions between the sterling area and the rest of
the world were also progressively lifted, and in 1958 convertibility of sterling
on current account for all non-residents was introduced.
In the 1960s the main objective in government economic policies has been
to achieve faster economic growth and to overcome the recurring balance of
payments problem (see p. 243) which has from time to time necessitated the
creation of a margin of spare capacity greater than would otherwise have been
desired and has thereby impaired the general expansion of the economy.
THE FRAMEWORK OF THE ECONOMY
The following sections sketch briefly the salient features of Britain’s national
economy in recent years. The source of Tables 11 to 14 is Preliminary Estimates
THE NATIONAL ECONOMY 237
of National Income and Balance of Payments 1961 to 1966 (Cmnd. 3244) and
Economic Trends.
OUTPUT AND
EMPLOYMENT
In 1966 Britain s gross national product at factor cost (the measure of the
value of total goods and services produced at home and net income from
abroad) is estimated to have totalled ^32>339 million. In real terms, that is,
after allowing for price changes, the increase over the ten-year period to
1966 has amounted to about one-third.
The working population has been rising relatively slowly; in the ten years
to the middle of 1967 it increased by about 1^ million (or some 5 per cent) to
about 26 million, of whom two-thirds are males. The expansion of the
national income over the same period has, therefore, been mainly the result
of higher productivity. Unemployment over the past two decades remained
very low, on average less than 2 per cent of the working population being
out of work, compared with 14 per cent between the two world wars. It has
tended to remain above the national average in Northern Ireland, Scotland,
Wales and the north-east and certain other parts of England (where special
measures are providing additional sources of employment), but in London,
the south and the Midlands the number of unfilled employment vacancies has
usually exceeded that of registered unemployed, thus leading to strong
competition among employers for available labour. While some industries,
notably coalmining, the railways, cotton textiles and agriculture, have under¬
gone a marked reduction in their labour force—of the order of 400,000, in the
last five years—the needs of the expanding sectors of the economy have not
always been fully met. Retraining of workers is progressing but the overall
shortage of labour is likely to continue for some years and will have to be met
through the further raising of productivity, especially in manufacturing.

consumption, investment and exports, and the diagram on p. 238 shows
changes in national expenditure between 1956 and 1966 (at 1961 prices).

Manufacturing industry contributes about 35 per cent to the total output
of goods and services, and together with mining and quarrying, construction
and public utilities (gas, electricity and water) makes up just under half of
the total; agriculture, forestry and fisheries account for just over 3 per cent;
and transport and communications, together with the distributive trades, for
20 per cent. The remainder, just over one-quarter of total output, includes
public administration, education, health and finance and other services. Over
the past ten years there has been a marked decline in the proportion contributed
by agriculture (though agricultural output is still rising).

It will be seen from the diagram above that the share attributable to fixed
capital formation rose appreciably between 1956 and 1966, in part reflecting
the growth of public investment, while public authorities’ current expenditure
on goods and services—which declined between 1953 and 1959 as a result of
reductions in defence expenditure—has risen relatively much faster over the
five years to 1966. Over the whole period the expansion in real terms of exports
of goods and services (34 per cent) and consumer expenditure (34 per cent)
has been broadly in line with the growth of the gross national product
(33 per cent), but in the case of capital formation the rate of increase (70 per
cent) has been more than twice as high.
Gross fixed investment has risen markedly in the last 15 years. In 1951 fixed
investment in the United Kingdom was about 15 per cent of the gross national
product; it has been maintained at a high level in recent years, reaching
over 20 per cent in 1966. Fixed investment in manufacturing, which accounts
for 22 per cent of all fixed investment, in 1966 amounted to £1,456 million at
current prices, an increase of 4 per cent over 1965. In real terms also the high
level reached in 1965 was maintained in 1966. Investment has recently been
especially high in the chemicals and electronics industries. Also, electricity
generation and transmission and gas are sectors with continuing large-scale
investment programmes. There has been a substantially expanded investment
in housing; in 1966 it was nearly 60 per cent higher than in 1961. In some

The rise in personal savings has taken various forms. There has been
increased investment by the personal sector itself in new dwellings and fixed
assets. Life assurance premiums and other forms of contractual savings, such
as superannuation funds, have grown almost without interruption for many
years and now contribute over half the total. National Savings have also
increased since the early 1950s, although in 1966, exceptionally, there was
a decline of £30 million. Building societies are able to attract considerable sums
of personal savings, deposits having reached a peak of £762 million in 1966.
The largest contribution to savings comes from companies. Up to 1959,
these provided about half the total, but the proportion has since fallen to about
40 per cent in 1966. In that year there was a decline of 6 per cent compared
with 1965 on account of a fall in profits in the United Kingdom.
Public corporations, as part of the policy of financing a larger share of their
investment needs from their own resources, have raised their savings total
considerably in recent years and the 1966 level accounted for about a twelfth
of total savings.
Current expenditure, that is, excluding public investment and other capital
expenditure but including interest paid on debt, by the central Government
(including the national insurance funds) and the local authorities rose by
46 per cent at current prices over the period 1961 to 1966 and in the latter
year amounted to about two-fifths of the gross national product. The main
causes of this increase have been the continuing growth of the social services,
especially education, and defence expenditure, which accounted for 16 per
cent of the total current expenditure of the public authorities in 1966
(compared with a peak of 27 per cent in 1953).
Several appreciable increases in taxation rates, imposed partly to reduce
the volume of demand on resources, have raised sharply the inflow of revenue.

Personal

Income from employment in 1966 totalled ,£22,346 million and accounted
for 71 per cent of total personal income (against 60 per cent in 1938). The
diagram on p. 242 shows the composition of personal income and expenditure
in 1966.
Of a total of 27-6 million incomes in 1965, there were only about 30,000
incomes of more than ,£6,000 a year after tax. About a quarter (6-8 million) of
incomes after tax were in the ^250-^499 range and 5-5 million were in the
next range of £500-^749. The number of incomes after tax of £1,000 a year
and above rose from 1 - i million in 1955 to 7-2 million in 1965. Just over 75 per
cent of the yield from income tax and surtax came from persons with annual
incomes in this latter category, although the total incomes before tax of this
group accounted for just under a half of total income.
The ownership of property and personal assets tends to be more concen¬
trated than income after tax. Estimates made by the Board of Inland Revenue
indicate that, in 1965, 80 per cent of net personal wealth (including landed
property), amounting to about £70,700 million, was owned by just over
5 million individuals, nearly 10 per cent of the population.

National Insurance benefits
While consumer expenditure rose by nearly 74 per cent at current prices
between 1956 and 1966 to reach a total of £24,007 million, in real terms (that
is, after discounting the effect of price changes) the increase was only about
33 per cent. The proportion devoted to food has been falling slightly each year
and now accounts for 25 per cent at current prices (1956, 31 per cent); outlay
on tobacco and alcoholic drinks is about 13 per cent of consumer expenditure.
In real terms expenditure on tobacco fell by 8 per cent between 1961 and 1966,
but substantial increases in taxes over the period caused total outlay to rise
by 24 per cent at current prices. At current prices housing absorbs 11 per
cent of total expenditure, and fuel and light about 5 per cent. Spending on
motor cars and motor cycles fell in 1965 and 1966 after rising strongly for a
number of years. There has also been a substantial growth in spending on
household electrical equipment (except in 1966), fuel and light, and clothing.
Outlays on running costs of vehicles have risen from £273 million in 1956 t°
£1,052 million in 1966. In general the pattern of consumer spending reflects the
social changes and other developments outlined in Chapter 1. The diagram on
p. 243 shows the change in consumers’ expenditure since 1958 in real terms
and at current prices.
PROBLEMS FACING THE ECONOMY
Throughout the post-war period, successive governments have sought solu¬
tions to a number of closely inter-connected problems facing the economy:
the problem of maintaining a sound balance of payments position and so
assuring the strength of sterling; the problem presented by the tendency for
incomes to rise faster than productivity and so leading to inflationary increases
in costs; and the need to achieve a higher rate of expansion of national output.
In recent years, the Government’s general approach to these difficulties has
been to promote structural changes in industry and the long-term develop¬
ment of the economy so as to mobilise more effectively economic resources
and to improve the nation’s economic performance. At times (most recently
in July 1966) the need to strengthen the position of sterling and to ensure
a sound balance of payments has required measures to restrict severely the
pressure of home demand.
THE NATIONAL ECONOMY
243
Balance of
Payments
CONSUMERS’ EXPENDITURE IN 1958 AND 1966

drink (rent, rates, and motor cycles durable goods services

costs)
The United Kingdom’s economic problems have been reflected in periodic
balance of payments difficulties, which have led to sharp checks to economic
expansion and productive investment; these in turn have left the country
vulnerable to further foreign exchange difficulties when expansion was
resumed. Britain’s exports have been growing at only an average rate of about
3 per cent per annum in volume over the past decade; the corresponding
increase in the volume of imports has been over 4 per cent per annum, and
imports of manufactures have risen particularly sharply. Despite a consider¬
able improvement in the terms of trade over the period the average current
surplus on visible and invisible trade together has not been sufficient to
finance Britain’s overseas expenditure arising from its overseas commitments,
private investment abroad and its position as bankers to the overseas sterling
area. The most important of these costs are overseas military expenditure,
which rose from ^101 million (net) to ^272 million (net) over the past ten
years, and economic grant assistance to less-developed or dependent territories,
which rose from £44 million to £85 million; in addition, there are government
loans to overseas countries and multilateral assistance in the form of contri¬
butions to international agencies. Britain also has to make repayments of
capital and interest from post-war loans from the United States and Canada,
the servicing of which requires about ^69 million a year.
At the same time Britain’s private overseas investment has averaged well
over ^300 million a year, a considerable portion of the outflow being to the
less-developed countries. Although this is partly offset by private investment
in Britain from overseas, mainly from the United States, in most years the
net flow has been outward.
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Following an expansion of output in 1963 and 1964 there was a deficit on
current and long-term capital account of £763 million in 1964. A substantial
recovery has taken place since and the deficit was reduced to £357 million in
1965 and £187 million in 1966. In May 1967 Britain repaid in advance to the
International Monetary Fund £145 million of its drawing of £357 million1
made in 1964 and the whole of its £28 million loan from Switzerland. It is
intended to repay the balance of the 1964 drawing by the end of 1967, and
to repay by 1970 a further drawing of £500 million made in 1965. Even after
the repayment of Britain’s undisclosed swap (reciprocal credit) facilities with
other central banks and the servicing of the North American loans (see p. 243)
the reserves were rising in most months in the first half of 1967; they stood
at £1,012 million at the end of June 1967. The temporary surcharge on
imports was ended in November 1966. Besides measures to assist exports,
the Government’s long-term efforts are being directed towards improving the
efficiency and competitiveness of the economy so as to reduce the demand for
imported goods and improve export performance; and a reshaping of govern¬
ment commitments overseas.
The problems to overcome in achieving a faster rate of growth are in the main
centred on improving industrial efficiency and increasing productivity, but of
necessity require a variety of approaches. Among the most important of these
is the work of the Economic Development Committees in examining the
points of weakness in the most important industries, the work of the Ministry
of Technology in fostering the introduction and development of advanced
techniques, and industrial training programmes to meet the need for skilled
labour. The Government’s intention of using the purchasing power of the
public sector to assist industry in improving its efficiency was set out in a
White Paper, Public Purchasing and Industrial Efficiency (Cmnd. 3291),
published in May 1967. An Industrial Reorganisation Corporation has been
set up to promote desirable amalgamations and reorganisations in industry.
Taxation policy is being used to strengthen manufacturing industry relative
to services and other non-manufacturing activities with the introduction of
investment grants (in place of tax allowances) and a selective employment tax
(see p. 380). This has been accompanied by special financial assistance to
industry in extended development areas where resources are under¬
employed and by incentives to improve labour mobility including legislation
providing for redundancy payments and improved re-training facilities.
Efforts are being made to eliminate restrictive practices in both sides of indus¬
try and legislation against monopolies and mergers has been strengthened.
As in many other countries where full employment has prevailed over the past
decade and the demands on resources have been strong, Britain has had to deal
with continuing inflationary pressures. The almost uninterrupted upward
trend in prices has resulted principally from the tendency for money incomes
to rise faster than the volume of production, thus raising costs throughout the
economy.
Since 1956 the average annual rate of increase in domestic incomes has
been about 6 per cent, while the increase in the gross domestic product per
head of the labour force has been only between 2 and 2| per cent. Retail prices
rose on average by nearly 4 per cent a year between January 1956 and
1 The amount outstanding on this loan had in fact already been reduced to £292
million on account of other countries’ drawings of sterling from the Fund.

December 1966; while over roughly the same period average weekly earnings
of manual workers went up by about 6| per cent a year. Company profits are
subject to large cyclical swings, but since 1956 and especially since 1961 they
have increased more slowly than employment incomes. These trends are
illustrated by the diagram above. Successive governments in attempting
to contain the pressure of demand have relied extensively on monetary and
fiscal measures; on variations in the volume and cost of bank credit; on hire-
purchase controls; and on changes in the levels of taxation and public expendi¬
ture. In recent years government policy on prices and incomes has been
directed towards relating increases in money incomes to economic growth by
establishing machinery (see pp. 247-8) to examine wage and salary claims and
selected price increases, and towards increasing public awareness of the need
for voluntary restraint of demands for increased incomes in order to preserve
reasonable stability in cost and prices.
ECONOMIC PLANNING
A framework of longer-term economic planning and consultation between
Government and industry has been evolved in recent years within which the
aim is for economic growth and improvements in industrial efficiency and real
incomes to be reconciled with a high and stable level of employment, a favour¬
able balance of payments and the promotion of social justice. A new govern¬
ment department, the Department of Economic Affairs (see p. 50), which
among other things is responsible for economic planning, was set up in October
1964. It works in close consultation with the Treasury and other government
departments. A Ministry of Technology (see p. 60) was set up at the same
time, to stimulate a more rapid application of scientific and technological
246
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
advances in British industry. A number of other bodies dealing with economic
planning and consultation have been in existence for some years; they
include the National Economic Development Council (NEDC) and its
Economic Development Committees (EDCs) and regional planning bodies
dealing with the special problems of Scotland, Wales and the English regions.
The Department
of Economic
Affairs
The Department of Economic Affairs (DEA) is responsible for framing plans
for economic development and for the general co-ordination of action to
implement them, including, in particular, policies for industry, the regions,
incomes and prices, and economic growth. It works with representatives of
management and unions directly and through the National Economic Develop¬
ment Council.
National
Economic
Development
Council
Economic
Development
Committees
The National Economic Development Council was set up in February 1962
originally to examine the economic performance of the nation with particular
concern for plans for the future in both the private and the public sectors, to
consider uses of national resources and to seek agreement upon ways of
increasing the rate of sound economic growth. In 1963 it published a document,
Growth of the United Kingdom Economy to 1966, which set out the main
economic projections and outlined a coherent pattern of growth. It was
reorganised in November 1964 following the setting up of the DEA.
The NEDC brings together representatives of Government and industry
and makes possible wide discussion of planning and policy. The Prime Minister
chairs some meetings. Ministers from the economic departments are also
members or may attend meetings. Other members are the President of the
Board of Trade, the Minister of Labour, the Minister of Technology, the
chairman of the National Board for Prices and Incomes, a number of repre¬
sentatives from private and nationalised industry, independent members and
the Director General of the National Economic Development Office (NEDO).
The Council, which meets at frequent intervals, is assisted by the NEDO,
whose permanent staff (not members of the Civil Service) is headed by the
Director General.
The NEDC has set up a number of Economic Development Committees.
With one exception each EDC is concerned with one of the major industries
and is composed of members from management and unions in that industry,
the responsible government department, the Department of Economic Affairs,
and other specialists. The EDCs assist in planning by advising on the implica¬
tions for their industries of developments in the economy and the potential
contribution of each industry to national growth. They also study and promote
the application of measures to improve efficiency in each industry.
National In the Government published its National Plan. This set a target of
Planning 25 per cent growth in output from 1964 to 1970, examined the prospects for
each sector of the economy and set out a programme of action to improve
economic performance. It was recognised that achievement of the growth
target would depend on success in dealing with the balance of payments
programme. The developments which necessitated the corrective measures
taken in July 1966, therefore, clearly invalidated many of the assumptions
contained in the Plan. The Government has stated that the programme of
action in the Plan remains valid. During 1967 there have been discussions in
NEDC and the EDCs to establish an agreed basis between Government and
industry for a further planning operation.

247
Long-term
Planning of
Expenditure
Incomes Policy
National Board for
Prices and Incomes
Early Warning
System
Prices and Incomes
Standstill
Long-term planning of public expenditure has been developed by successive
Governments, and annual surveys have been undertaken since 1961 (see
P- 375)’ One of the objects of such planning is to relate public expenditure
programmes, and their demands on national resources, to the expected
development of the economy. It is the Government’s policy in the light of its
assessment of economic and social priorities, to allow expenditure to grow
somewhat faster than the national income. In February 1965 the Government
announced its decision to limit the rise in expenditure by central and local
government to an average of 4^ per cent a year at constant prices between
1964-65 and 1969-70. The rise was not intended to be uniform each year and
it was announced in July 1967 after a further review that although there had
been deliberately above-average increases in the earlier years, it was hoped
that a rise of 3 per cent a year on average in the period to 1970-71 would be
sufficient to enable the programmes set out in the Plan to be fulfilled and thus
maintain the average of 4J per cent over the whole period.
In recent years it has become increasingly recognised that a generally stable
price level combined with sustained economic growth can be achieved only
within the framework of an incomes policy designed to keep the rise in money
incomes broadly in line with the long-term rate of growth in national
production.
The present Government’s incomes policy since 1964 has been developed
in consultation with representatives of management and workers. First, the
Joint Statement of Intent on Productivity, Prices and Incomes, signed in
December 1964, formulated the lines of action to be taken by the Govern¬
ment and by management and unions.
The next step was the setting up in April 1965 of a National Board for
Prices and Incomes (NBPI). The Board investigates all questions of prices
and incomes referred to it by the Government. It sits in private making as
thorough an examination of the issues involved as possible, using evidence
provided both by the parties involved and by outside inquiries. Up to August
1967 the Board published 40 reports on references made to it, including a
Second General Report (Cmnd. 3394) on its activities.
The third stage was the publication of a White Paper, Prices and Incomes
Policy (Cmnd. 2639), setting out considerations which should guide all
concerned with prices and incomes policy.
In September 1965 in view of the urgent need to make its prices and incomes
policy more effective, the Government announced its intention of introducing
legislation. In the interim a voluntary ‘early warning system’ was operated,
the purpose of which was to give the Government adequate opportunity of
considering proposals to increase wages or prices and whether to refer them
to the NBPI. Under these arrangements price increases were notified to the
appropriate government department while pay claims and settlements were
notified to the Trades Union Congress or to the Ministry of Labour. A
decision to refer had to be taken within 28 days. Where the Government
considered there was a prima facie case for reference to the Board there was a
further stand-still period of up to three months while the Board reported. This
system remains as part of the Government’s object of establishing a prices
and incomes policy on a voluntary basis.
On 20th July 1966 a stand-still on prices and incomes was announced in which,
for a period of 12 months, productivity would be allowed to catch up with
the excessive increases in incomes which had been taking place. The object
1

The Prices

Act 1966

BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
for the first six months (up to the end of December 1966) was to avoid as far
as possible increases in prices and incomes altogether; this was followed by a
period of severe restraint in the first half of 1967* In addition to wages and
prices the stand-still also covered other forms of remuneration, such as
directors’ fees, and company distributions.
The Prices and Incomes Act 1966, which received Royal Assent on 12th
August 1966, gave the Government powers of two kinds which could be
brought into operation by Order in Council. Under Part II of the Act powers
could be taken for a renewable period of 12 months to require notification of
increases in prices and charges, company distributions, and the terms and
conditions of employment. Under Part IV of the Act unrenewable powers
could be taken for a period of 12 months from the passing of the Act to require
that particular prices and wages should not be increased or should revert to
the level prevailing on 20th July 1966. Part IV of the Act was brought into
operation from 6th October 1966 to 11 August 1967, although only a limited
use had to be made of these powers, and Part II (as amended) came into force
on 12th August 1967 for a period of 12 months (see below).
A White Paper, Prices and Incomes Policy after 30th June 1967 (Cmnd. 3235),
outlines the current phase of the policy. It provides for more flexible arrange¬
ments for the regulation of prices and incomes by the re-application of the
criteria set out in the White Paper of April 1965 (Cmnd. 2639) (see p. 247)
together with the application of certain additional considerations, it also
provides for the continuation of the early warning system. The Government’s
powers to require advance notification of proposed increases in prices or
incomes under Part II of the 1966 Act were strengthened under the Prices
and Incomes Act 1967 which extended the maximum period of a stand-still
from three to six months from the date of a reference to the NBPI. The new
Act also gave the Government power to secure the suspension of an increase
either where it was made without early warning or before the Board had
reported.
The aim of regional economic planning is to secure a full and balanced
development of the country’s resources and to help achieve a faster and
steadier expansion in national output.
A system of regional councils and boards established in Great Britain in
1965 provides the basic machinery for regional economic planning. The
regional economic planning councils consist of about 25 part-time members
widely representative of experience in each area. The councils are advisory
bodies with no executive powers; they assist in the development of planning
in their regions and advise on the implementation of regional policy and the
implications for the regions of national policies. The regional economic
planning boards consist of civil servants representing the main government
departments concerned with aspects of regional planning in their respective
areas. Their functions are, in co-operation with the planning councils, to
help formulate plans for the region and to co-ordinate the economic planning
work of the government departments.
For purposes of regional planning, Scotland and Wales each form a single
region, and England has been divided into eight regions—Northern, Yorkshire
and Humberside, East Midlands, East Anglia, South-East, South-West, West
Midlands, and North-West (see map on p. 18).
Detailed studies of the regions are being made (in some cases studies
or development programmes for all or part of a region had been published or
THE NATIONAL ECONOMY
249
commenced before the councils were appointed). Studies prepared by
economic planning councils of the Northern, Yorkshire and Humberside,
East Midlands, and the South-West regions have already been published and
the W est Midlands Council has published a report on the future of its region,
based on a previous study. A development plan for Scotland up to 1970 was
published in 1966 and one for Wales in 1967.
Northern Ireland The Northern Ireland Government has set up an economic council, comprising
representatives of both sides of industry and other interests, to examine
means of furthering the economic development of Northern Ireland. Since
Northern Ireland government departments have responsibilities for planning
in Northern Ireland, it was not necessary to set up a special planning board.
A plan for Northern Ireland’s economic development up to 1970 was published
in 1965.
11 Industry
The Structure
of Industry
Manufacturing
ORGANISATION AND PRODUCTION
The United Kingdom was the first country in the world to become highly
industrialised, and today fourteen people work in mining, manufacturing and
building for every one engaged in agriculture. It is the world’s third largest
exporter of manufactured goods, and the range of its industrial manufactures
reflects its position as one of the most important workshops of the world.
The pattern of ownership and organisation in industry is varied. Personal,
corporate, co-operative and public enterprise all assume a number of different
forms, and all are important in the economy. Industrial enterprises vary
from the many small workshops to vast organisations such as the National
Coal Board, a public corporation with about 450,000 employees; Imperial
Chemical Industries Ltd., a limited liability company which, with its sub¬
sidiaries, employs some 126,000 persons in the United Kingdom; and the
Co-operative Wholesale Society Ltd., with about 50,000 employees.
Most manufacturing is in the hands of private enterprise. Exceptions include
fissile materials and radioactive isotopes made by the Atomic Energy
Authority, locomotives and rolling-stock built in the workshops of the
Railways Board, and military equipment and supplies made in establishments
of the defence services. Staff of the Stationery Office do some printing and
bookbinding, while the repair, and to a limited extent the construction, of
post office equipment is carried on in factories run by the Post Office. Certain
factories giving employment to the severely disabled are operated by Remploy
Ltd., a non-profit-making public company financed on the Vote of the
Ministry of Labour, which appoints the directors (see p. 432). The Govern¬
ment holds 51 per cent of the equity of a major oil company, British Petroleum
Limited, and has a controlling interest in a few other companies.
Surveys of the size of all manufacturing establishments employing more
than 10 persons are made periodically by the Ministry of Labour; the results
of the most recent of these surveys show that nearly a third of all employees
in such establishments are in those employing from 100 to 499 persons, while
slightly over a third are in establishments employing 1,000 or more persons.
A high proportion of the biggest establishments are in the heavy industries,
while the average size of establishments in industries making consumer goods
is smaller than in manufacturing industries as a whole. Comparisons with
results obtained in earlier surveys suggest a slow but significant trend towards
an increase in the average size of manufacturing establishments.
The size of establishments is not in itself an indication of the size of
manufacturing enterprises, as a single enterprise may own several establish¬
ments, not all of them necessarily engaged in the same or similar activities.
The most recent analysis of manufacturing enterprises by size (employment)
is provided by the Report of the Census of Production for 1958. An enter¬
prise, as defined in the Census, normally consists of either a single firm or a
holding company together with its subsidiaries. Just over half of all employ¬
ment in British manufacturing industries in 1958 was accounted for by about
950 large private enterprises employing 1,000 or more people, the largest
INDUSTRY
Building and
Civil Engineering
Mining and
Quarrying
Monopolies and
Restrictive
Practices
25i
70 or so accounting roughly for a quarter. A further indication of the size
of companies is the value of the capital employed (net assets). For the largest,
the Imperial Chemical Industries group, the figure exceeds £1,000 million;
about 50 companies registered in Britain have over £100 million net assets.
In some industries a small number of big companies and their subsidiaries
are responsible for most of the total production. Examples are oil refining,
non-ferrous metal smelting, the manufacture of motor vehicles and com¬
ponents, aircraft and aero-engines, heavy electrical equipment, bicycles,
tobacco, cement, and basic chemicals. Shares in these companies are usually
distributed among a great number of holders and it is rare for a few large
holders to have a controlling interest. For example, five of the largest public
companies each have more than 100,000 shareholders. With intensified
competition in the economy and in many branches of industry the growing
dependence of profitable operation on concentration and an increasing scale
of production, the trend towards mergers and regroupings has been particu¬
larly marked in the 1960s. Larger units of control have been established in
almost all the leading industries, for example, motor vehicles, aircraft frames
and aero-engines, electrical engineering, machine tools, brewing, textiles,
newspaper and magazine publishing. The growth of large industrial holding
companies, controlling a wide range of subsidiary companies with a diversity
of industrial interests, which had earlier been one feature of the changing
pattern of organisation in industry, appears to have been halted.
A new departure is the setting up of the Industrial Reorganisation Corpora¬
tion by the Government in 1966 with resources of up to £150 million provided
by the Exchequer. It is empowered to participate in schemes for concen¬
tration, rationalisation and modernisation of industry, in particular the
merging and regrouping of firms into larger units to meet the changing
situation in the markets for many of the most important products.
An account of some of the principal manufacturing industries is given on
pp. 288-314.
In building and civil engineering, large-scale work is usually carried out by
private contractors, although the Ministry of Public Building and Works is
the largest single employer of building labour while nearly 45 per cent of
the industry’s output is for public authorities.
Building firms may be divided into those undertaking general building and
civil engineering work and those concerned with highly specialised work,
many of which operate outside as well as inside the building industry.
Building is an industry of small firms; more than three-quarters of the firms
employ fewer than 20 employees. For a fuller account of the building and
civil engineering industries, see p. 286.
Much the most important of the British extractive industries is coalmining.
The coalmining industry of Great Britain (see p. 269) is operated as a single
co-ordinated enterprise under National Coal Board direction (see p. 270).
Nearly all other mining and quarrying (iron ore, sand, gravel, chalk,
limestone, salt, tin, slate, oil shale and china clay) is undertaken by private
enterprises, usually owned and operated by limited liability companies.
About 85,000 workers are employed, excluding coalmining.
Legislation exists for scrutinising and, if desirable, for the investigation by
an independent administrative body of monopoly situations and for the
judicial examination of restrictive trading agreements. The Government
intends to seek Parliamentary approval to strengthen and extend legislation
252
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
on restrictive practices and to introduce a temporary exemption procedure
for agreements beneficial to the national economy.
The Restrictive Trade Practices Act 1956 provides for the registration
and judicial examination of restrictive agreements. It requires the entry in a
public register of the particulars of a wide range of restrictive agreements
(including those relating to common prices, approved lists of dealers and the
limitation of production) which affect the supply or processing of goods for
the United Kingdom market. The Registrar of Restrictive Trading Agree¬
ments is responsible for keeping the register and for bringing the agreements
before the Restrictive Practices Court set up under the Act. The Court, which
includes laymen but is presided over by one of Her Majesty’s judges, is, in
effect, responsible for deciding whether or not an agreement is in the public
interest. If the parties to an agreement fail to satisfy the Court that any
restriction in their agreement produces one or more of seven beneficial
effects set out in the Act, and that the restriction is not unreasonable, having
regard to the balance between the benefit it confers and any public detriment
likely to result from its operation, that restriction must be found contrary to
the public interest. Agreements are void in respect of restrictions so found.
The Court can make orders preventing the parties from operating their
agreement, or from making new arrangements having the same effect. Agree¬
ments relating exclusively to exports are not subject to this procedure but
have to be notified to the Board of Trade. The first full hearing before the
Court took place in October 1958.
Monopolies and kindred arrangements (except those within the scope of
the Restrictive Practices Court) in the circumstances indicated in the
Monopolies and Mergers Acts 1948 and 1965 may be referred by the Board
of Trade to the Monopolies Commission for investigation and report. The
Board of Trade, in co-operation with the production departments (see p. 260)
concerned, take appropriate action on the reports but no Order can be made
without the approval of Parliament.
The 1965 Act strengthened and extended the legislation on monopolies.
It reorganised and enlarged the Monopolies Commission; provided for the
investigation, at the reference of the Board of Trade, of services and of
proposed or recently completed mergers; made special provision for news¬
paper mergers; and improved and extended the Government’s powers for
taking action on the basis of the Monopolies Commission reports including
new powers to prohibit mergers and break up undesirable monopolies and
mergers. The Commission has to date presented 38 reports, of which five
dealt with mergers.
Under the 1956 Act collective enforcement of resale price maintenance
was prohibited, but individual suppliers remained free to enforce resale
prices in the courts. The Resale Prices Act 1964 makes minimum resale price
maintenance unlawful, except in respect of classes of registered goods for
which temporary exemption has been sought under the provisions of the Act.
Where resale price maintenance is prohibited, it is also unlawful to notify
to dealers prices stated or calculated to be understood as the minimum price
which may be charged on the resale of goods in the United Kingdom, or to
seek to maintain such prices by withholding supplies. Suppliers may continue
to practise resale price maintenance on registered goods, pending a decision by
the Restrictive Practices Court as to whether a case for exemption has been
made out against the criteria in the Act. Periodically, the Registrar of Restrictive
Trading Agreements issues lists of classes of goods in respect of which the Court
has refused to make an Order exempting them from the terms of the Act.
INDUSTRY
253
Role of Public
Enterprise
Direct State participation in productive and commercial activities is effected
mainly through special statutory bodies set up to deal with a particular
activity. Such bodies, though not part of a government department, are under
a considerable but varying degree of public control (see below). The most
important of these statutory bodies are the public corporations which operate
major industries and services in the public interest. Altogether ten per cent
of the labour force works for these bodies.
The public corporation today is, generally speaking, a public body having
a clearly defined and specific task. Its managing board and its staff are chosen
for their experience and competence in a particular field; they are not civil
servants, and although they are accountable to Parliament for their actions
in a variety of ways, it is they and not the ministers of the sponsoring
departments who are responsible for the management of the corporations.
Certain of the corporations are self-supporting; others receive Exchequer
grants to help them carry out duties with which they have been charged.
Before the second world war, a number of public corporations had been
established in those industries and services where it was considered that the
national interest required co-ordination or control by a public authority.
Their constitutions had no standard pattern and their governing bodies
differed in the method of appointment and in composition. Immediately
after the second world war, the nationalisation Acts set up public corporations
to run certain major industries and services, including coalmining, inland
transport, gas supply, electricity generation and supply, and civil air transport.
These post-war corporations are less varied in the structure of their governing
bodies, which are appointed by the responsible minister.
The following corporations are now operating or controlling large-scale
industries or services:
Atomic Energy: The United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority.
Aviation: The British Overseas Airways Corporation, British European
Airways, the British Airports Authority.
Banking: The Bank of England.
Broadcasting: The British Broadcasting Corporation, the Independent
Television Authority.
Coal: The National Coal Board.
Electric Power: The Electricity Council, the Central Electricity Generating
Board, the Area Electricity Boards, the North of Scotland Hydro-Electric
Board, the South of Scotland Electricity Board, the Electricity Board for
Northern Ireland.
Gas: The Gas Council, the Area Gas Boards.
Steel: The British Steel Corporation.
Transport: The British Railways Board, the British Transport Docks Board,
the British Waterways Board, the London Transport Board, the Transport
Holding Company, the Ulster Transport Authority.
The Post Office is to become a public corporation in 1969 (see p. 367).
The extent to which the responsible minister has power over the working
of the boards which have been set up to run the nationalised industries varies
from industry to industry, but two features are common to almost all of them.
First, the minister appoints (and may dismiss) the chairman and members
of each board, and, secondly, he has power to give general directions as to
254
BRITAIN.' AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Industrial
Association
how the industry should be run, but does not interfere in day-to-day manage¬
ment. It is usually also laid down that the board shall give to the minister
any information, statistics and financial accounts which he may require. In
practice, as the responsible minister is kept fully informed and major policy
decisions are reached in consultation with him, there is very seldom occasion
for him to issue a formal directive.
The Minister also has financial powers and responsibilities. The usual
statutory requirement is that the board is required to conduct its business so
that receipts at least balance outgoings taking one year with another. The
responsible minister is usually empowered (subject to Treasury approval) to
say what shall be done with any surplus revenues which may accrue. As
regards finance of capital expenditure, the present system is that such finance
as cannot be met from internal sources is mainly provided, in the form of
interest-earning loans, by the minister from the Exchequer, bank advances
being used only for normal requirements of short-term capital.
The minister responsible for each nationalised industry must take steps to
see that the interests of the industry’s customers are protected. This is usually
done by the establishment of representative consumers’ councils to consider
complaints and suggestions made to them, and to advise the board or the
minister on the changes they think desirable.
In a White Paper (Cmnd. 1337) issued in April 1961 the Government out¬
lined certain general principles which it believed had to be applied for the
administration of the nationalised industries to be efficient. Among them were
a balancing of revenue accounts over a five-year period, a closer definition of
the financial and economic obligations of the industries, and greater freedom
in price policies. In accordance with these principles, financial objectives have
been introduced for the nationalised fuel and power industries and for BEA,
the Post Office and the London Transport Board.
Government policy towards the nationalised industries is subject to the
approval of Parliament. Opportunities for parliamentary discussion are
afforded by debates, including debates on their annual reports and accounts,
and by answers to parliamentary questions, which, in principle, are
admissible only if concerned with policy rather than details of administration.
A House of Commons Select Committee on the Nationalised Industries,
which examines the reports and accounts of the nationalised industries and
reports to Parliament, has been in operation since 1957.
From the middle of the nineteenth century, private industrial undertakings
have increasingly entered into voluntary association for a number of different
purposes. Some of the more important of these are classified as follows:
1. The provision of common services, the exchange of information, liaison
with the Government, and representation of their members’ point of
view.
2. The regulation of trading practices, sometimes including the regulation of
prices (see pp. 251-2).
3. Negotiation with trade unions on wages and conditions of work.
Associations for the first and third of these purposes cover, with varying
completeness, most of British industry, but there are wide sectors of industry
where there are no collective agreements to regulate trading practices.
Employers’ organisations which deal with labour matters usually consist of
firms engaged in the same type of operation or manufacturing process. Trade
associations mainly concerned with representations to the Government,
INDUSTRY
Location
255
provision of common services or the regulation of trading practices are built
up round a product or an allied group of products. In an industrial sector
concerned wholly with an allied group of products, a single association may
undertake all the required functions.
There are about 80 national federations and probably altogether about
1,500 employers’ organisations (mostly regional or local, and members or
branches of the national federations) all concerned with negotiation of wages
and conditions of work. The number of manufacturers’ associations concerned
with providing common services is not known precisely, but according to a
survey carried out between 1953 and 1956 by Political and Economic Planning
(an independent research organisation) some 1,300 were in existence, varying
greatly in importance, structure and activities.
The central body representing British industry nationally is the Confedera¬
tion of British Industry (CBI). It is recognised by the Government as a
channel for consultation between government departments and representa¬
tives of private employers as a whole. For its members it acts as an advisory
and consultative body providing them with information and statistics, ascer¬
taining their collective views and representing them nationally to the
Government and the public and also internationally, for example in the
Council of European Industrial Federations. CBI representatives sit on a
number of government advisory committees, on other statutory bodies and
on voluntary bodies concerned with matters affecting industry.
The CBI membership consists of some 13,000 companies and over 200
trade associations and employers’ federations. The nationalised industries have
joined as industrial associates. The CBI has a regional organisation in the
United Kingdom and is widely represented abroad.
In matters of common concern the CBI often acts jointly with the chambers
of commerce. These bodies are open to all kinds of producers and traders
and exist to promote the interests of local industry and commerce. The
Association of British Chambers of Commerce, founded in i860, is the central
organisation to which 101 local chambers of commerce (together with 22
British Chambers of Commerce operating in foreign countries) are affiliated.
In Scotland there is an additional central organisation, the Council of Scottish
Chambers of Commerce, and in Northern Ireland, the Association of Northern
Ireland Chamber of Commerce and Industry.
The main areas of industrial concentration in Britain are the London area,
north-east England, Yorkshire and Humberside, north-west England, the
Midlands, Severnside, South Wales, central Scotland, and Belfast in
Northern Ireland. All but two (London and Severnside) are the areas
associated with the rapid industrialisation of the nineteenth century, and all
but two (London and Belfast) are on or near major coalfields, then the
principal source of power. During the second quarter of the twentieth century
there was a tendency for the newer industries, such as those manufacturing
motor vehicles, electrical goods and rubber products, to develop rapidly in
the south (especially in and around Greater London) and in the Midlands.
In the last twenty years the older industrial areas which specialised in the
great staple industries—coalmining, steel, shipbuilding, heavy engineering
and textiles—and which remain for the most part of considerable importance,
have also acquired a much wider and more diversified industrial base, in part
the result of Government action and encouragement. Electronic products,
instruments, industrial components, clothing, man-made fibres and the
newer chemicals are examples of industries located throughout Britain.

BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The following is a summary of the geographical distribution of British
industry today, grouped by the areas covered by the regional economic
planning machinery (see p. 248).
London, situated at the head of ocean navigation on the Thames estuary,
is Britain’s capital and main communication centre, probably still the world’s
most important financial centre, one of the world’s three largest cities (with
Tokyo and New York) and one of the world’s three largest ports (with New
York and Rotterdam).
Greater London (see p. 71), including the urbanised fringe areas within
50 miles of Charing Cross, has a working population of over six million, of
whom over a third are in manufacturing industry. London is the main centre
in Britain of the clothing and food and drink industries, of printing, of
cinema film production, and of the manufacture of furniture, materials for
the arts, precision instruments and many other specialised products. Small
firms predominate in many of these industries and the average size of
manufacturing firms (particularly in inner London) is well below the national
average. London is also, especially its outer ring, an important area for light
engineering, chemicals and consumer goods and has some heavy engineering
plants and a number of leading research establishments.
Towards the periphery of the London conurbation and in the new urban
development outside it, industry, particularly the electronics and a variety of
consumer goods industries, has been expanding rapidly; some of the largest
aircraft plants are in these areas, for example at Weybridge and Hatfield, as
well as the factories, at Dagenham, Luton and Dunstable, of two of the five
main motor vehicle manufacturers. There are other major motor vehicle
manufacturing plants at Cowley, Oxford (population 109,000), some 50 miles
north-west of London. Along the lower Thames and Medway estuaries there
are large oil refineries as well as some smaller shipyards, engineering works and
major concentrations of the paper and pulp and cement industries.
The Channel coast has been much developed for tourist traffic and as a
place for retirement. A great part of the coast eastwards from Poole
(population 95,600) and Bournemouth (151,000) consists of built-up areas,
which from Brighton (163,000) eastwards are partly dormitories for people
working in London. Portsmouth (216,000) is a naval port and has some ship¬
building and general manufactures. Southampton (209,000) is the largest
port in Britain for ocean-going liners and its industries include ship repairing,
oil refining, cable-making, electronics and synthetic rubber. Dover, Folkestone
and Newhaven are packet ports.
Devon and Cornwall have a considerable tourist trade and some popular
retirement areas. Bristol, the largest city of the south-west (429,000) is a
leading port and commercial centre with aircraft, aero-engines, tobacco, food
processing, paper, printing and other industries and nearby, at Avonmouth,
are important non-ferrous metal and basic chemicals plants. Gloucester
(72,000), originally an inland port and commercial town, Cheltenham
(75,000), originally a resort town, and the area between and adjacent to them
produce a variety of manufactures, including machinery, instruments and
accessories and the well-known West of England cloth. Swindon (98,000),
besides its railway workshops, has important engineering works. Bath
(83,000), originally a resort town and the centre of an agricultural district,
has become noted for engineering and other manufacturing.
Besides being one of the most productive agricultural regions, the eastern
counties possess some sizeable towns. Cambridge (100,000) is a leading
INDUSTRY
West
Midlands
East
Midlands
North-west
England
257
centre of research-based industry; Ipswich (121,000) and Peterborough
(65,000) are noted for agricultural machinery and implements; and Norwich
(119,000) for footwear and food manufacture. Also at Norwich and the port
of King’s Lynn (28,000) chemicals are becoming important. Food canning
and freezing, based mainly on locally grown produce, have developed rapidly.
The fishing ports of Great Yarmouth (53,000) and Lowestoft (48,000) have
extensive fish processing plants, and are also becoming important bases for
companies engaged in the natural gas discoveries in the North Sea.
The main industrial area—the West Midlands conurbation—stretches from
Birmingham (1,103,000) through the Black Country to Wolverhampton
(267,000) and includes portions of Staffordshire, Worcestershire and
Warwickshire. It has an unusually wide variety of industry, including notably
the manufacture of metals, electrical and engineering products of all kinds
and also jewellery, rubber products, chemicals and domestic metalware. The
largest concentrations of motor vehicle manufacture, including components
and accessories, in the United Kingdom are situated in the Midlands, at
Coventry (332,000) and Birmingham.
The smaller conurbation of North Staffordshire, centred on Stoke-on-Trent
(276.500) , is devoted chiefly to the manufacture of pottery and china and to
coalmining, although other industries are growing in importance, while
Stafford (50,500) has heavy electrical and other engineering works.
Other industrial centres are Rugby (55,500), electrical engineering;
Worcester (68,000), machinery; Burton-on-Trent (50,500), brewing and
rubber; and Kidderminster (44,000), carpets.
The thriving industrial cities and towns of the East Midlands include Leicester
(284,000) noted for hosiery and knitwear, boots and shoes and machinery for
making these products; Derby (129,000) for general engineering, aero-engines
and man-made fibres; Nottingham (310,000) for hosiery, cycles and a variety
of other engineering products, lace, pharmaceutical products, tobacco;
Northampton (121,500) footwear, engineering; Chesterfield (70,000) engineer¬
ing. Corby (45,000), a new town in Northamptonshire, has a steel industry
originally based on local deposits of iron ore, and at Peterborough (64,000)
there are several large engineering works. The richest and most highly
mechanised coalfield in Britain lies in the north-east of the area and continues
into Yorkshire. Some of the towns on the coalfield, such as Mansfield
(55,000), have important manufacturing industries, particularly textiles.
Manchester (625,000) is the commercial hub of the cotton and man-made
fibre textile industries, a very important financial and commercial centre and
a major port. It is also one of the chief centres for electrical and heavy
engineering and the production of machine tools, petro-chemicals, dyestuffs,
and pharmaceutical goods, while it has a wide range of other manufactures.
In the traditional cotton-manufacturing towns man-made fibres are also
processed alone or blended with cotton; the largest of these are Bolton
(158,000), Oldham (111,500), Rochdale (86,500), Stockport (142,000), Burnley
(78.500) , Blackburn (103,000), Preston (109,000) and Bury (62,500). In the
majority of these towns engineering industries, notably the manufacture of
printing, paper making, textile and electrical machinery and heavy commercial
vehicles (especially in the Chorley-Leyland area), have been increasing while
the cotton industry has been declining. The Lancashire coalfield also lies in
the Manchester-Wigan area.
The Manchester Ship Canal, which carries a substantial volume of overseas
trade, links Manchester with Merseyside. It passes through the important
258
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Yorkshire and
Humberside
Northern England
industrial town of Warrington (74,500) with its metal industries (such as
wire-drawing), Widnes (54,000) and Runcorn (27,500) with their chemicals,
and Ellesmere Port (49,500) with its oil refinery installations, before reaching
the Mersey estuary. St. Helens (104,500), to the north of the canal, is famous
for glass manufacture. Liverpool (712,000) is the second port of Britain, a
great commercial and insurance centre and, after London, the greatest centre
for processing imported foodstuffs and raw materials, being noted especially
for flour milling, soap manufacture, sugar refining and rubber products. Among
its older industries is ship repairing; shipbuilding is a major industry across
the river at Birkenhead (143,500). Many new industries, including electrical
engineering, the manufacture of heavy industrial equipment and, more
recently, motor vehicle manufacture, have been established around Liverpool.
Salt, extracted in Cheshire, is used by chemical works on Merseyside.
Barrow (64,500), in the north-west of Lancashire, is well-known for ship¬
building and marine engineering. Blackpool (150,500) on the Lancashire coast
is Britain’s most popular holiday resort.
About three-quarters of the United Kingdom’s worsted and woollen indus¬
tries are found in the West Riding of Yorkshire. Bradford (297,000) is the
commercial centre of the wool trade and important for worsted; Wakefield
(60,000) produces both worsted and woollens; Morley (43,000) and Leeds
(508,000) have specialised in cheaper cloths, and Batley (48,500), Dewsbury
(53,000) and Spenborough (38,000) in heavy cloth, but their production is
becoming more diversified. Huddersfield (132,000) has a reputation for fine
woollens and worsteds and Halifax (95,000) for carpets. In most of the larger
centres of the wool industry a variety of engineering products are manu¬
factured. Leeds, the commercial capital of the area, has a large ready-made
clothing industry and important engineering plants. Farther south is the
heavy engineering centre of Sheffield (486,000), famous for its high quality
steels, cutlery and tools. The area’s extensive coalfields provide nearly a
quarter of Britain’s coal; Doncaster (86,500), also with tractor and nylon
manufacturing, and Barnsley (75,500) are the largest towns on the coalfield.
York (106,000) is noted for chocolates and confectionery manufacture and
has important railway workshops, and Hull (298,000), one of the world’s
largest fishing ports and with many manufacturing industries, including
engineering, vegetable oil processing, paints and sawmilling, is the most
important industrial town in the East Riding of Yorkshire.
On the south (Lincolnshire) side of the Humber lie Scunthorpe (70,000),
another important steel-making centre, and the major fishing port of Grimsby
(95,000) which has a food processing industry and also a growing chemicals
industry close by at Immingham.
The greater part of this region (Northumberland, Cumberland, Westmorland,
Durham and the North Riding of Yorkshire) is an area of mountains, lakes and
moors and is relatively thinly populated. Most of its population of 3-3 million
is concentrated in the coastal strip about 20 miles deep and 45 miles long,
from the coalfields north of the Tyne to the Tees. Within this area the main
centres are Tyneside, including Newcastle upon Tyne (254,000), Gateshead
(101,500), Tynemouth (72,000), South Shields (108,500), Wallsend (49,000)
and Jarrow (26,500); and Tees-side, including Middlesbrough (157,000) and
West Hartlepool (78,500). Other large towns are Sunderland (188,500),
Darlington (84,500) and, in the west, Carlisle (71,000).
The whole region is more dependent than other parts of England on
traditional heavy industries, notably coalmining, iron and steel manufacture,
INDUSTRY
Wales
Scotland
259
shipbuilding and repairing and chemicals (the complex of chemical plants
on both banks of the Tees is probably the most extensive in Europe), which
together employ nearly a third of the male workers. This proportion has
been falling steadily as the result of the establishment of industrial estates
and other government measures to attract new types of enterprise and promote
the diversification of industry. It is one of the most important areas for the
manufacture of electrical plant, and the many other industries include mining
machinery, rolling mill plant, earth-moving equipment, machine tools, ropes,
paint, glass, clothing and scientific instruments. Atomic energy is important
in Cumberland with its two nuclear power stations.
Nearly two-thirds of the population of Wales and Monmouthshire (2-7
million) live in the two counties of Glamorgan and Monmouthshire. In this
area are the coal mines which, though long worked and operating at increasing
depths, still produce nearly all Britain’s anthracite and much of its steam and
other specialised coals, and still employ more workers than any branch of
manufacturing industry. Rhondda (98,500) and Merthyr Tydfil (58,000) are
the largest centres in the coalmining area. The steel industry, with some of the
most modern plants in Europe, supplies almost all Britain’s output of tin plate
and a large proportion of its sheet steel. In the past 30 years many new
industries have been established, often located on government industrial
estates; they include plastics, synthetic fibres, clothing, electronics, motor
vehicle components and light engineering.
The main urban centres are also the three major ports—Cardiff (260,000),
Newport (106,500) and Swansea (171,000). Milford Haven (13,000), a magni¬
ficent deep-water harbour recently developed, has two major oil refineries.
In North Wales a number of light industries, notably man-made fibres,
are located in the seaside resorts and some other towns, particularly
Wrexham (37,000), and there is a large steelworks in Flintshire.
About three-quarters of Scotland’s population (5-2 million) is concentrated in
the central Lowlands, a belt some 65 miles wide and 15 to 30 miles deep
between the Firth of Clyde and the Firth of Forth. The principal cities in this
area are Glasgow (980,000) and Edinburgh (469,000). Clydeside, which
includes the city of Glasgow, is the United Kingdom’s largest shipbuilding
and marine engineering centre; it also has a great variety of general engineering
enterprises and other industries. The steel industry, sited mainly in north
Lanarkshire, produces a wide range of products. The widely dispersed
electronics equipment industry is represented by a growing number of firms
in such centres as Glasgow, north Lanarkshire, Dundee and central Fife, as
well as in Edinburgh, where this and other modern industries are expanding
alongside the long-established engineering, printing and brewing industries.
Motor car manufacture has been established in Renfrewshire and in West
Lothian there has been a major expansion of commercial vehicle building.
Outside the central Lowland belt there is considerable industrial concen¬
tration in the vicinity of Dundee (185,000) and in Aberdeen (184,500) and
a number of towns outside these areas have been attracting light industries in
recent years. Dundee’s traditional manufacture, jute, has been supplemented
in the last two decades by office machinery, clocks and watches, refrigerators
and electronic products. In north-east Scotland is the largest concentration of
whisky distilleries.
Most of northern Scotland is mountainous and much of southern Scotland
is hilly and rugged. These regions are sparsely populated, but the Scottish
Highlands possess significant resources of hydro-electric power (see p. 277).
