Northern Ireland
Relations
between the
Government
and Industry
There are high-quality tweed and knitwear industries both in the valley
towns of the southern uplands and in the Highlands and Islands.
Although the area of Northern Ireland is relatively small and it lacks minerals,
there is substantial and growing industrialisation, particularly in and around
the capital city of Belfast (403,000). The largest single shipyard in the United
Kingdom is sited in Belfast and other long-established activities include the
manufacture of marine engines, ropes, twine, tobacco and clothing. Northern
Ireland has also long been an important centre for textiles—it is particularly
well known for linen. The textile industry is now extensively diversified;
Northern Ireland is one of the most important areas in Europe for man-made
fibre production and provides about one-fifth of Britain’s output. There has
also been extensive development in automobile components, oil-well
equipment, electronic instruments, telephone switchgear, toys, shoes, carpets
and synthetic rubber.
The Government can influence industrial activity in a number of ways—
through fiscal and monetary policy, through the level of public expenditure,
through the policies of publicly owned enterprises, by physical controls, by
inducements, by exhortation and by the provision of services, information and
advice. Apart from labour legislation (see Chapter 16) and certain export and
import controls over a small range of products (see Chapter 15), there are few
physical controls over industry—the main ones are the use of the legislation
concerning monopolies and restrictive practices already described (see
p. 251) and the operation of powers to control new industrial and office
building and changes in land use. The latter are particularly relevant to the
improvement of the geographical distribution of industry (see p. 264).
There is a close and growing association between industry and the
Government through such channels as the National Economic Development
Council and the 22 Economic Development Committees for individual
industries (see p. 262) where views on matters of importance to the economy,
including productivity (see p. 261) can be made known and discussed.
Within the Government, the Department of Economic Affairs (DEA) has
general responsibility for co-ordinating work on economic planning, growth
of the economy, regional development and policies affecting industrial
efficiency, and prices and incomes. The department through which the
Government’s day-to-day relations with trade and industry are chiefly
conducted is the Board of Trade (which has regional offices in the principal
industrial centres) and its responsibilities cover a wide range of industries
and materials. Other departments concerned with particular subjects of
concern to industry generally are the Treasury, which is responsible for fiscal
and monetary policy; the Ministry of Labour, the channel through which man¬
power policy is conducted; and the Department of Education and Science,
which is responsible for the promotion of education and for civil science,
operating in the main through the research councils.
For particular industries a system has grown up whereby a particular
government department acts as the main point of contact, the ‘production or
sponsor department’, for each major industry. The Ministry of Technology,
which was set up in 1964, is concerned with the application of advanced tech¬
nology and new processes in industry. It is, therefore, the sponsor department
for the mechanical and electrical engineering industries and for those manu¬
facturing electronic equipment, computers, machine tools, telecommunications
equipment, aircraft and aero-engines. The Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries
and Food is the appropriate department for food processing, the Ministry of

The Central Statistical Office, which is attached to the Cabinet Office,
provides a comprehensive statistical service. Although departments them¬
selves compile statistics relating to their particular responsibilities, and may
publish them in their own standard publications, the comprehensive statistical
publications are prepared by the Central Statistical Office. (For the principal
regular series of statistics published, see Bibliography p. 505.)
Industrial production (mining and quarrying, manufacturing, construction,
and gas, electricity and water) was in the first half of 1967 some 2 per cent
lower than a year previously, about 34 per cent more than in 1958 and
about double the pre-war level. The course of production and employment
from i960 to 1966 is shown in Table 15.

Between 1958 and 1966 output in the chemicals and allied industries rose
by 65 per cent; in engineering and electrical goods by 52 per cent; in metal
manufacture by 25 per cent; in vehicles (including aircraft) by 29 per cent;
in paper, printing and publishing by 44 per cent; and in clothing and footwear
by 27 per cent (see diagram p. 262).
The increases in production in recent years have been due only to a small
degree to an increase in the labour force but mainly to a variety of factors
influencing productivity, including technical advances in products, machinery
and processes; the rate of fixed capital formation; more intensive competition
and sales promotion; and improved management of particular undertakings.
Gross fixed capital formation at home has been well maintained. In 1966
it amounted to 21 per cent of the gross domestic product and was estimated
to be over 60 per cent greater than in 1958. Part of this rising investment is
linked with the introduction of new techniques and equipment and in
particular of machines and instruments which lessen the demand for human
skill and supervision though they may require more skill from fewer people.
All of this is part of the process known as automation, which is giving rise to
far-reaching changes in the pattern of industry and in the internal organisa¬
tion and labour requirements of business enterprises and has already been
262
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Productivity
INDEX OF INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION 1966 (Average 1958^100)
sists of replacements, additions and improvements of a more traditional kind.
Both the long-term and the short-term growth of productivity thus depend
most directly on the decisions of individual undertakings. While the promo¬
tion of productivity is regarded as primarily a matter for industry, govern¬
ment departments and educational and research establishments also have an
important contribution to make. Government budgeting and financial policies
also have a strong influence on the extent and direction of demand. These,
therefore, are framed to a large degree on a realistic assessment of the
possibilities of sustained economic growth.
Leading industrialists have been recruited as advisers in the Department
of Economic Affairs to help overcome specific obstacles to efficiency and
industrial expansion. They work principally through the Economic Develop¬
ment Committees (EDCs), which are offshoots of the National Economic
Development Council. The Committees cover particular sectors of industry
and bring together managements, union and government representatives.
Employers’ associations and trade unions are engaged in activities to raise
industrial productivity. Employers’ organisations often provide technical
assistance, conduct market surveys, and support schemes of vocational
education and training. The trade unions in many industries organise special
schemes for training young people, and also a variety of courses designed to
give trade unionists an understanding of modern management techniques.
Private consultants specialising in management and work study are available
to give advice to firms on measures to increase their productive efficiency;
there are also many specialist institutions, both public and private, concerned
with various aspects of productivity.
The British Productivity Council (BPC) was established by both sides of
industry to stimulate interest in methods of raising productivity. It was set
up in 1952 to continue and develop the work of the Anglo-American Pro¬
ductivity Council. It is an independent body on which are represented the
Confederation of British Industry, the Trades Union Congress, the
Association of British Chambers of Commerce, and the nationalised industries;
its work is financed by contributions from these bodies and by a government
INDUSTRY
263
grant-in-aid. Advisory committees have been set up to promote productivity
in the building trades, in agriculture and in retailing. Much of the BPC’s
work is done through 130 local productivity committees and associations
throughout the country, but it is also responsible for special countrywide
campaigns such as the Quality and Reliability Year in 1967. The local
organisations arrange meetings, inter-factory visits, courses, conferences, film
shows and exhibitions.
The British Standards Institution (BSI) is a voluntary non-profit-making
body incorporated by Royal Charter. It prepares and promulgates standards
in respect of, inter alia, quality, performance, dimensions, testing methods
and codes of practice. Voluntary acceptance of such standards by manufac¬
turers, buyers and sellers reduces unnecessary variety and simplifies the
specification of requirements, thus promoting industrial efficiency. The BSI
is governed by a council consisting of representatives of the main organisa¬
tions of employers and workers, professional institutions and the larger
government departments.
The DEA is responsible for co-ordinating activities related to the promo¬
tion of productivity. The Board of Trade administers the government grants
to the BPC and the Council of Industrial Design. The Ministry of Technology
is charged with the function of extending the introduction of automatic control
systems and advanced techniques into industry, sponsors the BSI and
provides technical advisory services. It is also concerned directly wdth
research into such factors as productivity measurement techniques, produc¬
tion engineering and fatigue among operators.
A number of other departments have responsibilities which bear on pro¬
ductivity. The Ministry of Labour has a general responsibility for the
promotion of industrial training. The Ministry’s Industrial Relations Service
advises firms on personnel management and industrial relations. The
Department of Education and Science and the Scottish Education Department
are responsible for the technical colleges, at which courses are available in
such subjects as work study and industrial engineering. The Ministry of
Public Building and Works provides a Technical Information Service for the
building industry; and the Ministry of Power and the British Productivity
Council sponsor the National Industrial Fuel Efficiency Service. The Ministry
of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food provides a number of advisory services
to the farming industry in England and Wales; similar services are provided
by the three Scottish agricultural colleges. In Northern Ireland these services
are provided by the Ministry of Agriculture.
Management During the present century and particularly during and since the second
world war, the increasing pace of technical, organisational and social change
has made the successful conduct of enterprises dependent on knowledge of,
and practice in, a complex of managerial techniques for dealing with technical
and human problems. In Britain, as elsewhere, there is a growing awareness
of the importance of management as a subject requiring special skills and
knowledge. This has been reflected both in a change in the general educational
qualifications of recruits to management and in the spread of systematic
education and training for management.
The British Institute of Management (BIM) is the central national
management body, independent, non-political and non-profit-making. Its
purpose is to study and promote scientific management, including manage¬
ment education and training, throughout industry, commerce, and public
administration. It has nearly 5,000 member companies and over 14,000
264
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
individual members. Management studies and education for management are
expanding rapidly in Britain and have become a recognised feature of higher
education (see p. 167). Graduate Business Schools have been established in
London and Manchester.
Training courses for higher management are held at a few universities,
notably Bristol; by some firms of management consultants; and at the
Administrative Staff College at Henley-on-Thames, and Ashridge College of
Management, Berkhamsted. The larger firms, especially those with wide-
ranging responsibilities, often provide general management courses for the
training of senior executives, and systems of informal training within an
organisation are numerous. There are also various bodies concerned with
specialised branches of management, for example, the Institute of Personnel
Management, the Institution of Works Managers, the Institute of Office
Management and the Institute of Marketing.
The growing number of professional personnel working as management
consultants—now over 2,000—and the use of the services of independent
management selection firms in the appointment of senior staff are indications
of the interest in the science of management in Britain.
Encouragement
of Expansion
in Productive
Industry
Under the Industrial Development Act 1966 cash grants were introduced in
place of certain tax allowances for capital expenditure on plant or machinery
used in the manufacturing, extractive and construction industries. The grant
scheme, which is administered by the Board of Trade, also covers capital
expenditure on computers, ships, hovercraft and mining works. The standard
rate of grant for these is 20 per cent (25 per cent in 1967 and 1968). In order
to maintain a greater incentive to investment in development areas (see
below) the rate of grant was fixed at 40 per cent (45 per cent in 1967 and 1968).
In contrast with the plant and machinery grants previously available in the
development districts, these new investment grants are not dependent on the
provision of additional employment.
Government
Help for
Industry in
Development
Areas
Some parts of Britain have long been less prosperous than others. Their rate
of economic expansion has been below average and their level of unemploy¬
ment above average as a result of the decline of old-fashioned industries or
the lack of job opportunities. For many years unemployment has remained a
persistent problem in Scotland, Wales and the north and some other parts of
England. This regional imbalance has been aggravated by the tendency for
new industries to concentrate in the Midlands and the south-east where, as a
result, the demand for labour is high and there are increasing problems of
congestion. An important aim of the Government’s regional policy is to
achieve a better distribution of industrial development between the different
parts of the country. The Government has in recent years taken important
measures aimed at securing balanced economic development.
Government aid to areas of high unemployment began in the 1930s and
has been developed in various ways since the end of the second world war.
In August 1966 the Board of Trade designated large parts of Britain as
‘development areas’ where industrial development is to be encouraged. These
areas have now replaced the previous smaller development districts. They
cover northern England, Merseyside and nearly the whole of Scotland, Wales,
Cornwall and north Devon. They contain a fifth of Britain’s working popula¬
tion, and, in their reserves of manpower, have the potential for steady
economic growth. The Board of Trade provides businessmen with detailed
information on industrial location within the development areas and offers
INDUSTRY
Northern Ireland
265
a wide variety of inducements to new or expanding businesses in these
areas.
Besides the investment grants on plant and machinery there is a wide range
of financial and other inducements available under the Local Employment
Acts i960 and 1963 to encourage industry to expand in the development
areas. The Board of Trade may build factories for leasing at favourable rents
or sale on deferred terms; make building grants of 25 per cent (and 35 per
cent in special cases) of the cost of an industrialist’s own factory; make grants
towards unusual expenditure incurred as a result of siting a project in a
development area; and make loans for the general purposes of an undertaking
(for example, working capital, plant and machinery, etc.). Factory building
and estate management are undertaken on the Board of Trade’s behalf by the
English, Scottish and Welsh Industrial Estates Corporations; premises
administered by the three Corporations total approximately 58 million
square feet and give employment to some 250,000 people.
Assistance from other government departments includes grants to local
authorities for clearing derelict or neglected sites and for improving basic
services; and help from the Ministry of Labour with the cost of training
additional labour in development areas and of transferring workers in
connection with establishing new enterprises.
brom September 1967 manufacturing employers in development areas will
be entitled to an additional ‘regional employment premium’ for every employee
in respect of whom they can claim selective employment premium (see p. 380)
at the rate of 30s. a week for full-time male adult employees (with lower rates
for women, part-time workers, boys and girls).
Since 1948 control of new industrial building has been exercised through
the use of a system of Industrial Development Certificates. The control is
operated through the normal local planning machinery of the Town and
Country Planning Acts. Any application for planning permission for indus¬
trial development involving more than 5,000 square feet (or 3,000 square feet
in the Midlands and south-east) must be accompanied by a certificate from
the Board of Trade certifying that the development in question can be carried
out consistently with the proper distribution of industry. In considering
applications for certificates the Board of Trade is required to have particular
regard to the need for providing appropriate employment in the development
areas. In practice this obligation has led the Board of Trade normally to
refuse certificates for projects outside the development areas unless they are
satisfied that the project could not reasonably be undertaken in a development
area or in Northern Ireland. Subject to this priority, the control is also used
to encourage dispersal of industry to new or expanded towns taking population
from the more congested areas.
Under the Control of Office and Industrial Development Act 1965 the
Board of Trade also controls office developments of over 10,000 square
feet in the Midlands, the south-east and East Anglia and over 3,000 square
feet in the Metropolitan area.
Under its own legislation Northern Ireland provides for the payment of
investment grants at 40 per cent of the cost both of new plant and machinery
and of new buildings for the manufacturing, construction and extractive
industries in Northern Ireland. (For expenditure incurred in 1967 and 1968
the rate of grant is 45 per cent.) There is also provision for assisting firms by
means of loans to carry out major schemes of re-equipment, to move to
another area in particular need of industrial development or to undertake a
266

Councils to
Promote
Industry
Rural Industries
rehousing of their business in association with a major scheme of modernisa¬
tion and reorganisation.
As an alternative means of assistance the Northern Ireland Government
continues to use its comprehensive and flexible powers authorised under the
Industries Development Acts for projects which offer a reasonable amount of
employment. In such cases capital assistance of 45 per cent would normally
be available instead of the 40 per cent referred to above. (For expenditure
incurred in 1967 or 1968 the rate is 50 per cent.) For those projects which
offer exceptionally attractive returns in employment or are to be located in
areas in urgent need of development, grants towards operating costs could
also be made available in the initial stages of development. In suitable cases
loans can be made towards capital expenditure on plant, machinery and
buildings and grants may also be made towards such things as the cost of the
removal, including installation, of plant and machinery from an existing factory
to Northern Ireland.
Since 1945, 226 new firms have been established in Northern Ireland and
188 schemes of expansion carried out with government assistance, develop¬
ments which at present are employing over 62,000 persons. The Ministry
of Commerce is the Northern Ireland government department concerned with
the administration of this assistance. The Northern Ireland Economic Council
was set up in 1965 to assist in furthering economic growth. The chairman is
the Minister of Commerce and the membership includes representatives of
industry, commerce and the trade unions.
Certain regions and areas in England have industrial development associa¬
tions concerned with promoting local industry. These associations are
sponsored mainly by local authorities, trade associations and individual firms.
Several voluntary associations are concerned with Welsh industry. The
Development Corporation for Wales, founded in 1959, is the most prominent.
In Scotland, the Highlands and Islands Development Board, set up by
statute in 1965, works to stimulate the economic and social development of
the seven ‘crofting’ counties (see p. 328) in the Highlands and the Islands.
It provides grants and loans to industrial and other enterprises; it may also
acquire land, provide management services and set up and carry on businesses.
The Scottish Council (Development and Industry), a voluntary association,
promotes the general economic development of Scotland.
Encouragement is given to the development of rural industries. Much of this
work is done under the aegis of the Development Commission1 with finance
from the Development Fund, notably the provision of advice and guidance
to small businesses in rural areas and country towns. In England and Wales
this service is provided by the Rural Industries Bureau acting in consultation
with the Rural Community Councils; in Scotland by the Scottish Country
Industries Development Trust. Finance for small industries in England,
Wales and Scotland is provided by the Rural Industries Loan Fund, also
financed by the Development Commission. The Fund works in close liaison
with the Rural Industries Bureau and the Scottish Country Industries
Development Trust. Another service provided by the Commission in Wales
has been the financing of small factories to stimulate rural industries and to
combat rural depopulation.
1 The Development Commission approves and administers advances by grants or loans
from the Development Fund, established by the Development and Roads Improvements
Fund Acts 1909 and 1910. At the present time the Fund may be used to help and
expand agriculture and rural industries and also to promote the development and
improvement of fisheries.

The main primary sources of energy currently used in Britain are coal,
petroleum and, to a small extent, water power, nuclear energy and natural
gas; secondary sources produced from these are electricity, gas and coke.
Coal, mined within the country, supplies slightly more than half of primary
energy and it will remain the principal source for several years. For supplies
of crude petroleum Britain is virtually dependent on imports. Water power
resources are small. A large-scale programme for the construction of nuclear
power stations has been in progress for more than a decade, and nuclear power
is already significant in electricity supply. Most of the natural gas used is at
present imported in liquefied form, but the continuing discoveries of commer¬
cial quantities of natural gas under the North Sea open up an additional source
of energy.
The pattern of primary energy consumption has been changing considerably
in recent years. The proportion of total energy provided by coal has been
declining steadily in relation to oil, the latter’s share having risen from one-
fifth in 1958 to over one-quarter in 1961 and to over one-third in 1966.
Trends in consumption are shown in Table 16 and in the diagram on p. 269.
The fuel and power industries, with the exception of petroleum, are under
public ownership. General responsibility for ensuring the effective and co¬
ordinated development of fuel and power resources lies with the Minister
of Power. He is assisted in the formulation of energy policy by an Energy-
Advisory Council. Fuel research is undertaken by the fuel and fuel-using
industries. The Minister of Power also has an Advisory Council on Research
and Development.

In general, fuel and power industries require heavy capital investment in
long-term projects and both internal resources and borrowing are used to
raise the large sums needed. Until 1956 long-term borrowing by the corpora¬
tions was through the issue of stock, except in the case of the coal industry,
which borrowed direct from the Exchequer. Under the Finance Act 1956
and subsequent legislation, all state-owned corporations were given power to
raise money by means of Exchequer advances from the responsible minister
with the approval of the Treasury; since then, all the corporations have
done so, and no issues of stock have been made. Investment by the nationalised
fuel and power industries is estimated to amount to XI>°31 million in 1966-67
and is likely to reach £1,065 million in 1967-68.
The responsible ministers—the Minister of Power in England and Wales
and the Secretary of State in Scotland—are required by statute to set up
consultative councils for each of the nationalised fuel industries to ensure the

COAL
269
protection of the interests of consumers of fuel. Councils were established
for coal in i947> f°r electricity in 1948 and for gas in 1949; each consisting
of a chairman and from 20 to 30 unpaid members appointed from nominations
put forward by interested bodies selected by the ministers as representing
consumers. In the electricity and gas supply industries councils and commit¬
tees have been formed on an area and district basis; for coal there are councils
at national level only.
Coal has been worked in Britain for over 700 years and an organised coal¬
mining industry has been in existence for over 300 years, some 200 years
longer than in any other country. British coal exports dominated the world
market until about 1910. By 1913—the peak production year—the industry
wras producing 287 million tons of coal, exporting 94 million tons and
employing over a million workers. Economic depression in Britain and
ENERGY TRENDS 1958-66
270
BRITAIN! AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The National
Coal Board
Pattern and
Trends in
Supply and
Demand
Production and
Manpower
mounting competition in overseas markets caused a decline during the
inter-war years (1919-39) and both inland consumption and exports fell
substantially, bringing a reduction in the number of pits in operation.
Measures were introduced to rationalise production in larger and more
efficient units. During the second world war the industry came under the
control of the government.
In 1947 the coal mines passed into public ownership by means of the Coal
Industry Nationalisation Act 1946, which set up the National Coal Board as
a statutory corporation to manage the industry.
The National Coal Board (NCB) consists of a chairman and between eight
and eleven members appointed by the Minister of Power. The NCB has the
exclusive monopoly to extract coal in Great Britain, but is empowered to
license private operators to work small pits and open-cast sites. It has no
monopoly in distribution, and retail sales remain largely in private hands, but
it has, however, some retail depots and makes bulk sales to large industrial
consumers.
The NCB is responsible for the day-to-day running and the commercial
management of the industry, but is answerable to the minister (and through
him, to Parliament) for its efficiency. The minister has power to issue
directives on matters affecting the public interest, and to authorise borrowings
to finance capital investment.
The 438 collieries in operation at the end of March 1967 were grouped into
34 areas, which are the basic units for commercial management. The areas
in turn are grouped into eight geographical zones which roughly correspond
to the main coal-bearing regions; in each zone, a senior resident executive of
the NCB was responsible for co-ordination and for certain common-user
services. Reorganisation, which started in March 1967, will eventually reduce
the number of areas to 17.
Coal consumption in Britain increased by an average annual rate of nearly
4 million tons between 1947 and 1956; sales fell sharply, however, between 1956
and 1959 and large stocks of coal accumulated at pit heads. Growing
competition from oil, increasing efficiency in the use of coal and reduced
requirements of the gas, steel and other industries contributed to the fall in
demand. Since 1963 undistributed end-of-year stocks have been maintained
at about 18-20 million tons. The fall in consumption is shown in Table 17.
Nearly two-fifths of total output is consumed by the electricity authorities
and over one-quarter by domestic and industrial users together. Coke ovens
and the gas industry are other large users. Consumption by the electricity
industry has increased by one-quarter since 1961 to 68 million tons in 1966,
whereas the requirements of all the other main classes of consumer have
declined. In the case of domestic users this fall has been slightly offset by
increased purchases of solid smokeless fuels.
Coal exports have fallen heavily since the second world war due mainly,
at first, to increased internal consumption and, later, to keener competition
and the switch to other types of fuel in the most important markets overseas.
Exports fell from the post-war peak of 19 million tons in 1949 to 2-9 million
tons, valued at ^19 million, in 1966. The principal markets are in Western
Europe and the Irish Republic.
It has been estimated that Britain’s workable reserves of coal will last for
about 200 years at current rates of consumption. However, the very fact that
INDUSTRY 0>,T
2/1
the British industry was developed so early has meant that many of the best
seams of coal are now worked out; every year coal has to be mined from deeper
and thinner seams and productivity can be maintained only by a high level of
re-equipment and constant modernisation.
The main coal-bearing areas are: (i) the Yorkshire, Derbyshire and
Nottinghamshire field, which produces about 48 per cent of the total output,
(2) the Durham and Northumberland field, (3) the South Wales field, and
(4) the Scottish field. Other important coal-bearing areas are those of
Lancashire and the West Midlands (Staffordshire and Warwickshire).

According to forecasts by the Ministry of Power, the fall in coal consump¬
tion shown in Table 17 is likely to continue, but the Government is taking
measures to support consumption with the aim of holding the demand for
coal at around 155 million tons by 1970. The NCB plans to improve the
competitive position of coal by restricting production to the most efficient
pits. Between 1967 and 1969-70 almost one-third of the pits are scheduled
to be closed and the total labour force will fall by 18 per cent to about
333,000 workers. Productivity has risen by about one-third since 1961, and
three-quarters of output now comes from new or reconstructed collieries,
some with a daily output of 6,000 tons and a few of up to 8,000 tons; at
mechanised faces output averages 67 tons per shift as compared with 3-8
tons at non-mechanised faces, the average for all faces being over 5! tons.
In 1966, output per manshift at NCB mines rose to over i-8 tons, with
36,000 fewer workers. Among measures contributing to higher productivity
are new designs for loading and mechanical handling, improved layouts for
pit-bottoms and the extension of horizon mining. Experimental remotely
controlled longwall faces have proved successful at two Midlands collieries
and are being installed in others. The Bevercotes colliery in the East Midlands,
the first in the world to be planned as a fully mechanised and automated
pit from the coal face to the surface, was opened in 1967.

PETROLEUM
The National Coal Board raises capital, including working capital, by borrow¬
ing directly from the Exchequer. At present there is a statutory limit of
^750 million on such borrowing. Within its limit the Board may, with the
permission of the Minister of Power, borrow temporarily (by way of overdraft
or otherwise). The greater proportion of investment, however, is financed
from internal resources.
Capital expenditure by the industry totalled £462 million from 1947 to 1955
and about £790 million in the nine years 1956 to end-March 1964. At the end
of the 1964-65 financial year the total capital debt to the Exchequer amounted
to about £960 million. In 1965 a fresh study was made of the NCB’s capital
structure, and legislation was enacted to effect a capital reconstruction
involving the writing off of £415 million of the existing debt. As a result, the
total debt to the Exchequer at the end of March 1966 was reduced to £575
million.
Under the nationalisation statute, the NCB has been required to break even
on its current account (taking one year with another) after meeting all proper
charges including provision for reserves. It has made surpluses in some years
and deficits in others. In certain areas, such as Scotland, Lancashire and Wales,
deficits have been persistent, and profits from the areas of high productivity,
for instance, the Midlands, have been inadequate to cover the losses sustained.
By March 1966 the accumulated deficit on the current account had reached
^115-8 million which was included in the ^4I5 iDillion to be written off (see
above). Interest payments and depreciation provisions will be reduced as a
result of this writing off.
To assist the redeployment of manpower and the elimination of uneconomic
colliery capacity, the 1966 Coal Industry Act authorises the Ministry of
Power to make grants, with contributions on an equal basis from the
NCB, to meet expenditure up to a limit of ^30 million over the five years to
I97I-
The NCB has three research organisations: a Coal Research Establishment,
at Stoke Orchard, near Cheltenham, Gloucestershire, providing facilities for
fundamental research; a Mining Research Establishment, for the investigation
of underground problems, at Isleworth, Middlesex; and a Central Engineering
Establishment for developing new machines and testing equipment, near
Bretby, Derbyshire. In 1959 the Board set up a new department concerned
primarily with the further development of new processes for making smokeless
fuels. In 1947 the NCB took over the Coal Survey, a national organisation
for surveying coal resources within Britain; it has 70 laboratories in the various
coalfields.
A number of autonomous research associations receiving grants from the
NCB and the Ministry of Technology include the British Coal Utilisation
Research Association, the British Coke Research Association and the Coal Tar
Research Association. Much of the work of other bodies, such as the Safety
in Mines Research Establishment (SMRE), is closely related to the Board s
problems; the SMRE carries out research on explosions and fires, pneumo¬
coniosis, engineering and metallurgy.
The petroleum industry in Britain dates back to 1850, when Dr. James Young,
a Glasgow chemist, succeeded in obtaining lamp oil and lubricants from
natural mineral oil occurring in the Derbyshire coal measures. The Scottish
shale deposits, yielding similar products, were first worked in 1858 and ceased
production in 1962.
INDUSTRY
Indigenous
Production
International
Trade
Consumption
Refineries
273
Sources of crude oil within Britain meet only 1 ton in every 900 of total
United Kingdom requirements, the remainder being imported from overseas.
Annual production of crude oil from indigenous oilfields now totals about
77,000 tons. Prospecting for crude petroleum has so far led to the estab¬
lishment of several small oilfields, notably in Nottinghamshire (Eakring,
Egmanton and Bothamsell), in Leicestershire (Plungar), in Lincolnshire
(Gainsborough) and in Dorset (Kimmeridge).
Seismic prospecting in the North Sea has been going on since 1962. Under
the Continental Shelf Act 1964, the Minister of Power, by a system of licensing
for exploration and production, controls those activities in the areas over the
shelf appertaining to the United Kingdom. Britain’s share of the North Sea
shelf amounts to about 100,000 square miles. Licences covering about 42,000
square miles were issued in 1964 and 1965 (a few being in the Irish Sea).
Drilling, which started in 1964, has proved the existence of four fields of
natural gas capable of commercial production. A substantial field of natural
gas was also proved in 1966 in North Yorkshire, near Scarborough.
British and British-Dutch oil companies have been responsible for developing
the oil resources of many countries to mutual advantage, especially in the
Middle East, Far East, Africa and Caribbean areas.
Today these companies produce more than one-third of all oil entering into
international trade, with a tanker fleet (partly owned by them and partly on
charter) amounting to nearly a quarter of the world’s tanker tonnage. (United
Kingdom registered tanker tonnage is nearly one-seventh of the world’s total.)
In 1966 the United Kingdom imported 70-4 million tons of crude oil valued
at £427 million, the largest single item among imported products; approxi¬
mately 22 per cent came from Kuwait, the other largest suppliers being Iraq,
Libya, Nigeria, Saudi Arabia and Venezuela in that order.
Deliveries of petroleum products for inland consumption in 1966 totalled
slightly over 73 million tons, having risen by more than two-thirds since i960.
An outstanding feature has been the continued rapid advance in the use of black
oils. Fuel oil consumption (excluding refineries) has been expanding by about
9 per cent a year since i960 and totalled about 29-1 million tons in 1966.
Demand for gas and diesel oils (excluding those used in road vehicles) rose by
a further 0-7 million tons to 7-6 million tons in 1966. Sales of motor spirit,
after expanding by half a million tons annually for some years, increased by
nearly 1 million tons to almost 11 million tons in 1965; the increase in 1966
was about 250,000 tons.
The most important uses of gas and diesel oils in 1966 were for non¬
industrial central heating, agricultural tractors and the railways. Electricity
generation accounted for about 24 per cent of total fuel oil consumption,
excluding that used in oil refineries; the steel industry accounted for 14 per
cent; and non-industrial central heating for a further 11 per cent. Of the
remainder, the largest users were the cement, paper-making, general chemical,
glass, engineering, brickmaking and textile industries.
Before 1939 three-quarters of the United Kingdom’s supply of petroleum
products was refined overseas, as it was considered more economical to
refine at the source of production. Since the second world war the industry
has favoured the siting of refineries in the consuming areas.
At the end of 1966 rated refinery capacity in the United Kingdom amounted
to 82 million tons a year. Of the 19 refineries in operation, three have a

ELECTRICITY
SUPPLY
capacity of under 0-2 million tons. The seven largest are situated at Fawley,
near Southampton (15-7 million tons, which is being raised to 16-5 million
tons); Stanlow, in Cheshire (10-3 million tons); Isle of Grain (10 million tons)
and Shellhaven (9-8 million tons), both on the Thames Estuary; two at
Milford Haven in Pembrokeshire (6-2 million tons and 5 million tons) and
at Llandarcy near Swansea (8 million tons). Other important refineries are
located at Belfast, on the Firth of Forth (Grangemouth), at Billingham-on-
Tees, Heysham (Lancs.) and Coryton (Essex). These, and other projects in
hand or planned (notably on Humberside and Tees-side, both of which will
become important refining areas), will bring Britain’s total capacity to almost
100 million tons a year by the end of 1968.
Output of refined products (excluding refineries’ own consumption) has
risen steadily; from 4 million tons in 1948 to 25^ million tons in 1954, 40
million tons in i960 and the peak total of 65 million tons in 1966. There is a
substantial external trade in refined products which tends to follow trading
and seasonal requirements and the commercial arrangements of the major oil
companies. Exports from Britain, mainly in the form of heavier products
to European countries, were valued at £112 million in 1966; imports of
refined products (including liquefied gases) amounted to ^191 million.
Three main oil pipelines are at present in operation in Britain carrying crude
oil from harbours capable of berthing very large tankers to refineries: in
Scotland, from Finnart on Loch Long to Grangemouth; in South Wales,
from Angle Bay, Milford Haven, to Llandarcy; and in Lancashire, from
Tranmere to Heysham. Pipelines carry refined products from refineries to
major marketing areas, where the volume transported is sufficient to justify the
capital cost; for example, a complex of lines runs from the Stanlow, Cheshire,
refinery to the Manchester area and another, 78 miles long, takes petroleum
feedstock from Fawley refinery to the £100 million petroleum chemicals plant
at Severnside, near Bristol; others carry refined products from Fawley to west
London and London Airport and from Walton-on-Thames to London Airport.
Construction is in progress on a pipeline system with an initial capacity of
3 million tons a year to feed refined products to the Midlands from refineries
and installations on the Thames and Mersey, on a refined products line from
Stanlow to Hay dock, and on an ethylene line from the Tees to the Mersey.
Meanwhile, parts of the system of pipelines laid during the second world war
are being used by the petroleum distributing companies. The Pipelines Act
1962 is designed to secure the orderly development of privately owned
industrial pipelines.
Research into problems of petroleum technology is carried out mainly by the
leading oil companies, which have also endowed research at the universities
on a substantial scale. Research centres are situated at Sunbury-on-Thames
(the British Petroleum Company), Thornton, in Cheshire, and Woodstock,
in Kent (Shell), and Abingdon, in Berkshire (Esso). The first of these covers
the full range of petroleum research and development, from geology and
production to product utilisation and petroleum chemicals. In general, the
remainder are concerned with the evolution of new and improved fuels and
lubricants and the development of new uses for petroleum products and of
new products based on petroleum, especially chemicals.
A public supply of electricity was first provided in Britain in 1881, at
Godaiming, Surrey. From its earliest days a measure of public control has
INDUSTRY
275
been a feature of the industry, and the Electric Lighting Act 1882 authorised
the Board of Trade to grant licences for the establishment of electricity
undertakings by local authorities or by companies (which the local authorities
might compulsorily purchase after a given period of time) to supply consumers
in given areas. By the turn of the century a variety of independent supply
systems had grown up all over the country. In 1919 the Electricity Commis¬
sioners were set up as a supervisory body and to promote reorganisation on a
national scale through voluntary agreement. In 1926 the Central Electricity
Board was set up to construct and operate a national grid inter-connecting
individual power stations, thus co-ordinating generation and transmission.
In 1943 the North of Scotland Hydro-Electric Board (NSHEB) was
established as a public corporation to develop the water-power resources of the
Highlands. In 1948 all municipal and private undertakings (other than those
in Northern Ireland) were acquired under the Electricity Act 1947 and vested
in the British Electricity Authority and 14 regional boards, except in the north
of Scotland where they became the responsibility of the NSHEB. Two
subsequent Acts (1954 and 1957) effected a measure of decentralisation and
gave the industry its present structure. Electricity supply employs about
250,000 people, including 5,400 in Northern Ireland.
Present
Structure
England and Wales
Scotland
In England and Wales, electricity is generated and transmitted by the Central
Electricity Generating Board (CEGB) and distributed by 12 separate Area
Electricity Boards; co-ordination is effected by the Electricity Council. In
Scotland, two boards—the NSHEB and the South of Scotland Electricity
Board (SSEB)—both generate and distribute electricity. In Northern Ireland,
the Belfast Corporation and the Electricity Board for Northern Ireland generate
and distribute electricity, and the Londonderry Corporation distributes only.
The Electricity Council is the central body of the supply industry with
responsibility for general policy and programmes and for advising the
Minister of Power; it is also responsible for a number of common services,
principally capital financing, research and industrial relations. The Council
consists of a chairman, two deputy chairmen, the chairman and two designated
members of the Central Electricity Generating Board (CEGB), the chairmen
of the 12 Area Electricity Boards and not more than three other members.
The CEGB controls the operation and maintenance of power stations and the
main transmission system (the national grid) and supplies electricity in bulk
to the 12 Area Boards. The CEGB consists of a chairman, a deputy chairman
and between six and eight members. Each of the 12 Area Electricity Boards
acquires bulk supplies of electricity from the CEGB and is responsible for
distribution networks and sales of electricity to its area consumers.
Area Consultative Councils were set up under the Electricity Act 1947 in
the area of each Board to represent the interests of consumers; their chairmen
are ex officio members of their respective Area Boards. The Minister of Power
appoints the chairmen, deputy chairmen and members of the Electricity
Council, the CEGB, the Area Boards and the Consultative Councils; approves
each Board’s capital development programmes and the industry’s research
programme; and approves, in consultation with the Treasury, the industry’s
borrowing requirements. The Electricity Act 1957 requires each Board, and
not merely the industry as a whole, to pay its way taking one year with another.
The boundary separating the areas covered by the two Scottish Boards runs
roughly from Dumbarton on the Firth of Clyde to Newburgh on the Firth of
Tay. Members of both Boards and of the respective consumer consultative
276
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Northern Ireland
Generation
councils are appointed by the Secretary of State for Scotland; each Board
comprises a chairman and between four and eight members. The Secretary of
State’s responsibilities in relation to the Boards are similar to those of the
Minister of Power.
In Northern Ireland electricity is generated at power stations in Belfast and
at Ballylumford and Coolkeeragh. Those in Belfast are operated by the city
corporation and the remainder by the Electricity Board for Northern Ireland.
Generation at these stations is co-ordinated by the Northern Ireland Joint
Electricity Authority, set up by statute in 1967. The output of the stations
has, since 1948, been purchased in bulk and re-sold to distributors—the
Belfast Corporation for Belfast and district, the Londonderry Corporation
for the City of Londonderry, and the Electricity Board for the rest of Northern
Ireland.
As Britain has abundant supplies of coal, together with good rail and water
transport for moving it, most of its electricity is produced by coal-fired steam
generating stations. The development of hydro-electricity on any scale is
comparatively recent, water-power resources being relatively small and in
remote areas. Since 1965, however, nuclear energy has been contributing a
sizeable volume.
The output capacity of the generating stations of the electricity boards in
Great Britain at the end of 1966 totalled 42,972 megawatts (MW), an increase
of over one-third since i960.
In the years i960 to 1966 an annual average of over 2,000 M\\ of
generating capacity was installed, including 3,600 MW in 1965 and 2,507 MW
in 1966. It is planned to commission nearly 20,000 MW of capacity in England
and Wrales in the period 1966-69 inclusive. In the north of Scotland it is
planned to increase capacity from 1,749 MW at the end of 1966 to 1,840 MW
by 1970. The South of Scotland Electricity Board’s proposals provide for its
total capacity of 2,730 MW at the end of 1966 to be increased to 5,600 MW’
by 1970.
Sales of electricity in Northern Ireland (where, of the total installed
generating capacity of 857 MW, 300 MW is in oil-fired and the remainder in
coal-fired thermal stations) amounted to 2,594 million kilowatt-hours in 1966.
Generation by the public supply in Great Britain exceeded 181,000 million
kilowatt-hours in 1966; conventional steam power stations provided 88 per
cent of the total and hydro-electric and nuclear stations about 2 per cent and
10 per cent respectively. The high rate of expansion of output, which has been
a feature of the industry since its earliest years, has been maintained. The
total volume generated increased by 42 per cent between 1961 and 1966.
Generation of electricity outside the public supply system is relatively
small—under 20,000 million kilowatt-hours in 1966. dhe major sources
outside the fuel industries themselves are the chemical, iron and steel and
paper industries and the nuclear power plants of the Atomic Energy Authority
(AEA).
An analysis of electricity generation in Great Britain is given in Table 18.
In the mid-1950s, when a coal shortage seemed likely, programmes for oil¬

were introduced. There are 14 oil-burning power stations, or parts of
stations, operating in Great Britain (excluding old stations converted to oil¬
firing to conform with clean air legislation). They are mainly situated on river
estuaries and thus able to be fed conveniently from oil refineries. Oil-fired
stations of 2,000 MW are under construction at Fawley, on Southampton

The electricity authorities are the largest consumers of primary fuel in
Britain, and although most of their electricity generation is based on coal, oil
consumption rose from a negligible quantity in 1955 to over 5-5 million tons
in 1962. The rate of increase has slowed down considerably, and consumption
in 1966 was 7-1 million tons. Average thermal efficiency of conventional
steam stations in England and Wales (that is, the ratio of power output to
the fuel consumed) rose from 20-75 per cent in 1947 to 27-33 Per cent
as new plant was brought into use. The 20 most efficient stations, containing
much of the newest plant, had an average efficiency of 32-82 per cent in 1966.
Striking advances have been made in the design of steam-generating plant.
A cross-compound generating unit with an output capacity of 550 MW came
into operation in 1963 at Thorpe Marsh, near Doncaster. Forty-seven single¬
shaft units of 500 MW are being installed in 13 stations. The first came
into operation at the Ferrybridge ‘C’ station, Yorks, in 1966. Others will
be completed during 1967 at West Burton (near Retford, Notts), Eggborough
(Selby, Yorks), Ratcliffe-on-Soar (Notts), Aberthaw ‘B’ (Glamorgan), and
Cottam (East Retford, Notts). Station capacities are also increasing. By
1971, ten stations, each with capacities of 2,000 MW, with four 500 MW
single-shaft generating units, will be in service. Three larger generating
units, of 660 MW, will be installed at Drax (Yorks), which may have a final
capacity of nearly 4,000 MW. For location see map, p. 268. In Scotland, a
1,200 MW station at Cockenzie (1968) and one of 2,400 MW (four generating
units of 600 MW) at Longannet (1971) are under construction.
Large gas turbine units of 55 MW and 70 MW, based on aero jet engines,
have been introduced since 1965 for peak load operation. The CEGB and
South of Scotland Electricity Board have installed 724 MW of such units.
Smaller gas turbines have been introduced at new stations to safeguard the
auxiliary supplies to the large new steam units, and also to provide capacity
for peak operation. Auxiliary units of this kind in service at the end of 1967
will total 576 MW, and by 1970 will exceed 1,000 MW.
Hydro-electric generation is confined to Scotland and Wales, and most of the
water-power so utilised is drawn from high-level reservoirs with their own
natural catchment areas. The setting up of the North of Scotland Hydro-
278
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Nuclear Power
Stations
Electric Board in 1943 marked the beginning of an era of intensive water¬
power development in the Highlands of Scotland. A development scheme was
drawn up by the Board in 1944, showing the water-power resources which it
proposed to examine.
In 1966-67, 3,200 million units were sent out by the North of Scotland
Hydro-Electric Board from water-power, compared with 322 million in 1949.
At the end of March 1967 there were 54 main hydro-electric stations in
operation in the north of Scotland with a total installed capacity of 1,347 MW
and the largest—the Loch Sloy station—had a capacity of 130 MW; the Crua-
chan pumped storage section of the Awe scheme, with an installed capacity of
400 MW from four reversible-pump-turbines, came into full operation at the
end of 1966. Under construction or survey were 199 MW of conventional
hydro-electric capacity together with a 1,200 MW pumped storage project at
Loch Sloy, a 600 MW project at North Devon, and one for 300 MW at Loch
Ness. In addition, there are stations generating electricity by water-power in
the south of Scotland (123 MW) and in Wales (473 MW). The latter includes
the 360 MW pumped storage station at Ffestiniog, which was completed in
1963. (In pumped storage schemes electricity generated in off-peak periods is
used to pump water to higher levels from which it descends at peak periods to
operate turbo-generators.)
Some 10 per cent of Britain’s electricity was generated in nuclear power
stations in 1966 and the proportion is expected to rise to 12 per cent by about
1970. Britain has so far produced as much electricity by this means as the rest
of the world put together.
The AEA itself has four mains stations which produce electricity for the
national grid: Calder Hall, in Cumberland (185 MW electrical output);
Chapelcross, Dumfriesshire (188 MW); the Advanced Gas-Cooled Reactor
(AGR) at Windscale, Cumberland (35 MW); and the experimental fast
breeder station at Dounreay (15 MW).
Others are owned and operated by the electricity authorities. Under the
first commercial programme, originally announced in 1955 but since twice
modified, nine stations with a total installed capacity of 5,000 MW should be
in operation by 1969. So far eight (over 3,600 MW) have started operation:
Berkeley, in Gloucestershire (276 MW output capacity), and Bradwell, in
Essex (300 MW), were both commissioned in 1962; Hunterston, in Scotland
(300 MW), in 1964; and in the following year Hinkley Point ‘A’, in Somerset,
Trawsfynydd, in Wales (both 500 MW), and Dungeness ‘A’, in Kent (550
MW); Sizewell, in Suffolk (580 MW), was commissioned in 1966; Oldbury,
in Gloucestershire (600 MW), in 1967; and Wylfa, in Anglesey (1,180 MW),
should be completed by 1969. These stations, like Calder Hall and Chapel¬
cross, are all magnox stations—graphite-moderated, carbon-dioxide cooled
using natural uranium metal fuel elements canned in magnesium.
Under a second programme announced in 1964 and extended in 1965, a
further 8,000 MW installed nuclear capacity is planned by 1975. The first
station in this programme, Dungeness ‘B’, is based on the AGR at Windscale
which uses ceramic uranium dioxide fuel canned in stainless steel, a logical
development of the magnox system. Due to come into operation in 1970 with
a net electrical output of 1,200 MW it will be the most powerful in the world,
and the first in Britain to produce electricity more cheaply on base load than
the best coal stations. The second and third stations, Hinkley Point ‘B’ and
Hunterston ‘B’, are under construction.
A large prototype fast reactor (PER) of 250 MW capacity is being built by
the AEA, to be completed in 1971, at Dounreay where in October 1962 the

and

Capital

279
experimental fast reactor became the first of such type to produce electricity
for public use and to operate at a high power level.
Main electricity transmission lines—the national grid—supply most of the
country. By 31st March 1966 those of the CEGB totalled some 9,350 route
miles (16,250 circuit miles), of which 203 miles were operated at 400,000 volts,
2,000 miles at 275,000 volts, 6,840 miles were operated at 132,000 volts and
the remainder at 66,000 volts and below. In Scotland there were some 4,000
circuit miles of main transmission lines at the end of 1966, of which 1,100
circuit miles operated at 275,000 volts and the remainder at 132,000 volts.
Energy movements on the grid in England and Wales are controlled through
the eight operational areas, set up for that purpose and distinct from the
regions in which the generating side of the industry is organised; each area
has a separate control, and the operations are co-ordinated by a National
Control in London. The grid in Scotland is operated from the control
centres at Pitlochry (North of Scotland) and at Kirkintilloch (South of
Scotland).
To reduce the number of new transmission lines needed to meet the
country’s increasing power demands, most of the new ‘supergrid’ of main
transmission lines now operating at 275,000 volts are, since 1965, being up¬
rated to operate at 400,000 volts. The development of the grid system has
made the British system the largest integrated power network in the world.
Twin cross-Channel cables laid between Dungeness and Boulogne, capable
of transmitting up to 160 MW at 200,000 volts (direct current), have been
in operation since 1961; by this means advantage is taken of the differences
between France and Britain in the timing of peak loads.
A direct current transmission link to reinforce supplies in the London area
is being installed; due for completion in 1970, the scheme—the first of its
kind in the world—will have a capacity of 640 MW.
In England and Wales the Area Electricity Boards distribute to consumers
electricity acquired mainly from the Central Electricity Generating Board,
supplemented from other sources, such as industrial plants and the nuclear
power stations of the AEA. There are over 17-5 million consumers. Industrial
concerns are the biggest users of electricity. The principal domestic uses of
electricity are for lighting, cooking and for space and water heating, but the
demand for numerous other domestic purposes is rising steadily.
The North of Scotland Hydro-Electric Board has also pressed ahead with
the distribution of electricity to consumers in the north of Scotland. It has
about 450,000 consumers, many in remote areas, and well over four-fifths of
crofts have a supply of electricity. The South of Scotland Electricity Board
supplies about 1-5 million consumers, including almost all of the farmers in
the area.
About 11 per cent of the annual gross fixed capital formation of the United
Kingdom in 1966 was attributable to the electricity supply industry. The
industry in recent years has based its capital needs for five years ahead on an
average annual increase in demand of about 7 to 9 per cent; its plans up to
1972-73 are based on an average annual growth of 7-3 per cent.
Capital expenditure of the electricity supply industry has been expanding
very rapidly: from £249 million in 1956 it rose to £359 million in 1961 and
£714 million in 1966. More than two-fifths of the industry’s capital require¬
ments have been financed from internal resources. The statutory limit to
borrowings by the industry in Great Britain is £4,980 million. The industry

The Electricity Council, in consultation with the Minister of Power, is
responsible for drawing up a general programme of research, comprising:
direct research carried out by the Electricity Boards themselves; sponsored
research undertaken for the supply industry by universities and colleges;
and co-operative research with other organisations, in particular the industrial
research associations to which the supply industries subscribe. The Council
itself is empowered to conduct research. It is advised by the Electricity Supply
Research Council. Collaboration on research between the supply industry
and the plant manufacturers is co-ordinated by the Power Engineering
Research Steering Committee set up in 1966.
The main research establishments of the industry are run by the Central
Electricity Generating Board and comprise the Central Electricity Research
Laboratories at Leatherhead, Surrey, the Berkeley Laboratories in Glouces¬
tershire, concerned with nuclear problems, and the Engineering Laboratories
at Marchwood, on Southampton Water. In 1965 the Electricity Council
established a research centre at Capenhurst, Cheshire, at which intensive
research is being undertaken on distribution problems (to supplement the
work undertaken at the Central Electricity Research Laboratories) and on
appliances and methods of electricity utilisation.
Both Scottish electricity boards carry out research and experimental work
either on their own or in co-operation with other electricity authorities. The
North of Scotland Hydro-Electric Board undertakes a wide range of research
and development work, both independently and in conjunction with the
British Electrical and Allied Industries Research Association, universities and
manufacturers. The South of Scotland Electricity Board has recently extended
its own research activities and is associated with those of the Electricity
Council and Central Electricity Generating Board in England.
Public supply of gas in Britain dates from 1807, when Pall Mall, London,
was first lighted with gas. In 1812 the London and Westminster Gas Light
and Coke Company received a Royal Charter to supply gaslight in London.
In the early years of the industry gas was used almost exclusively for lighting
and was provided by a growing number of company and municipal under¬
takings.
The gas industry in its present form developed in the main during the
period between the two world wars when increasing competition from
electricity had to be met, and by 1939 the industry had become mainly a
supplier of heating rather than lighting.
The Gas Act of 1948 brought the industry in Great Britain, in which about
123,000 persons are at present employed, under public ownership and control
on 1 st May 1949. The assets of 991 undertakings, of which 269 belonged to
local authorities, were vested in 12 Area Gas Boards. The central body is
the Gas Council, appointed by the Minister of Power. It is both a co¬
ordinating council and, since the enactment of the Gas Act 1965, a trading
body, consisting of a full-time chairman and deputy chairman, the 12 chair¬
men of the area boards and up to three other members. Its general duties are to
advise the Minister on questions affecting the industry and promote the
efficient performance of their duties by the area boards. It has also specific
duties relating to finance, labour relations and research.

The Area Gas Boards, which have a large measure of financial and opera¬
tional responsibility and are similar in most respects to the central bodies
of the other publicly owned corporations, are responsible for manufacturing
gas and distributing it to consumers. Each of the Area Gas Boards, appointed
b) Minister of Power, consists of a full-time chairman and deputy chair¬
man, in some cases one or more full-time members, and usually five or six
part-time members, including the chairman of the Area Consultative Council.
There is no common pattern of organisation; each board is fully independent
and has devised its own subordinate structure. Each is required to pay its
way, taking one year with another. The operations of the area boards have
resulted, in the 17 years up to 31st March 1966, in an aggregate disposable
surplus of approximately £72 million, before taxation.
In Northern Ireland the gas supply industry remains in the hands of a
number of municipal undertakings and statutory and non-statutory companies.
The chief method of gas production in Britain used to be by carbonising coal
but oil-based production is expanding markedly; more than 40 per cent of gas
supplied in 1966 was derived from oil, and 3*1 million tons were used, three
times the amount in 1962. The gas industry used about 17 million tons of
coal (25 million tons in 1958) and another 24 million tons were carbonised
in coke ovens other than those of the gas industry.
About one-third of the output of gas from coke ovens is sold to gas under¬
takings for general distribution; the remainder is mainly consumed at the
ovens or at steelworks. There are about 13 million consumers, the total having
shown no significant change since 1955. Manufactured gas and gas acquired
from coke ovens and other sources for distribution is about 900,000 million
cubic feet annually.
In 1966 the quantity of gas produced in Northern Ireland was about
6,600 million cubic feet, most of it for household use.
Three-fifths of all gas sold by gas boards is for household use and the remainder
for industrial and commercial purposes. Total consumption has been rising at
an average rate of about 7 per cent per annum since 1961, after a period when
growth was almost negligible. Sales reached a level of about 3,630 million
therms1 in 1966.
About 40 per cent of the domestic load is used for cooking and space heating
and water heating account for the largest part of the remainder. Most homes
in Britain are supplied with gas, except in some rural areas where, owing to
difficulties in storage and transmission, mains gas is not economic, and bottled
gas, derived from petroleum, is widely used.
Gas is used extensively in industries which require the control of temperatures
to a fine degree of accuracy, for example, in the pottery industry and in
certain processes in the manufacture of iron and steel products. In 1965-66
sales of gas to industry totalled 928 million therms.
Production of coke at gas works in 1966 was 7-2 million tons (a fall of one-fifth
in two years) and at coke ovens 16-1 million tons, reflecting on the one hand
the increasing use of oil and on the other a fall from the high level of activity in
the steel industry in 1965. The gas industry and coke ovens jointly produce
about 3 million tons of crude coal tar and nearly 100 million gallons of crude

Under the Gas Act 1948, borrowing by the Gas Council and the Area Gas
Boards was limited to £250 million. In 1954 the industry’s borrowing powers
were increased to £45° million, in i960 to j£525 million, in !9^3
million and in 1965 to £ 1,200 million.
The industry had been spending about £5° million a year on capital
investment in the period 1955 I9^1 since 1961—62 expenditure has
increased sharply; in 1966—67 it reached £208 million and £285 million is
planned for 1967-68. Between vesting day (1st May 1949) and the end of
March 1967 about £ 1,178 million had been invested in fixed assets.
Considerable integration, by the linking of works for the transmission of gas
through gas grids and long-distance mains, has enabled production to be
concentrated in the most efficient units.
To maintain its competitive position, the gas industry has investigated
new and more economic methods of production and new sources of gas
supply. Although two plants which use the Lurgi method for the complete
gasification of inferior grades of coal have been commissioned, their capital
cost is high. More significant have been the developments in the gasification
of oil. In the 1950s these plants were small, produced gas at lower pressure
and were designed to meet peak-load needs. More recently the introduction
of processes using light distillates in large units producing gas at high pressure
has permitted even greater savings in both capital and running costs.
The work done in the Gas Council’s Midlands Research Station led to the
introduction of two new methods of manufacture, the Gas Recycle Hydro-
genator and the Catalytic Rich Gas processes, both of which enable a high
calorific value gas to be manufactured entirely from light distillate feedstock
without the need for enrichment from any outside source. The first plants
incorporating these processes were put on stream in i9^5" Gas made from
oil and gas purchased from refineries now amounts to nearly half of the total
supply available and the proportion is steadily increasing.
Since 1964 deliveries of natural gas from the Sahara have been made in liquid
form to Britain. A pipeline system distributes the gas from a terminal on
Canvey Island to 8 of the 12 Area Gas Boards.
Since the discovery of the first productive well in the North Sea in 1965,
sufficient natural gas has been found to supply twice Britain s current gas
consumption. The Ministry of Power has estimated that by 197® some 2,000
million cubic feet of gas per day should be available representing about
10 per cent of total energy requirements—and the Gas Council has stated the
industry’s plans to switch over entirely to natural gas within the next 10 years.
The first pipeline to pump natural gas to the shore, at Easington in
Yorkshire, was put on flow early in 1967.
The Gas Council expects gas consumption to increase by some 12 per
cent a year up to 1970 and therefore substantial expansion is required. The
need to provide additional storage capacity, particularly in underground
reservoirs of porous rock (regulated under the Gas Act i965)> an<^
strengthening of the distribution system will also mean substantial investment.
The Gas Council has a research committee which advises on the initiation
and implementation of research policy. Research organisations comprise five
stations in addition to Watson House at Fulham, London, for the design,

fuel
