testing and development of appliances. Research is also carried out on behalf
of the Gas Council at Leeds University and at other universities and colleges.
Efficiency in the use of fuel, among both industrial and domestic users, has
been assisted by various bodies representing producers and consumers and
by the technical advisory services of the fuel and power industries.
The Coal Utilisation Council consists of representatives of the National
Coal Board, solid fuel distributors and appliance manufacturers and distri¬
butors. Originally formed in 1932, it informs and advises domestic users
on the best use of solid fuel, including the choice of installation and the
operation of solid fuel appliances.
A non-profit-making company, the National Industrial Fuel Efficiency
Service, was formed in 1954 and sponsored by the fuel and power industries
to promote fuel saving in industry. In addition to consultancy work, it provides
advice and services to all non-domestic fuel users in a variety of forms, from
‘spot’ inspection to full-scale heat and power surveys and regular visits on a
contract basis.
WATER SUPPLY
Britain’s water resources are, with progressive development, sufficient for
domestic and industrial requirements. The sources of water are often distant
from the areas where supplies are needed, however, and water undertakings
are therefore mainly concerned with abstraction, storage, treatment and
distribution. Supplies are obtained partly from surface sources such as
mountain lakes, streams impounded in upland gathering grounds and river
intakes, and partly from underground sources by means of wells, adits and
boreholes. Unlike other public services in Great Britain, such as electricity and
gas, water supply remains in the hands of a large number of undertakings.
The Government has announced its intention of reorganising the water
supply industry under full public ownership. Ministerial responsibility in
England and Wales is shared by the Minister of Housing and Local Govern¬
ment and the Secretary of State for Wales; in Scotland it lies with the
Secretary of State for Scotland; and in Northern Ireland with the Minister
of Development.
It was not until the nineteenth century that the provision of water supplies
became a general public service, largely due to the efforts of Edwin Chadwick
and his colleagues who demonstrated the dangers arising from inadequate
water supply and sanitation. The Public Health Act 1848 laid the basis for
a long series of statutes dealing with public health. From the middle of the
nineteenth century onwards a number of water undertakings were set up
to provide water to the expanding urban population, and the water supply
system developed rapidly, although in piecemeal fashion and with some
overlapping and waste.
Local authorities have a duty as sanitary authorities to ensure that water
supplies are adequate for the needs of their areas, and they may do this
either by operating water undertakings themselves or by ensuring that other
bodies are providing adequate supplies. Over one-fifth of the water consumed
is supplied by statutory water companies. The householder receives his
domestic water supply at a comparatively small charge, varying in different
areas, which he usually pays by way of a water rate levied, like other rates,
284
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Present Supplies
on the value of his house. Industrial users are charged in most cases according
to actual material consumption.
The Minister of Housing and Local Government and the Secretary of
State for Wales have a duty to promote the conservation and proper use of
water supplies in England and Wales and are advised by the Central Advisory
Water Committee on general questions relating to water and organisation of
supplies. Since the passing of the Water Act 1945, over 800 smaller water
authorities in England and Wales have been absorbed by larger authorities or
by the creation of joint boards in order to improve the efficiency of the water
supply industry. In April 1967 there were in England and Wales 140 local
authority water undertakings, 83 joint water boards (including bulk supply
boards) and 4 joint water committees, 41 statutory water companies, 4
non-statutory water companies, and 1 private proprietor with statutory
powers. A number of private proprietors without statutory powers also
provide small supplies.
The largest undertaking in Britain is the Metropolitan Water Board, which
supplies over 360 million gallons daily to 6J million people in the London
area. It consists of 39 part-time members who are the elected representatives
of the various local authorities within the Board’s area of operations, together
with one representative each from the Thames and Lee Conservancies.
Public water supplies in England and Wales—reaching over 95 per cent of
the total population and about 90 per cent of the rural population—now total
some 2,500 million gallons a day, apart from large quantities taken privately
from rivers and underground.
Capital expenditure by water undertakings which averaged about £50
million a year in the period 1960-64 is now at a level of £60 million a year.
Interest, together with running costs, is largely met from annual income.
The provision of piped supplies for rural districts has been assisted by
grants under the Rural Water Supplies and Sewerage Acts 1944 to 1965. By
March 1967 schemes costing over £100 million had been completed or were
in progress with the aid of grants under these Acts.
The growth of towns in England and Wales has meant increased demands
for water, the needs of industry having grown so much that in many areas
they now exceed domestic demand. The use of water in irrigation of farm
land is also growing. In order that the country’s wrater resources should be
developed to meet these growing requirements the Water Resources Act 1963,
which came into full operation in April 1965, created a new administrative
structure consisting of 27 river authorities and a central Water Resources
Board. The river authorities, the Thames Conservancy and the Lee Con¬
servancy Catchment Board have a majority of members appointed by the
county and county borough councils in their areas. The remainder are
appointed by ministers for their knowledge of land drainage, fisheries, the
public water supply, and water in use in industry and in agriculture. The
authorities manage the water resources of river basins and carry out other
functions in respect of land drainage, flood control, administration of fisheries
and prevention of pollution. They are responsible for assessing water
resources and requirements, controlling and developing resources and
securing regulation by a system of licensing. Special arrangements exist for
the Greater London area, where the full range of river authority control is
not necessary. The work of the river authorities is co-ordinated by the Water
Resources Board, an expert advisory body which reports to the Ministry of
Housing and Local Government. Its duties include the review of national
water resources and requirements, the encouragement of the transfer of water
INDUSTRY
Scotland
Northern
Ireland
Measurement
of Resources
Barrages
285
between areas according to need, the co-ordination of proposals of river
authorities for capital investment and the initiation of research. From 1969
water conservation is to be financially self-supporting, the cost being met
from charges levied by river authorities on the abstractors and users of water.
In Scotland public water undertakings are carried on entirely by local
authorities, either separately or in combination with each other; they supply
about 97 per cent of the total population. The water problem in Scotland is
broadly similar to that in England and Wales except that there is not the
same need to allocate water between competing interests and less reliance
needs to be placed on underground sources. The Secretary of State for
Scotland has a general duty to promote the conservation of water resources
in Scotland; require local authorities to provide supplies of wholesome water
everywhere in their districts, where this can be done at reasonable cost; and
provide for a uniform system of rating for water throughout the country. The
Scottish Water Advisory Committee advises the Secretary of State on general
questions relating to resources and supplies. The Rural Water Supplies and
Sewerage Act 1944, as amended, makes available to Scottish local authorities
grant assistance up to a maximum of ^45 million towards the cost of water
supplies and sewerage schemes in rural areas.
Northern Ireland has abundant supplies of water for both domestic and
industrial consumption. The Water Supplies and Sewerage Act (Northern
Ireland) 1945 made it obligatory for water supply authorities to provide a
supply of wholesome water to houses and schools in their areas where this
could be done at reasonable cost; the Minister of Development may make
grants towards the costs of schemes undertaken by these authorities. Before
1945 only the more densely populated areas had a piped supply, but progress
has been such that even in the thinly populated rural districts most households
have now been, or soon will be, connected to a piped supply.
Information on the yield, behaviour and quantity of the nation’s surface
water resources is provided in the Surface Water Year Book of Great Britain,
published annually by Her Majesty’s Stationery Office. This publication
contains particulars of the run-off and related rainfall from a large number of
rivers, streams and reservoired areas. The Water Resources Board is respon¬
sible for the gauging, collation and publication of hydrological information:
the field work of surface water measurement is done by river authorities, water
undertakings and other bodies. Detailed studies of the resources and use of
water in specified areas have been published in the series of Hydrological
Surveys which cover approximately half of England and Wales. General
information on rainfall, published annually in British Rainfall, is the
responsibility of the Meteorological Office, while advice on ground water is the
responsibility of the Water Resources Board. The Hydraulics Research Station
of the Ministry of Technology at Wallingford and the Water Research
Association’s station at Medmenham carry out research into problems of the
design and calibration of gauging weirs and flumes for the measurement of
surface water, and into other hydraulic problems.
Preliminary ‘desk studies’ have been carried out of barrages across Morecambe
Bay and Solway Firth. A full-scale feasibility study is to be made at More¬
cambe Bay. Barrage projects involve dams across or within tidal estuaries to
form a lake of fresh water.

Pollution
Structure
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Each river authority is responsible for the prevention of pollution of rivers
and certain tidal waters in its area and its approval must be sought before
polluting effluents are discharged. Control of pollution in the tidal Thames
is exercised by the Port of London Authority. In Scotland nine river purifica¬
tion boards have been set up. The Secretary of State for Scotland is advised
by the Scottish River Purification Advisory Committee on questions affecting
the cleanliness of Scottish rivers. In several ports the petroleum companies
co-operate in the prevention of oil pollution from tankers and refineries.
The Water Pollution Research Laboratory at Stevenage investigates
problems connected with the treatment of polluted water, the treatment
and disposal of sewage and industrial waste water, and the effects and
prevention of pollution of surface water and underground water. Research is
carried out with general supervision and advice from the Water Pollution
Research Board.
CONSTRUCTION
The construction industry includes firms engaged on the construction,
alteration, repair and maintenance of buildings, highways, airfields, drainage
and sewerage systems, waterworks, docks, harbours and canals, sea defence
works, electrical wiring, heating and other installation work, open-cast coal
prospecting and mining, and structural work connected with thermal and
hydro-electric power stations and telecommunications. The industry employs
1-7 million persons, including all grades, equivalent to some 7 per cent of the
total labour force and their net output provides about 7 per cent of the gross
national product.
It was announced in February 1967 that over the next five years the
construction industry would gradually adopt metric in place of Imperial
weights and measures.
Constructional work is carried out both by private contractors and by public
authorities who employ their own labour. Over five-sixths of the work is
done by private firms. Although there are over 82,000 firms in the industry,
more than a fifth of them are one-man businesses. At the other end of the
scale are over 230 firms each with more than 600 employees.
Public authorities as a whole employ about 370,000 operatives but a very
large proportion of these are engaged on repair and maintenance work which
local authorities, for example, carry out with their own labour.
Over 40 per cent of operatives are occupied on building maintenance,
valued at over £1,100 million annually. The total labour force includes about
800,000 skilled craftsmen, who have been trained for four or five years under
the industry’s apprenticeship schemes. A further 108,000 are employed as
apprentices.
Some firms are vertically integrated, owning quarries and workshops,
mechanised plant and standard builders’ equipment; some undertake respon¬
sibility for projects from initial design to finished building. All but the
smallest projects are generally carried out under professional direction, either
by architects or, in the case of the more complicated civil engineering projects,
by consulting engineers. The functions of the latter, acting on behalf of a
client, embrace advice on the feasibility of projects, the drawing up of plans
and the supervision of the constructional work by the contractor.

1 he Ministry of Public Building and Works (see p. 59) is responsible for
all the construction programmes undertaken directly by the Government
(except for roads), including work for the armed services, both at home and
overseas. It is also responsible for co-ordinating research and development
throughout the government service and seeks to influence methods and
techniques in the building industry as a whole.
The volume of output of the industry has been rising steadily; by the end of
1966 it was running at an annual rate of 37 per cent above the 1958 level.
The value of work done in 1966 amounted to £4,039 million, of which £589
million represented work carried out by the labour employed directly by
public authorities. Private contractors carried out the remaining £3,450
million (£2,734 million on new work and £716 million on repair work).
About 390,000 houses were started in 1966 and some £1,065 million of
housing work was carried out by private firms, a record for the total volume
of housing work. Of this, about £554 million, or 52 per cent, was for private
owners and the remaining £511 million for public authorities. It is planned
to build 500,000 dwellings a year by 1970. Increasing use is being made of
industrialised building methods employing prefabricated components.
The National Building Agency, which was set up by the Government in
1964, comes under the Ministry of Housing and Local Government. Its main
function is to encourage the adoption of advanced methods of housebuilding,
especially industrialised building methods, as well as technical advice and
services, in particular, to local authorities. The Ministry plans that eventually
40 per cent of local authority housebuilding should be industrialised; the
current percentage is around 30.
Britain was the first country to develop civil engineering as a large-scale
modern industry and the first to provide techniques, finance and equipment
to carry out major civil engineering projects throughout the world. Prominent
figures in the early development of civil engineering included John McAdam,
pioneer in road construction; Thomas Telford, builder of roads, bridges,
canals, docks and railways; George and Robert Stephenson and Isambard
Kingdom Brunei, pioneers of railway building.
Among important construction projects in hand in the United Kingdom in
1967 were several major conventional power stations and nuclear power
stations (see p. 278); the io|-mile Victoria Tube line in London, costing
£60 million; and large-scale housing developments, such as the Thamesmead
(London) project to house 60,000 people, and the first stages of the new town
being built at Craigavon, Northern Ireland. Projects for road construction,
bridges and tunnels included a further 130 miles of motorways under con¬
struction (see p. 354), a £6 million high-level bridge over the Clyde, and the
£20 million second Mersey Tunnel. The £13 million Tyne Tunnel was
opened in 1967.
British constructional firms have been as active overseas as in the United
Kingdom. British consulting engineers, in particular, have built up a tradition
of knowledge and integrity which has caused their standards to become
international practice and their services to be in world-wide demand.
Among important construction projects by British contractors in hand in
overseas countries during 1967 were: a new township for the Government of
Bahrain, costing £6 million; the £10 million restoration of the Hejaz railway
288.
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL FIANDBOOK
Research
in the Middle East; and a £5 million road scheme in Malawi. British consult¬
ing engineers were engaged on a number of projects where British contractors
were not commissioned for the construction work. Notable examples were an
airport at Baghdad, costing £12-5 million; construction of two water barrages
in West Pakistan (£27 million); and water supply schemes for Hong Kong
(^19 million) and Libya (£6-3 million). A new port at Dammam, to cost
between ^10 million and ^12 million, is being designed for the Saudi Arabian
Government.
It has been estimated that the total value of work carried out during the
year ending in March 1967 by over 100 British contractors, operating in 104
countries, was £172 million, compared with £169 million in the previous
year, and that the value of newT contracts obtained was £170 million, compared
with £190 million in the previous year. Consulting engineers had projects
worth about £1,400 million in hand on 1st January 1967.
The Directorate-General of Research and Development in the Ministry of
Public Building and Works is responsible for co-ordinating research and
information services to increase efficiency in the building industry. On
1 st July 1967 the Ministry assumed responsibility from the Ministry of
Technology for the Building Research Station. The Station was originally
set up in 1921, thus making Britain the pioneer of organised building research,
and is concerned with research into all aspects of building.
The Civil Engineering Research Association which promoted research on
problems of civil engineering, agreed in March 1967 to enlarge its activities
to take in the whole field of construction with an information and advisory
service. The enlarged body, to be known as the Construction Industry
Research and Information Association, is financed jointly by the Government
and the industry.
The Heating and Ventilating Research Association, an industrial research
organisation, deals with problems of heating and ventilation of large buildings.
The major construction firms have research departments working on plant,
materials and methods. Other bodies concerned with research include the
universities and colleges of technology. Most of the producers of primary
building materials have trade associations which maintain research institutions
chiefly devoted to seeking new and more efficient use for their materials:
the Timber Research and Development Association and the Cement and
Concrete Association are examples.
MANUFACTURING INDUSTRIES
Britain’s manufacturing industries supply a wide range of products, many
of which are of major importance in world trade. Output has increased by
over a third since 1958, and in 1966 was 1 per cent higher than the previous
year. In 1966 this sector spent £1,406 million on fixed capital equipment,
including £327 million on building work and £982 million on plant and
machinery. The number of employees in manufacturing industry (including
the unemployed and those absent from work through sickness and other
causes, but excluding employers and the self-employed) was 9-1 million in
June 1966, 38 per cent of the total number of employees.
The employment and production figures listed in Table 19 give an indication
of the relative importance of broad sectors of manufacturing industry.
Expansion has been particularly rapid in those industries utilising advanced

In the subsequent sections, statistics of employees refer to numbers at
June 1966, and export statistics are taken mainly from the Overseas Trade
Accounts of the United Kingdom.
The metal manufacturing industries employ 624,000 persons. Of these,
356,000 are in the iron and steel industry, 122,000 in the manufacture of
iron castings, 60,000 in the manufacture of light metals, and 85,000 in the
copper, brass and other base metal industries. Exports of iron and steel
products and non-ferrous metals in 1966 had an aggregate value of £406
million.
Britain pioneered the application of coal to the smelting of iron ore from the
seventeenth century onwards and British inventors were responsible for the
discovery of the processes which led to the great expansion of steelmaking
in the second half of the nineteenth century. Today Britain is the world’s
fifth largest steel producing nation. Output of crude steel in 1966 totalled
290
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
24-3 million ingot tons, 10 per cent less than the record output of 27 million
tons in 1965. Capacity utilisation in 1966 averaged 79 per cent, compared
with 87-5 per cent in 1965. Total capacity at the end of 1966 was about
31 million tons. Pig iron production in 1966 amounted to 15-7 million tons.
Net deliveries of finished steel amounted to 19 million tons in 1966. The
3-7 million tons of iron and steel products which were exported had a value
of ^214-8 million; the United States (£32-7 million), Sweden (£13-5 million)
and Spain (£10-3 million) were the main overseas buyers.
The main producing districts are: South Wales (26 per cent of total crude
steel output); the north-east of England (16 per cent); Sheffield and district
(12 per cent); Scotland (11 per cent); Lincolnshire (11 per cent); and
Lancashire and Flintshire (10 per cent). South Wales concentrates mainly on
the manufacture of flat products, especially sheet steel and tinplate; the
output of the north-east coast and Scotland is predominantly of heavy steel
products (plates, sections and rails), although a wide strip mill for sheet
production is now in operation in Scotland.
During the period 1950-66 over ,£1,400 million was spent on major
development schemes. Capital expenditure reached a peak in the years
1960-62 of over ^170 million a year on average, due mainly to the strip mill
expansion programme, falling to ^42 million in 1966. The emphasis is
increasingly on improving efficiency rather than raising total capacity. Britain
has some of the most modern plant in Europe, and by 1966 steel production
by the converter processes had increased from 8 per cent of total output in
i960 to 27 per cent; steel from electric furnaces had increased from 7 per cent
to nearly 14 per cent; and the share of the older open hearth process had
fallen from 85 per cent to 59 per cent.
Output per blast furnace has risen markedly in recent years, due both to
an increase in average size and to improvements in efficiency, such as im¬
proved preparation of raw materials, the injection of fuel and oxygen, and the
use of higher blast temperatures. Industry-wide scientific and technological
research is carried out by the British Iron and Steel Research Association.
Total annual expenditure by the industry is nearly £12 million.
Outstanding development projects completed in the last few years include
wide strip mills at new integrated works at Newport (Monmouthshire) and
at an existing works in Scotland; a new plant at Stoke-on-Trent, which is
based entirely on continuous casting for supplies of semi-finished steel; an
advanced unit for the mass production of alloy and special carbon steels at
Sheffield; the world’s largest electric melting shop and a new steelworks in
which a linked three-computer system controls production planning through¬
out, both at Rotherham.
The iron and steel industry has been subject to some form of public
supervision since 1932. The Iron and Steel Act 1967, which received the
Royal Assent in March, brings into public ownership 14 major steel companies
together producing well over 90 per cent of Britain’s crude steel and employing
some 70 per cent of the manpower in the industry. Their shares and securities
were vested on 28th July in the British Steel Corporation, which was formally
established in April. The Corporation’s specific duties include promoting
the efficient and economic supply of iron and steel products, exports, and
research and development; it is statutorily responsible for the finances of the
nationalised industry. The Act requires the Corporation to report on the
reorganisation of the industry within a year of its establishment. The Iron and
Steel Board, which had exercised a general supervision over the industry under
the Iron and Steel Act 1953, was dissolved. The remaining private sector

includes some 200 companies accounting for about one-third of the value of
the industry’s sales.
Output of iron castings totalled 3-9 million tons in 1966, 0-2 million tons
less than the record level of 1965. The main users of iron castings are the
general engineering industry, the motor vehicle industry, the manufacturers
of pressure pipes and fittings, the building and associated industries and the
steel industry. The engineering industry accounts for nearly one-third of the
total tonnage sold and about one-half of the industry’s turnover. There are
about 1,200 firms in the iron founding industry and the number of employees
is 112,000. Exports are included in the total of steel exports in the previous
section.
The non-ferrous metals industry is the largest in Europe and as a consumer
of aluminium, copper and lead Britain is second only to the United States
among western countries. Output in 1966 included: aluminium, 37,000 tons
of virgin metal and 181,000 tons of secondary metal; refined copper, 43,000
tons of virgin copper and 142,000 tons of secondary metal; lead, 111,000 tons
of secondary metal refined from scrap and 61,000 tons of virgin lead refined
from imported lead bullion; zinc, 100,000 tons of slab metal; and tin, 19,000
tons. Mining in Britain is confined to the working of lead and tin ores on a
small scale, although detailed investigation is taking place into the possibilities
of a considerable expansion of tin mining.
In 1966 exports of non-ferrous base metals were valued at ^ 149-2 million.
The main products exported, including semi-finished products, were copper
and copper alloys (£78-9 million), nickel and its alloys (£24-4 million),
aluminium and its alloys (£20-8 million) and tin and its alloys (^11-9 million).
The Federal Republic of Germany (£20-3 million), the United States (£17-3
million), France, the Netherlands, Sweden and Italy were the largest pur¬
chasing countries. Indirect exports are also substantial.
Nearly half of the industry is situated in the Midlands; other centres
include South Wales, London, Tyneside and Avonmouth. Firms are engaged
in smelting, casting and fabrication by rolling, extrusion and drawing and
the techniques of powder metallurgy and pressure diecasting are also employed.
Some non-ferrous metals, such as nickel, molybdenum, tungsten and
vanadium, are largely used in the making of high-speed and other special
steels. New uses for non-ferrous metals with special properties have emerged
with the growth of new industries having particular requirements, as, for
example, production of nuclear energy (uranium, zirconium), jet aircraft
(niobium, magnesium, titanium) and electronic apparatus (selenium, silicon,
germanium, tantalum). Scientific and technological research for the industry as
a whole is conducted by the British Non-Ferrous Metals Research Association.
Mechanical engineering comprises a wide range of industries, including all
types of machinery, machine tools, engineers’ small tools, mechanical handling
equipment, construction equipment, industrial plant, ordnance and small
arms, watches and clocks, and scientific instruments. Vehicle engines are
included in the section on vehicles (p. 298). The number of employees is
1-4 million and the volume of production from these industries rose by 49 per
cent between 1958 and 1966. In 1966, the aggregate value of the main products
of all sections other than tractors, small arms, scientific instruments and
watches and clocks, was ^2,233 million. Exports of non-electric machinery
were valued at £1,041 million in 1966, 12 per cent higher than in 1965.

There are over 300 firms, employing 38,000 people, in the agricultural
machinery industry, including three very large firms with more than 1,000
workers. In 1966 output, excluding tractors, was valued at £53-2 million and
exports were worth £26-6 million; the main overseas markets were France,
the Federal Republic of Germany, the Irish Republic, the Netherlands and
the United States. The number of self-propelled combine harvesters, forage
harvesters, pick-up balers and grain driers in use has increased in Britain in
recent years. Deliveries in 1966 included 3,800 combine harvesters, 6,600
milking machines, 15,600 pick-up balers and 2,400 grain and grass driers.
The bulk of British tractor output and exports consists of agricultural tractors.
Some 214,000 agricultural and industrial wheeled tractors were delivered in
1966, 171,000 (80 per cent) for export. In addition, 32,000 small market
garden tractors, were delivered. Exports of new agricultural and track-laying
tractors had the record value of ^104-5 million in 1966, 14 per cent more than
in 1965. Agricultural tractor production is dominated by two large organisa¬
tions. Tractors are exhibited at the annual Royal Smithfield Show and
Agricultural Machinery Exhibition in London; Britain has one of the heaviest
tractor densities in the world (see p. 323).
Britain was the birthplace of the modern machine tool industry, and by the
early 1830s had developed to an advanced stage the boring machine and
screw-cutting lathe, as well as other machine tools. The industry’s output
today ranges from watchmakers’ lathes weighing a few pounds to machines
weighing hundreds of tons, including transfer lines for motor vehicle manu¬
facture and electronically controlled machine tools giving accuracies of one-
ten-thousandth part of an inch. Over 1,000 numerically controlled machine
tools have been installed in Britain.
The value of deliveries of metal-working machine tools rose by 5 per cent
in 1966 to £149 million (the highest ever recorded), compared with ^141-3
million in 1965. Exports in 1966 had a value of £41-1 million; and of the
orders on hand at the end of December 1966 (£101 million), 29 per cent were for
export. The United States (£6-1 million), India (£4-3 million), Australia (^3-7
million) and Canada (£3-6 million) were the main overseas markets in 1966.
The trend in the industry is towards the formation of larger groups although
the high degree of specialisation makes it possible for the small firm to
flourish. The industry is centred mainly in the Midlands, Yorkshire and
Lancashire, and to a lesser extent near London and Glasgow. There are
96,000 persons employed.
The Machine Tool Trades Association of Great Britain is the representative
body of most manufacturers and importers, and is responsible for the
International Machine Tool Exhibitions held in Britain every four years,
the next being due in 1968. The industry is served by its own research body,
the Machine Tool Industry Research Association, and its customers by the
Production Engineering Research Association.
Britain manufactures a wide range of industrial engines. Deliveries of engines
(including parts) had a value of ^137-8 million in 1966 and exports (including
marine engines) were worth £27-9 million; in addition, parts exported were
valued at ^20-5 million. The total brake horse-power of the 336,500 internal
combustion engines delivered was n-2 million ranging in size from under
15 b.h.p. to over 4,000 b.h.p. Production is concentrated among the large
firms in the industry, and a total of 44,000 people are employed.

One of the oldest of Britain’s mechanical engineering industries, the textile
machinery industry developed rapidly after the introduction of mechanical
spinning and weaving towards the end of the eighteenth century. Its range of
output embraces all stages in textile manufacturing processes. Deliveries in
1966 were valued at ^110-7 million and exports (including products of some
associated industries) at j£82'3 million, an increase of 16 per cent on 1965.
Principal markets were the United States (£8-5 million), India (£7-6 million),
Pakistan (^7-6 million) and the Federal Republic of Germany (^5-5 million).
The industry, which has 52,000 employees, comprises many firms and is
situated mainly in Lancashire, Yorkshire, Northern Ireland, Dundee,
Leicester and Nottingham. It makes a wide range of machines and accessories
for the manufacture and processing of yarns and fabrics from all types of
natural and man-made fibres. In the case of bast and leaf fibre machinery the
United Kingdom is still by far the world’s largest supplier.
Almost every industry makes use of mechanical handling equipment; the
products of the industry range from individual units and accessories to
complete operating systems. The value of deliveries in 1966 was ^129-8
million (10 per cent more than in 1965), the main products being cranes and
bridge transporters, lifts, escalators, conveyors, elevators and hoists. In
addition, British firms produced 17,100 powered industrial trucks, including
13,000 fork-lift trucks. Exports of mechanical handling equipment (including
industrial and works trucks) in 1966 were valued at £35 million. There are
many small firms in the industry; in all, 61,000 people are employed.
Almost the whole range of plant required by the construction industry is
produced. These include crawler tractors, motor graders, scrapers, trenchers,
dozer equipment, dumpers, excavators and loading shovels, and crushing,
pulverising and screening plant. The labour force numbers 31,500.
The value of deliveries from the industry was £154 million in 1966; by far
the most important single item was earth-moving machinery (with a value
of £9i'5 million), while other important products were crawler tractors
(^28-5 million), and concrete mixing machinery (£io-g million). Deliveries
of contractors’ plant for export in 1966 totalled ^75-4 million; France, Spain,
Australia and Sweden are important markets.
The office machinery industry has been expanding rapidly and is now second
in size only to that of the United States. In 1966 the value of deliveries of
office machinery was £79-4 million including £45-6 million for export.
Deliveries in 1966 included 103,000 standard typewriters and 212,000
portable typewriters. The value of deliveries of accounting and similar
machinery was ^50-6 million, of which £33-2 million was for export, and of
other office machinery ^18-7 million, of which ^9-4 million was for export.
Exports of all office machinery (including electronic computers and data
processing equipment) were valued at £77-i million. The most important
overseas purchasers were the Federal Republic of Germany (£17-9 million),
France (£8-2 million), the United States (£7-5 million) and Australia (^6-4
million). British subsidiaries or associates of United States firms are prominent
in the office machinery industry. There are 65,000 persons employed.
The manufacture of engineers’ small tools and gauges is an expanding
industry; deliveries increased in value from £55 million in 1959 to a peak of
£94 million in 1966; the main products were hard metal tipped tools (£14

British industry manufactures almost every type of industrial plant and
steelwork, and 161,500 are employed in this branch. Of particular importance
are steam-raising boilers, lime and cement kilns, gas and coke oven plant,
sintering plant, metallurgical furnaces and plant, chemical and mineral oil
refining plant, nuclear reactors, water and sewage treatment plant, and
steelwork for bridges, buildings, etc. The industry has several large-scale
enterprises. In 1966 the aggregate value of deliveries (including rolling mills)
was ^560 million, 25 per cent higher than in the previous year.
British companies delivered water tube boilers to the value of £97 •1 million
in 1966 compared with £81-2 million in 1965 "> shell boilers and other boiler-
house plant accounted for a further £47-9 million. Water tube boilers of
advanced design and of large steam-raising capacity are produced for power
stations, whereas shell boilers are used for steam-raising and heating in
factories and buildings. Exports of vapour generating boilers in 1966 amounted
to £10-4 million.
The steelworks plant industry provides, in association with firms producing
rolling mills, almost all Britain’s requirements as well as plant for export.
The value of deliveries in 1966 was ^37-5 million; rolling mills and ancillary
equipment accounted for an additional £26-6 million. This industry consists
of a small number of firms, most of which are business associates or members
of a consortium. Spain, India, South Africa and Canada are a few of the
countries in which British firms are undertaking large-scale steelworks plant
projects.
The manufacture of specialised equipment for the chemical and oil refining
industries has expanded rapidly in recent years. Deliveries of chemical plant
had a record value of £127-9 million in 1966 compared with £86-4 million in
1965 and £53-7 million in 1964. If the whole range of equipment manu¬
factured by British firms for the petroleum industry is aggregated, Britain
ranks second to the United States as a supplier. The range of chemical plant
produced includes distillation columns, heat exchangers, high-vacuum drying
equipment, and plant for the manufacture of chemicals from all feedstocks
including petroleum.
Three major consortia consisting of leading firms in the heavy electrical
engineering, civil engineering, boiler, instrument, and associated industries,
build nuclear power stations for the United Kingdom electricity authorities
(see p. 278), and have built stations in Italy and Japan. The Atomic Energy
Authority grants them non-exclusive manufacturing licences and is working
in close collaboration with them in research and development.
In addition to the mechanical engineering firms described in preceding
sections, there are about 1,750 enterprises whose principal product is a type of
machinery not so far mentioned. The main products include: mining
machinery, printing and book-binding machinery, refrigeration appliances,
space heating, ventilation and air-conditioning equipment, pumps and pump¬
ing machinery, industrial valves and cocks, compressors, scales and weighing
machinery, portable power tools, food preparing machinery and many other
types of equipment. The total value of deliveries in 1966 was some £762
million. There are 370,000 workers employed in these industries.

This industry makes a wide range of equipment and appliances, extending
from domestic and commercial refrigerators of varying sizes to industrial
refrigeration equipment for cold stores, manufacture of chemicals and other
products, ice-making plant and refrigeration plant for ships. In 1966, 806,000
domestic refrigerators were delivered to the home market and 178,000 for
export. Total deliveries of refrigerating machinery had a value of ^53 • 1
million.
The value of deliveries of space heating, ventilating and air-conditioning
equipment has been rising recently and in 1966 reached £79-3 million.
Exports of air-conditioning and non-domestic refrigerating equipment in
1966 had a value of £8-3 million.
Industrial valves controlling the movement of liquids and gases are a vital
component in many industrial processes, particularly in the chemicals, oil
and electric power industries. A wide range of materials is used, including
plastics and many different metals. The value of deliveries of pumps and
valves in 1966 was £142-3 million (15 per cent more than in 1965) and that
of air and gas compressors and exhausters ^45-1 million. Exports of pumps
and centrifuges were valued at million and exports of industrial valves
at £24 million.
The value of deliveries of other major products in 1966 was: mining machinery,
£58-8 million; food and drink machinery, £45-1 million; packaging
machinery, £26-6 million; and other machinery, £311-7 million. Important
export products in 1966 included: food and drink processing machinery,
£15-3 million; cigarette-making machinery, £9-3 million; paper-making
machinery, £12-6 million; and printing and book-binding machinery, £20-8

The industry manufactures photographic, scientific, surgical and industrial
instruments; it has a labour force of 138,000 persons. A rapidly expanding
sector is that making industrial process measuring and control instruments—
an essential element of automation in industry-deliveries of which amounted
to ^69-7 million in 1966, compared with £41-3 million in i960. The value of
deliveries of other broad categories was: optical instruments, £10-2 million;
electric, electronic, and nucleonic instruments, £26-7 million; and nautical
and aeronautical instruments, £26-9 million. The total deliveries for 1966
amounted to £185-7 million.
Export deliveries of scientific instruments have been rising markedly,
amounting to £52-8 million in 1966, compared with £27-9 million in i960.
The Scientific Instrument Research Association conducts research on behalf
of the industry.
Deliveries of photographic equipment in 1966 totalled £98 million, including
£38-8 million for export. The main products in 1966 were: film (other than
cinematograph film), £30-2 million; sensitised paper and cloth, £20-4 million;
and cinematograph film, £12-9 million. Deliveries of photographic cameras
were valued at £2-9 million.
The present industry is largely a post-war development. It employs 15,000
people, the great majority skilled craftsmen, and many of its factories are
located on new industrial estates in the older industrial areas, particularly in
Scotland. Sales in 1966 included clocks (£7-4 million), watches (£5-3 million)
and time switches (£7-6 million); export sales were valued at £4 million.

Behind the firms manufacturing the major products outlined in this section
are nearly 4,000 enterprises, employing 252,000 people, whose main functions
are to supply parts and components, to conduct research and development
work, and to undertake general sub-contracting and repair work. (Some enter¬
prises are included because the mixed character of their work makes it
impossible to classify them under any single industry.) They include some
very large undertakings: several with more than 5,000 employees. Ball and
roller bearings, and chains, are important products; exports of the former
were valued at ^14-1 million in 1966, and exports of chains at £6-i million.
The electrical engineering industry is engaged in the manufacture and
installation of a wide variety of electrical equipment, including all types of
generating, transmission and distribution equipment; motors; telecommunica¬
tions apparatus; domestic appliances; and specialised laboratory and
electronic equipment. Annual output rose in volume by nearly three-fifths
between 1958 and 1966, and the total value of production in 1966 was estimated
at about £1,900 million.
Exports of electrical machinery, apparatus and appliances in 1966 were
valued at £346 million. Products are exported to all parts of the world; in 1966,
South Africa (£26-5 million), Australia (£25-3 million), the United States
(£20-9 million), the Netherlands (£15-2 million), New Zealand (£14-7
million), Canada (£14-4 million) and the Federal Republic of Germany
(£14-2 million) were the main markets.
Altogether the industry employs a labour force of 920,000. The leading
organisation is the British Electrical and Allied Manufacturers’ Association
while scientific and technological research on behalf of the industry as a whole
is carried out by the Electrical Research Association.
British scientists and engineers have been responsible for many of the basic
advances in the generation and transmission of electric power. The experi¬
ments of Michael Faraday pointed the way to the production of electricity
as a source of cheap and abundant power. Sir Charles Parsons produced and
patented the first turbo-dynamo, the forerunner of the giant turbo-generating
sets of today. The industry is providing the plant required for the large-scale
expansion programme of the electricity authorities in Britain and has built
all types of equipment for overseas countries.
In 1966 deliveries of electrical machinery were valued at £455-1 million,
comprising £156-9 million worth of rotating electrical machinery (motors,
generators and rotary converters), £68-3 million worth of transformers for
lighting, heating and power, £198-2 million worth of switchgear and control
gear and £31-7 million worth of other electrical machinery.
Exports of generators, motors, converters, transformers and rectifiers
amounted to £51-4 million in 1966, the main purchasers being South Africa
(£6-8 million) and Australia (£6-8 million). Switchgear, starting and control
gear exports were valued at £36 million.
Over 600 firms manufacture electrical machinery, including several with
over 7,500 employees. The total labour force numbers 236,000. Manufacture
takes place in many areas; among the most important are Manchester, Rugby,
Tyneside, Stafford and Larne (Northern Ireland).
Production of electronic equipment is one of the most rapidly expanding of
British industries. United Kingdom scientists and inventors have made many
basic contributions to electronics—the thermionic valve, the development of

which has led to far-reaching changes in methods of production in the radio

1 he consumer goods sector of the industry is concerned with the manufacture
of radio and television sets and radiograms. The industry is dominated by
several large firms. Output of television sets in 1966 fell to 1-4 million,
while the total value of sales was ^55 million, almost all in the home market.
Sales of radios and radiograms, numbered i-6 million in 1966 and were
worth £19 million. The industry is equipped to meet demand for colour
television sets with the introduction of colour transmission towards the end
of 1967.
1 he total value of deliveries of electronic apparatus in 1966 was £315 million,
including £83 million for export. Indirect exports of equipment incorporated
in other products, such as ships, aircraft and machinery, are also considerable.
The largest sectors of the industry, by value of deliveries, in 1966 were radar
and navigational aid equipment (of which 36 per cent of the deliveries of
£77 million was for export) and electronic computers (^61 million). Other
important sectors include electronic control equipment (^54 million), radio
communications equipment (£42 million) and electronic measuring and
testing equipment (^31 million).
Britain has the largest indigenous computer industry outside the United
States and has supplied over 1,000 installations in the United Kingdom.
One British company has supplied half the world’s radar-fitted merchant
ships, and many of the world’s airports outside the American continent use
British radar and navigational aids. The development of all-weather landing
techniques for aircraft has made notable advances in recent years.
The industry produces cables and wires for the distribution of electric power,
for telegraph and telephone networks and for many other purposes; its pro¬
ducts include submarine cables and cables insulated by a great variety of
materials. It is supplying the high voltage cable to carry the rapidly expanding
output of electric power in Britain (see p. 276). The value of deliveries in
1966 was ^254-8 million, 16 per cent more than in 1965. Exports of electric
cables, wires, etc., were worth ^34-9 million; the main purchasers were
Hong Kong and New Zealand.
The industry has a labour force of 67,000 persons and includes three firms
with over 5,000 employees.
Britain is one of the largest exporters of telegraph and telephone equipment.
Shipments overseas had a value of £30-2 million in 1966. Research and
development work is done by firms in the industry in co-operation with the
Post Office; in future all new small- and medium-sized exchanges installed in
Britain will be electronic (see p. 371). The industry, employing 96,000
persons, is organised for large-scale operations, and includes several very
large firms.
Deliveries of other electrical goods in 1966 included: domestic electrical
appliances, £159-2 million; electrical equipment for motor vehicles, cycles
and aircraft, £89-9 million; batteries and accumulators, £56-8 million;
electric lamps, £34-9 million; and other electrical goods, £140 million. By
number, deliveries included: 1-5 million electric blankets, 1-5 million vacuum
cleaners, 0-7 million domestic washing machines and 2-4 million electric

The industries which manufacture vehicles and aircraft provide a significant

Motor Vehicles
Cars
Commercial
Vehicles
Accessories,
Parts, etc.
In both size and value the largest section of the vehicle industry comprises
the manufacture of cars and commercial vehicles. In the last few years
development schemes costing over £200 million have been completed and,
whereas the industry was at one time located mainly in the Midlands and
London areas, manufacturing and assembly plants are in operation on Mersey¬
side, in Wales and in Scotland.
Car and commercial vehicle output is dominated by the five largest firms
(British Motor Holdings, Ford, Rootes, Leyland Motor Corporation and
Vauxhall), who account for over 95 per cent of complete vehicle production;
the balance is in the hands of smaller, specialist producers of heavy commercial
vehicles, omnibuses, coaches, limousines and sports cars. The principal trade
association is the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT),
which holds a motor show annually in London and a Commercial Motor
Exhibition every two years. The Motor Industry Research Association
carries out collective research on vehicles and components.
Car output in 1966 totalled i-6 million units, compared with 1-72 million
units in 1965. Exports in 1966 amounted to 553,000 cars with a value of
£233-9 million. The United States (£50-3 million) was again the largest single
purchaser; South Africa (£17-2 million), Canada, New Zealand and Australia
were the other main markets. About one-fifth of all exports went to EFTA
member countries and one-seventh to the EEC.
Production of commercial vehicles, including chassis, increased from 146,000
in 1946 to 439,000 in 1966. Exports in 1966 of new commercial vehicles
numbered 162,000 with a record total value of £142-1 million. South Africa
(£14-5 million), Australia (£13-3 million), New Zealand (£7-3 million)
and EFTA countries (£23 million) were the main markets for goods vehicles.
Since 1961 Britain has been the world’s largest exporter of commercial
vehicles.
Exports of parts and accessories for cars and commercial vehicles in 1966 had
a value of £142 million; engines and parts for motor vehicles were valued at a
further £58-7 million. Caravan and trailer exports totalled £9-4 million.

Cycles
Deliveries of bicycles have declined in recent years, the total in 1966
amounting to 1 -4 million. About 75 per cent of British manufacturing capacity
is in the hands of a single group of companies, and output is concentrated
in the Nottingham area. About 750,000 cycles worth £7-2 million were sent

overseas in 1966; the United States {fz million) was much the largest single
market. A small-wheel bicycle, developed in Britain, is the first major technical
change in the bicycle for 60 years.
Deliveries of all types of motor cycle amounted to 105,000 in 1966, slightly less
than in previous years. The total included 15,000 mopeds, 2,000 motor scooters
and 10,000 three-wheeled vehicles. Manufacture of motor cycles is dominated
by two large groups. Exports of motor cycles and parts totalled £15-3 million
in 1966, 50 per cent more than in 1965. The United States continues to be by
far the biggest market.
The British Railways Board has its own workshops which supply British
Railways and certain other users in Britain; private firms build locomotives,
carriages and wagons for British Railways, for industrial users and for
export.
Deliveries in 1966 included 163 electric locomotives, of which 100 were for
export, 304 diesel and diesel-electric locomotives, 471 coaching vehicles and
2,595 wagons. Deliveries of locomotives by private firms in 1966 were valued
at £15-9 million. The total value of exports of railway vehicles and parts in
1966 was £15-8 million; Nigeria (^1-7 million), South Africa and Kenya
were the largest purchasers.
Almost all the aircraft produced by the British industry today are based on
civil and military applications of the gas-turbine aero-engine, first developed
by Sir Frank Whittle. Turbo-prop aircraft in current production and operation
include the Argosy and Herald and the Hawker Siddeley J48 of which 162
have been sold or are on order. Two of a second generation of jet airliners,
the medium-haul Trident and the longer-haul Vickers VC 10, entered airline
service in 1964, followed in 1965 by a third, the BAG One-Eleven, the world’s
first jet transport designed to operate economically on short-haul routes.
Other civil aircraft in production include the HS 125 executive jet, the
Skyvan light transport aircraft, the Beagle range of light aircraft, using
piston and turbo-prop engines, the Handley Page Jetstream business airliner
seating up to 18 passengers, and the Islander, an economical feeder-line
aircraft. The Concord, the world’s first supersonic airliner, is being developed
jointly by Britain and France; the first prototype is expected to fly in
February 1968.
The industry produces a wide range of military aircraft. It is also engaged
on work on rockets, earth satellites and other aerospace requirements,
including the Blue Streak and Black Arrow satellite launchers. Hovercraft,
a new type of transport vehicle invented in Britain, are being increasingly
used throughout the world.
In 1966 the value of annual exports of the aerospace industry exceeded
£200 million for the first time. Exports of new aircraft and parts in 1966
(excluding electrical equipment) had a value of £130 million, compared with
jjfSo-q million in 1965. Leading buyers included the United States (^52-3
million) and South Africa (^14-5 million). In addition, exports of instruments
were worth ^4-1 million, and tyres £i-z million.
The construction of aircraft is dominated by two large airframe manufac¬
turers (which are negotiating a merger) and one helicopter concern, though
there are a few important smaller companies outside these groups. Besides
extensive research work by the industry, research on a substantial scale on
problems of aircraft and their engines is carried out by the Government,
chiefly at the Royal Aircraft Establishment and the National Gas Turbine
300 * BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Establishment, both at Farnborough, and the Royal Aircraft Establishment
at Bedford.
The British aerospace industry has over 50 collaboration agreements with
overseas governments and companies.
Aero-Engines Aero-engines and parts provided some £740 million in export earnings from
1946 to 1966. In 1966 exports of new and used engines and parts totalled
£71 million; major customers were the United States (£14-5 million), France
(j£8-9 million) and Canada (^8-5 million). Thirteen different British jet
engines power over 30 types of aircraft currently in production overseas.
Nearly half of the world total of jet and turbo-prop airliners on order or in
service have British power plants. Famous engines in production include the
economical Dart and Tyne turbo-props, the Avon, Conway, Viper and Spey
turbo-jets and the revolutionary Pegasus lift-thrust engine for vertical take-off
and landing (VTOL) aircraft. The power plant for the Concord will be a
further development of the Olympus.
One company is responsible for almost all aero-engine production.
Shipbuilding
and Marine
Engineering
The building of large ocean-going vessels is concentrated in four main
areas: the river Clyde in Scotland, the north-east and north-west coasts of
England and Belfast in Northern Ireland. Numerous yards around the coast
build smaller vessels such as fishing vessels, yachts, harbour craft and
barges.
Co-operative research into shipbuilding and marine engineering is under¬
taken by the British Ship Research Association with its headquarters in
London and a research station on the river Tyne.
Following the Geddes Committee’s report on the competitive position of
the industry in 1965, the Government set up the Shipbuilding Industry
Board in 1966. It will supervise the reorganisation of the industry into larger
groups and the rationalisation of facilities. One of the Board’s functions will
be to administer Government grants and loans to shipbuilders and ship¬
owners.
Merchant A gradual fall in tonnage launched from the 1955 peak of 1 - 5 million tons was
Shipbuilding halted in 1964, and launchings in 1966 were about at the same level as in 1965
totalling 1-08 million gross tons. British launchings were the fourth largest
in the world in 1966 accounting for 7-6 per cent of the world total,
compared with 8-8 per cent in 1965. Twelve oil tankers, totalling 244,000
gross tons, were launched in 1966. Launchings also included bulk carriers
totalling 350,000 gross tons and 18 cargo ships between 10,000 and 13,500
gross tons. At the end of 1966 orders on hand of merchant vessels of 100 gross
tons and over were 254, totalling 2-3 million gross tons and valued at £267
million. Of these vessels, 82 (1-2 million gross tons) were for export.
Modernisation in British shipyards over the last few years has involved
the replanning of yards, the erection of large prefabrication shops for welding
massive sections under cover, the installation of heavy-lift travelling cranes,
and much other reconstruction.
Ship Repairing There are many specialist ship-repairing establishments and most of the
larger shipbuilding firms also carry out repair work; about one-quarter of
ship-repairing activity is concentrated on the north-east coast of England.
Repair yards and dry docks are situated in all the large ports.
Marine Engineering Many of the larger shipbuilding yards maintain or have closely associated
engine building works, building various types of marine slow-speed diesel

and there are two independent builders of these engines. Steam turbines of
the highest powers are also built.
The group of industries manufacturing metal products not already described
consists of a large number of companies with a total labour force of 601,000
in 1966; the main groups were tools and implements (25,000 persons), cutlery
(14,000), bolts, nuts and screws (46,000), wire and wire manufactures (45,000),
cans and metal boxes (39,000), jewellery, plate, and refining of precious
metals (28,000), and other metal industries (405,000). The total value of
exports in 1966 was about £155 million.
The production of cutlery and flatware is centred mainly in the city of
Sheffield and the industry’s reputation has been built up on the skill of its
craftsmen. Mass-production methods are, however, extensively used except
in the case of some of the highest quality wares, although firms remain
mainly small. The value of sales of cutlery and flatware in 1966 was £15-5
million, including export sales of .£3-8 million.
This industry, located mainly in the Midlands, Lancashire, Yorkshire, South
Wales and London, produces a wide range of domestic utensils, such as
saucepans, buckets and dustbins, mainly from aluminium and wrought steel.
The value of sales in 1966 was £23-4 million, of which £3-1 million were
sales for export.
The manufacture of hand tools is one of the oldest British industries, covering
the manufacture of such tools as files, saws, hammers, axes and spades;
Sheffield, Birmingham and other Midland towns are the most important
centres. The value of sales of implements and tools, other than machine tools
and portable power tools, was £41-5 million in 1966, of which £12 million
worth were exported; the totals included sales of hand tools, at home and for
export, valued at £25-8 million and £11-5 million respectively.
The making of jewellery, gold and silver ware and the refining of precious
metals is an industry in which British craftsmen are heirs to a long tradition.
Most of the firms in the industry are small. The law requires that gold and
silver plate shall not be sold until it has been hall-marked at one of the Assay
Offices situated in London, Birmingham, Sheffield and Edinburgh. The
Birmingham office, located in the main centre of the jewellery industry, is by
far the most important. The total value of sales of jewellery, goldsmiths’ and
silversmiths’ wares and electro-plated nickel silver wares in 1966 was £27-6
million, of which £4-2 million was for export.
The chemicals industry, with a labour force of 479,000, comprises the
manufacture of: chemicals and dyes (227,000 employees), pharmaceutical
and toilet preparations (80,000 employees), explosives and fireworks (31,000
employees), paint and printing ink (48,000 employees), oils, fats, soap and
detergents (39,000 employees), synthetic resins and plastics (39,000 em¬
ployees), polishes and gelatine (14,500 employees), and fertilisers (10,000
employees). The industry is capital intensive; the fixed capital expenditure of
the industry, excluding mineral oil refining, amounted to over £1,100 million
during the six years 1961-66 and totalled £254 million in 1966. The value of
exports in 1966 was £469 million, or 9-3 per cent of total British exports.

Production in the general chemicals industries rose by 67 per cent between
1958 and 1966.
The inorganic chemicals industry dates back to the middle of the nineteenth
century; over half the output of this sector consists of a limited number
of relatively simple chemicals, such as sulphuric acid, caustic soda, chlorine
and ammonia, produced in very large quantities and serving as basic materials
for industry. Sulphuric acid has the largest production of any chemical and
3-1 million tons was produced in 1966. The remaining output of this sector
consists of a very wide range of chemicals of varying complexity. Almost all
inorganic chemicals are consumed in other manufacturing processes and
substantial quantities are used in the manufacture of such products as
fertilisers, detergents, paint, glass and metals. Exports are important; about
one-quarter of output is estimated to be exported directly.
Production of organic chemicals (which include coal-tar chemicals) rose
by 146 per cent between 1958 and 1966. To an increasing extent petroleum is
the raw material used and it is estimated that in 1966 petroleum-based
chemicals accounted for 75 per cent of the total output of organic chemicals;
deliveries of feedstock for the petroleum chemical plants totalled 3-6 million
tons in 1966 compared with i-i million tons in 1959. The most important
products (by weight) in 1966 were ethylene (571,000 tons) and propylene
(311,000 tons). The main outlets for organic chemicals are plastics materials,
solvents, synthetic rubber, man-made fibres and detergents. Consumption of
dyestuffs is geared to demand by the textile industry; about 32,800 tons of
synthetic dyestuffs were produced in 1966.
Exports of chemical elements and compounds amounted to £110-8 million
in 1966. Exports go to a large number of countries including, in 1966, the
Netherlands (£12-7 million), the United States (£8-4 million), Australia
(£6 million), France, South Africa, Canada and Sweden.
The first plastic, Parkesine (later called Celluloid), was produced and
patented in Britain in 1865 by Alexander Parkes; other British discoveries
include polyethylene. Plastics manufacture is one of the fastest growing
sections of the economy. Output of synthetic resins has more than doubled
since 1959 and total production in 1966 was 1,001,000 tons (an increase of
6 per cent over 1965), of which 685,000 tons consisted of thermoplastic resins.
Expansion in recent years has mainly been in thermoplastic materials, of
which the most important are polyethylene (used in coverings and packaging—
notably for foodstuffs), polyvinyl chloride (known as PYC and used for a
wide range of industrial purposes and consumer goods) and polystyrene
(a cheap non-inflammable material used for toys, light mouldings and many
consumer goods). One of the newer thermoplastic materials is polypropylene,
a versatile material which can be fabricated as mouldings, films and fibres.
Rapid expansion of capacity for all the main types of plastics materials is
planned. Exports of plastics materials in 1966 amounted to 372,000 tons,
valued at £89 million. The main purchasers were Australia (£10-6 million),
the Netherlands (£6 million), South Africa (£5-3 million) and Sweden (£5-2
million).
The first general purpose synthetic rubber to be manufactured on a com¬
mercial scale in the United Kingdom was marketed in 1958. High styrene
rubbers for shoe soles and flooring, and nitrile rubbers for use where oil
resistance is required, are now in large-scale production, and neoprene rubber

is manufactured in Northern Ireland. Production in 1966 amounted to 191,000
tons, much of which came from the styrene-butadiene plant at Hythe, near
Southampton. Exports of synthetic rubber and latex totalled 58,000 tons
in 1966.
The development of artificial fertilisers owes much to the pioneer work of
the British scientists Sir John Lawes and Sir Joseph Gilbert. Two firms
predominate in the production of fertilisers and there are a large number of
firms marketing compound fertilisers from the principal constituents—
nitrogen, phosphorus and potassium. To encourage use, sales on the home
market are assisted by government subsidies paid to the farmer (see p. 327).
Output of nitrogenous fertilisers (in terms of nitrogen content) has been
increasing and in 1965-66 totalled 655,000 tons, while 420,000 tons (in terms
of phosphate content) of phosphatic fertilisers were produced; production
of compound fertilisers amounted to 2-7 million tons in 1965-66. The use of
ammonium nitrate (35 per cent nitrogen), ammonium phosphate, and, to a
limited extent, urea (mostly 45 per cent nitrogen) is resulting in more con¬
centrated fertilisers. The value of exports of manufactured fertilisers, mainly
nitrogenous, was £7-9 million in 1966.
Sales of paint and varnish during 1966 amounted to nearly 92 million gallons
(including 13 million gallons of emulsion paint) valued at ^135-5 million.
Britain is the largest exporter of paints in the world; exports of pigments,
paints, varnishes and related materials in 1966 amounted to £32-7 million. The
industry’s indirect contribution to exports in the form of surface coatings
for finished goods is also considerable.
In recent years many improved techniques have been introduced, in
particular the use of important new ranges of synthetic resins and pigments;
quick-drying paints and paints needing only one application have been
developed.
The whole range of drugs is produced in the United Kingdom, including
sulphonamides, anti-malarial drugs, anti-histamine products, anaesthetics,
vaccines, sera and naturally occurring drugs. Research expenditure totalled
j£ii-6 million in 1965.
Notable British contributions to the development of new products include:
the discovery of penicillin by Sir Alexander Fleming and its evaluation by Sir
Howard Florey and E. B. Chain; the evaluation of sulphapyridine (M & B 693)
by Sir Lionel Whitby; the introduction of the anti-malarial drug proguanil;
the discovery of griseofulvin; and, more recently, the isolation of the penicillin
nucleus and the development of several semi-synthetic penicillins and the
cephalosporin antibiotics. Several of the larger pharmaceutical companies in
Britain are subsidiaries of overseas firms.
In 1966 exports of medicinal and pharmaceutical products rose by 10 per
cent to the record level of £73-i million, of which j£i6-i million worth were
antibiotics. The largest purchasers were the Irish Republic (^4-4 million),
Australia (^3-9 million), France (£3-5 million) and Nigeria (£3-4 million).
Notable discoveries by the British crop protection industry include the
insecticidal activity of BHC (benzene hexachloride), the first selective weed¬
killer, MCPA, and more recently Gramoxone, a non-residual general herbicide
based on paraquat. Sales of pesticides and allied products were valued at
£26-5 million in 1966, 17 per cent higher than in 1965; herbicides (£14-8

and weedkillers in 1966 totalled £13-5 million, a third more than in 1965.
Sales of toilet preparations were valued at £105 million in 1966, including
export sales of about ^13 million; home market sales of hair preparations
totalled about £30 million. Petroleum is the source of the principal raw
material used in the manufacture of organic surface-active agents in deter¬

two companies supply about 90 per cent of home sales. Sales of polishes in

The textile industries in 1966 had a labour force of 816,000 persons, including
51,000 employees engaged in the production of man-made fibres: 109,000
were employed in the spinning and doubling of cotton, flax and man-made
fibres, 103,000 in the weaving of cotton, linen and man-made fibres, 176,500
in the woollen and worsted trades, 136,000 in hosiery and knitted goods,
71,000 in textile finishing and 43,000 in carpets. Over half the employees are
women. The total value of textile exports in 1966 was £261 million, somewhat
less than in 1965. Production of textiles rose by 17 per cent between 1958 and
1966. Considerable reorganisation is taking place within the textile industry,
connected with the increasing use of man-made fibres. Several large multi¬
fibre, multi-process groups have been formed under the leadership of
manufacturers of man-made fibres.
The Textile Council for the Man-made Fibres, Cotton and Silk Industries
was established in January 1967, superseding the Cotton Board. It is a
development council, that is, a statutory body with constitution and powers
laid down under an Act of Parliament, and is financed by a levy on the
industry.
Scientific and technical research for the industry is carried out by the
Cotton, Silk and Man-made Fibres Research Association.
Cotton was Britain’s chief consumer goods industry and cotton piece-goods
its largest export during the nineteenth century. Increasing foreign competi¬
tion and the tendency of many countries to set up their own textile industry
have cut progressively into British markets and a global limit has been placed
on imports of cotton goods from low-cost countries during 1966-70.
Output in 1966 consisted of: 456 million lb. of single cotton yarn, 136 million
lb. of spun man-made fibre and mixture single yarn, 233 million lb. of
doubled yarn, 62 million lb. of textured yarn, 915 million linear yards of
woven cotton cloth, and 619 million linear yards of man-made fibre and
mixture cloth. In 1966 exports of cotton yarn and woven fabrics (excluding
man-made fibres) amounted in value to £37-1 million, including woven
fabrics worth £26-6 million, for which the Irish Republic and South Africa
were the most important markets.
Most of the industry is located in Lancashire, the north-east of the county
being mainly concerned with weaving and the south-east with spinning.
Manchester is the commercial centre and Liverpool is the chief port of entry
for raw cotton. Legislation to assist the reorganisation of the industry was

Wool
Man-made
Fibres
305
introduced in 1959. Exchequer funds have paid for two-thirds of the cost of
removing surplus capacity, and also provided grants of about one-quarter
towards the cost of approved re-equipment and modernisation schemes.
The wool textile industry, the largest in the world, is the most ancient of
Britain’s staple industries and has been important since medieval times. There
are two main branches—woollen and worsted. While the West Riding of
Yorkshire is by far the most important producing area, Scotland and the West
of England remain famous as specialised producers of high-quality woollen
cloth. In recent years an increasing amount of man-made fibre has been
blended with wool.
In 1966 output included 230 million lb. of wool and hair tops and 315
million lb. of woollen yarn. Production of worsted yarn amounted to 221
million lb. and of woven fabrics to 302 million square yards. In addition,
large quantities of raw wool are scoured and cleaned in Britain. Consumption
of raw wool in 1966 was 388 million lb., compared with 518 million lb. in 1959.
Exports in 1966 included wool yarns (^20-1 million), woollen fabrics (^38-5
million) and wool worsted fabrics (^23-1 million). The main buyers of woollen
fabrics were the United States (^4-7 million), the Federal Republic of Ger¬
many and Canada. Raw wool (cleaned or scoured in Britain) and other animal
hair and tops exported had a value of £56-4 million. Research is carried on
mainly by the Wool Industries Research Association. The National Wool
Textile Export Corporation is responsible for assistance to exporters and the
development of new markets.
The small or medium-sized business predominates in the industry and there
are only a few large firms.
Man-made fibres produced from cellulose were first made commercially
available in the United Kingdom in 1905, and much of the early development
of viscose rayon and acetate took place in Britain. Large quantities of chemicals
are consumed in their production, which is spread throughout the country;
Northern Ireland is of growing importance. Large firms predominate in the
industry. There has been a rapid expansion of output in recent years, the
1966 record total of 881 million lb. being 2 per cent higher than in 1965 and
23 per cent more than in 1963. Output consisted of 470 million lb. of staple
fibre and 411 million lb. of filament yarn in 1966. Of the staple fibre, 174
million lb., and of the continuous filament, 211 million lb., were of fully
synthetic materials.
Two main types of man-made fibres are manufactured: those made from
cellulose (such as rayon) and those produced by fully synthetic processes from
chemical substances (such as nylon). Viscose rayon is still the most widely
used of all man-made fibres and output in 1966 totalled 401-4 million lb.
It can be modified to produce a wide range of different fibres, such as Vincel,
a competitor to cotton, and Evlan, specifically developed for the carpet
industry. The world’s largest rayon staple factory is at Greenfield (North
Wales), with an annual output of 200 million lb., while other large rayon
plants are at Grimsby, Preston and Wolverhampton. Almost all the rayon
produced in Britain is made by a single company and its subsidiaries.
Triacetate {Tried), a stronger form of acetate, was first produced in Britain
in 1955-
Production of nylon, the first fully synthetic fibre, in the form of nylon 66,
started in Britain in 1941; another type of nylon (nylon 6) has been manu¬
factured since 1963. Total productive capacity of nylon is planned to reach
