about 390 million lb. a year by the end of 1967 compared with about 160
million lb. in 1964. Nylon is used extensively in the manufacture of clothing,
fabrics and stockings, and has many industrial uses.
Terylene, a polyester fibre, was invented in Britain during the second
world war. It is resistant to fading and is particularly suited to blending with
wool. Annual manufacturing capacity totals about 100 million lb. A group
of fibres of growing importance are the acrylic fibres: Courtelle (a British
discovery) and Acrilan are examples. Synthetic elastomerics or spandex
fibres, which are man-made textile fibres having inherent properties of stretch
and recovery, are now produced commercially. Polythene {Courlene) and
polypropylene (Ulstron) fibres have been developed mainly for industrial uses.
Exports of man-made fibre yarns had a value of ^38-1 million in 1966,
and woven fabrics £16-5 million. Sweden, the Netherlands and South Africa
were the most important purchasers of yarns.
The hosiery and knitwear industry is predominantly one of small-scale
enterprises. The industry is widely distributed, with Scotland and the east
Midlands as the two most important centres. Sales of knitted goods were
valued at £325-7 million in 1966 including £131-7 million worth of outerwear
and £76 million worth of socks and stockings. Exports of knitted clothing
and accessories were valued at £17-6 million in 1966; the largest buyers were
the United States, Switzerland and Canada. Exports of knitted fabrics
amounted to £5-9 million. The British Hosiery and Knitwear Export Group
co-ordinates the export activities of the industry and organises overseas
missions. The Hosiery and Allied Trades Research Association, with
laboratories at Nottingham, undertakes collective research.
The linen industry is concentrated in Northern Ireland (the greatest linen¬
manufacturing region in the world), with most of the remainder in Scotland.
Broadly speaking, the Northern Ireland industry concentrates on yarns
and the lighter types of fabrics, while in Scotland production is largely of
coarse linens and canvas, although household types are also produced.
Northern Ireland manufacturers produced 46-9 million linear yards of cloth
in 1966, while weavers in Great Britain delivered 27-7 million square yards,
including 16-9 million square yards of sailcloth and canvas. Exports in 1966
included £8 million worth of linen fabrics and £3-1 million worth of flax
yarns and linen thread.
Jute is manufactured on a large scale in the Dundee area—the centre of the
world’s oldest jute industry—and 17,000 people are employed in all. Jute is
used in the manufacture of carpets, cordage, ropes and woven into fabrics for
a wide range of uses in the packaging, carpet, upholstery, building and motor
car industries. Research is being undertaken into new uses, for example,
plastics reinforcement. In 1966, 121,000 tons of raw jute were used, and
exports of jute fabric and yarn totalled £2-2 million.
Sales of finished lace goods amounted to £19-4 million in 1966. The most
important lace product is from the warp knitting machines, with sales valued
at £io-6 million. Sales of lace products for export were worth £4-9 million
in 1966.
In addition to the products mentioned specifically in this section, British
textile firms manufacture a wide range of other goods, including many special
yarns and fabrics, net, household textiles such as blankets, tablecloths and

curtains, and floor coverings other than carpets. Sales of narrow fabrics
(including elastic machinery belting and ribbon) totalled £42-6 million in
1966, including export sales of ^6-2 million. Sales of floor coverings of
linoleum, vinyl and other synthetic materials were valued at ^37-3 million
in 1966; just under one-fifth were for export. The British cordage industry is
the largest in Europe. Exports of ropes, cordage, nets and netting in 1966
were valued at £4-4 million.
In 1966 total sales of all types of carpets and rugs amounted to 112-7 million
square yards, valued at ^161-4 million. Exports in 1966 had a value of £13
million; Australia (£2-8 million) was the largest single market.
There are over 100 enterprises engaged in the manufacture of carpets,
including several large firms. In addition to the manufacture of woven carpets
such as Axminster and Wilton, over one-third of total sales by quantity in
1966 were of tufted carpets, a form of carpeting in which the pile, usually
containing a high proportion of artificial fibres, is inserted into a pre-woven
backing. Axminster-type carpets account for about 40 per cent of the value of
exports. The principal manufacturing centres include Kidderminster (in
Worcestershire), Halifax and Dewsbury (in the West Riding of Yorkshire),
Durham (in north-east England), Glasgow and Kilmarnock (in Scotland) and
several towns in Northern Ireland. About a third of the carpets produced (by
quantity) are made predominantly of wool and a growing proportion of
traditional woven carpets contain some man-made fibre.
There are 615,000 employees in the clothing, leather and footwear industries.
Some 446,000 are in the clothing industry, 109,000 in the footwear trade and
61,000 in leather, leather goods and fur manufacture. The aggregate value of
their exports in 1966 was ^102-3 million.
The British clothing industry is the largest in Europe and total deliveries
of made-up clothing have increased by 33 per cent since 1958. Consumer’s
expenditure on clothing in 1966 totalled £1,725 million. Exports in 1966,
including knitted goods, were valued at £52-7 million; the United States
(£10-i million) was the main purchaser. Exports of women’s outerwear rose
sharply in 1966. Substantial quantities of clothing are also sent by parcel post.
Although there are some large firms employing mass-production methods
on an increasing scale, the typical firm is small. The principal manufacturing
centres are London, Leeds and Manchester, but several firms are also situated
on industrial trading estates throughout the country. Fashion is important in
the production of haute couture models and throughout the ready-to-wear
industry, and British designers are making an increasing impact abroad.
The Clothing Export Council, representing over 150 companies, organises
promotions for various sectors of the industry.
Leather tanning is one of Britain’s oldest industries. In 1966, 14,900 tons of
sole and other heavy leather and 448 million square feet of upper, lining and
other light leathers were produced. Britain is one of the world’s leading
exporters with exports in 1966 valued at £23-8 million. The United States is
the largest single market (£4-9 million in 1966), followed by Canada (£2-5
million) and Italy.
Tanneries are situated in most parts of Britain, but there are important
concentrations in Lancashire, Cheshire, Yorkshire, the north Midlands and
the London area. Many different types of leather are produced, ranging from

leather for footwear, leather goods, gloves and clothing. The British Leather
Manufacturers’ Research Association is the foremost of its type in the world.
The British footwear industry is the third largest in the world. In 1966
manufacturers’ sales of footwear totalled 194 million pairs. Exports of all
types had a value of j£i6-6 million; the United States (£3-9 million), Canada
and the Soviet Union were the largest markets.
Factories are located throughout Britain. Some areas concentrate on
production of particular types; for example, the Rossendale Valley region
of Lancashire on slippers, and Leicester and Norwich on women’s and girls’
shoes. The Shoe and Allied Trades Research Association enjoys a world-wide
reputation in all matters connected with shoemaking.
The food, drink and tobacco industries employ 849,000 persons in the
production of a great variety of goods. The value of their combined exports
in 1966 was £297 million. Exports of alcoholic and other beverages accounted
for ^136-8 million; sugar, sugar preparations and honey for £21-6 million;
cereal and cereal preparations for £41-6 million; fruit and vegetables for
£15-3 million; and coffee, cocoa, tea and spices for ^13-4 million.
The household consumption of bread, which has been falling, averaged about
2 lb. 7 oz. per week in 1966. In England and Wales particularly, the small
‘family’ type of baker, producing bread with some mechanical aids, is still
found, but the trend towards concentrating production in large mechanical
bakeries has become more pronounced; well over two-thirds of the bread is
made in these bakeries, which specialise in sliced and wrapped loaves; 4 groups
have a dominant position. In the smaller bakeries production of cake and other
flour confectionery is usually allied to bread production. There are 162,000
employees in the bread and flour confectionery industry; a further 43,000 are
employed in grain-milling.
There are 51,000 employees producing biscuits, and annual output has been
over 570,000 tons in recent years. Weekly consumption of cakes and biscuits
per head in Britain was 12-2 oz. in 1966. British biscuits have gained a world¬
wide reputation, and despite the problem of import restrictions in several
overseas markets, exports in 1966 were valued at £7-6 million.
The chocolate and sugar confectionery industry, which has 92,000 employees,
is composed of a small number of very large manufacturers and many medium¬
sized and small firms. The main ingredients used by the industry are sugar,
cocoa beans, glucose, milk, nuts and fats. Production of chocolate and
sugar confectionery was 664,000 tons in 1966. Consumption of chocolate and
sugar confectionery in the United Kingdom is far higher than in any other
country, being equivalent to 7-8 oz. per head per week.
The value of exports in 1966 of cocoa preparations (including chocolate)
was ^10-9 million and of sugar confectionery, £12 million. The United
States and Canada were the main markets for cocoa preparations. Over 30 per
cent of total world exports of chocolate and sugar confectionery come from
Britain, the world’s largest exporter of these products.
Among the fruit and vegetable products manufactured are jam, marmalade,
sauces and vinegar. The labour force numbers 73,000. Output of jams and
marmalade, which fell from 329,000 tons in 1949 to about 215,000 tons in

berry, raspberry and blackcurrant jams are the most popular. Exports of
jams and marmalade in 1966 were valued at ^1-9 million.
In 1966, 708,000 tons of canned vegetables were produced. The British
Navy was using canned foods in 1813, but rapid development in the industry
did not take place until after 1935. Processed and fresh peas (281,000 tons)
and beans in tomato sauce (272,000 tons) are the vegetables most in demand
as canned products. In addition, output in 1966 included 97,000 tons of
canned and bottled fruit, and 298,000 tons of canned soup. Strawberries are
the most important single fruit used for canning, followed by rhubarb and
apples. Sales of prepared fruit pie fillings are increasing.
Sales of frozen foods are rising in Britain, and nearly 98,000 tons of vegetables
and 1,300 tons of fruit were preserved by this method in 1966; peas accounted
for 63 per cent of all quick-frozen vegetables. Sales of dehydrated products,
including accelerated freeze dried foods, are increasing.
The industry comprises the curing of bacon and ham, the canning and
preserving of meat and fish, the manufacture of sausages and pies and the
preparation of extracts and pastes. The labour force numbers 88,000. Output
of canned meat and meat products in 1966 rose to 102,500 tons, but the
quantity of bacon and ham cured fell to 205,000 tons. There has been a rapid
expansion of quick-frozen fish output, and some 78,000 tons were produced
in 1966; small quantities (8,000 tons in 1966) are also canned. Exports of fish
and fish preparations had a value of £9-9 million in 1966 and those of meat
and meat products were worth £12-8 million.
The industries producing beer, spirits, wines, cider and soft drinks have a
labour force of 166,000. Exports were valued at £136-8 million in 1966,
11 per cent more than in 1965.
Exports of whisky (almost all of it Scotch whisky) reached the record level
of 41-6 million proof gallons with a value of £120-4 million in 1966; over half
went to the United States (£62-4 million or 22-7 million proof gallons).
Scotch whisky was first distilled in the fifteenth century. It is blended from
20 or more different types, some from malted barley and some from other
grains. Whisky requires several years to mature, and the 134-5 million proof
gallons (a record) of Scotch whisky produced in the 1966 distilling year will
not be on sale for some years. Stocks of whisky amount to nearly 600 million
proof gallons, representing ten years’ consumption. About four-fifths of
annual sales are to overseas buyers.
Production of gin in Britain has risen steadily since the early 1950s.
The main distillers are in London and one company accounts for a large
proportion of total output. Although the larger manufacturers also own
distilleries abroad, exports had a value of £9 million in 1966.
There are 99,000 employees in the brewing and malting industry. In recent
years there has been a strong tendency towards the creation of larger brewery
units, partly to secure wide distributive outlets for the products of the large
brewing groups, many of which market beer throughout the country. In 1966,
30-2 million bulk barrels of beer were produced, the highest for some years,
and consumers’ expenditure on beer amounted to £887 million. Exports in
1966 of malt beer were 329,000 bulk barrels, worth £2-9 million. Firms are
experimenting with new methods, including continuous brewing processes,
and automated batch production plants are well established.

The main raw materials used in brewing are malt, hops and some sugar.
Malt is made almost entirely from home-grown barley. Some brewers make all
or part of their own malt, others purchase it from independent maltsters who
also supply distillers, vinegar brewers, and malt extract manufacturers.
British malt is used by brewers throughout the world, and exports in 1966
amounted to 40,000 tons, worth £2 million.
The soft drinks industry has expanded markedly in the last decade although
sales are liable to be affected by the weather. Output in 1966 included 55
million gallons of concentrated liquid, and 243 million gallons of unconcen¬
trated drinks. Though there has been some amalgamation in recent years,
there are still several hundred firms supplying regional markets. There are two
very large firms among the 20 or so producing widely advertised brands which
are marketed on a national scale. There is also some degree of specialisation by
firms in the production of various types, such as carbonated drinks, cola-based
drinks, squashes and cordials, tonic waters and ‘mixers’, and comminuted
drinks (in which the whole fruit is used). Sales of canned carbonated drinks
are increasing rapidly.
The tobacco industry manufactures almost all the cigarettes and other
tobacco goods sold in Britain. In 1966 consumers’ expenditure on these
goods amounted to ^1,504 million (of which about 69 per cent was tax
revenue) and, in addition, exports worth £21-9 million (of which cigarettes
accounted for 89 per cent) were shipped to a large number of overseas
markets; Kuwait, Aden and Hong Kong were the most important. The main
centres of production are in and around Bristol, Liverpool, London, Man¬
chester, Newcastle, Nottingham, Glasgow and Belfast. The two biggest
manufacturing groups account for a large proportion of total output. The
industry has 50,000 employees.
The tobacco industry used 301 million lb. of unmanufactured tobacco
in 1966 (1 per cent more than in 1965), all of which was imported. In 1966
the main sources were the United States, Canada and India. Total consump¬
tion of tobacco in Britain in 1966 amounted to 257-2 million lb., including
223-5 million lb. consumed in cigarettes, 29-7 million lb. in pipe and hand
rolling tobacco and 3-3 million lb. in cigars. In 1966, 118,000 million cigarettes
were consumed, 6,000 million more than in the previous year; 61 per cent of
the total were tipped compared with 16 per cent in i960.
This group comprises the manufacture of bricks, fireclay, refractory goods,
pottery, glass, cement, abrasives, asbestos and other building materials. The
industries have a combined labour force of 356,000, which includes 71,000
in the bricks, fireclay and refractory goods trades, 81,000 in the glass industry
and 66,000 in the pottery industry.
Firms in the industry manufacture such items as bricks, roofing tiles, chimney
pots, fireclay ware and heat-resisting products including furnace and kiln
linings. Brickmaking, one of Britain’s oldest industries, was introduced by
the Romans, and manufacturing methods vary from traditional hand fabri¬
cation to highly mechanised systems. In 1966 about 7,068 million building
bricks were produced in Great Britain, 42 per cent of which were of the
Fletton type, made mainly in the Bedford and Peterborough areas. Refractory
goods (firebricks, silica bricks, magnesite bricks and chrome-magnesite bricks)
are manufactured mainly for home use. Exports of refractory construction
materials in 1966 were worth ^6-i million.

Pottery The pottery industry is a long-established and complex industry, largely
located in the Stoke-on-Trent area of Staffordshire. Much of its raw material
is indigenous, such as china clay, ball clay and china stone from Devon
and Cornwall. It supplies nearly all home needs for domestic and industrial
pottery and its exports in 1966 exceeded £27 million and were the highest
ever. The United States and Canada are important markets.
The largest section of the industry, about half, makes domestic pottery,
sub-divided into china, earthenware, stoneware, jet and Rockingham; the
other main divisions are glazed tiles, sanitary ware and electrical ware, and
such specialised industrial products as acid-proof stoneware, porous ceramics
and laboratory porcelain are also manufactured. Among famous makes of
British pottery are Wedgwood, Spode, Royal Worcester, Royal Doulton,
Minton, Coalport and Royal Crown Derby. Total sales of domestic
pottery were £43-8 million in 1966 including export sales of ^18 million.
The industry employs 66,000 people, of whom 35,500 are women. There
has been considerable re-equipment; gas or electrically fired kilns have
replaced almost all the coal-fired kilns and new decorating techniques and
automatic and semi-automatic machinery have been introduced.
Glass Britain’s glass industry is the third largest in the world. The section of the
industry devoted to the manufacture of plate and sheet glass in their various
forms is organised for quantity production, much of it in the form of the
‘float’ glass process, which was developed in Britain and has been licensed
to glass makers throughout the world. Its use for internal decoration and as
a finish for internal and external walls has greatly increased in recent years.
Large quantities of safety glass are produced for the motor industry. Other
products include glass bricks, tubular glass (produced on a large scale),
mirrors, lamp and bulb glass, scientific and medical glassware, glass fibres,
and all types of glass containers (often made by fully automatic machinery).
A traditional product is hand-made lead crystal glassware of very high quality,
much of which is exported.
Direct exports of glass and glassware reached the record value of £26-3
million in 1966. Those of glass were worth ^16-2 million, the most important
markets being the United States, Canada, Australia and South Africa. The
figures included ^4 million of float glass.
Collective research is undertaken by the British Glass Industry Research
Association, and much research work is also carried out by the Department
of Glass Technology of Sheffield University.
Cement The cement industry of the United Kingdom is chiefly concerned with the
manufacture of Portland cement. Invented by Joseph Aspdin and patented
in 1824, this material and the methods of its production have been the subject
of continuous technical improvement and intensive research. The capacity
of the industry, which has 18,000 employees, has increased substantially
since the war to meet the growing demands of the building industry and
further expansion is planned. The Dartford-Gravesend district of Kent is an
important producing area. Annual output totalled 16-5 million tons in 1966.
PAPER, PRINTING The paper, printing and publishing industries have 651,000 employees,
AND PUBLISHING inciU(jing 98,000 in the manufacture of paper and board, 68,000 in the pro¬
duction of cardboard boxes and packing cases, 145,000 in the publishing of
newspapers and periodicals and 264,000 in other types of printing and
publishing.

The manufacture of paper in Great Britain was not firmly established until
1678, but records show that some paper was produced as far back as 1492.
The British paper and board industry is the largest in Europe. Total
production in 1966 of all types of paper and board maintained the record
level of 4-5 million tons. Of this, newsprint accounted for 735,000 tons,
board for 1-3 million tons and other paper for the remainder. Exports of
paper, board and manufactured paper items were valued at £54 million in
1966, over 6 per cent more than in 1965. The main purchasers were the
Irish Republic, Australia and South Africa.
Wood pulp is the main raw material, but large and increasing quantities
of waste paper are also used. A £20 million integrated pulp and paper mill,
the first in Britain, was opened at Fort William, in the Scottish Highlands,
in 1966. Two-thirds of the timber it uses is home-grown.
There are a few very large groups in the industry and many medium-sized
and small firms. The large groups hold considerable interests abroad, includ¬
ing pulp and paper producing mills in the United States, Canada and other
parts of the Commonwealth and Europe. Sales of household paper products,
including facial tissues, have risen sharply. Sales of cardboard boxes and
cartons were valued at ^107-8 million in 1966 while those of fibre board pack¬
ing cases totalled £98-6 million. Sales of manufactured stationery totalled
^89-9 million in 1966. Wallpaper manufacturing is dominated by one firm; a
recent development has been the introduction of plastic and plastic-
coated wall coverings. Research is undertaken by the Paper and Board Industry
Research Association and the Printing and Allied Trades Research
Association.
The printing industry produces an immense range of goods, from national
newspapers and periodicals to books, catalogues and greetings cards. The
industry includes many very small enterprises. Mergers in recent years have
led to the formation of large groups in the newspaper, magazine and book
publishing sections. Four large firms each employ more than 7,500 persons.
General printing, publishing, engraving and bookbinding remains essentially
an industry of small firms.
Publishers’ turnover in 1966 amounted to £120 million, of which export
sales accounted for a record total of £51 million, forming a higher proportion
of output than in any other country. Consumers’ expenditure on books, news¬
papers and magazines totalled £339 million in 1965* Book titles published in
1966 totalled over 28,000, nearly 22,000 of them new ones. Popularity of
paper-backed books has increased rapidly in recent years. According to the
overseas trade returns, exports of printed matter, manuscripts and typescripts
were valued at £51-4 million in 1966, including books (£26-5 million), and
newspapers and periodicals (^7‘4 niillion), but these figures do not include
parcel post shipments, which are possibly as large again as the recorded totals.
The United States and Australia are the most important overseas markets.
The Book Development Council was formed in 1965 to promote the supply
and use of British books overseas. Firms have introduced the latest develop¬
ments in high-speed printing equipment, including electronic engraving
machines and advanced processes of photographic reproduction, and some
newspapers are now set by computer.
Other manufacturing industries include the timber and furniture group, with
299,000 employees, rubber manufacture, with 134,000 employees, and a group
of miscellaneous manufactures which together embrace some 211,000

employees, including 95,000 employees engaged in plastics moulding and
fabricating.
Britain’s rubber manufacturing industry is the oldest in the world, dating
from 1819. Macintosh invented waterproof garments, and Dunlop in 1888
devised the pneumatic tyre. Tyres and tubes represent more than half the
total output of the industry but firms also make a great variety of other rubber
manufactures, the most important being rubber footwear, conveyor belting,
cables, hose, and latex foam products.
The British industry is one of the largest in the world. In 1966 its consump¬
tion of rubber totalled 404,000 tons, comprising 181,000 tons of natural
rubber, 191,000 tons of synthetic rubber and 32,000 tons of reclaimed rubber;
the proportion of synthetic rubber used is increasing. In 1966, 212,000 tons
of rubber were used in the production of tyres and tyre products. Tyre
manufacturers include several subsidiaries of United States and other
overseas companies. Tyres and tubes exported were valued at ^26-4 million;
this figure excludes large indirect exports on vehicles. Direct exports of all
rubber manufactures (including tyres) in 1966 were worth -£47-9 million,
with Sweden, Australia, Denmark and the Federal Republic of Germany as
the main markets. In addition, the industry in 1966 exported about ^16-6
million worth of rubber footwear and £17 million of rubber gloves and other
miscellaneous products.
London is the largest centre for furniture manufacturing, but High Wycombe,
in Buckinghamshire, is an important centre for domestic furniture.
Deliveries of domestic furniture rose by 23 per cent in volume between
1958 and 1966, and in the latter year their value was £157 million. Exports of
all furniture were worth XI4'9 million in 1966. There are numerous enter¬
prises manufacturing furniture in Britain (including domestic, upholstered,
office, school and other furniture) with a total labour force of 95,600. The
bedding industry employs 16,800 people; sales of new bedding in 1966 were
valued at £33-3 million. Many firms are small but in recent years there has
been a tendency towards concentration.
Scientific research and technical information services are provided by the
Furniture Development Council and the Furniture Industry Research
Association. The Council is concerned with the management problems of the
industry and produces an annual statistical and economic review.
The brush industry is located throughout Britain, and embraces highly
mechanised establishments as well as small craft units. The value of sales in
1966 was £21-2 million, of which £2-5 million was for export.
The timber industry employs 100,000 people. Britain is mainly dependent
on imported supplies of timber (valued at ^194 million in 1966) but sawmill
output of home-grown timber totalled 21-4 million cubic feet in 1966. Other
products include plywood and chipboard.
The number of people engaged in manufacturing toys and sports equipment
in Britain is 41,000. Sales of toys in 1966 were worth £59-8 million and
exports had a value of £15-5 million. The United States and the Federal
Republic of Germany were the main overseas markets. Current trends are
towards increased production of small-scale precision models of vehicles (over
100 million a year are produced) and toys linked to television characters.
The value of manufacturers’ sales of games was £5-4 million and that of
sports equipment ^17-8 million, of which ^6-7 million was for export.
12 Agriculture, Fisheries
and Forestry
AGRICULTURE
Although Britain is a densely populated, industrialised country relying on
imports for half its food supply, agriculture remains one of its largest and
most important industries. It occupies about 800,000 people in Great Britain
or just over 3 per cent of those in civil employment, provides about 3 per
cent of the gross national product, and uses 48 million of the 60 million acres
of land.
In Northern Ireland 2-7 million of the 3-3 million acres of land are in
agricultural use, and the corresponding proportions for employment and
gross output are 13 per cent and 15 per cent.
Land used for farming is conventionally divided into improved land suitable
for cultivation (crops and grass) and rough grazing, nearly all of which is
hill or mountain land with a native herbage of coarse grasses, rushes, bracken,
heather or scrub trees. Rough grazing has a low potential output—usually
assessed at about one-sixth of that of agricultural land—but is valuable for
sheep. In England and Wales only about one-sixth of farming land is classified
as rough grazing. In Northern Ireland the proportion is about one-quarter,
but in Scotland it is about three-quarters. In the United Kingdom as a whole
there are 31 million acres under crops and grass. Improved land and rough
grazing together represent 81 per cent of the land area. The rest is mountain
and forest, or put to urban and kindred uses. The area available for farming
is gradually decreasing to meet the needs of housing and industry; however,
the loss is more than outweighed by the increase in output from what remains.
The soils of the country are extremely varied. Many of those in the west
and north, overlying hard rocks, are poor and thin. The lowlands and river
valleys are usually fertile, varying in texture from clay to sandy loam, silt
and peat. Clay soils everywhere necessitate under-drainage, and as all are
constantly leached by rainwater, lime has to be applied at regular intervals.
In hill country the area of improved land is often small, but is usually supple¬
mented by grazing on a comparatively large area of hill land.
Size and For many centuries the bulk of land in Britain lay in estates ranging in size
Ownership from a few hundred acres upwards, comprising farms of varying sizes let to
of Farms tenants. Social changes of the past half-century have completely changed the
pattern of rural life in England and Scotland. Estate duties have been a
principal factor in the breaking up of estates. Most surviving estates are still
owned by private individuals or family trusts, but the Crown, local authorities,
and other corporate bodies hold considerable areas. Of the farms sold, many
have been bought by the tenants already in occupation. About half the farms
in Great Britain today are owner-occupied.
There are about 440,000 agricultural holdings in the United Kingdom,
giving an average size of about no acres. Slightly over half are part-time
holdings, the occupiers generally having another source of livelihood besides
THE LAND AND
ITS USES
Types of

AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 315
farming. A recent survey has shown that there are about 220,000 full-time
holdings, and about half the industry’s total output comes from the 42,000
holdings classified as large ‘commercial’ farm businesses. A further 66,000
fall within the category of small ‘commercial’ businesses, which are able to
operate as viable enterprises. Of the remaining 112,000 full-time holdings,
farming is in general on too restricted a scale for commercial viability, and
amalgamations are being encouraged.
The average size of full-time holdings in England and Wales is between
M5 and 15° acres of crops and grass. In Scotland the crops and grass area of
the 29,000 farms worked on a part- or spare-time basis averages only 12 acres,
but for the 27,000 full-time farms the average is 147 acres.
In Northern Ireland the land is divided into about 67,000 holdings, almost
all of which are owner-occupied. About 40 per cent of these holdings are
either very small or let in conacre (seasonal lettings for crops or grazing), so
that the number of effective farm businesses is about 41,000, of which rather
more than half provide a full-time occupation for the owner. The typical
farm size is between 40 and 70 acres of crops and grass.
Most British farms produce a variety of products; the pattern varies from
farm to farm. In England the farms devoted primarily to arable crops are
in the eastern part of the country, in East Anglia, Kent, Lincolnshire, and
the East Riding of Yorkshire. Potato and vegetable growing on a substantial
scale marks the farming of the Fens (south Lincolnshire and Cambridgeshire),
the alluvial areas around the rivers Thames and Humber and the peaty
lands in south Lancashire. Elsewhere, horticultural crops are widely dispersed
amongst agricultural crops. In Scotland the rich lowlands of the east coast
are also primarily arable.
Interspersed between these arable areas, and also in the Midlands, the
south-east of England and the north-east of Scotland, there are large tracts
where, although much of the land is kept under the plough, the rearing and
fattening of cattle is an important enterprise. In the south-west of Scotland
dairying is extensively practised, but most of the north-west is devoted to
rearing sheep on rough hill land. The parts of England bordering the Pennine
hills and most of Wales are also sheep-rearing areas, though a good deal of
dairying, based on purchased feedingstuffs, is also done there. Dairy farming
is widely practised throughout much of the rest of Britain. In Northern
Ireland mixed farming is practised, the most important products being milk,
fat and store cattle, pigs and eggs, with sheep and stock raising in the hill
areas. Oats and barley are widely grown, mainly for livestock feeding, and the
only important cash crop is potatoes, both ware and seed.
There are three main categories of grassland in the United Kingdom—
temporary grass, permanent grass and rough grazing. Temporary grass may
be part of an arable rotation, providing a break of from one to seven years
between tillage crops, or it may be part of an all-grass system where its
advantages over permanent grass are that it can provide early and late season
grazing and often heavier crops.
Since the end of the second world war there has been an increase of about
1 million acres in the area of temporary grass and the total arable area is
about 5^ million acres more than it was pre-war. In England and Wales nearly
one-half of the 24 million acres of crops and grass (excluding over 3 million
acres of rough grazing) is under permanent grass, nearly one-third under
cereals and one-sixth under temporary grass. About three-quarters of all

agricultural land in Scotland is in rough grazing and of the 4-3 million acres
of crops and grass about one-fifth is in permanent and two-fifths in temporary
grass. Excluding about 640,000 acres of rough grazing the crops and grass
area of Northern Ireland is about 2 million acres, of which over half is under
permanent and nearly one-third under temporary grass.
Farmers everywhere are exposed to the vagaries of the weather, of pests and
diseases, and of the market; but over the past 30 years much has been done
in Britain to mitigate these risks. This has been partly due to the advance of
science, partly to self-help by farmers’ organisations, but largely to govern¬
ment action. The role of the Government as guarantor and provider of techni¬
cal and advisory services, is described on pp. 323-32.
The steady expansion in productivity which has taken place over the last 25
years is summarised in Table 20. Total cattle stocks rose steadily each year
between 1953 and 1961, but over the next three years showed a slight decline
and are only now beginning again to increase. The milk-producing herd
reached its peak level in 1962, thereafter suffering a temporary decline with
some recovery in 1965 and 1966. Numbers of sheep and lambs have shown
a fairly steady increase each year, while pigs and poultry have undergone a
considerable expansion over the past decade. Production of wheat at some
4 million tons a year has more than doubled since the end of the second
world war, while barley output at nearly 9 million tons a year is now o\er
four times the 1946 figure. There has been a marked fall in the production of
oats, and a smaller but significant drop in potatoes, a crop whose yield is
particularly prone to severe weather fluctuations. Between 1955 and 1966
output of pigmeat increased by nearly one-third, and eggs by nearly one-half,
and these, together with the increase in beef and milk output, resulted in
higher consumption of feedingstuffs, mostly from home resources. Imports of
concentrated feeds have in fact fallen slightly in recent years, from 6-i million
tons in 1960-61 to 5-9 million tons in 1966-67.
The index of agricultural net output (all holdings) at constant prices has
risen steadily. By 1953-54 it was about 56 per cent above the immediate
pre-war average. Using the average of i954—55 t° I95^—57=IO° as basis, it
reached 112 in 1959-60, 137 in I9^4_b5 an<^ in 1965-66; 135 is forecast
for 1966-67.
Since 1939 the population of the United Kingdom has increased by over
6| million, or about 14 per cent. In spite of this growth Britain now produces
about half of its total food requirements or two-thirds of all that can be grown
in temperate climates; this latter figure comparing with about one-half before
the second world war. Home production of the principal foods is shown as a
percentage by weight of total supplies in Table 21.
Table 22 shows how the level of the main food supplies passing into
consumption has changed since before the second world war and within the
last decade. The main trends reflected in the table are that consumption of
bulky foods (carbohydrates), such as flour and potatoes, tends to decline,
while that of high-protein foods, such as meat and eggs, continues to increase
with greater availability and rising living standards.
The possibilities of wheat growing, which is mainly confined to England,
have been changed radically by the advent of new strong strawed and heavy
yielding varieties, mainly from Europe. These permit the liberal use of

fertilisers, and spring dressings of nitrogen have become accepted practice.
Crop yields of 2 tons per acre are no longer unusual. Almost 3-5 million tons
were harvested in 1966, with yields averaging 31-2 cwt. per acre.
There are two distinct markets for barley—for malting and for feeding to
stock. Malting barley commands a higher price than feeding grain, but the
disparity has now decreased. New varieties have greatly enlarged yields.
Since i960 the acreage under barley increased by over 80 per cent and
production has doubled.
The widespread use of combine harvesters has necessitated the installation
of drying and storage facilities on many farms. Such equipment is also widely
used on a co-operative basis.
In England and Wales the total acreage of fodder crops continues to decline
because in many cases farmers can provide winter feed more economically
Sugar Beet
Potatoes
Dairy Farming
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 319
by increased grass production and improved methods of conservation. In
Scotland the decline in the acreage of fodder crops has been less rapid and
the acreage of turnips and swedes is now greater than in England.
Beet is grown mainly in East Anglia and Lincolnshire where most of the beet
sugar factories are situated. The crop is grown under contract to the British
Sugar Corporation, which takes the entire output at guaranteed prices and
also provides technical advice and assistance. Precision drilling is the usual
method of sowing and more than three-quarters of the crop is mechanically
harvested.
Early potatoes are grown in England and Wales in numerous, widely scattered
districts with favourable soils and climate. The crop is marketed during the
summer months and reaches the consumer within a few days of lifting. Main
crop varieties, which are normally stored before sale, are grown chiefly in the
Fen counties, Essex, Lincolnshire and Yorkshire. In Scotland, early potatoes
are grown in coastal areas of Ayrshire and Wigtownshire, main crop
potatoes being grown mostly on the eastern side of the country; a substantial
part of the industry is concerned with supplying seed potatoes to English
and foreign growers. In Northern Ireland both ware and seed potatoes are
produced, and about one-quarter of the crop is shipped to Great Britain and
abroad. The long-term trend is for the area planted with potatoes in the
United Kingdom to diminish and for yields to increase. The acreage has
declined from 829,000 acres in i960 to an estimated 670,000 acres in 1966.
The yield in 1966 was 9-7 tons per acre compared with the record of io-i tons
per acre in 1965. Although cultivation and harvesting is largely mechanical
much hand labour is still necessary for planting and grading.
Milk is much more valuable when sold on the liquid milk market than when
converted into cheese, butter or other milk products. In Great Britain milk
is produced primarily for liquid consumption, but in Northern Ireland the
greater part of the milk is used for manufactured products. Production and
liquid sales are now much greater than before the war. The average consump¬
tion per head is now about 5 pints per week.
Average yields per dairy cow have increased during the last decade by more
than 15 per cent and now average over 800 gallons a year. Freedom from
tuberculosis has reduced herd wastage, and through the artificial insemination
(AI) centres, operated by the Milk Marketing Boards and other organisations,
the influence of a small number of high-potential bulls is widely disseminated.
It is estimated that about two-thirds of Britain’s total cattle are bred by AI.
The Friesian breed is dominant in the dairy herds of England, Wales and
Northern Ireland, but in Scotland the Ayrshire breed is the most numerous.
Milk production has also been stimulated by advances in grassland manage¬
ment, intensive grazing techniques and new methods of making high
quality hay; new methods of conversion into silage are being exploited. Most
dairy farmers practise some degree of intensive grass management, but hay of
the traditional type remains the basic winter feedingstuff; it is supplemented
with purchased concentrates.
Clean dairy farming methods and hygienic standards for equipment and
buildings used in milk production are prescribed by regulations made and
enforced by the appropriate ministers.
Livestock
A great number of specialised breeds of livestock have been developed over
the centuries in Britain. It has been found that they meet the needs of breeders
3 20
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Beef Cattle
Sheep
Pigs
Poultry
in most countries and substantial export sales are made to buyers seeking
to replenish and improve their herds with British animals.
The majority of consumers no longer want joints from fully fattened beasts.
The average age of slaughter is about two years. Systems of semi-intensive or
intensive beef production were being increasingly adopted in the early 1960s
but their use is now declining. In the hill regions hardy herds of beef cattle
are kept, especially of the Galloway breed and its crosses; in marginal land
and lower areas the sires used are predominantly of the Aberdeen Angus,
Beef Shorthorn and Hereford breeds. Nowadays much beef derives from the
dairy herds, some females being mated to beef sires, the majority by AI.
There is a large and complex trade in store cattle (increased by animals
imported from the Irish Republic) whose general movement is from the
upland west to grazing areas in the Midlands and arable areas in the east.
Britain has outstandingly good pastures for sheep. Moreover, veterinary
research has provided vaccine and sera protection against nearly all the
epidemic diseases to which sheep are subject. More than 30 breeds and
innumerable crosses are to be found in Britain, each breed having originated
within a circumscribed area.
In the hills, and especially in the Highlands, winter conditions are usually
severe. Draft ewes and lambs are brought from the hill areas every autumn
to swell the lowland flocks, usually in two stages: firstly, to farms at inter¬
mediate altitudes, where they are mated with rams of a larger and more
rapidly maturing breed; then, the cross-bred progeny pass on in due course
to the more genial lowland conditions and especially to the Midlands and the
south and east of England, where they become crossed again with Down
rams for fat lamb production. The hill breeds bring in hardiness and the
lowland sires fecundity and early maturity.
Although wool is of considerable importance to the sheep farmer and
research into breeding for wool is being undertaken, the prime purpose of
British sheep farming today is the production of fat lambs, in response to the
change in the preference of consumers away from mature sheep.
Pig production is a complex enterprise, owing to the varying uses to which
the carcase is put. In Britain the carcase is used in three different ways:
for curing as bacon, for sale in fresh condition as pork, and for sausages or
other processed forms. Consumption per head, as pork, is now more than
double the pre-war level. For the several trades, pigs of three different weight
ranges seem to be called for but leanness is desirable in all three. Breeders,
in the main, aim at the long type required by bacon curers, for which there is
a classification system based on weight, carcase measurements of length
and back-fat. The Large White and Landrace breeds yield carcases which
meet the requirements of both the bacon and the pork trades.
Apart from type, breeders’ attention is now focused on utility qualities,
such as size and weight of litters, and on food consumed per pound of
liveweight gain. Litter recording and the performance and progeny testing
schemes for boars operated by the Pig Industry Development Authority are
providing basic data. The functions of this authority, which was set up under
the Agriculture Act 1957 to promote improvement in the production of pigs
and in the processing and distribution of pigmeat, are being taken over by
the Meat and Livestock Commission (see p. 330).
The organisation of the poultry industry has changed very considerably over
the past 20 years. Specialist techniques and intensive husbandry have been
introduced over a large part of the industry and considerable concentration has
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY
Horticultural
Crops
321
occurred. There are now several flocks of over 100,000 birds and only a
small proportion of total production is in the hands of the smallest producers.
More than two-thirds of the laying birds on farms are in flocks of 1,000 or
more. With the rise in the poultry population and in the yield of eggs per bird
(now averaging over 200 eggs a year), the estimated production of eggs has
more than doubled the 1938 level and for several years nearly all eggs con¬
sumed in Britain have been home-produced.
Within the industry the trend is towards specialisation in the breeding and
supply of stock and in the production of eggs and table poultry. The mass
production of special table chickens, or ‘broilers’—about 185 million were
produced in 1966—has become a major industry.
Horticultural crops occupy only a small fraction of the cultivated land of
the country—about 21 per cent of the area under crops and grass—but
their value in terms of output per acre is very high. The total value of
horticultural crops sold in 1966-67 is estimated at about £188 million,
compared with some £374 million for farm crops in the United Kingdom.
About 370,000 acres are under vegetables and about 240,000 acres under fruit.
Market gardening has grown up around all the large centres of population,
notably in the Lea Valley, near London. It has also flourished in more rural
areas with favourable soil or climatic conditions—in Bedfordshire, Cambridge¬
shire, Hampshire and Kent, and in a concentration of smallholdings around
Evesham, in the Avon valley. Districts with mild climates, such as the
Penzance region of Cornwall, have been favoured for the production of
selected early crops. More recently, selected vegetable crops have been grown
in increasing quantities by farmers as an alternative to potatoes.
Specialised horticultural holdings range from a few acres up to about
300 acres, and many have glasshouses, frames or forcing houses. Use of
fertilisers, particularly of an organic nature, is very heavy, and much of the
field work is mechanised. The larger holdings normally have specialised
packing sheds, with washing and grading machinery, and irrigation plants.
More and more growers, however, are coming together in co-operatives for
marketing their produce and many of these co-operatives provide grading
and packing facilities for members.
Britain has some 4,000 acres of glasshouses, about half of the area being
used primarily for the cultivation of tomatoes, the main centres of which
are the Lea Valley in Essex and Hertfordshire, and the Worthing district
in Sussex. In the Lea Valley, on a narrow belt of gravel and brick earth, over
500 acres are covered with glass. Production of tomatoes in the country is
estimated at about 75,000-80,000 tons annually and the value of all glasshouse
crops (including flowers) at some £35 million to £40 million per year.
Hard fruits grow well in many parts of England and Wales, the chief risk
associated with their culture being late frosts. The main centres are in the
south, south-west and east of England, and Kent in particular. Production
of apples has been about equally divided between cooking and dessert varieties,
with Cox’s Orange Pippin heading the latter group, but production of cooking
apples is declining. About 27,000 acres of varieties of cider apple are grown
mainly in Devon, Herefordshire and Somerset for the cider-making industry.
In Northern Ireland there are 7,000 acres of cooking apples—Bramley
Seedlings—mostly concentrated in County Armagh. Plums and soft fruits
are grown in many counties; concentrations of plums are found in Kent
and Worcestershire, of blackcurrants in Norfolk, Kent and Hereford, of
cherries in Kent and of strawberries in Norfolk, Kent and Hampshire.
322
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Raspberries are exceptional in that of some 8,200 acres grown in Britain nearly
three-quarters are in Scotland, mainly in the Blairgowrie district of Perthshire
and in Angus.
Hop-growing for the brewing industry is confined to two main areas, in
Kent and Sussex and in Herefordshire and Worcestershire. Capital outlay
and cultivation costs are very high, but crops per acre average about 12 cwt.,
worth some ,£455. The total annual value of the crop is about ^8f million.
FARM
EXPENDITURE
AND EARNINGS
Estimates of farm expenses and sales and the aggregate net income of agri¬
cultural producers are prepared annually by the agricultural departments
(see Table 23).
The estimates show that Britain’s farming is based on livestock; two-thirds
of farmers’ income in Britain is derived from the sale of animals or their
products. The aggregate net income of farmers rose from £394 million
in 1960-61 to £472 million in 1966-67. The annual cost of government
support to the industry has averaged £270 million during this past five
years.
Growing items of farm outlay are machinery and equipment, amounting
currently to about one-sixth of total expenses. Feedingstuffs amount to
almost one-third. Since 1956 wages have risen by nearly 70 per cent, offsetting
the lower costs resulting from the reduction in manpower made possible by
mechanisation.
Until 1958 rents tended to lag behind other costs. This was due partly to
the reluctance of landlords to put up the rents of satisfactory tenants, and
partly to the terms of reference given to arbitrators. These terms were
modified in the Agriculture Act 1958 and since i960 rents in England and
Wales have gone up by about two-thirds.

AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY
Capital

Net Incomes
THE ROLE
OF THE
GOVERNMENT
323
The capital required for land and buildings may be provided by the farmer,
if he is an owner-occupier, or by the landlord, if the farm is let to a tenant.
Each year fixed capital totalling about ^7° million is added to the value of
land and buildings (annual gross investment in fixed assets exceeds £175
million). The bulk of the capital required to stock and run the farms is
provided by the occupiers. Bank advances are an increasingly important
source of outside capital, both fixed and working; about half the total bank
advances to agriculture are believed to be for short-term purposes. Agricultural
merchants are also an important source of short-term credit.
Accounts of some 2,200 farms in England and Wales, analysed by university
agricultural economists, show average valuations of occupiers’ capital ranging
from £10 to £35 per acre. In Scotland a similar sample of 800 accounts shows
a wide range in tenants’ capital per acre, from about £3 on hill sheep farms
with extensive rough grazings to between £50 and £60 per acre on lower
ground farms. In Northern Ireland average valuations of occupiers’ capital
range from £80 on the smaller, more intensive farms to £40 per acre on the
larger farms. On all types of farms investment in machinery is a heavy item:
on dairy farms it is often 3^18 per acre and on arable farms up to £22 per acre;
on stock-rearing farms it may amount to £9 per acre.
Britain has one of the heaviest tractor densities in the world, with half a million
tractors in 1967, or one to every 35 acres of arable land. Power-take-off
implements now characterise arable farming; and some 65,000 combine
harvesters were in use in 1966. A wide variety of machines for harvesting and
preservation of grass are employed. Milking machines are installed on all
except the smallest farms, many with mechanical means of handling milk.
Over 90 per cent of the farms in Great Britain have an electricity supply
and accompanying equipment. There are some 1,300 farmers’ machinery
syndicates through which farmers have the use of expensive equipment
without tying up their own capital.
Research, development and testing of farm machinery are carried out at
the National Institute of Agricultural Engineering in Bedfordshire. This
Institute developed the first farm tractor in the world employing hydrostatic
transmission and also one of the most effective complete potato-harvesters
now in production.
The range of net incomes between individual farms is very wide, varying with
the type and size of farm, quality of land, and managerial ability of the
occupier. The average net income for farms of different types usually varies
from about £5 to £15 per acre and generally there is a tendency for small
farms to show higher profits per acre than large ones, reflecting the more
intensive pattern of farming on small farms.
Profits per acre on arable farms have, with occasional seasonal exceptions,
been maintained at a higher level than on other types; dairy farming has
shown consistently increasing profits, coming near to arable farming in some
years, but profits per acre on stock-rearing farms have usually been lower—
these farms are generally larger than the other types, and are situated on poorer
land.
By the beginning of the 1930s the need for some form of State assistance
to agriculture had become pressing; it was during this time that the
Government initiated the various forms of protection and financial assistance
for agriculture.
324 BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
During the second world war and the immediate post-war years, agri¬
cultural production was closely controlled by the State, with County War
Agricultural Executive Committees, composed of landowners, farmers and
farm workers, acting as the Government’s local agents.
Government Government policy today is founded on the Agriculture Act 1947* The
Policy main objective, as set out in Section 1 of the Act, continues to be ‘a stable
and efficient agricultural industry capable of producing such part of the
nation’s food and other agricultural produce as in the national interest it is
desirable to produce in the United Kingdom, and of producing it at minimum
prices consistent with proper remuneration and living conditions for farmers
and workers in agriculture and an adequate return on capital invested in
the industry’. To this end, the Government is empowered to provide, for
the main agricultural products, guaranteed prices determined in the light of
annual reviews (see p. 325).
Post-war policy falls broadly into two periods, with the dividing line about
1954. During the first, the chief aim was to encourage expansion and a return
to something like the traditional pattern of British farming. With the ending
of the period of scarcity, policy has put stress on more economic production
of food of the kinds and qualities demanded by the market.
The Agriculture Act of 1957 assured farmers that the prices guaranteed
under the 1947 Act would not be steeply reduced, and at the same time
provided grants towards the cost of bringing fixed equipment up to date.
The Agriculture and Horticulture Act 1964 gave the Government powers
to introduce minimum import prices for agricultural and horticultural
products. These powers have been used in the case of cereals. In the same
year an understanding with overseas suppliers on the sharing of the bacon
market became effective.
Under the selective expansion programme announced in 1965 the agri¬
cultural industry is expected to increase production to meet the major part
of the growth in demand for temperate foodstuffs by 197° an<^ release
substantial manpower resources. The main emphasis in expansion is on the
production of meat, particularly beef. A substantial part of the increased
demand for cereal feed would be grown at home.
Machinery of The functions of government in relation to agriculture are mostly exercised
Government by the agricultural ministers, that is to say, for England and Wales the Minister
of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, for Scotland the Secretary of State for
Scotland, and for Northern Ireland the Home Secretary, who is the minister
responsible for United Kingdom aspects of Northern Ireland agriculture,
local aspects being the responsibility of the Northern Ireland Minister of
Agriculture. The agricultural ministers are assisted by a number of advisory
committees composed of general agriculturists and specialists.
The headquarters of the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food is
divided functionally, each division being responsible for a particular subject
or service. Its relations with individual farmers are conducted mainly through
its local offices, grouped in England in regions, each administered by a
regional controller working in close collaboration with the regional heads of the
technical services. Local offices in Wales are grouped under a Welsh Secretary
with similar functions and with special responsibility for Welsh affairs.
In Scotland most of the agricultural functions of the Secretary of State are
discharged through the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries. The
Secretary of State for Scotland also appoints the members of the Crofters
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 325
Commission and the Red Deer Commission, which deals with the conservation
and control of red deer.
The Northern Ireland Ministry of Agriculture is responsible for imple¬
menting agricultural policy inaugurated by the Northern Ireland Government.
It is organised on similar lines to the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and
Food, for which it acts as agent in the administration in Northern Ireland
of United Kingdom agricultural schemes.
In November 1966 an Economic Development Committee (see p. 246) for
agriculture was established, comprising representatives of farmers, workers
and landowners, as well as official members.
CURRENT
SUPPORT POLICY
Annual Review
In February each year, in accordance with the 1947 Act, the agricultural
ministers review the economic condition and prospects of the industry.
Between annual reviews, a special review may be held if the ministers consider
it warranted, but this has seldom been necessary. In holding reviews, the
ministers are required to consult with representatives of agricultural pro¬
ducers—in practice, the three farmers’ unions in the United Kingdom. The
ministers consider such factors as production trends and market requirements,
world market prospects, the cost of subsidies, the trend of profits in the
industry as a whole, the increasing efficiency of the industry and changes in
production costs, trading relations (especially with the Commonwealth) and
the national economic situation. In the light of their conclusions, they
determine guaranteed prices for fat cattle, fat sheep, fat pigs, eggs, wool,
milk, cereals, potatoes and sugar beet. These guarantees apply to livestock
and livestock products for the ensuing 12 months, and to crops to be
harvested in the current year. Various grants in aid of particular kinds of
production or farming practice (known as ‘production grants’) are also
considered. Any changes in ‘relevant’ production grants (broadly, those
payable to occupiers rather than landowners) are taken into account. The
Government’s conclusions and its decisions on changes in guaranteed prices
and relevant production grants are published as a White Paper.
The long-term assurances provided for in the 1957 Act require the total
value of the guaranteed prices and relevant production grants in any year to be
maintained at not less than 97^ per cent of their value in the preceding year,
after allowing for changes in costs. In addition, the guaranteed price (adjusted
for any change in the basis of the guarantee) for each commodity must be
not less than 96 per cent of that of the previous year. For livestock and live¬
stock products—where farmers’ decisions need time to take effect—there is
a further provision that reductions in the guaranteed price for any product
must not total more than 9 per cent in a period of three years. The cost of
government support to the industry in 1966-67 was about ^228 million; the
estimate for 1967—68, adjusted for the effect of the 1967 review decisions,
forecast an increase to about £287 million.
Price
Guarantees
The general policy of the Government is to use methods of agricultural
support that allow the ordinary channels of trade to flow freely. The form of
guarantee most generally used is the deficiency payment, which means that
the Government makes payments to producers, related to the differences
between the average market price realised and the guaranteed price, for
output eligible for the guarantee.
The deficiency payments schemes for cereals and fatstock are administered
directly by the agricultural departments. New arrangements, first introduced
for the 1961-62 season, provided growers with an incentive to hold barley
326
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Production
Grants
until later in the season. ‘Standard quantity’1 arrangements for wheat and
barley were introduced for the 1964 crop* Deficiency payments for fatstock
are made weekly to individual producers on certified sales on a liveweight or
deadweight basis but there may also be a second payment at the end of the
year for cattle and sheep.
For most of the remaining commodities the Government operates the
guarantee through the appropriate marketing board, which takes account of
any payments from or to the Government in deciding what to pay producers
for their produce. In the case of milk there are five boards, and the full
guaranteed price is paid only on a ‘standard quantity’ relating to the volume
of liquid milk sales plus a reasonable reserve. Milk produced in excess of
the standard quantity is sold for manufacturing considerably below the full
guaranteed price. The retail price of liquid milk is determined by the
Government so as to cover the full cost of the guarantee and, taking one year
with another, there is no Exchequer subsidy. For eggs, a subsidy is paid to
the British Egg Marketing Board on all first-quality eggs sold to the Board
through packing stations. A deficiency payment is made for potatoes in years
in which the growers’ average price for potatoes for human consumption
(excluding new potatoes) is less than the guaranteed price; payment is made
to the Potato Marketing Board for the benefit of growers in Great Britain
and to the Ministry of Agriculture, Northern Ireland, for the benefit of
growers there.
For wool a fixed price is guaranteed to the British Wool Marketing Board
for every pound of fleece wool it buys from producers. This enables it to
fix in advance a schedule of producers’ prices, based on types and quality,
after making allowance for the Board’s marketing costs.
Under the Sugar Act 1956 and the Agriculture Act 1957 the British
Sugar Corporation contracts to buy the whole of the sugar beet crop produced
from a specified acreage (at present 443,000 acres) at a scale of fixed prices,
determined as a result of the annual review and related to sugar content.
Refined sugar produced by the Corporation is sold, under market-sharing
agreements with the refiners, at a price based on the world price.
The Sugar Board buys Commonwealth sugar under the Commonwealth
Sugar Agreement and sells it commercially. The deficits or surpluses which
result from the transactions of both the Corporation and the Board are
ultimately reflected in the Board’s accounts. When these accounts show a
deficit a levy is charged on all sugar, imported or home-produced, entering
the United Kingdom market, including the sugar content of composite sugar
imports, and when there is a surplus a distribution payment is made corre¬
spondingly, so that taking one year with another the Board balances its account.
The price supports outlined above relate only to current production. To
increase productivity, however, the Government offers to farmers a wide
range of inducements, known as production grants, for improvements to land,
crops, livestock and equipment. In 1966-67 the Exchequer’s contribution in
the form of production grants was ^107 million. The form taken by these
1 The Agriculture Act 1947 postulates that the guarantees should be related to the
volume of agricultural produce which, in the national interest, it is desirable to produce
domestically (see p. 324). This is effected by including ‘standard quantities’ in the
guarantee arrangements for milk, pigs, barley, wheat, potatoes and sugar beet.
‘Standard quantity’ agreements vary in form but, in general, the basic guaranteed price
determined in the Annual Review is related to a specific quantity of produce marketed
annually on a national basis; if this quantity is exceeded, the producers’ average unit
return falls.
Amalgamations
of Small Farms
Horticulture
Investment

OTHER
GOVERNMENT
ASSISTANCE
AND ACTION
Agricultural
Credit
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 327
schemes varies considerably but they fall into three main categories. Firstly,
improvements to land fertility, which include a subsidy on fertilisers and
lime and grants for drainage and water supply; the Exchequer cost of these
improvements currently runs at nearly £48 million a year. The second type
of inducement is aimed at maintaining and improving breeding herds of
cattle and sheep (particularly in upland areas) and includes a calf subsidy on
animals destined for the beef herds; the total cost is about £46 million a year.
The third type consists of a contribution towards farm improvements
generally but with particular reference to farm buildings, silage, roads,
drainage, fences and other equipment. A special business management
scheme exists to help small farmers improve the efficiency of their holdings.
A grant is also available to farmers and growers to encourage the keeping of
farm business records as an aid to sound management decisions. Under the
Agriculture Act 1967 a hill land improvement scheme was introduced which
provides for 50 per cent grants for various improvements designed to increase
the productivity of hill land.
Under the Agriculture Act 1967 the Government is empowered to make
grants to meet 50 per cent of the approved costs of voluntary amalgamations
of small farms with other land to form commercial units; and to pay lump
sums or annuities to farmers who give up such holdings for amalgamation,
Where an owner wishes to dispose of an uncommercial holding the Govern¬
ment may buy it outright for this purpose.
Horticultural produce, because it is perishable and liable to seasonal variation
in quantity and quality, does not lend itself to a system of guaranteed prices.
Hitherto the principal means of support has been tariffs on imports, but
greater emphasis is now being placed on the need to strengthen the com¬
petitive efficiency of the industry so as to reduce its dependence upon the
tariffs. To this end grants of one-third are available to meet the capital cost
of a wide range of buildings, plant and equipment used in the production,
storage, preparation for market and transport of horticultural produce.
Additionally, small-scale horticulturists who are prepared to undertake a
three-year programme for improving the efficiency of their businesses may
qualify for a grant of up to £500. The cost to the Exchequer of these schemes
is about million a year.
Special arrangements for the agricultural and horticultural industries have
been made under the investment incentives procedure which replaced invest¬
ment allowances in 1966. Broadly speaking, the Minister of Agriculture is
empowered to pay grants of 10 per cent of approved expenditure on fixed
equipment, plant and machinery, and agricultural tractors, and 5 per cent
supplements to other improvement grants with a basic rate of 45 per cent
or less. For expenditure incurred between January 1967 and December 1968
grants will be paid at 15 per cent for tractors and self-propelled harvesters,
and at 12^ per cent for fixed equipment.
A number of facilities for specific purposes enjoy government encouragement
and support.
In England and Wales finance for the purchase or improvement of agri¬
cultural property is available from the Agricultural Mortgage Corporation
Ltd. (see p. 390). The Corporation’s funds are derived mainly from public
issues of stock, but it receives a measure of government support. Similarly
