BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Advisory Bodies
RAILWAYS
Organisation
under Public
Ownership
Operations
Under the Transport Finances Act 1966 the limit on the Government
subsidy to the British Railways Board, previously £450 million to the end of
1967, was raised to £800 million to the end of 1968. The Act also enabled the
Government to pay a £16 million subsidy to the London Transport Board
over the same period.
A Nationalised Transport Advisory Council of up to 12 members advises
the Minister on questions relating to the co-ordination and other aspects of
the nationalised transport undertakings. Another body, the Transport
Tribunal, sits in two divisions, one having jurisdiction over changes of London
road and rail fares and the other hearing appeals relating to applications for
road haulage licences. The Area Transport Users’ Consultative Committee,
originally set up under the 1947 Transport Act to consider complaints and
suggested improvements of nationalised transport services, now participates
in the statutory procedure which the Railways Board and the London Trans¬
port Board must follow if they want to close a railway passenger service. The
area committee concerned in any particular case considers objections from users
and reports to the Minister, who then decides whether to consent to the closure.
There is also machinery whereby complaints on charges from coastal
shipping in connection with competition from the railways may be made to
the Minister of Transport.
Britain was the pioneer of railways. The opening of the Stockton to Darlington
Railway in 1825, and of the Liverpool and Manchester line in 1830, when
George Stephenson’s famous ‘Rocket’ locomotive was used, began a century
of widespread railway development. The great period of railway building
was from 1840 to 1875.
The railways first came under centralised government direction during the
first world war, and afterwards some 130 private companies were amalgamated
into four large regional groups under the Railways Act 1921. Thereafter they
suffered from the prolonged industrial depression and growing competition
from road transport, and following the second world war the Transport Act
1947 brought the railways under public ownership as a single enterprise,
British Railways. It was grouped in six regional sub-divisions and operated
under the overall management of a Railway Executive established as the agent
of the BTC. The 1953 Transport Act abolished the Railway Executive and
provided for decentralisation of the administration. Under the Transport
Act 1962 the British Railways Board was set up and came into existence on
1 st January, 1963, with sole responsibility for managing railway affairs. Under
the Act the railways were relieved of much of their burden of accumulated
debt and were given freedom to alter their charges at will, except for passenger
fares in the London area. The Board’s responsibilities for the operation of the
various parts of the system are delegated to five regional boards.
The process of rationalisation arising from changing public transport require¬
ments is reflected in the reduction of over 4,400 miles of standard-gauge route
since 1961. A total of 835 million passenger journeys was made and 214 million
tons of freight traffic conveyed on British Railways in 1966. The financial
position of the railways has not improved as quickly as was hoped despite
increases in fares and freight charges. The operating deficit in 1966 was
^71 '6 million, while there was a surplus of £6-4 million on other activities—
ships, harbours, hotels and letting of land. At the end of 1966, 338,951 people
were employed by railways, a reduction of 136,271 in four years.

TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS 351
In 1966 British Transport Hotels Ltd. managed 32 hotels, the catering
facilities on trains (including Pullman trains), as well as refreshment rooms at
204 stations, by agreement with the British Railways Board.
British Railways’ subsidiary, British Rail Hovercraft Ltd., set up in 1966,
runs regular hovercraft services across the Solent to the Isle of Wight.
In 1955 the BTC produced a modernisation plan which was designed to
transform virtually all the services offered by the railways. The plan has since
been modified in the light of ensuing economic and technical developments.
Capital expenditure has been substantial over the past few years and amounted
to ^107 million in 1966.
In spite of the considerable injection of new capital over the period 1955-62
British Railways incurred a steadily increasing overall deficit (including
interest charges), which rose to a peak of more than £150 million in 1962.
The new Railways Board was given the task of preparing a scheme for re¬
organising the railways in such a way that they could be run as a commercially
viable undertaking. In March 1963 a Report on the Reshaping of British
Railways (‘Beeching Report’) was published and was accepted in principle by
the Government. Its proposals included the withdrawal of passenger services
from about a third of the country’s railway system. These little-used lines
carried only 1 per cent of the total passenger traffic.
Other important proposals were for the improvement of inter-city passenger
services, with the emphasis on speed, reliability and comfort; the introduction
of express freight services (‘freightliner trains’) to link all the main industrial
areas; increased mechanisation in the carrying of coal (the railways’ most
profitable traffic); and the continuing replacement of steam by diesel and
electric traction. A further report, The Development of the Major Railway
Trunk Routes, was published in February 1965.
As promised in the White Paper on Transport Policy (see p. 348), a basic
network of railway routes, secure from closure, was announced in March
1967. The network covers 11,000 route miles. The position of the remaining
2,500 is still subject to review.
On main lines in 1955 there were about 18,000 steam, 7 main line diesel and
71 electric locomotives. At the end of 1966 the corresponding figures were
1,689 steam, 4,962 diesel and 340 electric locomotives. In addition, there
were 4,087 diesel and 7,293 electric passenger-carrying multiple units.
Passenger services have improved in speed and comfort with the replace¬
ment of steam by electric or diesel traction, which has also helped to reduce
operating costs. The replacement of steam locomotives is almost complete.
The replacement of out-of-date passenger coaches by new stock, with improved
amenities, is still proceeding.
On certain sections of the London-Bristol-South Wales line and of the
London-Edinburgh line passenger trains are permitted to run at up to
100 m.p.h. Similar speeds are also in operation on the London Midland
Region’s services on the electrified line between London and Manchester and
Liverpool, introduced in 1966. This electrification scheme was the largest
modernisation project undertaken by British Railways and included station
reconstruction, bridge works, a new colour-light signalling system and new
rolling stock. The total cost was ^160 million. The final stages of the scheme
involving extension of the electrified route to Birmingham and Wolverhampton
via Rugby and Coventry and to Manchester via Stoke were completed in
1967. Other electrification projects completed in 1967 include a £6^ million

ROADS
extension to the Glasgow suburban service, and the ^15 million London to
Southampton and Bournemouth scheme.
There has been considerable development of motorail services (carrying
both passengers and cars) and in May 1966 the world’s first car-train terminal
was opened in London.
The efficiency of freight services is being improved as new and modern
type freight vehicles come into service and as facilities for concentrating freight
traffic at fewer and better equipped and sited marshalling yards and terminals
are completed. There are now fully automated marshalling yards at Tinsley,
near Sheffield, and Bescot, near Walsall, providing faster and smoother
working with considerable saving in labour costs. To exploit the trend towards
greater use of standardised containers an inland freight depot has been set up at
Lawley Street, Birmingham, for customs clearance of imports and exports.
‘Freightliner’ services using specially designed containers and rolling stock
now link many centres, for example, London with Glasgow, Manchester,
Liverpool and Aberdeen, and Glasgow with Liverpool and Manchester.
Efforts are being made to secure more bulk products traffic. Oil is being
moved from refineries under long-term contracts, while coal is being fed
direct from collieries to power stations in ‘merry-go-round’ trains, on which
coal is loaded and discharged automatically from a new type of high-capacity
wagon. Long-term contracts have also been signed for the carriage of cars,
china clay, milk, grain and newspapers.
A Railway Technical Centre has been erected at Derby; it covers 20 acres
and will eventually employ about 1,500 people. A projected 150 m.p.h.
gas-turbine passenger train is one of the developments under study.
Early in 1964 the British and French Governments agreed in principle to the
construction of a rail Channel Tunnel (either a bored tunnel or an immersed
tube). The construction cost is estimated at £155-^170 million (1966 prices).
It is expected that the Tunnel will be open in the mid-1970s.
The advent of the motor vehicle made it necessary for the Government to
set up a central road authority; accordingly, the Road Board was established
by the Development and Road Improvement Funds Act 1909. In 1919 the
Board’s responsibilities were taken over by the newly established Ministry
of Transport.
In April 1967 Great Britain had over 200,000 miles of public highway.
There were 8,770 miles of trunk roads including 446 miles of motorway,
20,154 miles of principal roads, and over 170,000 miles of other roads. Roads
are classified according to their traffic value, those of purely local traffic
importance remaining unclassified. As a result of the Local Government Act
1966 the classification into classes I, II and III (still retained for certain
purposes) has been superseded in the making of grants for road building by
a new category of ‘principal’ roads. On maps and signposts the trunk and
principal roads can usually be identified by the letter ‘A’ in front of a route
number. Trunk roads are the main arteries of national traffic and the whole
cost of their upkeep is met from Exchequer funds. The Minister of Transport
is the highway authority for trunk roads in England and on these roads he
administers expenditure, which is provided wholly from central government
sources, although for many purposes he employs local authorities as his
agents. The highway authority for principal roads is, in general, the council
of the county or county borough in whose area the roads lie. The Minister
makes specific grants towards approved expenditure on construction and
major improvement of these roads and contributions from public funds
TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS

Motorways
353
towards maintenance and other expenditure is made through grants to local
authorities. The Secretary of State for Scotland has corresponding responsi¬
bilities for roads in Scotland and the Secretary of State for Wales for roads
in Wales. Roads, other than trunk and principal roads, are entirely the
responsibility of the local authority in whose area they lie.
While it was impossible for several years immediately following the second
world war to spend much more on the roads than was required for their
essential maintenance, a large and steadily expanding road-building pro¬
gramme has now been in progress since 1955. Public expenditure on new and
improved roads in Great Britain is estimated at over ^265 million in 1967-68,
and a further steady growth is planned. A substantial proportion is devoted
to work in urban areas. The current programme includes a considerable
mileage of motorways constructed for the use of limited classes of traffic
under powers granted by the Special Roads Act 1949 (consolidated in the
Highways Act 1959)- It also includes the building or reconstruction of 350
miles of all-purpose trunk roads.
The motorways form part of a programme designed to provide a national
network of modern through routes. At the same time, work done under this
programme will eliminate some of the worst bottlenecks in urban areas and
thus help to give free outlets from the big cities and from other main sources
of traffic to the trunk routes.
It is planned that 1,000 miles of motorways should be completed by the

The largest bridge-building programme in Britain for over a century is
approaching completion. The £2-3 million Medway Bridge, which is part of
the M2 and one of the largest prestressed concrete structures of its kind in the
world, was completed in 1963 and the suspension bridge across the Firth of

tunnel (under the Thames) has been open to traffic since the end of 1963.
Work on the £20 million second Mersey Tunnel began in 1967 and is due for
completion in 1970.
Research on roads is carried out at the Road Research Laboratory (see p. 200).
Its aims are to find more economical ways of designing, constructing and
maintaining roads and of facilitating the flowr of traffic on them and to reduce
road accidents. The layout of roads, their traffic, the safety features of road
vehicles and the behaviour of road users are investigated, and new methods,
materials and processes are developed for building roads and providing
them with a smooth, safe and durable surface. The Laboratory has a Tropical
Section, which undertakes research and advice on road problems overseas.
In 1966 there were over 13 million motor vehicles licensed to use Great
Britain’s roads. Of these, i-6 million were goods vehicles and 94,000 were
public road passenger vehicles (that is, buses and taxicabs).
The first world war greatly stimulated the development of motor vehicles
and road transport began to make itself felt as a serious competitor of the
TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS
Licensing
Organisation of
Road Haulage
State-owned
Services
Size of the
Industry
355
railways. The first step towards government regulation of public road
transport was the passing of the London Traffic Act 1924, which gave the
Minister of Transport power to control the number of buses and their
journeys in London; this was followed in 1933 by the setting up of the London
Passenger Transport Board (see p. 359).
The Road Traffic Act 1930 ended the licensing of public service vehicles
(that is, buses and coaches) by local authorities and set up instead traffic areas,
of which there are now eleven, covering the whole country and each under
the control of three traffic commissioners (except for the London metropolitan
area, which has one) appointed by the Minister. The commissioners regulate,
by means of a licensing system, all public road passenger transport services,
and they sanction routes and time-tables in order to secure proper co-ordina¬
tion of services and eliminate unnecessary competition; they may also control
fares.
The Road and Rail Traffic Act 1933 established a system of licensing for
road haulage vehicles, which is still in operation, designed to restrict vehicle
operations to proved needs and to eliminate wasteful competition. A licence
has to be secured from the licensing authority (the chairman of the appropriate
body of traffic commissioners) before a goods vehicle can be used on the road.
There are three types of licence: the ‘A’ licence for general public haulage;
the ‘B’ licence for public haulage limited to certain goods or certain areas and
covering also the carriage of the licensee’s own goods; and the ‘C’ licence for
the carriage by traders solely of their own goods. Applications for ‘A’ and ‘B’
licences are examined by the licensing authorities to see if they are necessary
in view of existing transport services, and competitors may raise objections.
There is a right of appeal to the Transport Tribunal against the decision of
the licensing authorities. The ‘C’ licence is granted on application, as of right.
All goods vehicle operators are bound by regulations concerning the fitness and
loading of vehicles, the movements of large vehicles likely to obstruct traffic,
the keeping of records, and driving hours and rest periods of their employees.
The main licensing provisions contained in the Road Traffic Act 1930, and
the Road and Rail Traffic Act 1933, as subsequently amended, were con¬
solidated in the Road Traffic Act i960.
New licensing arrangements are to be introduced. It is proposed to
strengthen control of long-distance haulage and to abolish ‘C’ licensing for
light vehicles. Road haulage would be prevented from competing with British
Railways’ freightliner trains where these were considered to provide as good a
service.
From September 1956 to January 1963 the nationalised road haulage services
were controlled by British Road Services (BRS), a division of the British
Transport Commission, and operated through five companies, which together
owned about 16,000 vehicles: British Road Services Ltd. (general haulage);
BRS (Pickfords) Ltd. (special traffic and some contracts); BRS (Contracts)
Ltd.; BRS (Parcels) Ltd.; and BRS (Meat Haulage) Ltd. Under the Transport
Act 1962, these organisations have been operating as companies incorporated
under the Companies Act, with their own boards. They are grouped together
under the Transport Holding Company, responsible to the Minister of
Transport. All the companies’ vehicles are subject to the licensing system.
The number of licensed vehicles in the road goods transport industry has
shown only a relatively slow growth, from 1-4 million in i960 to 1-5 million
in 1966, when 1,245,000 were on ‘C’ licence. Of the other 240,000 vehicles,

With the exception of the London transport system which is operated by the
London Transport Board, road passenger transport in Great Britain is run
by about 5,000 operators, 95 of them being local authorities owning and
operating urban bus and trolleybus services. About 4,700 are independent
operators of coaches and, of these, 3,600 have not more than 5 vehicles. Most
of the remainder operate both bus and coach services and belong to three main
groups—Tilling, Scottish Omnibuses and British Electric Traction. The
British Electric Traction Group is a private concern but substantial share¬
holdings in many of its companies, without any controlling interest, are held
by the Transport Holding Company, who own Tilling and Scottish Omni¬
buses. The Tilling bus companies are grouped into six regions covering
England and Wales, with a total vehicle strength of about 9,400. The Scottish
group, with a vehicle strength of 4,700, covers most of Scotland, with the
exception of the major municipalities of Glasgow, Edinburgh, Dundee and
Aberdeen and services in the Highlands and Islands.
There are some 250 concerns operating fleets of over 24 vehicles, about
one-third of which are local authorities, the largest being the Corporations of
Birmingham, Glasgow and Manchester.
Britain has the highest density of road traffic in the world. In 1966, 7,985
people were killed on the roads and about 384,000 injured. This compares with
over 7,000 persons killed and 230,000 injured in 1934, when there was one-
fifth of the present number of motor vehicles on the roads—an indication
that the problems have, to some extent, been held in check by road safety
measures introduced since 1930. Since 1946 the volume of traffic has at least
trebled: but road accident casualities have only doubled. The fatal accident rate
in Britain is better than that in most other European countries, but slightly
worse than in the United States. Road accident statistics are compiled and
published by the Ministry of Transport, the Scottish Development Depart¬
ment and the Welsh Office from reports made by the police.
Modern roads, designed for present-day traffic and segregating pedestrians
from vehicles, are safer than the roads they replace and surveys have shown
they result in a marked fall in casualties. The more important measures
directed primarily towards road safety include speed limits of 30 and 40 m.p.h.
in and around built-up areas and 50 m.p.h. on certain trunk and important
classified roads in rural areas; the provision of pedestrian crossings—some
illuminated by flashing beacons and marked with conspicuous white stripes
(‘zebra’ crossings); and the system of road markings and traffic signs (which
are being replaced by greatly improved signs over the next few years).
A 70 m.p.h. speed limit is in force on all motorways and, on a temporary
basis, on ordinary main roads where no lower limit applies.
The safety of vehicles, both in design and use, is controlled by regulations;
a system of vehicle testing, which applies at present to vehicles three or more
years old, is being gradually extended. Heavy goods vehicles were previously
subject to a separate procedure of spot checks but legislation enacted in 1967
established a system of annual tests and stricter requirements in respect of the
condition of vehicles.
TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS
Relief of Congestion
357
All drivers of motor vehicles, including motor cycles, motor scooters and
powered pedal cycles, unless they have either held a full British licence or
passed the driving test in the last ten years, are required to pass the test before
being granted a full licence to drive.1 Until they pass the test they must obtain
a ‘provisional’ licence which necessitates their displaying ‘L’ (Learner) plates
on their vehicle, and in all cases where vehicles are constructed to carry
passengers, other than pillion passengers, learner drivers must be accompanied
by a qualified driver (a person who holds a current driving licence for the
same type of vehicle as that driven by the learner). A learner driver of a motor
cycle is restricted, until he passes the driving test, to a machine not exceeding
250 c.c.
The Road Traffic Acts, which embody the law relating to road users, are
enforced by the police and the courts. A person convicted of any of the 26
most serious offences is liable to be disqualified from driving for a period. The
standard of conduct for all road users—pedestrians and drivers—and a sum¬
mary of the requirements of the law is set out in easily understandable form
in the Highway Code. A failure to oberve the code does not of itself render a
person liable to criminal proceedings but may be taken into account in any
such proceedings.
A National Road Safety Advisory Council was set up by the Minister of
Transport in 1965 to keep under review the road accident situation in Great
Britain and methods of accident prevention, and to report on other matters
affecting road safety.
A Bill making it an offence to drive with more than a prescribed level of
alcohol in the blood became law in 1967.
National campaigns to persuade people to take greater care on the roads
are conducted by the Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents, acting
as the Government’s agent and with the participation of the local authorities.
The police and education authorities also help by arranging courses of
instruction, especially courses for children.
In a White Paper (see Bibliography, p. 511) the Government has announced
proposals for reducing accidents. These include the setting up of a central
road safety unit within the Ministry of Transport, extension of local authority
activity in safety matters, publicity and training campaigns, and a review of
pedestrian safety.
The Road Traffic and Roads Improvement Act i960 permits the employment
of traffic wardens (with strictly limited powers), and provides for fixed
penalties (the ‘ticket’ system) for parking offences. Other measures in the
Act, designed to reduce traffic congestion, include the granting of greater
powers of action to local traffic authorities. In 1965 the Greater London
Council became the traffic authority (formerly the responsibility of the
Minister of Transport) for the whole of Greater London. Several extensive
schemes for the improvement of road safety and the relief of traffic congestion
are being undertaken: these include ‘fly-overs’ at road junctions; new outlet
roads from cities; and the designation of certain stretches of trunk roads as
‘clearways’, on which waiting on the carriageway is (with certain exceptions)
prohibited. In London and most of the other large towns street parking in
certain areas is permitted only for limited periods and on payment at parking
meters, and increased off-street parking facilities are being provided; some
towns, such as Leicester and Cheltenham, are experimenting with other
methods of controlled street parking.

BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
INLAND
WATERWAYS
The System
Increasing use is being made of traffic management to promote the smoother
and more rapid flow of traffic. In i960 a Traffic Management Unit was set
up in London by the Minister of Transport. This was superseded in 1965 by
a Traffic Advisory Unit, with the object of making available to all traffic
authorities the experience gained in London and elsewhere since i960. The
main measures introduced are comprehensive control of street parking and
comprehensive one-way working systems. Others include the banning of turns,
particularly right turns, peak hour clearways and ‘tidal flow’ arrangements.
A computer-controlled system to regulate traffic is being installed in West
London.
In 1761 James Brindley completed the Bridgewater Canal to take coal from
the collieries owned by the Duke of Bridgewater at Worsley to Manchester.
This marked the beginning of canal building in modern Britain, with which
the names of Brindley, Telford, Rennie, Jessop and other great engineers are
associated. Canals played an important part in promoting industrial and
commercial expansion in the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries.
The whole canal system was practically complete by 1830. As a result of
developing competition from the railways, however, about one-third of the
canal mileage had passed to the control of the railway companies by the middle
of the nineteenth century. During the two world wars government control of
railways included railway-owned canals. Under the Transport Act 1947, most
of the country’s canals passed to the British Transport Commission in
January 1948. From 1955 the canals were managed separately by the water¬
ways division of the Commission, known as British Waterways; under the
Transport Act 1962, control has been vested in the British Waterways Board
since 1st January 1963.
There are about 2,500 miles of navigable inland waterways in Great Britain,1
some 2,000 miles of which belong to the British Waterways Board; the
remainder are mainly still in the hands of local authorities or private com¬
panies. Many of the Board’s canals are narrow waterways which can generally
be used only by boats not exceeding 7 feet in width, capable of carrying a load
varying from 25 to 30 tons; the remainder are broad waterways and canalised
rivers some of which can be used by craft of up to about 700 tons capacity.
The Caledonian and Crinan canals in Scotland are broad waterways. Of the
2,000 miles of inland waterways under the control of the British Waterways
Board some 300 miles are major commercial waterways and a further 100 miles
are used for specialised commercial traffic. It is proposed to maintain on a
permanent basis a substantial additional mileage for purposes of recreation;
an advisory council is to be set up.
For certain operational purposes, such as maintenance engineering and
estates work, the canals of England and Wales are administered from two
regional centres, one at Gloucester and the other at Leeds. Sales promotion
is, in the main, centrally and nationally directed by the Board’s headquarters
in London. In Scotland the canals (other than the Caledonian, which is run
by a manager) are, for engineering purposes, under the control of an area
engineer; estates work is supervised centrally.
In 1966 total traffic on British waterways amounted to just over 7-6 million
tons, of which 2-9 million tons were coal, 1-9 million tons liquids in bulk and
2-8 million tons general cargo. Some 95 per cent of the total traffic is carried
1 In Northern Ireland, the only inland waterway which is still used for commercial
transport purposes is the Lower Bann Navigation.

Development

The London

System
on about 400 miles of broad waterways, which are mainly canalised rivers.
Although the British Waterways Board is the largest single carrying
operator, most of the traffic is handled by independent carriers or by traders
in their own craft. The Board at the end of 1966 owned 14 tugs and 795
carrying craft, with a carrying capacity of 34,544 tons, including 88 power-
driven craft with a carrying capacity of 5,309 tons.
The British Waterways Board now controls about 300 miles of first-class
waterways linking important industrial districts with ports. Large investments
in improved facilities have been made. These waterways are the Aire and
Calder Navigation, the Sheffield and South Yorkshire Navigation, the Trent
Navigation, the Lee Navigation, part of the river Severn, including the
Gloucester and Sharpness Canal, the Weaver Navigation and the Grand Union
Canal (below Slough).
The total revenue of the British Waterways Board in 1966 amounted to
^4-7 million, of which only £o-(i million arose from the Board’s own freight¬
carrying activities. The sale of water is an important source of revenue and
has more than trebled since 1948. British Waterways encourages pleasure
boating and receipts from this source are rising, reaching £106,386 in 1966.
Income from fishing rights was £22,515 in 1966.
London is, with Tokyo and New York, one of the world’s three largest cities.
The area known as Greater London, within a radius of about 15 miles from
Charing Cross, contains over 8 million people.
London’s passenger transport system, in its modern sense, began in 1829
when the first omnibus, horse-drawn, appeared on the London streets. The
first regular tram service, also horse-drawn, began in 1870. In 1863 the first
underground steam railway, the Metropolitan, was built by digging a great
trench for the line and roofing it over. In 1870 the world’s first tube railway,
the Tower Subway, was constructed under the river Thames; it was cable-
operated and ran for only a few months. The first electric tube railway in the
world, the City and South London Railway, was opened in 1890, and this was
followed in 1900 by the opening of the Central London Railway. Shortly
afterwards the steam-operated underground lines were electrified. Meanwhile,
horse-drawn buses and trams were being replaced by motor buses and
electric trams.
Until 1933 there were many separate undertakings providing passenger
transport facilities in London, but in that year they were all vested in a single
public corporation, the London Passenger Transport Board. In 1948, with
the establishment of the British Transport Commission, the London Trans¬
port Executive took over control as an agency of the Commission.
Under the Transport Act 1962 the London Transport Executive has been
replaced by a financially independent board, the London Transport Board.
Exchequer loans finance the Board’s external capital needs. The limits
of its borrowing powers were raised by £50 million to £250 million in 1965.
Under the 1966 Transport Finances Act the Government is enabled to pay,
till the end of 1968, a subsidy of up to £16 million to London Transport to
meet losses due to road congestion, the fall in numbers of bus passengers and
general rising costs.
The London Transport undertaking operates all road and rail passenger
transport services in the London area with the exception of the London lines
of British Railways and the taxicabs. (Some 6,000 taxicabs that ply for hire

Roads
in the streets are privately operated by companies or owner-drivers and are
licensed annually by the metropolitan police.) London Transport’s operations
extend beyond Greater London to cover an area of 2,000 square miles (known
as the London Passenger Transport Area) within a radius of about 25 miles
from Charing Cross and with a population of io£ million. Between 1956
and 1966 the number of passenger journeys made annually on the London
Transport system fell from 3,914 million to 2,645 million, largely owing to
increased private motoring and changes in leisure-time habits, such as the
increase in television viewing.
London Transport’s railway network stretches 18 miles from north to south
and 32 miles from east to west. The total length of the railway over which
London Transport trains operate is 244 miles, of which 88 miles are under¬
ground. London Transport trains serve 273 stations, and its buses and coaches
travel over 3,200 miles of roads. To carry traffic over all this area, in December
1966 London Transport owned 4,069 railway cars and 7,922 buses and
coaches. The total staff employed was 73,816.
Improvements carried out by London Transport have included complete
renewal of the bus and coach fleet, replacement of trams and trolleybuses by
diesel buses, and extension and modernisation of parts of the Underground
system. In 1962 work started on the building of a new lo^-mile tube railway
between Victoria Station and Walthamstow, in north-east London. It is
estimated that the work will cost about £60 million and it is hoped to open
the northern section of the line towards the end of 1968, and the remainder in
1969. A j£i6 million, 3|-mile extension from Victoria to Brixton in South
London has been approved and should be open by 1972.
Public transport in Northern Ireland is in the process of being reorganised.
The Ulster Transport Authority is still responsible for all rail services in
Northern Ireland, but as a result of the withdrawal of certain passenger and
freight services in 1965 the total railroad mileage has been reduced to 203
miles. The Transport Act (Northern Ireland) 1966 ended the monopoly of
the Ulster Transport Authority in the carriage of goods by road, and on
1st July 1966 a private enterprise system of road haulage under licence was
created. A new company has been set up to take over the road passenger
operations formally carried out by the Authority. Pending the enactment of
legislation, the Authority, which in the past provided all public road passenger
services in Northern Ireland, apart from Belfast city services, is giving consent
to a limited number of private operators to provide services in certain areas.
Legislation has been introduced for the winding up of the Authority, the
provision of an organisation to operate the present railway system and
the provision of a limited licensing system for private and passenger
operators.
On 31st March 1967, there were 13,971 miles of public roads in Northern
Ireland, comprising 387 miles of trunk roads, 983 miles of Class I roads,
1,728 miles of Class II roads, 2,869 miles of Class III roads and 8,004 miles of
unclassified roads.
The Ministry of Development is directly responsible for the trunk road
system and bears the entire cost of maintenance and reconstruction work on
these roads. In addition to major reconstruction schemes on trunk roads, an
extensive system of motorways is planned including an urban motorway
system in Belfast, part of which will be classified. About 31 miles were in use
by the middle of 1967.

The Ministry of Development administers the Road Fund (the proceeds
of motor vehicle taxation, driving licence fees, etc.), from which grants are
paid to the local authorities (county, county borough, borough and urban
district councils) who are responsible for the other roads. The rates of grant
range from 90 per cent for major improvement works on Class I roads to
25 per cent for maintenance work on the unclassified roads.
Gross capital expenditure on all roads in the financial year to 31st March
1967 was £13-1 million, and expenditure on maintenance and minor improve¬

period is expected to be about £75 million, compared with about
£41 million in the five-year period to 1966. Expenditure on maintenance and

CIVIL AVIATION
British airmen were among the first to carry mails (at the time of the
Coronation of King George V in 1911) and among the first to operate regular
mail and passenger services, which were inaugurated on 25th August 1919,
when a daily passenger service was opened between London (Hounslow)
and Paris (Le Bourget).
In April 1924 four small British companies merged to form Imperial Airways
Limited, which received a government grant of ^1 million. This company
pioneered the commercial development of intercontinental air routes. By
1929 there was a through service from England to India. In 1931 the first
service was established to Central Africa. The first mail service to Australia
started in December 1934, followed by a passenger service in 1935.
The British Overseas Airways Corporation, a public corporation, took over
the undertakings of Imperial Airways Limited and British Airways Limited
in 1940. British European Airways was established under the Civil Aviation
Act 1946 as a separate public corporation to cover the United Kingdom
and Europe. In addition to the two nationalised corporations, there are about
30 independent air transport operators.
General responsibility for the development of United Kingdom civil aviation
was transferred in 1966 from the Ministry of Aviation to the Board of Trade.
Under the post-war nationalisation legislation the air corporations had a
statutory monopoly of British scheduled services, and independent operators
were confined, broadly, to charter work. From 1949, and increasingly from
1952, the independents were allowed to develop new scheduled services,
provided they secured Ministerial approval and operated, technically, as
associates of the corporations. The Civil Aviation (Licensing) Act i960
abolished the corporations’ monopoly and provided for a licensing system,
administered by an Air Transport Licensing Board, to which the nationalised
and independent operators could apply on an equal footing for licences for
scheduled or charter services, or for revocation or variation of existing licences.
The ATLB is an independent body of six to ten members appointed by the
Board of Trade. Its main function is to consider and decide on applications for
licences (or their revocation or variation). The ATLB must have regard to an
applicant’s financial resources, staffing, organisation, the need for the proposed
services, the adequacy of, and possible effect on, existing services, and any
objections or representations made by interested parties. It also has the
general duty of furthering the development of British civil aviation.

There is provision for appeals on ATLB decisions to the Board of Trade,
who appoint independent commissioners to hear appeals publicly and report
with recommendations upon them. In the period from its inception to 31st
March 1967 the ATLB received some 8,400 applications for air service
licences of various kinds, including charters and package holiday tours, of
which some 6,500 were granted.
In 1967 the Government set up a committee to inquire into the affairs of
the civil air transport industry, including the methods by which it is regulated
and controlled.
The constitution and functions of BOAC and BEA are laid down in the Air
Corporations Act 1967 which consolidates, with certain exceptions, the
provisions of the Air Corporations Acts 1949 and 1966. Each corporation
consists of 5 to 11 members, including the chairman. The chairman of each
board is a member of the other.
In 1966 BOAC’s capital was reconstructed. The Corporation was relieved of
liability for Exchequer borrowings of £176 million, outstanding at 31st March
1965, and instead provision was made for an initial Exchequer investment in
the Corporation of £66 million. Of this, £31 million is loan capital, carrying
a fixed rate of interest, and £35 million is ‘Exchequer Dividend Capital’ on
which a variable dividend, related to each year’s earnings, is payable. The
accumulated deficit, amounting to £82-5 million at 31st March 1965, was
written off and a reconstruction reserve of some £30 million created. The
introduction of Exchequer Dividend Capital is experimental over a five-year
period. The statutory limit on BOAC’s borrowings and Exchequer Dividend
Capital is £90 million, which can be increased by Order to £120 million.
BEA’s borrowing limit remains at £110 million, which can be increased by
Order to £125 million.
The Board of Trade has certain statutory powers and duties in respect of the
air corporations, including the power, very seldom used, to give directions
of a general character as to the exercise and performance of their functions
in relation to matters affecting the national interest. With the approval of the
Treasury, the Board has power to make Exchequer advances within the limits
laid down by Parliament. The Board of Trade is responsible for approving
the lines of the corporations’ capital expenditure. The Board also sets, after
consultation with the corporations, their financial targets and, in BOAC’s
case, approves the amount payable annually as dividend. There is also close
consultation on overseas traffic rights and air safety. Day-to-day matters
concerning the corporations’ activities are the responsibility of the commercial
management of BOAC and BEA.
Total capacity-ton-miles offered on all services has more than trebled since
1959, and had risen to 1,680 million capacity-ton-miles in 1966. In 1955,
2-5 million passengers entered or left the United Kingdom by air, compared
with 5-7 million who arrived or departed by sea; in 1962 there were for the
first time more air than sea passengers, and by 1966 the figures had risen to
13-1 million by air and 8-7 million by sea.
BOAC is engaged on long-haul airline operations. Its scheduled services link
Britain with Europe, the Middle East, the Far East, Australasia, Africa and
North and South America, and it also provides complete round-the-world
services. It co-operates closely with airlines of several other Commonwealth
countries; it also has financial interests in eight companies operating local and

regional services in the Far and Middle East and in the Caribbean in areas
adjacent to BOAC’s main routes.
The capacity offered on BOAC’s own scheduled services reached 1,380
million capacity-ton-miles at the end of March 1967, having risen by 54 per
cent in the last four years. Over half of this capacity was on the western routes
to North and South America. The overall load factor in 1966-67 was 54 per
cent: the break-even load factor (the figures at which operating costs are
covered) was again lower. The Corporation’s passenger fleet, made up
entirely of pure jets, consists (June 1967) of Super VC 10s (10 with a further
7 on order), VC 10s (12), Boeing yoys (19) and Boeing 336C all-freighters
(2 with another 2 on order). Six Boeing y4ys are also on order.
The VC 10, introduced into service in 1964, operates on African, Middle
East and Far East routes. The Super VC 10 (a larger and more powerful
aircraft than the standard version) went into service in April 1965 on trans¬
atlantic routes. Both aircraft have set up passenger-carrying records on many
routes. The Boeing 336C took over the transatlantic all-freighter operation in
January 1966. BOAC has reserved delivery positions on eight of the Anglo-
French Concord aircraft and on six of the projected US Boeing SSTs
(supersonic transports).
BOAC is building its own passenger terminal at Kennedy International
Airport, New York, to be completed by the autumn of 1969. The Corporation
opened a new round-the-world jet service across the South Pacific to Australia
in April 1967. It is making a substantial investment over the next ten years on
the installation of an advanced airline computer system to control a wide
variety of international activities, including accounting, flight planning, and
seat reservations.
BOAC’s financial position has shown a great improvement in the last two
years, after several years of deficits. In 1966-67 the Corporation earned a
record group operating surplus of over £23-3 million and net profits of
£23-9 million after interest on borrowings and taxation. Of its gross revenue
(£137 million) £91 million was earned in foreign currencies, of wdiich
.£59 million came from the sterling area and £32 million from the dollar
area.
BEA operates a network of services to over 80 places in Britain, Europe,
North Africa and the Middle East. Its services in Britain include a number
which cannot be operated on a commercial basis but which meet a vital
social need; these include services to the Highlands and Islands of Scotland.
BEA maintains a close working relationship with BOAC, whose aircraft, by
agreement, use a number of European stopping points. BEA also co-operates
with other airlines in order to create ‘through travel’ facilities. It has a
financial interest in several associated companies, most of which collaborate
with BEA in providing a network of services.
For the year ended 31st March 1967, the increases in capacity offered, and
passenger-miles and freight-ton-miles flown were 13-9 per cent, 11 -6 per cent
and 18-8 per cent respectively over the previous year; in the same year some
7-3 million passengers were carried, an increase of 7 per cent.
In 1966 BEA’s passenger fleet consisted of Vanguards, Viscount 800s,
Comets and Tridents. The Trident, introduced in 1964, is a three-engine
600 m.p.h. jet designed for medium-haul routes: delivery of 23 of these
aircraft was completed in 1966. A new version, the Trident 2, and 18 BAG
One-Elevens are on order.

Only twice in the past decade has BEA failed to show an overall profit.
In 1966-67 the corporation had an operating surplus of £4-3 million and there
was a net profit of £708,000 after payment of interest on borrowings. The
target level set for BEA by the Government for the five years to 1967-68
is a return of 6 per cent annually on net assets; an average return of 6-5 per
cent has been earned in the first four years (to March 1967).
The official body representing the majority of independent operators is the
British Independent Air Transport Association. The largest companies,
British United Airlines and British Eagle International Airways, however,
are not members. The Association also represents air taxi operators and a
large number of companies which, although not themselves aircraft operators,
have substantial air transport interests; total membership is 53.
Although the two State corporations had a statutory monopoly up to 1961
there has been a significant expansion in recent years not only of the number
of passengers and volume of freight carried but also in the diversity of services
operated. As well as a wide network of domestic and international services
the independent operators provide vehicle ferry services; specialised air cargo
facilities; and enable travel agents to offer low-cost all-in holidays abroad.
They have also been responsible for air transport of service personnel and
supplies all over the wrorld. They compete with BEA over several domestic
routes, including the busiest internal route in Europe, from London to
Glasgow. In 1966-67 they carried some 6J million passengers. To meet future
demand a programme of aircraft re-equipment is in progress. Several jet air¬
craft are already in service and further orders have been placed. Jet airliners
on domestic routes in Britain were first introduced by British United Airways
in 1966.
In addition to the public transport operators there are a large number of
companies engaged in miscellaneous aviation activities such as crop-spraying,
aerial survey and photography, and flying instruction.
The proportion of Britain’s overseas trade carried by air is increasing steadily.
In 1956, 1-7 per cent of imports and 2-9 per cent of exports (by value) were
carried by air. In 1966 the corresponding percentages were 9 and 10, and
the total value of exports, imports and re-exports by air was £1,094 million.
The chief export items are expensive machinery and parts, aircraft and vehicle
parts, and electrical and electronic products; furs and skins account for a large
proportion of the total value of re-exports by air.
At Heathrow, London, freight traffic is increasing at an annual rate of over
20 per cent and totalled 225,000 tons in 1966. Scheduled services of British
airlines carried 360,000 tons of freight in 1966, compared with 196,000 tons
in 1959.
The estimated number of aircraft on the United Kingdom register used for
business and private purposes is over 600, while approximately 500 are
owned by clubs, groups and training schools. About 14,000 student and
private pilots hold licences. About 130 companies use private aircraft and
some 80 companies are members of the Business Aircraft Users’ Association.
The Board of Trade has a general responsibility for civil aerodromes. It may
itself establish and maintain airports, and local authorities may also do so
subject to its approval. Aerodromes which are municipally or privately owned
Development
TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS 365
and which are used for the public transport of passengers and/or flying
instruction are subject to government licensing, inspection and regulation.
The Board of Trade is also responsible for the navigation facilities at a
number of main municipal airports.
The British Airports Authority, an independent statutory body operating
on a commercial basis, took over on 1st April 1966 the ownership and manage¬
ment of London’s two major airports (Heathrow and Gatwick), Prestwick in
Scotland, and Stansted in Essex. (The Government decided in 1967 that
Stansted should be developed as London’s third airport.) At these airports
the Board of Trade is responsible for the provision of navigation services
and may direct the Authority to take measures to control noise and
vibration.
There are approximately 124 civil aerodromes in the United Kingdom;
in addition, 53 Service aerodromes are available for civil use. Those under
civil control include 14 directly controlled by the Board of Trade, 3 in the
Channel Islands and 1 in the Isle of Man administered by the local island
governments, and 41 aerodromes licensed for public use, of which 25 are
owned by municipalities. Nine of the Board of Trade’s aerodromes and 19
others are designated Customs airports; limited customs facilities are available
at a further eight aerodromes.
Aircraft and passenger movements at the principal airports have risen very
markedly in the last five years, and in 1966 United Kingdom civil airports
handled 234 million passengers. The number of movements of aircraft
engaged on commercial transport operations was 556,000.
For international scheduled services Heathrow and Gatwick are the main
airports, and Heathrow is the largest and busiest airport in Western Europe.
In recent years the annual increase in the number of passengers handled at
Heathrow has been about 1 million, reaching 12 million in 1966. Domestic
and European short-haul services are handled at the passenger building in
the central terminal opened in 1955. An additional building for short-haul
services is being constructed. To accommodate the rapid expansion expected
in freight movements, £23 million is being invested in a new cargo terminal
and associated developments due to be completed in 1969. Travelling time
from central London to Heathrow has been appreciably shortened since the
opening of a section of the M4 motorway in March 1965. There are plans to
build a rail link between Heathrow and central London (Victoria) and to
extend the Underground system to the airport.
The airport at Gatwick, 25 miles south of London, was opened in June
1958 as the second airport for the London area. The terminal building has
since been doubled in size; two more piers have been constructed and the
runway extended. Built alongside the main London to Brighton railway,
Gatwick airport is the first in the world to contain road, rail and air transport
in one unit. In 1966 Gatwick handled i-6 million passengers. A second main
runway is to be constructed.
A privately owned helicopter terminal (or ‘heliport’) is in operation at
Battersea on the south bank of the Thames.
Prestwick airport in Scotland has been developed to accommodate large
jet aircraft and a new passenger terminal building and freight area were
brought into use in 1964. The freight facilities are currently being extended.
A £6 million airport at Abbotsinch, near Glasgow, was opened in May
1966, taking over services from Renfrew. Owned and run by the Glasgow
Corporation, it is expected to handle over 2 million passengers a year by 1970.
Major developments completed in 1966-67 include a ^3 million scheme at

BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Woolsington airport, Newcastle, new terminal buildings at Tees-side and
Leeds and runway extensions at Birmingham and Belfast.
Manchester (Ringway), Glasgow (Abbotsinch) and Belfast (Aldergrove)
handled over a million passengers in 1966; Southend, Edinburgh (Turnhouse),
Birmingham and Prestwick each handled over 500,000.
The hovercraft, a vehicle which rides on a cushion of air over both land and
water surfaces, has been in regular public passenger service around the coasts
of Britain since 1965. New 160-ton large-capacity passenger and car ferry craft
are due to be introduced in 1968 as an extension to the present cross-Channel
services to France, making an all-year-round service possible for the first time.
The role of the Government in promoting air safety lies in research and in
setting up and supervising standards for both aircraft and personnel.
Research on aircraft design and construction is done at the Royal Aircraft
Establishments at Farnborough and Bedford, which are exceptionally well
equipped with testing facilities.
The Board of Trade determines the policy and legislative requirements for
the safe operation of civil aircraft, analyses accidents and initiates preventive
measures and research in flight safety.
All aircraft registered in the United Kingdom must have a valid certificate
of airworthiness issued (or rendered valid) by the Board of Trade on the
recommendation of the Air Registration Board, which was set up in 1937 and
consists of 18 members, six of whom are independent, the others being
representatives of constructors, operators and insurers of aircraft. No aircraft
built in Britain is granted a certificate of airworthiness unless it has been
constructed in accordance with British Civil Airworthiness Requirements, a
code compiled and frequently reviewed by the Board. Continued airworthiness
is ensured by regular inspection and by requiring aircraft to be maintained in
accordance with a schedule approved by the Board.
Every operator of aircraft above a certain weight used for public transport
must possess an Air Operator’s Certificate which is granted by the Director of
Aviation Safety when he is satisfied that the operator is competent to secure
the safe operation of his aircraft. The Director is advised by the Board of
Trade’s flight operations inspectors (who are experienced airline pilots) on
all matters affecting the operation of aircraft, except aircraft maintenance,
which is the responsibility of the Air Registration Board.
Each member of a flight crew must hold the appropriate official licence. Flight
operations inspectors check the standards maintained by the operators, which
must be adequate for purposes of the Air Operator’s Certificate.
In order to supplement the supply of well-trained pilots for civil airlines from
the Royal Air Force, which has declined in recent years, the College of Air
Training was set up at Ramble in i960. It is sponsored and financed by the
Government and two airways corporations. The Government may approve
independent colleges, whose standards are adequate for the training of
professional pilots. Three training schools, at Perth, Oxford and Carlisle,
have been approved so far.
Responsibility for policy, planning and execution of both civil and military
air traffic control over the United Kingdom and the surrounding seas rests
with the national Air Traffic Control Services Organisation, under the joint
control of the Board of Trade and the Secretary of State for Defence.
Technical
Provisions
Eurocontrol
TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS 367
This organisation has an integrated policy and planning staff drawn from both
ministries.
In 1950 the then Ministry of Transport and Civil Aviation introduced a
system of airways covering the main traffic routes with controlled zones
around the major airports. Subsequently, a revised and extended airways
system was brought into use to meet traffic needs. There are three main air
traffic control centres: at London for southern England, at Preston for the
north of England and Wales, and at Prestwick for Scotland and the Atlantic
Ocean to 30° W.
A variety of radar installations and other equipment provide the means by
which the system can accept the increasingly heavy load of air traffic. Britain
was the first country to use radar for the control of civil air traffic, and the
Instrument Landing System (ILS) is now installed at all major airports in
the United Kingdom. During the next few years virtually the whole of the
airspace over the United Kingdom above 5,000 feet will be brought under
surveillance by the latest types of primary and secondary radar equipment,
which will provide data to be used in two new air traffic control centres,
located at West Drayton (near London) and Prestwick. A subsidiary centre
will be located at Manchester to deal with traffic in the Manchester terminal
control area. Extensive use will be made in these centres of automatic data-
processing and other advanced electronic techniques.
The Board of Trade provides radio navigational aids to help pilots navigate
their aircraft in all weather conditions. In addition, the Board of Trade
supports the Decca Air and Marine Navigator System now operating over a
wide area of the United Kingdom and northern Europe, which can be used,
by arrangement with the Decca Company, by any aircraft fitted with the
appropriate receiving equipment.
Britain has pioneered in the development of all-weather landing systems.
The Blind Landing Experimental Unit of the Royal Aircraft Establishment
at Bedford and private industry have worked together towards fully automatic
blind landing, which has now been achieved with passenger-carrying aircraft
of both BOAC and BEA.
Britain is a member of Eurocontrol, a European international agency con¬
cerned with the traffic control problems arising from the increasing use of
high-flying, high-speed jet aircraft. Set up in 1963 it provides control at the
higher flight levels for civil aircraft and for military aircraft operating
according to civil procedures. A -£5 million experimental centre at Bretigny-
sur-Orge, near Paris, was opened in January 1967. An upper airspace control
centre is being built at Maastricht, Holland, and will come into use in 1971,
to provide services for air traffic in the north Germany-Benelux area.
THE POST OFFICE
The Post Office, founded in 1657, provides the postal and public tele¬
communications services of the United Kingdom. Although at present a
government department it is in effect a nationalised industry. It is to become
a public corporation in 1969.1
1 Details of the prospective change were given in a White Paper, Reorganisation of the
Post Office (Cmnd. 3233), published in March 1967. As in other nationalised industries,
the board will be appointed by and responsible to a Minister.
368
Organisation
Finance
Postal Services
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The present political head of the Post Office is the Postmaster General (see
p. 58). For most operational purposes Britain is divided into nine geographical
regions, each under a Director (two in London) with his own supporting staff.
In March 1967 the Post Office had 406,000 employees and 25,000 post offices.
The Post Office Act 1961 recognised the commercial character of the Post
Office by separating its finances from the Exchequer and giving the Postmaster
General sole responsibility for them. Post Office expenditure is subject
neither to Parliamentary control by Estimate nor to Treasury control. Income
is determined by tariffs which the Postmaster General fixes, subject only to
negative resolution of Parliament. The Post Office makes its own investment
plans, subject only to the same need for broad government approval as
applies to other nationalised industries. Like them, it is expected to aim at
an adequate return on its capital and to contribute suitably to the financing of
its investment. Its present financial target is an average return on net assets
of 8 per cent over the period 1963-64 to 1967-68.
Table 24 gives recent figures of income, profit and capital. Nearly all the
capital is invested in telecommunications, which are rapidly drawing ahead
of the postal services in size and profitability.
The development of postal communications in Britain can be traced from
the time when horsemen carried dispatches to the Tudor Court up to modern
airmail transport. The first dispatch of mails by train was made in 1830
between Liverpool and Manchester. The inauguration of the penny post
(the uniform charge for any inland distance being prepaid by means of
postage stamps, which originated in Britain) in 1840 was followed by a rapid
extension of the scope of the postal services. The registered post, ensuring
additional safety for valuable mail, wTas introduced in 1841. The money order
system, which had operated as a private venture from 1792 to 1838, was
supplemented in 1881 by the issue of postal orders for fixed amounts.
Letterboxes had been instituted in London in 1855, and in 1883 the parcel
post was introduced. In 1919 the Post Office inaugurated its own motor
transport fleet and the first mail was carried by air in Britain in 1911.
Table 24 gives statistics of items of inland and overseas mail carried. Each
year about 7,500 tons of mail are carried by air within the United Kingdom.
Out of the 516 million items of overseas mail carried in 1966-67, 66 per cent
was carried by air, compared with 51 per cent in 1955-56. The air parcel
service now operates to all countries in Europe and to over 180 countries
outside Europe.
Several new highly-mechanised sorting office buildings were opened in
1967 and it is anticipated that further mechanised installations will be brought
into service in 1968.
Over the next eight years £48 million is to be spent on sorting machines
and research into new techniques. Over half of this sum will be spent on letter
coding and automatic letter-sorting machines. Letter segregating and facing
machines are being installed at over 20 centres. Postal address coding was
extended to a number of large towns in 1967.
A Postal Consultancy Service offers facilities to overseas countries to aid
them in the planning and mechanisation of their new offices; it is actively
engaged on a number of major projects overseas.

Services
At the post office counter, besides making use of its postal and telegraph
facilities, the citizen can draw his pension and his family allowance, buy a

All private telegraph systems in Britain were transferred to the control of
the Postmaster General in 1870. Teleprinter-working for the transmission
of inland telegrams was introduced generally in 1928 and conversion to the
present automatic switching system was completed in mid-1954. It is now
one of the most up-to-date systems in the world and gives direct connection
3?o
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Telex Service
Telephone
Services
between any of the 450 larger telegraph offices. The overseas telegraph
services were shared until 1950 between the Post Office and Cable and
Wireless Ltd. This company was brought into public ownership in 1947.
The Post Office, which acquired the British services, operates all overseas
telegraph services from the United Kingdom, except those offered by foreign
telegraph companies. Cable and Wireless Ltd. continues to operate its cable
and wireless services in many dependencies and foreign countries.
Telegraph services to overseas countries are operated from Electra House in
London, the world’s largest overseas telegraph office, and from nine other
London and provincial area telegraph offices. Direct connection via the Centex
system between these British offices and the larger towns in Belgium, France,
Germany, Holland, Luxembourg, Italy and Norway minimises delivery delay.
In addition, the Post Office is well to the fore in the development of telegraph
message relay techniques for services beyond Europe.
The Telex Service (opened in England in 1932) combines the speed of the
telephone with the accuracy of the printed word. Calls may be made direct
between the rapidly increasing number of telex users in the United Kingdom
(about 22,000 by the end of 1967) and also to over 300,000 subscribers through¬
out the world. For call charging purposes Britain is divided into 50 charging
areas, each with its own telex centre. The United Kingdom telex service is
fully automatic and immediate connection is made by direct dialling to any
subscriber in this country, and to many subscribers in Europe, New Zealand,
the United States and Canada. Other overseas calls are connected by operators
at the International Telex Exchange in London which provides a teleprinter
service to over 120 countries abroad. Once a call is established the subscriber
types his message on the keyboard of his teleprinter and it is then reproduced
simultaneously on both the sending and receiving subscribers’ installations.
Inland and overseas telex traffic is growing annually by about 25 per cent; the
Post Office is planning for a system of about 80,000 United Kingdom sub¬
scribers by 1980. The Post Office’s remotely controlled high frequency radio
station at Leafield, Oxfordshire, became fully operational in 1966. It is the
most advanced of its kind in the world and handles overseas public radio¬
telegraph, radiotelephony and telex services as well as broadcasting news
services overseas.
When the Post Office bought the property of the National Telephone Com¬
pany in 1912 it became the owner of almost the whole telephone service in
the country. Hull Corporation was the only municipality to exercise its option
of operating its own service under licence from the Postmaster General; this
service (and the service in the Channel Islands, also operated under licence) is
connected to the Post Office trunk network. At the end of March 1967 there were
6,094 local telephone exchanges and about 11-4 million telephones in Britain.
In March 1967, only 259 exchanges remained to be changed to automatic
working. Trunk dialling by subscribers began in Bristol in December 1958; by
March 1967 the facility had been extended to 1,390 exchanges, serving 69 per
cent of all subscribers; by 1970 it will be available on over 90 per cent of
all telephones. The introduction of the new group routing and charging
equipment brings the advantages of quicker service, automatic accounting and
cheap long-distance calls of short duration, and constitutes the most radical
reform of the telephone service since the Post Office assumed national
responsibility for it. Telephones in London have been given all-figure numbers
in which exchange names are replaced by figures, and numbers in other large
cities are being similarly changed.
TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS
371
Electronic exchanges are now being ordered for all new exchanges with
from 200 to 2,000 lines. The first operational electronic exchange in Europe
was opened at Ambergate, Derbyshire, in December 1966. Similar equipment
for larger exchanges is being tested.
Pulse code modulation systems are to be used to increase the circuit
capacity of lines on short-distance routes between exchanges. Equipment for
about 1,000 systems, each providing 24 circuits, has been ordered.
International subscriber dialling between London and Paris was inaugurated
in March 1963, extended to the rest of France, Belgium, Switzerland, the
Federal Republic of Germany and the Netherlands in 1964 and to Luxem¬
bourg in 1966. Edinburgh, Birmingham, Glasgow, Liverpool and Manchester
are now included in the network.
Operator-connected calls are handled at the London Continental Exchange,
from which nearly 1,700 direct telephone circuits give service to European
countries. These circuits are also used to send and receive pictures, and
special circuits are used for broadcast transmissions.
A radio tower, 620 feet high, has been erected in London to provide more
microwave radio links for carrying long-distance telephone and television
circuits. It was opened for operational purposes in October 1965. There are
over 100 Post Office communications towers in use; one of 500 feet in
Birmingham was brought into operation early in 1967.
Special Telephone There are several specialised services available by telephone, including the
Services *999’ emergency dialling service enabling subscribers to be connected as
quickly as possible, and free of charge, to the police, ambulance or fire brigade
services; the speaking clock; and a telephone weather forecast service available
in 25 centres. In London a telephone information service provides details in
English, French, Spanish and German of important events taking place in and
around the capital on the day of the call and a similar service (in English only)
in Edinburgh exists during the summer months. A recorded daily cooking
recipe is provided at 22 centres. A test match cricket score service operates
at more than 30 centres during the cricket season and a road weather service
is provided in collaboration with the Automobile Association at 18 centres
from 1 st October to 30th April.
A public radiotelephone service, introduced in 1959, enables the users of
vehicles fitted with suitable radio equipment to make calls to, or receive them
from, any telephone in the United Kingdom network. The area of this service
was initially restricted to South Lancashire and parts of Cheshire but a service
to cover the Greater London area was opened in 1965.
Computer Post Office computer centres are operating in London, Lytham St. Annes in
Operations Lancashire, Portsmouth, Derby and Edinburgh. An Act passed in 1967
enabled a computer data-processing service to be set up.
