Re-exports are goods which are exported (1) in the condition in which they
were imported or (2) after having undergone minor operations—such as
simple blending, cleaning, husking, repacking—which leaves them essentially
unchanged. Traditionally, the greater part of United Kingdom re-export trade
has been in raw materials and foodstuffs, for example, wool, rubber, tea, non-
ferrous metals and fur-skins. Commodities imported from Commonwealth
countries and sent on to countries in Europe, particularly traditional re-exports
such as tea and wool, account for a considerable proportion of the total value.
In recent years a considerable re-export trade has developed in manufactured
goods, part of which is accounted for by machinery, for example, aircraft and
aero-engines, which have been repaired or overhauled in the United Kingdom.
In 1966, the value of re-exports reached a peak total of £194 million. The
principal items were: fur-skins, non-ferrous metals, tea, aero-engines, electrical
400
BRITAIN.' AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Invisible
Transactions
and other machinery and chemicals. Over half of the re-exports went to
countries in Western Europe.
As previously mentioned, the United Kingdom has usually imported more
goods than it exports; however the gap has normally been covered by net
earnings from invisible transactions. In recent years these have tended to be
around ^150-^200 million a year; but a number of special factors coincided
in 1966 to produce an unusually low £92 million. In that year total credits
were valued at £2,866 million and total debits at £2,774 million.
Invisible transactions are divided for statistical purposes into six main
groups: government; transport (mainly shipping); interest, profits and divi¬
dends; travel; other services; and private transfers. Some of these figures
BRITAIN’S INVISIBLE OVERSEAS TRANSACTIONS (net) 1964-66
Tourist Trade
COMMERCIAL
POLICY
TRADE AND PAYMENTS 4OI
are precise (for instance, for government transactions), others are estimates.
The diagram shows the breakdown of the figures from 1964 to 1966.
Under the heading of government current transactions, the main items
on the debit side are military expenditure overseas and grants to developing
countries. Shipping receipts come mostly from export freights and cross trade
between other countries and also from passenger traffic. Shipping payments
arise mainly on account of foreign tramp shipping services. Shipping trans¬
actions produced net deficits between i960 and 1964 but have subsequently
registered net credits of £4 million in 1965 and £12 million in 1966. Civil
aviation has produced net earnings since 1958, amounting to £23 million
in 1966.
About half of Britain’s receipts under the heading interest, profits and
dividends come from investments in the sterling area. Net earnings under
this heading increased markedly after 1961 from £264 million to £451 million
in 1965; and were £417 million in 1966. The drop in 1966 was due largely to
the resumption of full interest payments on the post-war North American loans
and to factors of a temporary nature. The major items on the debit side
include the earnings of foreign investment in Britain, interest paid on sterling
held by other countries (which fluctuates with changes in short-term interest
rates in Britain) and interest payments on the North American loans. Major
components of other services include payments and receipts in respect of
insurance and films; expenditure of United States and Canadian forces in
Britain; net earnings of merchants; and royalties, commissions, banking and
other services.
Tourism yields a substantial income from overseas; in the ten years 1957-66
overseas visitors spent over £1,700 million in Britain. For 1966 alone these
tourist receipts, excluding fares, were estimated at about £215 million.
United Kingdom residents on holiday, or travelling for business or other
purposes overseas, spent about £301 million (excluding fares) in the same
year. The United Kingdom usually has a large net surplus on earnings from
tourism with North America and the overseas sterling area, but a substan¬
tial net deficit with Western Europe. The total number of visitors to the
United Kingdom in 1966, excluding visitors from the Irish Republic, was
estimated at over 3 million—an increase of some 15 per cent over the 1965
figure, and more than twice the number in 1956.
Britain’s national tourist organisation is the British Travel Association,
which derives the major part of its income from a government grant-in-aid.
The Association undertakes publicity overseas aimed at attracting visitors to
Britain and works towards the improvement in Britain of hotel accommoda¬
tion, catering, transport, entertainment and other amenities for the tourist. It
maintains offices (see Appendix, p. 485) or agencies in 16 overseas countries.
The Association works in close collaboration with the Scottish Tourist Board
and the Wales Tourist Board (contributing to their information and publicity
services), as well as the Northern Ireland Tourist Board, which is a statutory
body receiving a grant from the Government of Northern Ireland. In Northern
Ireland the Ministry of Commerce can assist, by way of grant, schemes sub¬
mitted by local authorities for the promotion of tourist traffic.
Britain’s prosperity depends on the prosperity of those who buy her exports
and theirs will depend on how they sell their exports elsewhere. Thus Britain
is a strong advocate of the removal of artificial barriers to trade and to this end
has taken a leading part in setting up such organisations as the International
402
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
General Agree¬
ment on Tariffs
and Trade
Monetary Fund (IMF), the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade
(GATT), the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
(OECD) (formerly the Organisation for European Economic Co-operation)
and the European Monetary Agreement (formerly the European Payments
Union). Britain has had a large share in these organisations’ activities,
especially those to free trade from the restrictions which grew up in the
second world war and post-war periods. It also played a full part at the first
session of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development held
in 1964 and is a member of the Trade and Development Board which acts on
behalf of the Conference between sessions. The Conference’s second plenary
session takes place in New Delhi, India, in February 1968.
Customs duties on imports into Britain are divided into two broad cate¬
gories: revenue duties (to which there correspond excise revenue duties on
comparable British-produced goods) and protective duties. Purchase tax is
chargeable on imported as well as home-produced goods but in the main the
charge on imports is deferred until the goods are sold by a registered to a
non-registered trader. In the financial year 1966-67 revenue duties charged
on imported goods yielded about £1,950 million, by far the greater part of
which came from tobacco and hydrocarbon oils (petroleum products). The
yield from protective duties in the financial year 1966-67 was £179 million,
or about 3 per cent of the value of all imports.
At the beginning of the twentieth century the only customs duties were
those imposed for revenue purposes on a small range of products. Certain
duties were imposed during the first world war (the McKenna Duties), in
1921 (for strategic reasons) and in 1925 (initially for revenue purposes) but it
was not until the Import Duties Act 1932 that any serious departure was made
from the principle of free trade. This measure provided a degree of protection
for British industry and, at the same time, a basis for negotiations with
foreign countries already in possession of a tariff structure. A series of bilateral
trade negotiations between 1932 and 1939 led to some modification in the
level of protection but in the next ten years, because of government purchase
and import controls introduced during and immediately after the second world
war, the tariff lost much of its importance. The substantial relaxation of
quantitative import controls from 1949 onwards re-established the tariff as the
main instrument of protection.
The Import Duties Act 1958 replaced the existing legislation relating to
the protective tariff and brought it up to date in a single measure. Following
the passing of the Act, the tariff was recast into an internationally agreed form
(the Brussels Nomenclature), which came into use from 1st January 1959.
Under the Customs Duties (Dumping and Subsidies) Act 1957, the Board of
Trade is empowered to impose duties on imported goods of any description
which have been dumped or subsidised and which are causing or threatening
material injury to a particular industry.
In October 1964, as part of its immediate measures to deal with the balance
of payments situation, the Government imposed a temporary charge on
imports at 15 per cent ad valorem. In broad terms it applied to all imports
except food and feedingstuffs, fuel, unmanufactured tobacco and raw materials.
The rate was reduced to 10 per cent in April 1965 and lapsed at the end of
November 1966.
The United Kingdom’s protective tariff has been considerably modified in
recent years as a result of a series of multilateral tariff negotiations held under
the auspices of the GATT, which seeks to increase the volume of world trade
TRADE AND PAYMENTS
Commonwealth
Preference
European
Economic
Integration
403
by reducing tariffs and other barriers to trade, and by eliminating discrimina¬
tion in international commerce. Tariff reductions, and bindings against
increase, negotiated between countries under the GATT are applied equally
to all other GATT countries under the ‘most favoured nation’ clause.
As a result of the latest GATT tariff negotiations, the ‘Kennedy Round’
(May 1964-June 1967), average reductions of over 30 per cent will be made
by the major trading countries in their tariffs on industrial goods. Bilateral
agreements between the United Kingdom and the EEC, the United
States and Japan provide for reciprocal reductions which are estimated
to average 37 per cent, 40 per cent and 34 per cent respectively, and affect well
over 70 per cent of British exports of dutiable industrial goods to these coun¬
tries. The implementation of the tariff reductions will be spread between
1968-72.
The principle of Imperial Preference was introduced into the United
Kingdom customs duties in 1919 and at the Ottawa Conference in 1932
agreements were concluded with independent Commonwealth countries
providing for reciprocal preferential tariff treatment over a wide range of
goods. The Import Duties Act 1932 had already provided for the duty-free
entry of goods from the United Kingdom dependencies.
Under the Import Duties Act 1958 goods grown, produced or manufactured
in the Commonwealth preference area may be exempted from duty or charged
with duty at a preferential rate (and the Commonwealth preference rate of
duty for nearly all goods is nil). Certain countries outside the Commonwealth,
including the Republic of South Africa and the Republic of Ireland, are part
of the Commonwealth preference area.
In May 1964 at the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development
in Geneva, Britain declared itself prepared to extend tariff preferences to all
the developing countries if other major industrialised countries would do the
same, if the Commonwealth countries concerned would agree and provided
that preferences were not created by introducing new, or increasing existing,
general tariff rates.
The European Free Trade Association (EFTA) was set up under the Stock¬
holm Convention of January i960 by Austria, Denmark, Norway, Portugal,
Sweden, Switzerland and Britain, with the object of creating an industrial
free trade area between the members and of working towards a wider European
settlement. Under the Convention, protective tariffs and quotas on trade in
industrial products between members of EFTA were to be eliminated by
1 st January 1970. The first tariff cuts were made in July i960, and duties were
finally removed (with certain minor exceptions) on 31st December 1966, three
years earlier than originally planned. Finland, which joined EFTA in 1961 as
an associate member, will make its final tariff cuts in December 1967. EFTA is
the first completed free trade area in the world and now forms a single market
of almost 100 million people. Since 1959 intra-EFTA trade has more than
doubled and has increased almost twice as fast as trade between the group
and non-member countries.
A free trade agreement between the United Kingdom and the Irish Republic
came into operation on 1st July 1966. On that date the United Kingdom
removed all protective import duties on goods of Irish Republic origin
imported from that country. After 1st July 1975, with certain exceptions,
the Irish Republic will not apply any protective duties on goods of United
Kingdom origin.

BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Methods of
Trading
CONTROLS ON
TRADE AND
PAYMENTS
Exchange
Control
In August 1961 the British Government applied formally to join the EEC
but negotiations were suspended in January 1963. In November 1966 the
British Government announced that it was to make a new approach to the
governments of the EEC member countries to see whether conditions for
negotiating British entry into the EEC existed. Discussions took place with
each of the Six in the early months of 1967 and in May 1967 the British
Government made an application for membership.
The export trade and virtually all the import trade of the United Kingdom are
conducted by private firms.
Methods of export trading vary considerably, according to the firm, the
industry, the product and the market. A good deal of United Kingdom export
trade, especially of the smaller manufacturing firms, is conducted through
exports merchants in the United Kingdom; many firms, however, sell to
importers and consumers abroad through their own agents or resident repre¬
sentatives in the countries concerned; in other cases, sales are made through
a firm’s own branch offices, distributing organisations or subsidiary sales
companies established in overseas markets.
Similarly, in import trade, many large firms engaged in manufacture or
domestic trade buy directly from overseas suppliers, while smaller firms may
find it more convenient to buy through intermediaries such as import/export
houses, commission agents, and the representatives of overseas firms. Since
January 1957 overseas trading undertaken directly by the Government has
been confined to imports of certain jute goods; the purpose of this is to
protect employment in Dundee, where the jute industry is concentrated and
forms the mainstay of employment.
Most of the restrictions imposed on the movement of goods and services
during and immediately after the second world war have been progressively
abolished. Because of the heavy balance of payments deficit in 1964 exchange
control requirements for investments outside the sterling area have been
revised and made more stringent.
Exchange control is confined mainly to transactions between residents of the
United Kingdom and residents of countries outside the sterling area and, for
current payments, has been greatly relaxed in the past few years. Since the
end of 1958 residents of all countries outside the sterling area have been able
to settle transactions between themselves in sterling. Sterling held by non¬
residents of the sterling area on an external account is freely convertible into
other currencies, including dollars.
The remaining important restrictions relate to the movement of capital
from the United Kingdom to non-sterling countries. Exports of goods to
destinations outside the sterling area are subject to exchange control and, in
general, have to be paid for within six months in an acceptable currency or
by sterling from an external account. Control is also exercised over imports
to ensure that currency authorised for their payment is, in fact, used for that
purpose.
Since April 1966 certain restrictions have been placed on the release of gold
for manufacturing purposes and on the buying, selling and holding of gold coins.
Exchange control policy is the responsibility of the Treasury, but most of
the administration is, in practice, carried out by the Bank of England as agent
of the Treasury; and, in turn, the Bank of England has delegated to the
commercial banks a wide variety of powers to deal with applications.

Overseas

GOVERNMENT
ASSISTANCE
TO OVERSEAS
TRADE
405
Following its illegal declaration of independence in November 1965, Rhodesia
was removed from the sterling area and all transactions between residents of the
United Kingdom and residents of Rhodesia became subject to exchange control.
A basic allowance of £50 per person is allowed for private travel to countries
outside the sterling area. The purpose of this restriction is to assist the balance
of payments. This allowance covers all foreign exchange expenditure, taken
in the form of cash or travellers’ cheques, and also the cost of hotel and other
travel services, except fares paid in sterling to travel agents in the United
Kingdom. The amount of sterling notes that a traveller may take out of the
country is restricted to £15 a journey. From November 1959 to July 1966
there had been no limit on the amount of foreign currency that United
Kingdom travellers could take abroad.
The Import, Export and Customs Powers (Defence) Act 1939 empowers the
Board of Trade to make statutory orders prohibiting or regulating the import
or export of goods. The powers of both import and export control derive
from the same legislation, but the purpose and mechanism are quite distinct.
In accordance with its international obligations under the GATT and the
IMF, the United Kingdom Government has progressively removed quanti¬
tative restrictions from almost all imports from the countries of the free world.
The very short list of goods on which controls remain includes some items
of special difficulty and a few where restrictions are recognised internationally,
such as arms, ammunition and radioactive materials. They require a specific
import licence and quotas have been set up for most of them. Some quotas
refer specifically to individual countries and are usually shared out among
exporters by the authorities of the countries concerned. Others are accorded
on an overall or global basis; these are generally allocated by the United
Kingdom authorities to United Kingdom importers, usually on the basis of
their share of the trade in the commodity in the past. Apart from these
quantitative controls, some further restrictions or prohibitions are applied
on health grounds (for example, on animals, plants and drugs); and there is
also a temporary general import restriction on goods from Rhodesia.
Except for the control necessary to ensure that exports to destinations outside
the sterling area are paid for in the proper manner, United Kingdom exports
are not, except in a very minor way, subject to any government control or
direction. The few controls that are in operation are imposed to supervise
exports of military and strategic importance, to conserve materials which may
be in inadequate supply, to assist exchange control operations in preventing
the export of capital in the form of valuable goods, and to prevent the export
of works of art classed as national treasures. Normally, individual licences are
required for specific consignments of goods subject to export licensing control.
Goods controlled for strategic reasons, not included in the category of atomic
energy materials and appliances, arms and ammunition, may, with certain
exceptions, be exported to the Commonwealth, the Irish Republic, the
Republic of South Africa and the United States of America without licence.
There is also a temporary general export restriction on goods to Rhodesia.
The British Government1 assists exporters by its efforts to create conditions
1 Export promotion is also assisted by the Scottish Council (Development and Industry)
and the Development Corporation for Wales. In Northern Ireland, the Ministry"
of Commerce provides a liaison service with the Board of Trade Export Services Branch
and the overseas posts.

BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Information
and Advice to
Exporters
Export Credit
Insurance
favourable to the export trade and by providing credit insurance facilities and
information and advice about opportunities for trade in other countries.
Its general economic policy includes the use of fiscal, credit and other measures
to maintain a stable economy and to control excessive demand for goods and
services by the home market, and action through international negotiation
to reduce barriers to the free flow of trade and payments.
Facilities exist for the repayment of protective duties paid on goods which
have been imported for export trade purposes. Since October 1964 an export
rebate scheme has been in operation designed to relieve exported goods of the
burden of certain indirect taxes (for example, hydrocarbon oil duty and some
elements of purchase tax) which enter into their production costs.
Exporters wanting assistance and advice can consult the Board of Trade or
the commercial posts of Her Majesty’s Diplomatic Service overseas. There are
over 200 posts in all the principal cities and trade centres abroad and they
supply the Board of Trade with information of every kind aflfecting trade with
their territories.
Overseas officers regularly report on local economic and commercial
conditions, pay special attention to local demand for particular commodities,
and generally assist the exporter to overcome any difficulties he encounters
in trade with the country in question, particularly those arising out of govern¬
mental regulations. These officers investigate potential markets for British
products, advise about methods of trading with particular areas, and seek out
and pass on opportunities for export business and inquiries for British goods.
Assistance is also given to United Kingdom exporters in appointing agents
and locating potential importers. From records kept in London, brought up
to date by reports from its overseas officers, the Export Services Branch of
the Board of Trade can provide information concerning any country on:
1. prospects for United Kingdom exports and requirements of particular
markets;
2. governmental regulations affecting trade, including import restrictions
and tariffs and duties on particular commodities;
3. methods of trading;
4. local tastes and preferences in design; and
5. the commercial standing of firms with which an exporter contemplates
business relations.
The Government’s official information services overseas help to promote
trade by publicising British industrial achievements and providing informa¬
tion on new developments in British industry.
The Export Credits Guarantee Department is an autonomous government
department responsible to the President of the Board of Trade. ECGD carries
on a commercial business, providing insurance for exporters against the main
risks in selling overseas. These facilities have been progressively developed
since the Department was first formed in 1919. From very small beginnings
the amount of business covered by ECGD has grown to reach over a quarter
of the country’s export trade. ECGD is obliged to carry on its business on a
self-supporting basis, and in no way does it provide subsidies to exporters,
nor is it a charge on the taxpayer.
The risks covered include insolvency or protracted default of the buyer,
governmental action which blocks or delays transfer of payment to the
TRADE AND PAYMENTS
Trade Fairs
407
United Kingdom exporter, imposition of new import licensing restrictions
in the buyer’s country, war between the buyer’s country and the United
Kingdom, cancellation or non-renewal of a United Kingdom export licence,
or ‘any other cause of loss occurring outside the United Kingdom and not
within the control of the exporter or the buyer, and not normally insurable
with commercial insurers’. Cover may commence from the date of contract
or (at lower premiums) from the date of shipment.
The main types of export insurance policy are:
1. Comprehensive policies normally covering goods sold on terms of up to
six months’ credit. The exporter insures the whole of his trade, or the
whole of his trade with an agreed group of markets, for the twelve months
(or, in some cases, three years) covered by his policy. For certain engineer¬
ing goods this type of cover is extended to goods sold on credit terms of
up to five years.
2. Specific policies which cover capital goods sold on credit terms normally
not exceeding five years. Specific policies are negotiated for each individual
contract.
In April 1961 ECGD introduced financial guarantees for United Kingdom
banks providing finance on a long-term basis for overseas purchasers of large
capital goods and works, and in January 1962 the London Clearing Banks, the
Scottish Banks and a number of insurance companies agreed to provide finance
at fixed rates of interest for such loans, and also in respect of other export
financing on longer than three years’ credit which was secured by an ECGD
guarantee to the bank concerned. In April 1965 bank guarantees covering
100 per cent of the credit, instead of the previous 90 per cent, were made
available for two or more years’ credit and at the same time the premium
was halved. In March 1966 a similar scheme was introduced to include the
financing of exports for credit between 30 days and two years. Cover is also
available for British concerns carrying out services (including construction
projects), for overseas firms or, under certain conditions, entering into an
international consortium.
The exporter or merchant is normally required to retain an interest in the
debt or risk involved and, consequently, guarantees are given up to a maximum
of between 90 and 95 per cent of loss; 100 per cent cover is now available
for transactions involving over three years’ credit which have already operated
satisfactorily for one year. Premium rates are assessed separately for each
country and vary according to the risks and the terms of payment.
Some 300 exhibitions, of which about 200 were trade fairs, were held in
Britain in 1967, compared with 154 in 1954. Some of the specialised fairs,
such as the Motor Show and the Royal Agricultural Show, attract large
numbers of the public, as well as many trade buyers from home and overseas,
and provide an important means of advertising and selling British goods.
United Kingdom products are shown at most of the large international
trade fairs throughout the world with the support and help of the Board of
Trade. For example, the United Kingdom is usually well represented at the
Milan, Hanover and Poznan Fairs. In addition, since 1954 through a subsi¬
diary company, British Overseas Fairs Ltd., the CBI has organised British
trade fairs in 12 major cities abroad, including the British trade fairs in Oslo
in 1966 and in Toronto in 1967. British trade fairs were also organised by
Industrial and Trade Fairs Ltd. (now merged with British Overseas Fairs
Ltd.), in Moscow in 1961 and Peking in 1964 and again in Moscow in 1966.

BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Exports
Councils
FINANCING OF
INTERNATIONAL

Commodity
Markets
United Kingdom manufacturers have been prominent at the many important
specialised international fairs which are held in North America and Europe.
Participation in trade fairs, ‘British weeks’ and store promotions overseas is
a form of export promotion for which the Government provides information,
advice and, in certain cases, free facilities. The amount allocated to the Board
of Trade for these purposes has risen from £60,000 in 1955-56 to nearly £3
million in 1967-68. (‘British weeks’ differ from trade fairs and exhibitions in
that they are primarily designed to promote sales of consumer goods in shops
overseas.)
The British National Export Council (BNEC), sponsored by representatives
of industry, trade, finance and organised labour in Britain, was established in
July 1964. The Council is an independent body but has the support of the
Government. A Commonwealth Export Council was set up in October 1964
to assist the BNEC in achieving its aims with respect to British exports
to the other members of the Commonwealth. Associated with both these
councils are ten Area Councils or Committees with the primary responsibility
for developing British exports to a particular market or group of markets:
Europe, the Middle East, Latin America, Africa, Asia, the Caribbean,
Southern Africa, the United States, Canada, Australia, New Zealand and
Israel.
The tasks of the BNEC are to keep all British export activity under review;
to initiate, guide and inspire export efforts of British industry; to co-ordinate
the work of the associated Area Councils and to provide the necessary finance
and services for this purpose such as the sending overseas of export missions.
There is an annual scheme for Royal recognition of export and technological
achievement by industry, namely, the Queen’s Award to Industry; the first
awards were made in 1966.
In the nineteenth century, the rapid growth of British industry, commerce
and shipping under the stimulus of the industrial revolution made Britain
the market as well as the workshop of the world. It became the site for the
chief world markets in raw materials (see below), freight, insurance, and
precious metals. A sound commercial banking system and a flexible system
of central bank control have been built up, while specialised institutions such
as discount houses, merchant banks, accepting houses, the stock exchanges,
investment trusts and finance corporations have evolved to satisfy particular
needs for short-term or long-term finance. The facilities provided by merchant
banks and accepting houses, for example, have long been used to finance
shipments of goods not only to and from Britain, but also between overseas
countries themselves.
At the same time, the banks which were already engaged in financing trade
naturally developed to become channels for finance for longer-term ventures.
British capital invested in overseas countries has assisted their development,
increased their output and exports, and provided markets for manufactured
goods. A substantial volume of loans has been floated in the London capital
market by Commonwealth Governments (see p. 4I3)- ^ number of specialised
institutions have also been established in recent years to assist the provision
of financial services for overseas countries (see p. 414).
Britain is the traditional centre for marketing many of the world’s basic
commodities. Among the more important are the Baltic Exchange (the market
for shipping and air transport, grain, seeds and vegetable oils), the London
TRADE AND PAYMENTS
The Foreign
Exchange
Market
The London
Gold Market
The Sterling
System
409
Commodity Exchange (cocoa, coffee, copra, hides and skins, rubber and
sugar), the London Wool Exchange, the London Metal Exchange, the
Liverpool Cotton Exchange and the Liverpool Corn Exchange. A fishmeal
market opened in London in April 1967 and a soya bean oil futures market
in July 1967. These markets not only cater for the import of goods for home
consumption but do much business in effecting transactions between buyers
and sellers in other countries. In addition to these formal markets, there is
scarcely any product which cannot be traded through an intermediary in the
United Kingdom. For example, London is the world’s most important philatelic
market and also the leading international centre for the sale of works of art.
The Foreign Exchange Market is subject to United Kingdom exchange
control regulations governing the purchase and sale of foreign currencies in
the sterling area, but these regulations have been progressively relaxed in
recent years. The turnover of the market has increased materially since the
introduction in December 1958 of external convertibility for the principal
European currencies.
The market consists of about 130 authorised banks and nine firms of
brokers, all linked together by telephone in the United Kingdom, and by
telephone, telex and cable with overseas centres.
The London Gold Market, which had remained closed from the outbreak
of war in 1939, was reopened in March 1954, under the general supervision
of the Bank of England. It has regained its pre-war position as the leading
centre for dealings in gold, handling the major part of the gold coming on to
the free markets of the world. All authorised banks may deal in gold but,
in practice, dealings are largely concentrated in the hands of the five members
of the gold market plus one or two others. Membership of the market confers
the right to be present at the daily price-fixing when the official London gold
price is settled.
An important development was the setting up of a gold pool, initiated in
i960 to co-ordinate the gold operations in London of certain European central
banks and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The pool consists of a
selling consortium, which is not in operation all the time but may be invoked,
to stabilise the market, when conditions demand, and a buying syndicate.
As a result of Britain’s early lead in international trade and finance, several
countries tended not only to use sterling as their natural currency for inter¬
national transactions, but also to maintain central currency reserves in
Britain. When Britain abandoned the gold standard in 1931 these countries,
which came to be known as the ‘sterling bloc’ and later as the ‘sterling area’,
did likewise, and pegged their currency exchange rates to the pound sterling.
In 1939, after the outbreak of war, the pound sterling was no longer freely
convertible into other currencies and the sterling area became more formally
defined as a currency area for exchange control purposes. The United
Kingdom imposes no exchange control on transactions with residents of other
sterling area countries.
All the Commonwealth countries (except Canada and Rhodesia), together
with Iceland, the Irish Republic, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, the Republic of
South Africa, South West Africa, the British Protected States in the Persian
Gulf, and Western Samoa, are members of the sterling area. These countries
contain one-quarter of the world’s population and account for one-quarter of
the world’s trade. The main feature of the sterling area is that the greater part
410
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
of the overseas trade of member countries is financed in sterling, they keep
their foreign reserves largely in the form of sterling and generally maintain
a fixed relationship between their currencies and sterling. Member countries
for the most part sell their foreign currency earnings in London in exchange
for sterling and can purchase for sterling the foreign currency they require.
They generally also sell gold in the London market for sterling. The United
Kingdom reserves of gold and foreign currencies are held in the Exchange
Equalisation Account, which buys and sells exchange in the market as appro¬
priate. All these currency arrangements are voluntary; there are no strict or
centralised rules of conduct.
THE BALANCE OF PAYMENTS
Estimates of the United Kingdom’s balance of payments are published
quarterly and provide a summary of the most important transactions with
other countries, classified by type of transaction and by area. For a summary
of the balance of payments position between 1962 and 1966, see Table 31,
p. 411.
The transactions fall into three main groups—current account, long-term
capital account and monetary movements. The balance on current account is
composed of the balance of visible trade (that is, the difference between mer¬
chandise imports and exports and re-exports) and the balance of invisibles.
On long-term capital account, the main groups of items are intergovernmental
loans (including amortisation) and other identified net long-term investment
abroad by United Kingdom residents, or in the United Kingdom by non¬
residents. The third heading, monetary movements, reflects in part the
United Kingdom’s position as an international banker. It includes identified
capital transactions not of a long-term character (for example, changes in
acceptances), changes in overseas sterling holdings and changes in the United
Kingdom reserves of gold and convertible currencies.
Britain has long been a net exporter of capital. To support this outflow
and, in particular, to give financial assistance to developing countries, it needs
a surplus on current account. It tends to import more than it exports but
its trade deficit has usually been more than offset by the surplus earned on
invisible transactions (see pp. 400—t)* Britain’s net invisible earnings are
now running at a lower level than some ten years ago, so that additional
emphasis is placed on expanding exports and narrowing the gap between
imports and exports.
Between 1945 and 1951 the balance of payments on current account
fluctuated widely. From 1952 to 1963 there were surpluses in all years except
for 1955, i960 and 1961. In 1964 there was a substantial deficit of ^395
million, which fell to £118 million in 1965 and to £59 million in 1966; this
latter figure was made up of a surplus of ^257 million in the current balance
with the overseas sterling area and a deficit of million in the balance
with non-sterling-area countries.
The net outward flow of long-term capital, which reached a peak of ^3^^
million in 1964 and was still at the relatively high level of £239 million in
1965, was reduced substantially in 1966 to £128 million. The reduction was
almost entirely in private investment where the net outward flow fell from
£155 million in 1965 to £49 million in 1966. This resulted from a fall of £41
million to £315 million in net investment abroad and a rise of £65 million to
£266 million in net investment in the United Kingdom, largely as a result of
"ABLE 31
Jnited Kingdom

measures taken in 1965. The net outward movement of official capital at
£79 million was a little less than in 1965. Within official capital, new loans to
overseas governments, largely as part of the aid programme, rose by £20
million between 1965 and 1966; repayments made by the United Kingdom
on intergovernment loans also rose by £32 million, instalments on the post¬
war North American loans having been paid in full for the first time since 1963.
Movements of capital, both short-term and long, may mean that changes
in the balance on current account are not necessarily reflected in the reserves
of gold and convertible currencies.
The general level of the reserves has not changed greatly since the early
1950s and has usually been in the region of ,£1,000 million. In 1964, when
there was a very large deficit in the balance of payments, they fell by £122
million. In 1965, however, they rose by £246 million because of official
external borrowing, mostly from the IMF, and in 1966 they rose by £34
million, primarily as a result of the transfer of ^316 million from the Treasury
portfolio of dollar securities (see p. 412). At the end of the year the reserves
amounted to ,£1,107 million, of which ,£693 million was in gold. Britain’s net
external liabilities in sterling (excluding liabilities to the IMF) amounted to
£3,632 million at the end of 1966. Nearly three-quarters of these were towards
countries in the overseas sterling area. Net external claims in non-sterling
currencies amounted to £34 million.
In addition to its reserves of gold and convertible currencies, Britain has
drawing rights on the IMF based on its quota, which was raised to £696
million in 1959 and to £871 million in March 1966. Under its stand-by
arrangement with the IMF, made in August 1962 and renewed in 1963 an<i
1964, Britain drew $1,000 million (£357 million) in 11 different currencies in

December 1964. At the end of May 1965, $1,400 million (^500 million) was
drawn and in March 1966 a further $123 million (£44 million); repayments
are not due to begin until the end of 1967, but in fact part was repaid in May
1967. Britain had recourse to the IMF’s facilities on three previous occasions,
of which the most recent was in 1961 when $1,500 million was drawn.
Informal arrangements between the central banks of certain European
countries to hold each other’s currencies, together with the gold pool (see
p. 409), provide further means of safeguarding the position of sterling.
In June 1966 ‘swap (credit) facility’ arrangements were entered into by the
Bank of England with nine overseas central banks and the Bank for Inter¬
national Settlements for offsetting the effect on the United Kingdom reserves
of fluctuations in the sterling balances of overseas countries. These were
renewed in March 1967. Alongside these arrangements an earlier facility
arranged in September 1965 with the United States authorities continued in
being, together with a renewable three-month credit facility with the Bank
of France. The total of these credit facilities is $1,000 million. In addition
there is a long-standing reciprocal ‘swap facility’ with the United States
Federal Reserve System of $1,350 million.
An additional line of reserves is provided by the portfolio of dollar securities
held by the Exchange Equalisation Account. Their value had risen to around
$1,400 million (£500 million) by February 1966 when part of the portfolio
(£316 million) was transferred to the gold and convertible currency reserves.
In the estimates of Britain’s external capital assets and liabilities at the end of
1966, it is emphasised that the various elements are fundamentally different
in kind and are subject to different methods of valuation1. But two main
features of Britain’s international capital position continue to stand out. One
is the heavy net long-term indebtedness of the United Kingdom Government
to overseas Governments, which amounted to -£1,218 million in 1966, although
this figure represents a reduction of ^316 million compared with a 1962
estimate.
In marked contrast to this heavy official long-term debt are the much
larger net long-term overseas assets of the private sector, which amounted in
aggregate in 1966 to about £5,500 million representing an improvement over
1962 of about £1,000 million. It is estimated that by the end of 1966 the gross
long-term assets of the private sector were approaching £10,000 million, of
which direct investment, including oil, accounted for some £6,500 million
(at book value) and portfolio investment for well over £3,000 million (at
current market prices).
Britain’s official long-term liabilities have mostly arisen from the second world
war and its aftermath. At the end of 1966 about £2,500 million was still out¬
standing, of which £1,836 million was owed to other Governments, the greater
part to the United States and Canada.
The largest item among official external long-term claims is British
Government aid in the form of loans (see p. 415).
Overseas investors in Britain are allowed to repatriate the proceeds of the
sale of their investments, including any capital gains that may have accrued.
Earned profits and dividends can be transferred, irrespective of the amount;
transfers of this kind have never been restricted.
1 Bank of England, Quarterly Bulletin, September 1967.
Private
Investment:
Outgoing
TRADE AND PAYMENTS 413
Overseas long-term investment in the private sector of the British economy
has increased substantially since the war. According to the Bank of England
estimates the market value of overseas portfolio holdings of British company
securities at the end of 1966 was of the order of ,£1,025 million. The book
value of net assets held in Britain (that is, overseas direct investment) by
companies incorporated abroad (except banks, oil and insurance companies)
was about £2,250 million, and the approximate book value of the net assets
of United States and European oil companies was some £925 million.
By far the largest proportion of private investment by overseas countries
in Britain is made by United States firms. It has been provisionally estimated1
that the total value of United States direct investment in Britain amounted to
$5,119 million (,£1,828 million) at the end of 1965, compared with $847
million (,£303 million) in 1951. Nearly two-thirds of these investments were
in manufacturing, one-fifth in the oil industry and rather less than one-tenth
in distribution.
Private investment abroad may take several forms: portfolio investment,
that is, investment in overseas securities including the loans raised by overseas
countries on the London capital market; or direct investment by the estab¬
lishment of subsidiary companies abroad, by ploughing back profits earned
overseas, or by acquiring an interest in an overseas enterprise.
Apart from the voluntary programme introduced early in 1966, and still
in force, aimed at slowing down British investment in Australia, South Africa,
New Zealand and the Irish Republic, the United Kingdom imposes no
restriction on investment in the sterling area by United Kingdom residents
and about 50 per cent of Britain’s total supply of private long-term capital
abroad and 60 per cent of its direct investment goes to sterling area countries.
Direct investment is frequently made from a firm’s existing resources.
However, borrowers outside the United Kingdom must in certain circum¬
stances obtain the consent of the Treasury (which is advised by the Capital
Issues Committee) if the amount borrowed exceeds £50,000 in any one year.
Borrowing by Commonwealth and Colonial Governments in the London
capital market has fallen in recent years, but averaged about £50 million a
year in the 1950s. The market’s facilities have been made available to the
member governments of EFTA. Finance is also made available by the
Commonwealth Development Finance Company (see p. 391).
Investment outside the sterling area is subject to Exchange Control regula¬
tions. Broadly speaking, direct investment is not permitted unless it promises
benefit to the United Kingdom balance of payments in the short-term.
Britain’s private long-term capital assets abroad include portfolio invest¬
ments which, at the end of 1966, had a total estimated market value of some
£3,200 million.
In addition, there are direct British investments abroad. Bank of England
estimates indicate that their book value, relating to all companies except oil,
insurance and banking, was worth about £4,500 million at the end of 1966.
The approximate book value of oil companies’ assets at the end of 1966 was
some £1,500 million. The total value of the overseas interests of British
insurance companies is not known but, again according to estimates, the value
of direct investments by these companies at the end of 1966 in the United
States alone amounted to about £400 million. The British insurance industry
1 United States Department of Commerce’s Survey of Current Business, September
1966.

also operates extensively in other foreign countries and throughout the
Commonwealth. A survey by the Board of Trade estimated that the flow of
private direct investment abroad by United Kingdom companies (excluding
oil) was about £314 million in 1966; 63 per cent was directed to the sterling
area. The figures include long-term and short-term investment and reinvested
profits.
Owing to the increase in recent years in British Government aid to developing
countries, intergovernmental loans form the largest item among official
external long-term claims. The total of such loans outstanding at the end of
1966 was £618 million and included £480 million in loans to governments of
overseas sterling area countries. New Government loans (less repayments)
totalled £113 million in 1965-66. Amounts owed by countries outside the
sterling area are mostly in respect of advances by the British Government in
the second world war. Other official lending, which amounted to ^162 million
at the end of 1966, includes investments of the Commonwealth Development
Corporation (see below) and the United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority.
In addition, there are the official subscriptions to, and shareholdings in,
international financial organisations (see below). The Government also owns
real estate overseas, such as embassy buildings and military installations.
BRITISH
GOVERNMENT
AID FOR
DEVELOPMENT
OVERSEAS
The total disbursed to the developing countries between 1945 and 1966 in the
form of loans and grants for economic development, technical assistance,
budget support and emergency relief, and of contributions to multilateral
agencies providing financial aid and technical assistance amounted to over
£2,000 million; and in the four years 1963-66 it averaged £190 million a
year (see Table 32). Since the end of the 1950s Britain’s aid programme has
become world-wide in scope, and the net flow of resources to the developing
countries, including private capital as well as official aid, has exceeded 1 per
cent of the national income in each of the last five years. In 1966 total aid
disbursements amounted to £209 million; bilateral disbursements to 116

and loans) and £31 million technical assistance. Assistance provided through

Economic difficulties in 1966 made it necessary to introduce measures to
restrain public expenditure and particularly expenditure overseas. As a result
the Government announced that the aid target for the financial year 1967-68
would be £205 million as compared with £225 million in 1966-67.
Historically, Britain’s aid programme began as part of the discharge of her
responsibilities towards the dependent territories and the main emphasis
today remains on territories which are, or were until recently, a British
responsibility.
In 1966, ^138 million of bilateral financial aid (66 per cent of the total
programme) was disbursed to Commonwealth countries both dependent and
independent. Of the total of £158 million bilateral financial aid in 1966,
36 per cent was in grant form and 64 per cent in loans. Grants are pre¬
dominantly for budgetary aid and for general development; about two-thirds
of the loans are provided for general development purposes. The terms of new
development loans from Britain have been progressively softened since 1958
and a new policy of interest-free loans for certain developing countries was
introduced in June 1965. In 1966, the total value of loan commitments entered
into, excluding investments by the Commonwealth Development Corporation
(CDC) was over ^87 million and of these over 90 per cent were on interest-free
terms. Among the recipients of interest-free loans in 1966 were Ceylon, India,
Kenya, Malawi, Pakistan, Turkey and Uganda. Where loans are made on
interest-bearing terms waivers of interest are granted in appropriate cases.
Of all loans committed in 1966, 97 per cent of value carried grace periods for
capital repayments averaging about six years, while the weighted average
maturity of loans was about 24 years.
Until 1966 loans for development assistance in both independent Common¬
wealth and foreign countries were administered by the Export Credits
Guarantee Department. Loans for development and other purposes are now
administered by the Ministry of Overseas Development, the department
responsible for the official aid programme. They are used mainly for the
purchase of goods, equipment and services from Britain, although there may
be a substantial element for local costs in appropriate cases. Between 1958 and
the end of 1966 about 109 loans were negotiated involving a commitment of
£529 million, of which £396 million has been disbursed. The largest recipients
have been India and Pakistan.
Aid to dependent territories includes budgetary assistance, development
grants and loans under the Colonial Development and Welfare (CD & W)
Acts, technical assistance, and investments by the CDC. Grants account for the
predominant share of this assistance. In the post-war period aid to the
dependent territories increased to a peak of £ 100 million in 1961 but, with the
achievement of independence by many of these territories, this has declined
to £37 million in 1966. Britain is providing a total of £390 million for devel¬
opment and welfare schemes over the period 1946-70 of which £343 million
had been committed by the end of March 1967. Exchequer loans in this
context were introduced in 1959 to provide a supply of loan finance to replace
the traditional source—the London capital market. A total of £125 million
is being made available over the period 1959-70, and loans approved to the
end of March 1967 total ^90 million.

BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Although Britain’s formal responsibility to a dependent territory ceases when
it attains independence, its continuing needs have been recognised by offering
aid in appropriate forms. Almost all of the independent Commonwealth
countries have received help towards their development by way of loans; most
have received it for special purposes connected with the transition to inde¬
pendence. Some have continued to receive budgetary aid, and all except
India, Pakistan and Ceylon can receive CDC investment. In 1966 independent
Commonwealth countries received £128 million (68 per cent of bilateral
economic aid).
The CDC was set up in 1948 to provide finance and management for
development projects in Commonwealth countries, and acts on a commercial
basis, often in partnership with private enterprise or territorial governments.
It receives advances from the British Government (£7-2 million in 1966).
At the end of 1966, £109-2 million had been invested out of a total
commitment of ^132-8 million. Of the latter, £23 million was in the Far
East and £20 million in the Caribbean, and almost all of the remainder was
in Africa.
Expenditure on technical assistance, as a proportion of total aid expenditure,
has increased markedly from 5 per cent in 1962 to 15 per cent in 1966. The
largest component of expenditure (£20 million in 1966) is on sending or
maintaining experts including those in the Overseas Service Aid Scheme
(OSAS) and volunteers in developing countries; the next largest is for students
and trainees in Britain (£4 million).
Under the OSAS Britain meets the additional costs of employing experienced
expatriate British personnel in the public services. The scheme cost £15 million
in 1966 and covered over 10,000 expatriate officers in 41 Commonwealth
countries, principally in East and Central Africa. Britain receives large
numbers of students and trainees from developing countries. Over 9,000
were financed in Britain in 1966 under regional programmes of technical
assistance, by awards under the Commonwealth Education Co-operation
Scholarships and Bursary Schemes, and under the various schemes of the
British Council. At the end of 1966, of the 15,500 British experts and
volunteers who were working in developing countries and financed by the
British Government or recruited by multilateral agencies, almost 9,000 were
engaged in the maintenance and improvement of education, public adminis¬
tration and communications.
The first volunteers were sent overseas in 1958-59; the British Volunteer
Programme has since been expanded and there were 1,720 volunteers in
developing countries in 1966-67. This includes graduates and school-leavers,
whose recruitment, training and placing overseas is undertaken by a number
of voluntary bodies; 75 per cent of the British costs (£700,000 in 1966-67)
are met by the British Government.
Britain is the second largest contributor (after the United States) to the
World Bank group of institutions. Britain has provided £31 million to the
United Nations Development Programme since 1950 and has provided more
experts and training places under multilateral schemes than any other
country—750 experts and 168 training places in 1966. Other contributions
are to the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees
(UNRWA), the World Food Programme, the United Nations Children’s
Fund (UNICEF) and the Asian Development Bank.

TRADES
TRADE AND PAYMENTS 417
INTERNAL TRADE
The internal trade of the United Kingdom can be divided into two broad
categories: trade in raw materials, capital goods and intermediate products
(for example, vehicle components) and trade in consumer goods, involving
the network of distributive trades by which home produced or imported
goods reach the consumer. (The pattern of consumers’ expenditure is outlined
in Chapter 10, The National Economy.)
There have been a number of official statistical inquiries into the distributive
trades. Most recently, during 1963 and 1964, the results of a full Census
of Distribution for 1961 were published by the Board of Trade, covering the
retail and (related) service trades in Great Britain. This was the second full
census of its kind undertaken in Britain; the first, covering also the wholesale
trades, related to 1950. A large-scale sample census, however, was conducted
by the Board of Trade into the retail and service trades in 1957 and a full-scale
inquiry into the wholesale trade for 1959. Further censuses of the wholesale
trades in 1965 and the retail trades and certain service trades in 1966 have
been taken and the data obtained are being prepared for publication. Sample
monthly and annual inquiries are also undertaken, covering such aspects of
the distributive trades as turnover, stocks and capital expenditure. Most of the
figures given in the following pages derive from either the last published
censuses or the sample inquiries.
The first census of retail distribution and other services to be taken in
Northern Ireland relates to 1965.
Only a proportion of the trade in consumer goods passes through whole¬
salers: sales are also made to consumers through producers’ own selling
organisations (including their own retail outlets and mail order businesses);
and other sales are made directly by producers to retailers. Wholesale channels
are particularly in evidence in the distribution of textiles, agricultural produce
and foodstuffs. The inquiry made by the Board of Trade in respect of 1959
showed that out of a total of 19,000 business units engaged in wholesale
distribution in Great Britain, over 3,000 dealt in clothing, footwear and
textiles, 2,000 in grocery and provisions, 2,000 in vegetables and fruit, and
over 3,000 in other food and in drink. In addition, there were 8,000 dealers
(wholesale or retail) in coal, builders’ materials, grain or agricultural supplies,
and 7,000 dealers in other industrial materials and machinery. The value of
stocks held by wholesalers and dealers at the end of 1966 is estimated at £1,189
million; expenditure on capital assets during the year was about £177 million.
Methods of wholesale distribution vary according to the type of merchan¬
dise handled. Fish, for example, is auctioned at the ports to port whole¬
salers (who sell to inland wholesalers at the main distribution centres) or,
increasingly, is sold by contract to fryers and processors, or direct to retailers.
Fruit and vegetables may be sold by growers to commission agents (who
dispose of the produce either to wholesalers or direct to retailers) or the
grower may deal only with wholesale firms. The sale of some agricultural
products is regulated by statutory marketing boards (see p. 326).
London’s wholesale markets are of outstanding importance in the
distribution of foodstuffs, particularly imported supplies. Covent Garden
handles about 1 -2 million tons of fruit and vegetables each year; over 405,000
tons of meat and poultry pass through Smithfield market each year; Billings¬
gate is the principal distributing centre in Britain for fish. Other markets in
London include those at Leadenhall (poultry) and Spitalfields (fruit and
vegetables).
418
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The co-operative movement in Britain has established its own wholesale
societies, the two largest being the Co-operative Wholesale Society Ltd.
(CWS) and the Scottish Co-operative Wholesale Society Ltd. (SCWS), to
serve the needs of retail societies, membership being restricted to incorporated
co-operative organisations. The CWS had sales of over £480 million in 1966
and the SCWS had sales of some £90 million.
Two kinds of voluntary wholesale chains have developed in recent years
particularly in the food trades. Firstly, local retailers’ buying groups were
formed and later (since 1954) wholesaler-sponsored voluntary chains (groups
of independent traders linked to a wholesaler or a group of wholesalers). Both
kinds benefit from the lower operating costs of large-scale trading without
losing their independence and both are numerically of roughly equal impor¬
tance. The 1961 Census of Distribution showed that about 27 per cent (or
40 per cent in terms of turnover) of smaller grocers—mostly medium-sized
independents and small multiples with not more than nine branches—then
belonged to these chains.
RETAIL TRADE
Types of
Retailers
Retail businesses in Britain may be classified under three main headings:
(1) multiple traders, that is, organisations other than co-operative societies
with ten or more branches; (2) retail co-operative societies (see p. 419); and
(3) independent retail businesses, including for this purpose the small
multiple stores (that is, chains of stores with nine or fewer branches). Busi¬
nesses in each of these categories may own department stores. Other retail
outlets include gas and electricity showrooms owned by the area gas and
electricity boards and mail order businesses (see p. 422). Table 33 shows the
number of establishments and turnover for some of the main groups of retail
business between 1957 and 1966.
A very wide range is covered in the size of retailing establishments. On
the one hand there were ten shops (nine of them department stores) with
sales in 1961 exceeding £5 million or having takings of more than £2,000 an
hour; at the other extreme there were more than 70,000 establishments taking
less than ^2,000 in a year. Some of these are market and street traders, whose
volume of business may be very small.
The 1961 census showed that, in comparison with 1957, a larger volume of
trade had been handled by almost exactly the same number of shops and by
much the same number of people. A notable feature was the continued

expansion of the large multiple firms; these showed a further increase between
1961 and 1966 relative to other types of shops. Independent shops, however,
still account for half of Britain’s retail trade.
According to the Census of Distribution there were nearly 70,000 shops
owned by multiples (including multiple departmental stores) in 1961, having
a total turnover of ^2,580 million. This form of organisation showed the
largest rise in numbers between 1957 and 1961 and their share in total sales
went up from 25 per cent to 29 per cent. In the food trades their turnover
increased by 42 per cent, compared with 11 per cent for independent retailers
and only 3 per cent for co-operative societies. Large traders of all kinds
(including co-operative societies) accounted for nearly 50 per cent of sales
in food shops as a whole and for 64 per cent of the sales of all clothing shops.
The 7,500 shops with a turnover of over £50,000 belonging to independent
businesses accounted for 12 per cent of total retail trade. The share in total
retail trade of co-operative stores dropped from 12 to 11 per cent between
1957 and 1961 though the number of stores increased slightly. They account
for a fifth of the turnover of all grocers and a third of the turnover of all
dairymen.
The retail co-operative societies are voluntary non-profit-making organisa¬
tions engaged in retail trade and controlled by their members, who are also
their customers. Any operating surplus is returned periodically to members as
a dividend; the amount distributed is proportionate to the value of the
member’s purchases.
Retail co-operatives also sell to the general public, but membership is open
to anyone paying a small deposit on a minimum share, which entitles the
member to an equal voice with other members in determining the policy of
the society. Investment by individual members is limited to £1,000 (less in
some societies). Only a low rate of interest is paid on the shares.
At the end of 1965 there were 804 retail co-operative societies registered
under the Industrial and Provident Societies Act. Amalgamations are slowly
diminishing the number of societies (the total in 1958 was 1,015). By far the
largest single society in Britain is the London Co-operative Society with just
over 1 million members and a turnover of over £60 million a year. Total
sales of the retail co-operative societies in 1966 reached about £1,100 million
(this figure includes certain activities not covered by the Census of Distribution
figure in Table 33). The approximate average rate of dividend paid to
members in 1966 was 9d. in the £.
Smaller independent shops have been giving ground only slowly in the face
of increased competition from the larger undertakings. The proprietors of
many of the smaller shops often have other means of livelihood. Average
turnover per shop has continued to increase, though by less than for the retail
trade as a whole. None the less, allowing for a 4 per cent increase in prices,
the average small independent shop sold more goods in 1961 than in 1957.
There were nearly 800 department stores in Britain in 1961, having a turnover
of nearly £550 million—about 6 per cent of the total turnover of all retail
establishments. Department stores were defined for the purposes of the 1961
census as having 25 or more persons concerned with selling clothing and at
least four other major commodity groups. Women’s, girls’ and infants’ wear,
haberdashery and other drapery were the most important categories of goods
sold, accounting for over a third of turnover. A firm or a group of firms

frequently owns several department stores. Three groups of this kind owned

for nearly 40 per cent of the turnover in this kind of business.
Out of a total of over 580,000 establishments recorded by the 1961 Census
of Distribution, and shown in Table 34, grocery and other food retailing
groups numbered over 278,000 establishments, and the clothing and foot¬

Though the total value of retail trade in Great Britain (exclusive of
electricity and gas showrooms and mail order business) rose by 18 per cent
between 1957 and 1961, rates of growth varied appreciably between different
types of trade. The slowest growth between 1957 and 1961 was in the food,
drink and tobacco sector, in clothing and footwear, and in the category
including booksellers and stationers; this trend seems to be continuing, except
that tobacco and confectionery have gone ahead. The fastest growth in
specialised shops between 1957 and 1961 was in furniture, general household
goods (other than furniture) and chemists’ and photographic goods, but the
pace has apparently slackened since 1961. Gas and electricity showrooms’
business was buoyant between 1957 and 1961 (and still is for gas showrooms);
their combined turnover, however, is relatively small, amounting in 1961 to
slightly more than £100 million.

The aggregate number of shops in Great Britain decreased slightly between
I957 an<^ There were modest decreases in shops selling groceries,
clothing and footwear, and in the booksellers and stationers group, and a
noticeable fall in the number of confectioners, tobacconists and newsagents.
The highest proportionate increase was in the number of general household
goods shops.
Provisional results of the Northern Ireland 1965 Census of Retail Distribu¬
tion (and other services) show total spending of ^385 million through 22,000
establishments.
Retail prices, which had previously been rising for some years until 1958, were
relatively stable in 1959 an<^ I9^°> again moved upwards between 1961
and 1966. The rise was relatively large in 1964 on account of higher import
prices and increased taxes.
1 he development of self-service in retail establishments since 1950 has
probably contributed to the notable expansion in sales achieved by the
multiple stores. According to the 1961 Census of Distribution, self-service
sales exceeded £525 million, two and a half times the level of 1957, and the
average turnover in fully self-service grocery shops was over £55,000
compared with £13,000 in other grocery shops. About 9,500 stores, of which
9,100 were grocers, were operated wholly or partly on self-service lines
towards the end of 1961, compared with 4,000 in 1957, less than 500 in
I95° and 10 in 1947; by the end of 1966 it is estimated that there were
probably over 17,000.
Supermarkets may be defined as self-service shops with a minimum selling
area of 2,000 square feet. There were about 870 supermarkets in 1961, accord¬
ing to the Census of Distribution, of which 524 were owned by multiples,
308 by co-operative societies and 38 by independents. It has been estimated
that by the end of 1966 over 3,000 had been opened.
New forms of automatic vending machines have come to the fore since
1955, and an increasing number of coin-operated machines are being installed
in factories (over 7,000 factories are estimated to provide facilities) and
commercial premises as well as in normal retail outlets. The range of goods
sold is widening; in addition to the traditional cigarettes, sweets and stamps
there are now machines selling hot and cold beverages, prepared foodstuffs,
stockings, paper-back books and other commodities including coal and various
solid fuels. Various estimates have been made of the trade done through
automatic vending machines; possibly some 300,000 machines are in use, and
total sales may be of the order of £20 million to £25 million a year. Traders
who owned and operated automatic vending machines, but were not otherwise
engaged in retail trade, had sales of over £4 million in 1961.
Some 11,700 mobile shops1 were reported in the Census of Distribution for
1961, with sales amounting to £93 million. Nearly a quarter of this turnover
was concentrated in Scotland (where the density of population is lower than
in England) compared with a tenth of all retail sales. Co-operative societies
accounted for 39 per cent of sales through mobile food shops, against 6 per
cent in ordinary food shops. For the most part, mobile shops were concerned
with food sales; about 42 per cent were travelling grocers, and over 28 per
cent and 21 per cent respectively were greengrocers and butchers. Only a

very small proportion (about 6 per cent) were non-food shops, and these
specialised mainly in paraffin supplies and hardware.
Stamp trading—the practice of giving stamps in proportion to the value of
goods sold, which may be exchanged later for a ‘free gift’—has expanded
rapidly in recent years. There are, however, signs that the rate of growth is
levelling off. According to an unofficial estimate made in 1964 they are saved,
on average, by about 36 in every 100 women in Britain, with a possibly
higher proportion in the London area, and are given by some 50,000 retail
outlets, the majority of which are food shops and petrol stations. The two
largest stamp companies in Britain claim about 90 per cent of the business,
the rest being shared among a number of small companies. Issuers of stamps
are required by law to mark them with their cash value and redeem them in
cash if so requested. Gifts distributed by the companies had a retail value of
about £8 million in 1965.
A facility which is being extended in Britain is the ‘credit card’. Users are
issued with a card on production of which their signature is accepted on
bills in participating shops, hotels and restaurants. The issuers then meet
the bills and recover from the card-holder through a single account presented
periodically. Normally users are required to pay a regular subscription as
well.
Mail order trading has been one of the most rapidly growing forms of selling
in Britain in recent years. Mail order sales through all channels reached
£276 million in 1961. The 1961 Census of Distribution showed that the sales
of specialist retail mail order businesses had risen from ^126 million in 1957
to £227 million in 1961, a rise of 80 per cent; they showed a further increase
of 84 per cent between 1961 and 1966. Mail order sales in 1961 by large
retailers amounted to ^12 million, by manufacturers to £34 million and by
wholesalers to ^4 million.
An inquiry conducted by the Board of Trade showed that sales by manu¬
facturers direct to the public totalled £144 million in 1961, compared with
£70 million in 1950. Mail order sales accounted for 24 per cent of the former
total, sales to employees for 11 per cent, and charges for work done for 9 per
cent. Other direct sales, including sales by door-to-door salesmen, accounted
for the balance. Included in these sales were items as various as carpets,
washing machines, brushes, books and soft drinks.
Closely connected with the distributive trades are those trades which offer a
service directly to the public, notably the catering and hotel trades, laundries
and dry cleaners, the garage and motor repair trades, hairdressers and boot
and shoe repairers.
An inquiry undertaken by the Board of Trade relating to 1964 showed
that there were 151,000 establishments primarily concerned with catering
(defined to cover public houses, canteens, and fish and chip shops, as well as
licensed hotels and restaurants, etc.) with a total turnover in that year of
^2,036 million. Hotels and holiday camps (excluding boarding houses and
unlicensed hotels) had receipts of about ^286 million, of which ^124 million
was from residential accommodation. Nearly half the total turnover of the
catering trades was from the sale of alcoholic drinks. Between 1964 and 1966
the catering trades’ turnover increased by 11 per cent.
There were about 1,400 commercial laundry businesses with an annual
turnover of about £67 million in 1961. Between 1961 and 1966 turnover

increased by 23 per cent. Dry cleaning firms in 1961 had a turnover of £40
million which increased by 30 per cent between 1961 and 1966.
An inquiry undertaken by the Board of Trade for 1962 showed that there were
nearly 47,000 businesses in the motor trades in Britain, with nearly 58,000
establishments. Their total turnover amounted to £2,979 million, including
transactions between traders amounting to roughly £6oo-£8oo million.
Traders classified as new vehicle dealers had nearly 14,700 establishments
and accounted for two-thirds of the total turnover. Over 14,000 establishments
were classified as being primarily petrol stations, and 12,600 were also general
repairers. Between 1962 and 1966 the motor trades turnover has increased
by 33 per cent.
Takings in hairdressing establishments increased very rapidly between 1950
(£38 million) and 1961 (£97 million). They rose again between 1961 and 1966
by another 15 per cent. There are about 40,000 hairdressing establishments.
There are some 10,000 establishments specialising in boot and shoe repairs
(excluding repairs handled through footwear shops); they had takings of £25
million in 1961.
Other establishments found in shopping areas and offering a service to the
public include launderettes (over 1,000 businesses were running these in 1961),
licensed betting offices (over 15,000 in 1964) and over 3,500 funeral under¬
taking businesses.
The annual expenditure of British industry on packaging has been estimated
at over £750 million. The expansion of self-service shops, the growth of sales
in the form of branded and standardised products, and developments in partly
prepared foods, for example, ready-washed vegetables and ready-made cake
mixes, have been major factors in the great changes which have taken place in
packaging methods. Paper packaging, including cartons and boxes, remains
the most extensively used with a turnover of £340 million a year, the fastest
growing sector being paper sacks. New uses are being found for tinplate
(output, £120 million a year), especially in sales of soft drinks and beer. Glass
and plastic packaging each account for about £60 million a year. The use of
plastics continues to develop; output of polypropylene film reached some
4,000 tons in 1966.
The rapid growth of sales of household and durable consumer goods, such
as cars, furniture, washing machines, television sets, refrigerators and cookers,
has been greatly helped by instalment purchase. Instalment credit debt
outstanding to the main providers amounted to £1,005 million at the end of
March 19671; nearly three-quarters was owed to finance companies and the
remainder to durable goods shops and department stores. There are a large
number of finance companies but a high proportion of the business is done by
a small number which operate on a national scale.
The Board of Trade has powers to regulate the terms of hire-purchase and
credit sales agreements in order to restrain the expansion of consumer credit.
The current terms are: a minimum deposit of 25 per cent on most durable
consumer goods except, mattresses and furniture (15 per cent), photographic
and optical equipment (33^ per cent) and cookers and water-heaters (10 per
cent). There is usually a maximum repayment period of 30 months for most
1 Not included in this total is the debt of £181 million outstanding to certain other
instalment credit retailers.
