goods except cookers and water heaters (4 years), cars and motor cycles
(3 years), and photographic and optical equipment (2 years).
Hire-purchase in Northern Ireland directly financed by the major finance
houses operating from offices in Northern Ireland amounted in 1966 to over
£14^ million and at the end of 1966 the hire-purchase debt owed to them
amounted to ^15^ million.
Advertising
and Industrial
Information
Public Relations
About £439 million is estimated to have been spent on all forms of advertising
in 1966. About £289 million was expended on press advertising and £109
million (including tax) was spent on television advertising. The remainder
was divided between other media, such as posters, films, catalogues, window
displays, exhibitions, and free samples and gift schemes. Most of the advertis¬
ing is carried out by advertising agencies, which, in some cases, also provide
marketing, consumer research and other services; their representative
organisation is the Institute of Practitioners in Advertising. The trade associa¬
tion for the industry as a whole, including agencies, advertisers and owners of
advertising media, is the Advertising Association. It was responsible for the
setting up of the Advertising Standards Authority, an independent body whose
objective is the promotion and enforcement of the highest standards of
advertising, in particular through the British Code of Advertising Practice.
Industry and commerce have in recent years paid increasing attention to
improving public understanding of their work and objectives. Public relations
consultancy firms and the public relations departments of advertising agencies
provide general services, apart from the increasing employment by industrial
organisations and trade associations of staff specialists in public relations.
Their professional body, founded in 1948, is the Institute of Public Relations:
not only commerce and industry, but the professions, national associations,
central and local government are represented within the Institute.
Consumer Various legislative measures exist in the United Kingdom to protect the
Protection consumer against specific abuses. Non-statutory organisations also exist to
further the consumer’s interests. Weights and measures legislation, one of
the earliest forms of consumer protection, was brought up to date and
extended in scope by the Weights and Measures Act 1963; it is strictly
enforced by qualified inspectors of local weights and measures authorities.
The Merchandise Marks Acts 1887-1953 are designed to ensure that the
marking of goods is both accurate and honest. The purity, hygiene and
description of food are controlled by the Food and Drugs Acts 1955, 1956
and 1958. The Consumer Protection Act 1961 gives the Home Office power
to make regulations to ensure the safety of any class of goods.
The Hire-Purchase Act 1965 and the Hire-Purchase (Scotland) Act 1965
provide safeguards to the consumer who buys goods on hire-purchase or
credit sale terms. The protection extends to agreements up to £2,000
although most of the safeguards do not apply to credit sale agreements for
less than £30. Similar legislation has been in operation in Northern Ireland
since 1st July 1966. As a precaution against fraud, virtually every hire-
purchase agreement on a car is registered with H.P. Information Ltd., a
non-profit-making company whose members are car dealers or finance
companies concerned with car sales; dealers and finance houses can check
with it in confidence.
The British Standards Institution (see p. 263) has established a number of
standards for consumer goods, and the Council of Industrial Design (see
p. 221) helps to foster improvements in the design of consumer goods.
TRADE AND PAYMENTS
The Consumer
Council
Consumer
Associations
Resale Price
Maintenance
425
The Consumer Council, financed by a grant-in-aid from the Board of Trade,
was set up in 1963 to concern itself with and promote the consumer’s interests.
Within the limits of its finance and terms of reference it is fully independent
and so is free to criticise government departments and to bring pressure to
bear on other bodies. It is specifically debarred from engaging in comparative
testing of products, from law enforcement action and from taking up
complaints on behalf of individual consumers. It works in close touch with
the Citizens’ Advice Bureaux (see p. 129).
Advice to its members on the merits of consumer goods is provided by the
Consumers’ Association (CA), a private body financed by the subscriptions of
members. It arranges tests and makes reports on the quality of goods bought
on the open market and its findings are published in its monthly bulletin
Which ?, issued to subscribers. The Research Institute for Consumer Affairs,
established with a grant from the CA, undertakes research into consumer
goods and services, and publishes reports. There are also a number of local
independent consumer groups, which in 1963 formed themselves into a
national Federation of Consumer Groups. Assistance with certain aspects
of consumer guidance is also given by a number of other private bodies and by
certain government departments and local authorities. Individual trades and
industries have also taken measures to raise standards of quality.
The practice of resale price maintenance and its enforcement by the cutting
off of supplies was made unlawful under the Resale Prices Act 1964, though
exemptions may be granted on certain grounds by the Restrictive Practices
Court (see p. 252).
16 Labour
First Factory
Acts
Early Trade
Unions and
Employers’
Associations
Formation of
Ministry of
Labour
Less than 200 years ago, government concern with all aspects of employment
was at a minimum. It was generally considered that it was not a function
of government to ‘interfere’ between employers and employed, and that the
unregulated pursuit of self-interest would of itself produce the best results
for both parties and for the community. The statutes passed in medieval
and Tudor times to regulate the level of wages and the training of craftsmen
were no longer applied, and it was a matter of principle that the new industrial
development based on the introduction of power-driven machinery and the
factory system should proceed without hindrance from any restriction on
the conditions under which workers were employed in the mills and mines.
Even associations of workmen seeking by joint action to improve their situation
were forbidden as a threat to civil peace and individual liberty.
State intervention came first in the sphere of safety, health and welfare. By
the end of the eighteenth century, a reaction had begun in favour of legislation
to protect the workers, especially little children, from excessive toil and
hardship, and the reformers became strong enough to secure the passage of
the first factory legislation in 1802. The first effective Factory Act was that
of 1833 which not only limited the hours of work for children but set up a
national system of inspection to enforce its provisions. Since that date,
legislation extending, strengthening, adapting and consolidating the statutory
protection for employees has been passed at an accelerating rate. (The record
of legislation providing for monetary recompense for industrial injury or
death is part of the history of social security, see p. 136.)
Trade unions ceased in 1824 to be ‘actionable conspiracies in restraint of
trade’, but their activities were still closely circumscribed and they had no
proper legal status, while their development met strong opposition. However,
during the nineteenth century new unions of skilled and semi-skilled workers
grew up, more soundly organised and more acceptable to the public because
their ambitions were more restricted. A number of employers’ associations,
mainly local, were formed during this time, unions and employers learned to
bargain together, and procedures for conciliation and arbitration began to
be agreed. Following the recommendations of a Royal Commission, legisla¬
tion was passed in the 1870s clarifying and regularising the legal status of
trade unions. Today it is customary for employers’ associations and trade
unions to be statutorily provided with representation on advisory committees
and administrative tribunals concerned with labour questions. For workers
in trades with weak organisation, which were unable to secure and enforce
minimum standards of remuneration, the Trade Boards Act 1909 introduced
for the first time in the modern era a state-sponsored machinery to determine
and enforce minimum rates of wages.
In the following year, 1910, the first employment exchanges were introduced.
This move represented the defeat of the concept that people unemployed
were so through unwillingness rather than inability to find work. The
employment exchanges provided a nation-wide service for putting employers
LABOUR
Growth in
Working
Population
427
in touch with workers and vice versa. In 1917 the exchanges were transferred
to the newly created Ministry of Labour. (The factory inspectorate was
added to its responsibilities in 1940-) This department is today the principal
instrument of the government’s labour policies in Great Britain; in Northern
Ireland employment matters are among the responsibilities of the Ministry
of Health and Social Services. The range of services has extended to take in
special help to particular groups, such as disabled and young people, the
provision and promotion of training, measures to foster good industrial
relations and good personnel management practices, and the administration
or supervision of schemes to give financial benefits to the unemployed, the
migrant worker, the redundant and those in training.
The experience of mass unemployment between the two world wars led
to a new appreciation of the role the government could and should play in
securing for the people the opportunity to work; the first legislation in Great
Britain dealing with structural unemployment was passed in 1934 and
provided inducements to industry to settle in areas of heavy unemployment.
In the last two decades governments in Britain have accepted an even wider
responsibility for securing, without interference with individual liberty and
freedom of choice, an adequate supply of manpower, in the right numbers,
with the right skills, in the right places, as part of its total concern, in association
and consultation with the representatives of employers and employees, for the
development of the whole economy.
MANPOWER
The total working population of Great Britain at the middle of June 1966
was about 25^ million, some 48 per cent of the total population, and included
about 74 per cent of persons of normal working age (15 to 59 years for
women, 15 to 64 years for men). About 93 per cent of the men of working
age are today in or seeking gainful work. The remaining 7 per cent consist
mainly of those continuing their education, of the severely disabled and of
some persons of private means. The proportion of women of working age
in or seeking gainful work is much lower, about 53 per cent, as many
housewives either do not wish or cannot manage to take employment outside
the home. Just over half of the women at work are married. Besides those of
normal working age, there are probably over a million older men and women
still at work. The great majority of the working population work for a wage
or salary, but about 1*7 million are employers or self-employed.
Northern Ireland, which has 2-7 per cent of the total population of the
United Kingdom, has 2-3 per cent of its working population. The ratio of
working to total population in Northern Ireland is about 40 per cent, and
farmers and smallholders working their own holdings account for about
one-tenth of the working population.
The rate of increase in the working population has slowed down (see Table 35)
since 1962 for demographic reasons. These include a tendency for young
people to stay longer in full-time education, a higher proportion of women
marrying and interrupting their working life (many re-enter the working
population later on when their family responsibilities permit), and a reduction
in immigration resulting in a change from a net inflow to a net outflow.
Because of the effect of the lower birth rates in the early 1950s and of the
change in migration patterns, no net growth in the working population
428

between 1966 and 1971 is expected, and because of the raising of the minimum
school-leaving age in 1971 it is expected to be lower between 1971 and 1975
than it was in 1966. After 1975 the working population is expected to increase
again, so as to show a total increase of some 3 to 4 per cent in the period 1966
to 1981, compared with an increase of some 6 per cent between 1956 and 1966.
Though successful development policies in the less-prosperous regions may-
raise the numbers above the levels forecast, it is clear that increasing demand
for labour must be met by better deployment of manpower and improved
productivity. Married women form the only substantial reserve and the
Government is studying the nature of the obstacles to employing those who
are willing to work and how they may be overcome.

Deployment of The present industrial distribution of employees in civil employment is shown

Most industries employ women as well as men though not always for the

secretaries are men. It is illegal to employ women in certain jobs, such as
underground work in coal mines. The industrial groups in which women are
chiefly employed are: the metal-using industries; the manufacture of textiles
and clothing; the food, drink and tobacco industries; the distributive trades;
and professional and miscellaneous services.

A manpower research unit was set up in the Ministry of Labour in 1963 to
examine manpower requirements over the whole economy and in particular
industries and occupations during a period five to ten years ahead. The
forecasts are designed to help the Industrial Training Boards (see p. 433) and
all concerned with training to meet future requirements in industry, youth
employment officers (see p. 431) and others giving vocational guidance to
new entrants to the labour force, and in economic planning generally.
The general unemployment rate in Britain as a whole in the last 20 years has
been among the lowest in the world—usually between 1 and 2 per cent.
It has been particularly low in the south-east and Midlands of England, and
consistently higher in those parts of the country which have the greatest
dependence on shipbuilding, coalmining, and certain branches of the heavy
engineering and metal manufacturing industries, notably parts of Scotland

and Wales, and north-east England and Merseyside. These areas have been
the subject of a series of measures of selective assistance to stimulate industrial

expansion in areas of manpower shortage (see p. 264). The general unemploy¬
ment rate in Great Britain at July 1967 was 2-1 per cent; the areas with the
highest rate were northern England, Wales and Scotland (3-7 per cent).
The total working population of Northern Ireland—including employers and
self-employed but excluding certain unpaid helpers—was about 591,000 in
June 1966 (393,000 males and 198,000 females). The number of insured
employees was about 511,000. The largest productive industries are agricul¬
ture, engineering, textiles and clothing. Most of the agricultural work in
Northern Ireland is done without hired help.
The unemployment rate in Northern Ireland has remained higher than in
other parts of the United Kingdom. In July 1967 it was 7>7 per cent of the
insured employees. The Ministry of Commerce of the Northern Ireland
Government has wide powers (similar to those in Great Britain) to assist the
development and diversification of industry. It is using these powers
vigorously in an attempt to improve the situation.
GOVERNMENT EMPLOYMENT AND TRAINING SERVICES
The main government employment services are provided in Great Britain
through the Ministry of Labour’s country-wide network of some 1,000
offices, which act as employment exchanges. The services in Northern
Ireland are run on similar lines by the Ministry of Health and Social Services
but there are some variations related to the much smaller area of administra¬
tion and the higher rate of unemployment.
The primary function of the employment exchanges is to introduce, free of
charge and without obligation, suitable persons seeking employment to
employers requiring employees, thus providing an efficient service to employers
and job-seekers and meeting the needs of the national economy. Employers
and employees alike remain free to use general or specialised fee-charging
private employment agencies and direct recruitment by advertisement or
personal introduction. The employment exchanges accept on their registers
both those seeking employment (full or part time) and those in work who
desire a change, and every exchange receives particulars of posts vacant and
applicants available in other areas. Local employment committees, on which
employers, workers and other local interests are represented, are attached to
certain employment exchanges as advisory bodies to secure the full benefit of
local knowledge and the close co-operation of employers and workers.
The employment exchanges offer a selective service to certain groups of
employers and employees through specialised registers. All exchanges hold
a Commercial Register of situations vacant and wanted in the distributive
trades, clerical and typing posts and catering and other services. Nearly
40 of the larger exchanges hold a Professional and Executive Register concerned
with posts in the professions, management, science, business and technical
employment at home and overseas. There are nearly 30 offices, in places
where there are large groups of hospitals, which have officers specially
trained to deal with the employment problems of nurses, midwives and those
in related occupations. Elsewhere nurses and their employers are dealt with
LABOUR
431
at the local employment exchange. In view of the increasing number of
older persons in the population, employment exchanges have instructions to
make special efforts to find them employment and to encourage employers
to consider older workers on their merits.
Vocational guidance services for young people in co-operation with local
authorities (see below) and for the disabled as part of the Disablement
Resettlement Service (see below) are well established as is the selection of
candidates for the government vocational training scheme (see p. 434). The
Ministry of Labour also operates an Occupational Guidance Service for adults
staffed by specially trained officers at a number of the larger employment
exchanges. Guidance is given to adults of any age who may be in doubt about
the kind of work for which they are best suited.
Employment exchanges holding the Professional and Executive Register
are also ready to give information about the professions and allied occupations
to young men and women considering a career and to older people seeking a
new one, for example, ex-Regular officers of the armed forces.
The Youth Employment Service in Great Britain is the responsibility of the
Minister of Labour, and is under the general direction of the Central Youth
Employment Executive (composed of senior officers of the Ministry of
Labour and the education departments) appointed by him. It is operated in
most areas through Youth Employment Offices established by local education
authorities in accordance with schemes approved by the Minister of Labour.
In the remainder it is operated by the Ministry’s local offices.
The main functions of the service are to collect and disseminate information
on careers, give vocational guidance, find suitable employment and keep
contact with young workers to help them settle down; a further function is
to help employers to fill vacancies for young people. Local youth employment
committees, made up of teachers, employers, workers and other appropriate
interests, assist the service in an advisory capacity.
In Northern Ireland the functions of the Youth Employment Service are
similar to those in Great Britain but its organisation is different in that
parliamentary responsibility rests with the Minister of Education and the
service is operated by a statutory board composed of representatives of local
education authorities and other educational and industrial interests. Of the
board’s expenditure, 80 per cent is met by the Ministry of Education and
20 per cent by local education authorities.
The Disablement Resettlement Service is designed to help disabled persons
to get and keep suitable work. It is available to anyone over school-leaving
age who is substantially handicapped as a result of injury, disease or congenital
deformity in obtaining or keeping employment. The Ministry of Labour is
responsible for the administration of the Service and is assisted by the
National Advisory Council on the Employment of the Disabled.
The help given falls under five main headings:
Vocational guidance is given at local offices by specialised disablement
resettlement officers (DROs) in consultation, as necessary, with the local
disablement advisory committees, hospital resettlement clinics and medical
interviewing committees, and also in the industrial rehabilitation units (see
p. 432).
Having regard to a disabled person’s qualifications and aptitude and to medical
guidance, and concentrating on what the person can do rather than on what

he or she cannot do, the DRO endeavours to find the work most suited to
each, with or without an intervening period of industrial rehabilitation or
vocational training. A Register of Disabled Persons is maintained, and in
mid-April 1966 the number registered was over 654,000; registration is
voluntary. All employers of 20 or more persons are required to employ a
quota (at present 3 per cent for all industries, except shipping, in respect
of the manning of ships) of registered disabled persons. The number of
registered disabled persons unemployed in mid-April 1967 was under 58,000.
There are 30 Blind Persons Resettlement Officers (BPROs) attached to
offices of the Ministry of Labour whose particular responsibility is to place
blind persons in suitable work and assist them to settle or become resettled
in the working community.
Industrial rehabilitation is provided at 21 units run by the Ministry of
Labour (for medical rehabilitation of the disabled, see p. 143). The aim of
these units is to provide the final link between sickness and employment by
enabling men and women to adjust themselves gradually to normal working
conditions and to receive vocational guidance based on skilled assessment of
their aptitudes in a practical workshop situation. Attendance at the unit is
voluntary and maintenance allowances are paid. The staff includes a doctor,
occupational psychologist, social worker, DRO, industrially experienced
workshop supervisors, and usually a remedial gymnast, all under the general
leadership of a rehabilitation officer.
The Ministry gives financial assistance to two centres conducted by
voluntary organisations which provide similar facilities for the blind, and to
four schemes by other bodies for the rehabilitation of patients from mental
hospitals. It also helps with the cost of industrial rehabilitation in separate
centres for spastics.
There are vocational training facilities for the disabled at Government
Training Centres (see p. 434), educational institutions and employers’ estab¬
lishments. For the more seriously disabled there are special residential
training colleges run by voluntary organisations with the financial assistance
and technical help of the Ministry of Labour. There are also arrangements for
the training of special categories of disabled persons such as the blind, and for
providing grants to disabled persons who are of the appropriate educational
standard to undertake study or training for professional or comparable
employment.
Remploy Ltd., a non-profit-making public company with no share capital,
provides sheltered employment for registered severely disabled people who
are unlikely to obtain work except under special conditions. At the end of
1966 it employed over 6,800 severely disabled men and women in 87
factories. Some 150 home workers were supplied with work from six centres.
The directors are appointed by the Minister of Labour; funds for capital
development and to meet operational costs are provided by loans and grants
from public funds.
The Ministry also gives financial assistance to local authorities and voluntary
organisations towards the cost of providing facilities for sheltered employment
for 2,000 severely disabled sighted workers and for 3,700 blind workers.
As part of the policy of encouraging geographical mobility of labour within
Britain to balance resources and demands, the Ministry of Labour makes
grants and allowances to help with costs of fares, temporary lodging and
acquisition of and removal to the new home, in specified instances. They are

available to unemployed workers moving to new employment, and therefore

Commonwealth citizens from overseas are subject to control under the
Commonwealth Immigrants Act 1962, which came into force on 1st July 1962
and applies, broadly, to all Commonwealth citizens1 (except for those who
were born in the United Kingdom or hold passports issued by the United
Kingdom Government). If they wish to come to Britain for full-time employ¬
ment, they must first obtain a voucher issued by the Ministry of Labour.
Vouchers are issued to Commonwealth citizens (subject to a numerical
limit laid down from time to time by the Government) on the application of
an employer who has a vacancy for a particular individual, or on their own
application if they have certain special qualifications or skills. (Commonwealth
citizens who wish to work in Northern Ireland, and who are not ‘Northern
Ireland workers’,2 need special Northern Ireland employment permits,
which are issued only in respect of definite jobs.)
Foreigners are admitted to the United Kingdom to take up employment
provided they hold a permit issued to the prospective employer by the
Ministry of Labour (the Ministry of Health and Social Services for Northern
Ireland if the proposed employment is in Northern Ireland). In Great Britain,
over 66,000 such permits were issued in 1966. Approximately 18,500 workers,
mainly skilled, came to work in industry and commerce, nearly 16,000 to
work in the hotel and catering industry, 12,500 for domestic work and 8,600
as student employees. Employment is limited to a maximum of one year in
the first instance but may be extended on the employer’s application.
Before a permit is issued, the Ministry of Labour must be satisfied that
there is a vacancy for which no suitable British or foreign worker already
long-resident in Britain is available, and that the wages and conditions of
employment are not less favourable than those enjoyed by British workers.
These conditions are waived for student employees who are admitted for
limited periods in order to improve their English and to gain a wider
knowledge of their occupations. A foreigner in employment in the United
Kingdom may not change his job unless his prospective employer has obtained
prior approval from the Ministry.
Britain, as a member of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and
Development, participates with 13 European countries in the arrangements
for assisting nationals of the countries concerned to obtain employment in
other member countries.
As part of its plans for increasing productivity in industry the Government is
fostering the expansion and improvement of industrial training. The whole
framework of training in industry was strengthened by the Industrial
Training Act 1964. Under this Act the Minister of Labour is setting up
industrial training boards to be responsible for the quantity and quality of
industrial training in the industry concerned; up to June 1967 19 boards
had been set up. Each board can provide its own training courses or arrange

2 People qualified by birth and residence to work in Northern Ireland.

Government
Vocational

for other organisations to provide training. It raises a levy from employers
and makes grants to those whose training courses it approves. The Minister
meets the initial administrative costs of each board and is making grants
towards certain other expenditure: for example, training courses for trainers
and research projects. To advise the Minister of Labour on the administration
of the Act and on industrial training questions generally, a Central Training
Council (CTC) consisting of employer and trade union members, representa¬
tives of nationalised industries, educationists, selected chairmen of training
boards and others with a special interest in industrial training has been set
up. It also advises the Minister on the running of the Industrial Training
Service (ITS), which is grant-aided by the Ministry of Labour. The work of
the ITS includes assessing training needs both for industries and individual
companies, developing training schemes, and promoting group training
schemes.
In some of the industries for which training boards have not yet been set
up, apprenticeship training is governed by agreements between employers’
associations and trade unions. Practical training is provided mainly within
the individual firm, and associated technical education is obtained by attending
a technical college. Training of operatives is usually arranged by the individual
firm but in a few industries there are agreed national or regional schemes.
Government measures to stimulate training activity include grants for the
training of training officers on approved courses, for the appointment of
training development officers and for the promotion of group training
schemes. A direct contribution is made by the Government’s own training
centres (see below).
The Government Vocational Training Scheme, administered by the Ministry
of Labour, is intended to augment what industry is doing to overcome
shortages of skilled workers in industries of importance to the national
economy, as well as helping persons in special need, such as the disabled
(see p. 432) and ex-Regular Service men and women, to fit themselves for
suitable employment. Training is provided for suitable persons over 18 years
of age who are unskilled or whose prospects of employment in their existing
trade are poor. Employed persons as well as the unemployed are accepted for
training in trades of importance to the national economy. Most of the training
is provided at the 33 (being increased to 42) Government Training Centres
(GTCs), which are situated within easy reach of the main industrial centres
of the country, and between them offer courses in about 40 different trades,
with emphasis on those in which there is a shortage of skilled labour. Schemes
of training for particular trades are agreed with representatives of the employers
and workers concerned.
For the disabled and for ex-Regular Service men and women and the un¬
employed with special resettlement problems, training in other trades is also
available under the scheme at technical and commercial colleges and private
training establishments or by means of individual courses at employers’
establishments. For severely disabled persons training is provided at four
residential training colleges run by voluntary organisations with government
financial assistance.
During training, trainees are paid good allowances to maintain themselves
and their dependants. During 1966, 10,458 people were trained under the
scheme and over 90 per cent of them were subsequently employed in the
trade for which they had been trained.
Training can also be given in GTCs to men sponsored by their employers
where it can be fitted in with the Ministry’s other training commitments.

Special Ministry
Services
Legislation and
Conventions
435
The employer continues to pay the trainee’s wages and is charged a fee for
the training provided.
The Ministry of Labour’s Regular Forces Resettlement Service helps
Regular officers and other ranks returning to civilian life to find suitable
employment. Nearly all those leaving the Services are successful in securing
satisfactory resettlement. The Ministry arranges special six-week business
training courses for Regulars and ex-Regulars (mainly ex-officers) at com¬
mercial and technical colleges; four-week courses in industrial supervision
are provided at the Ministry of Labour, Ebury Bridge House, London, for
non-technical warrant officers and senior NCOs (or other Service equivalent
ranks). In addition to full courses for a civilian trade, refresher courses and
conversion courses required for ex-Service men and women can be arranged
under the Vocational Training Scheme.
The Ministry is providing full-time training for a limited number of
apprentices. Instruction is given in four trades: engineering; radio and
electronics servicing; basic electrical work; and sheet and plate metal work.
The apprentices are sponsored by their employers, who pay their wages
during the course. A charge is made where the appropriate Industrial
Training Board has approved the training and has instituted a system of
‘off the job’ training grants.
The Ministry also provides assistance with training for firms on first
moving into a development area or expanding an existing business there.
The assistance includes grants for training carried out by the employer and
direct training of employees on the firm’s premises by staff loaned by the
Ministry.
A special service to industry is the Ministry of Labour’s Training Within
Industry for Supervisors (TWI) scheme. Its object is to develop the skill of
supervisors in instructing others, in human relations, in improving methods
and in preventing accidents (there are separate programmes for each of
these). There are special versions of TWI, usually in courses of a week’s
duration, for supervisors employed in offices, retail distribution and hospitals.
Ministry Training Officers either give these courses or train employers’
nominees to enable them to run TWI courses in their own concerns.
In addition, courses in industrial teaching techniques for the training of
apprentices and trade instructors are available to outside firms as well as
GTC staff at the Ministry’s two Instructor Training Colleges (one in England
and one in Scotland).
Vocational training services at GTCs, TWI courses, and courses at
Instructor Training Colleges are available to trainees from overseas under
approved schemes (for instance, those of the ILO or the Colombo Plan).
TERMS OF EMPLOYMENT AND WORKING CONDITIONS
There are few restrictions in Britain on the freedom of an employer to hire
an employee on any terms which the employee will accept. Recent legislation,
however, embodies certain safeguards for the employee. The Terms and
Conditions of Employment Act 1959 provides machinery for enforcing on
an employer the observance of terms or conditions established by collective
agreement in his industry; under the Contracts of Employment Act 1963
employers are required to give their employees written particulars of the
main terms of employment, and employees are given rights to minimum
periods of notice when their employment is to be terminated; and under the
43 6
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Earnings
Redundancy Payments Act 1965 employees with a minimum period of
service of two years are entitled to lump sum payments if their jobs cease
to exist (for example, because of technological improvements or because
of a fall in demand) and their employers cannot offer suitable alternative work,
the cost being partly met from a fund subscribed to by industry as a whole.
Employers are under no legal obligation to recognise a trade union, or
to refrain from refusing to employ trade unionists; nor is a collective agree¬
ment with a trade union held to be in itself a legal contract of employment,
though the terms of a collective agreement may be expressly or by implication
incorporated in an individual contract of employment. However, it is by
collective agreements that in the majority of trades and industries minimum
or standard wages, normal working hours and other terms of employment are
effectively settled. The negotiation and observance of settlements continue
to depend primarily on the strength, integrity and representative character
of the signatory organisations rather than on any legal sanction. The deter¬
mination by statute of minimum wages, holidays and holiday pay is in
principle confined to those trades and industries where the organisation of
employers or workers, or both, is inadequate to negotiate collective agree¬
ments and to ensure their observance.
Although there is legislation on minimum standards of safety, health and
welfare in most places of employment, it is recognised that the causes of many
accidents are not amenable to statutory control. Therefore, voluntary action
taken by employer organisations, often in association with trade unions, is
encouraged.
The further considerations which affect workers’ satisfaction with their
jobs and promote harmony between employers and employed, which can be
summed up as ‘good human relations’ between management and individual
employees, are hardly susceptible of codification; they have been recognised
for some time and are receiving increasing attention from managements and
from voluntary and official organisations.
Minimum or standard time rates for the lowest-rated manual workers, as
determined by agreements or by statutory orders, vary between 4s. 6d. and
6s. od. an hour for men and between 3s. 3d. and 4s. qd. for women. Actual
earnings are usually higher. Higher rates are sometimes paid, and piece rates,1
shift rates and overtime rates raise the level of average earnings.
On the basis of the latest survey in a series conducted half-yearly by the
Ministry of Labour into earnings and hours of work in manufacturing
industries and some leading non-manufacturing industries in Great Britain,
the average earnings of full-time male adult manual workers in October 1966
were 8s. lod. an hour and £20 6s. id. a week. Full-time women manual
workers at the same date earned an average of 5s. 3^d. an hour and £10 is. 4d.
a week.
Minimum time rates for women manual workers tend to be set at around
70-90 per cent of the corresponding male rate, though the gap is gradually
closing. Women’s earnings are markedly lower than those of men, partly
because on average they work shorter hours, with less overtime paid at
premium rates, but also because a smaller proportion of women do skilled
work. The Government has announced its intention of implementing the
principle of equal pay and is having talks with the Trades Union Congress
and the Confederation of British Industry about the problems involved.
1 Piece rates are of declining importance in manufacturing industries, where methods
of production tend to dictate the output of a worker, not his or her own skill or energy.

Earnings in coalmining and dock work, not covered by the Ministry of
Labour survey, are somewhat above the average; earnings are below the
average in railway work and agriculture.
Between April 1955 and October 1966 average weekly wage rates increased
by about 59 per cent and average weekly earnings by about 85 per cent. Part
of the increase has been offset by a rise in prices. The trends of manual
workers’ wage rates and earnings, salary earnings, and retail prices from 1955
to 1966 are shown in the diagram above.

Remuneration in commercial, technical and professional careers is normally
by annual salary, often on a scale carrying annual increases, and such careers
generally afford opportunities for promotion to posts with higher remunera¬
tion. Starting salaries may be in the range of ^600—^800 (lower for trainees
in their teens and higher for some graduates entering industry). The average
weekly earnings of male administrative, technical and clerical employees in
October 1966 were found by a Ministry of Labour survey to be £26 13s. gd.
The average weekly figure for females was £14 4s. nd.
Most of the senior posts in business, the professions and the Civil Service
are in the range of £2,750 to £7,000 a year. The posts with salaries in the
range of £8,000 to £15,000 a year include those of Cabinet Ministers, top-
ranking judicial appointments, the highest positions in government depart¬
ments and the largest municipal authorities, editors of daily newspapers,
some persons outstanding in their professions and in the higher managerial
posts in industry, commerce and banking. A few persons in business draw
still higher salaries, while the earnings of star entertainers and certain other
very successful people exceed £25,000 a year.
Women have the same right of entry as men to nearly all public offices,
administrative posts and professions. They are paid the same salary for
doing the same work in journalism, broadcasting and architecture, and as
Ministers of the Crown, members of Parliament, salaried magistrates and
solicitors. Women in independent professions are not expected to charge
lower fees than men. The principle of equal pay applies to non-manual work
in the public sector but remains the exception in private non-manual
employment.
The average earnings of all salaried employees increased by 86 per cent
between 1955 and 1966, as illustrated in the diagram on p. 437.
In October 1966 the number of hours actually woiked by manual workers
averaged 46 for full-time men and 38-1 for women on full-time work. Agreed
weekly hours are mainly in the range 40 to 42 and are generally worked as
either a five-day or a five-and-a-half-day week according to the industry and
the rule of the particular establishment. Hours actually worked by men are
somewhat longer owing to overtime working. While the hours of work of
adult men are not, in general, restricted by statute, normal hours of work for
both sexes and those of all ages are usually within the legal limits on the hours
of women and young persons.
National legislation in the United Kingdom limits and defines permissible
hours of work for women and young persons in a number of industries or
trades—the maximum permitted, with limited exceptions, being 48 hours a
week and 10 hours a day (9 hours a day for 6-day-week workers) in premises
covered by the Factories Act (see p. 439) for adult women over 18 and young
people between 16 and 18; young people under 16 are limited to 44 hours a
week. The employment of women and young people at night is prohibited in
industrial undertakings, except that in certain continuous process industries
young men over 16 may, subject to certain conditions, be so employed.
With a few exceptions, manual workers (including shop assistants) in indus¬
tries covered by agreements or statutory orders are entitled to paid holidays
of at least 12 days or two weeks. Moreover, payment is made for bank or
statutory public holidays, which are as follows: in addition to Good Friday
and Christmas Day, there are bank holidays in most parts of England, Wales
and the Channel Islands on Easter Monday, the last Monday in May or first

in June, the last Monday in August or first in September, and the first
weekday after Christmas (Boxing Day); and in Scotland on New Year’s Day,
the last Monday in May or first in June and the last Monday in August or
first in September1. Northern Ireland observes all the English holidays and,
in addition, has a holiday on St. Patrick’s Day, 17th March, and on 12th July
(commemorating the Battle of the Boyne, 1690); the Tuesday after Easter is
also a customary holiday for industry and trade. Many agreements provide
that payments should also be made for specially proclaimed holidays.
In some industries agreements provide for extended holidays related to
length of service, work status, or both.
Where statutory wage-regulating machinery exists, it consists of bodies
known as Wages Councils. These are composed of equal numbers of
representatives of employers and workers in the respective sectors of industry,
with additional independent members. Wages Councils may submit proposals
for fixing minimum remuneration and holidays with pay to the Minister of
Labour, who must then make orders giving statutory force to such proposals,
subject only to his right to return them as a whole for further consideration.
The Ministry’s Wages Inspectorate helps employers and workers to interpret
the provisions of wage regulation orders and sees that they are complied with.
Agricultural Wages Boards (there are separate boards for England and
Wales and for Scotland) perform similar functions in relation to employment
in agriculture.
A variety of additional benefits in monetary form exist in varying degree. It
has been estimated that, in 1964, 13 million employees were covered by
occupational sick pay schemes and between 11 and 12 million by occupa¬
tional pension schemes (additional or complementary to the state schemes,
see p. 134). A smaller number are covered by schemes for redundancy pay¬
ments above the statutory minimum (see p. 436). Such ‘fringe’ benefits are
rather more usual among clerical and professional employees receiving a
standard salary than among manual workers with a chance to earn overtime
and other additions to their pay. The former also tend to get longer holidays.
Senior members of firms may enjoy the use of a company car.
Employers have a duty at common law to take reasonable care of their
employees and provide a safe system of working, while employees have a
duty of care towards each other. In addition, minimum required standards
of safety in certain kinds of workplaces or work are laid down under a number
of statutes; some of these also deal with health and welfare.
About 220,000 industrial premises (factories, workshops, slaughterhouses,
shipyards and docks) and about 30,000 building and civil engineering sites
come under the Factories Act 1961 (consolidating earlier legislation), which
is administered by the Ministry of Labour and enforced by H.M. Inspectorate
of Factories, which forms part of the Ministry. About 700,000 premises come
under the Offices, Shops and Railway Premises Act, which is also administered
by the Ministry of Labour; enforcement is shared by H.M. Inspectorate of
Factories and local authorities. Under these Acts, anyone intending to employ
other people in industrial or commercial premises to which they apply has
1 The appointed dates for the spring and autumn bank holidays in 1968 are 3rd June
and 2nd September.

BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Other Work
Premises
Prevention
to notify the enforcing authority of his intention before he begins to employ
people and every fatal accident and every accident causing more than three
days’ incapacity must be reported; under the Factories Act provision is also
made for compulsory notification and for investigation of certain dangerous
occurrences.
The Acts are designed to secure the health, safety and welfare of employed
persons, and a wide range of provisions in the Acts and in regulations,
according to the nature of the premises, deal with such matters as: the
fencing of machinery; precautions against fire, dangerous substances and
special risks; the safe condition of the premises, cleanliness, lighting, tempera¬
ture and ventilation; and the employment of women and young persons.
Comparable provision with appropriate variations covers mines and
quarries under the Mines and Quarries Act 1954; two statutes are concerned
with agriculture—the Agriculture (Poisonous Substances) Act 1952 and the
Agriculture (Safety, Health and Welfare Provisions) Act 1956; and specialised
statutes and delegated legislation are concerned with transport—the Railway
Employment (Prevention of Accidents) Act 1900, the Merchant Shipping
Acts, the Road Traffic Acts and the Air Navigation Order and Regulations.
As with the Factories Act these other provisions are, with some exceptions,
enforced through inspectorates—the Mines and Quarries Inspectorate (part
of the Ministry of Power which is responsible for safety in mines and quarries),
the Agricultural Inspectorate of the agricultural departments, and, as regards
railways, the Railway Employment Inspectorate of the Ministry of Transport.
The Board of Trade is responsible for administering the Merchant Shipping
Acts and for safety in air transport (most of the powers in respect of air
worthiness are delegated to the Air Registration Board, see p. 366), and the
Minister of Transport is responsible for road and rail transport safety matters.
There are at present no specific statutory safety requirements in hotels,
places of entertainment or educational establishments, except in so far as
they are covered by fire regulations applicable under local authority by-laws
to all large buildings or (in respect of their offices and shops) by the Offices,
Shops and Railway Premises Act. The Ministry of Labour has no statutory
responsibility in regard to safety in workshops or laboratories in educational
establishments, though it keeps in touch with university authorities and
the education departments. Employers, however, are bound by their common
law obligation to provide a safe system of work, and employers and educational
authorities may voluntarily seek the advice and help of the Factory Inspec¬
torate, which is given freely on request.
Safety depends, in fact, at least as much on the education and voluntary
efforts of the employers and of the workers as upon safety regulations.
The voluntary accident prevention movement is strongly supported by
the Factory Inspectorate. Inspectors inquire into notified accidents and safety
aspects of machine design and specification, circulate expert advice by personal
exhortation, lectures and literature, and encourage the appointment of safety
officers and the formation of works safety committees. The Factory
Inspectorate maintains an industrial health and safety centre in London, at
which various types of machinery demonstrating the effectiveness of guards
are displayed, as well as a wide range of protective clothing and equipment.
The Ministry also actively encourages the development of voluntary central
organisation within each industry at national level for the consideration of
safety matters and the formulation of policy on accident prevention.

Other

441
Organisations in industry are now concerning themselves to an increasing
extent with the promotion of safety at work and the provision of information
and advisory services to their members. They participate also in joint standing
and advisory committees appointed by the Minister of Labour. Representa¬
tives of the Trades Union Congress, the Confederation of British Industry,
the nationalised industries and other interests meet on the Industrial Safety
Advisory Council under the chairmanship of the Minister of Labour.
Training for safety is an important facet of the accident prevention effort and,
to help in this work, the Ministry of Labour provides a safety course in its
TWI scheme (see p. 435). In 1965 the Central Training Council, which
advises the Minister of Labour under the Industrial Training Act 1964
(see p. 434), drew the attention of Industrial Training Boards to the need to
include specific provisions for safety training in their general training
recommendations.
The Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents (RoSPA) provides a
variety of safety courses for special needs at its Industrial Safety Training
Centre in Birmingham and elsewhere. Other courses are organised by bodies
such as local accident prevention groups and organisations such as the
Federation of Civil Engineering Contractors. RoSPA also helps the accident
prevention movement by providing publicity and organising conferences;
during 1965-66 it appointed a number of Regional Industrial Safety Officers,
primarily to promote safety activity among top-level managers. The British
Safety Council also provides safety publicity and offers safety training
courses.
A substantial amount of research is being done by industry, universities
and other academic bodies, and government research organisations into
problems of guarding machines, ergonomics, safe handling, electrical hazards,
protective personal equipment, construction methods, fires and explosions,
psychological factors and causes of accidents, both generally and in particular
sectors of industry. A register of research into industrial health and safety
matters has been compiled by the Ministry of Labour to give an indication
of the scale and nature of research being undertaken. Industrial research
associations include amongst their more purely economic research projects
the improvement of working conditions and the reduction of hazards.
The National Coal Board has its own safety organisation—a Standing
Committee on Safety, a chief safety engineer, and safety engineers at
divisions, areas and the largest collieries. It conducts courses of safety
training for workmen and officials and is constantly on the alert for new
methods of reducing risks. Its research programme includes a number of
projects with a direct bearing on safety.
The Minister of Power has a statutory responsibility for research concerning
the safety and health of coal miners. This responsibility is largely exercised
through its Safety in Mines Research Establishment with laboratories at
Sheffield and Buxton.
To safeguard the many interests which might be adversely affected by the
use of chemicals in agriculture and food storage, a voluntary scheme is
operated by the Government with the help of an advisory committee and
with the full co-operation of the chemical industry.
Transport operators and Ministries concerned with road and air travel
give high priority to safety measures affecting crews and passengers. Every
endeavour is made to counter the higher risks resulting from rising traffic
densities, by improving the design of vehicles, transport plant and
442
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
HEALTH AND
WELFARE
Industrial
Health Services
equipment, by traffic regulation and control of standards of maintenance and
by training crews in competency and safety awareness.
Local authorities have power, under the Public Health Acts, to regulate the
provision of suitable sanitary accommodation in houses and at places of work
and to treat workplaces which are dirty or badly ventilated or overcrowded
as nuisances the abatement of which can be enforced. Factories, certain other
industrial premises, offices, shops and railway premises must comply with the
health and welfare requirements of the Factories Act or the Offices, Shops and
Railway Premises Act. These include: the cleanliness of workrooms, adequate
ventilation and suitable temperature and lighting, the avoidance of over¬
crowding and the provision of sanitary accommodation, and the protection
of workers against inhaling harmful dust or fumes; the provision of washing
facilities, lockers or other accommodation for outdoor clothing, drinking
water, first aid, and seats. Legislation concerning safety in other types of work,
for example, agriculture, also prescribes appropriate measures to promote
health and welfare.
The laws restricting the employment of children, young persons and women
form an important part of protective legislation. National legislation, besides
forbidding any employment of children under 13 years of age, forbids the
employment of children who have not reached the statutory minimum school¬
leaving age (see p. 154) in any industrial undertaking; of women and young
persons underground in mines and in certain other dangerous occupations
(for example, certain processes connected with lead manufacture); and of
women in factories and workshops within one month of childbirth. It also
limits and defines the permissible hours of employment for women and young
persons in factories, and for young persons in certain other occupations. Local
authorities, moreover, have wide powers under the Children and Young
Persons Acts 1933-63 as well as the Education Acts 1944-48, which regulate
hours and conditions of employment of children under 15 years within their
areas within the limits of national legislation.
These are the main legislative provisions relating to health and welfare
at work, but it is essential to note that employers frequently achieve health and
welfare standards considerably higher than those prescribed by law. They are
helped to do this by the inspectorates, by government departments and
agencies, by employers’ associations and trade unions and by expert voluntary
bodies.
A number of employers voluntarily maintain medical services for their
employees over and above the statutory requirements. It is estimated that
there are about 430 factories with full-time and about 4,630 factories with
part-time doctors employed. In addition several thousand nurses are employed
in industry. Compulsory medical examinations under the Factories Act and
regulations are carried out by 2,300 part-time Appointed Factory Doctors.1
The big employers, including the state and the boards of nationalised
industries, have naturally taken the lead but a number of smaller factories
also provide medical services and in a few cases have joined together in group
medical services. The Minister of Labour is advised on measures to further
the development of industrial health services by the Industrial Health Advisory
Committee which includes members nominated by the Confederation of
1 A report recommending reorganisation of the Appointed Factory Doctor Service
is currently under consideration.

443
British Industry, the Trades Union Congress, the nationalised industries,
the British Medical Association, the Royal College of Nursing and other
organisations closely concerned with the promotion of industrial health.
Occupational hygiene services can give valuable assistance in securing
healthy working conditions in industry. Her Majesty’s Factory Inspectors
give advice on occupational hygiene problems as part of their normal duties.
In addition there are at present two centres in Great Britain which undertake
studies of particular problems or health risks and also carry out routine
physical, chemical and biological tests for industry.
Prompt and effective action in industrial health depends, among other
things, on adequate and properly co-ordinated arrangements for investigation
and research. Field investigations are carried out by the Factory Inspectorate,
which has specialised medical and technical branches. Research facilities are
provided by government agencies such as the Medical Research Council;
by university faculties of industrial health and social medicine; and by the
research departments of various industries and large industrial concerns.
Other types of amenity vary considerably from one firm to another. The
requirements of a factory, office or shop where the work is light, and where
many employees are women or young persons, are different from those of an
iron foundry or steelworks, where much of the work is arduous and is under¬
taken by men. Progressive firms are careful to find out what their employees
want, and welfare policy is often decided in consultation with the workers,
through regular consultative machinery or by other means. An increasing
number of firms pay part or all of the cost of recreational facilities. Some have
their own rehabilitation centres or support convalescent homes. The provision
of low-priced meals at the place of employment has become usual in large
undertakings and quite common in smaller ones. Colliery canteens provide
meals for about 98 per cent of coal miners. Many offices and shops which are
unable to provide canteen facilities for their staff have adopted luncheon
voucher schemes. There are now over 15,500 firms using this service.
Practically all large industrial firms and many small ones now have a personnel
department staffed by one or more specialist officers. While the form of
organisation of personnel departments varies, personnel officers are generally
responsible for advising all levels of management on every aspect of labour
relations. They also have particular duties with regard to recruitment,
selection, education and training, transfer of labour, the application of wage
agreements, the promotion of good communication and consultation and the
supervision of working conditions and employees’ amenities.
Recruitment and promotion policies are matters which each undertaking
decides for itself, although in some industries the decisions may be limited
by collective agreements or by trade practices. Great importance has recently
been attached to selection; and courses for training personnel officers in
modern interviewing techniques, including the use of test procedures, are
now well attended.
Both official and voluntary organisations are concerned with promoting
better human relationships in industry. The Government has sought to
extend by research the available knowledge of the factors influencing human
relations in industry and human efficiency. Such research is sponsored or
conducted by the Social Science Research Council (see p. 213) and the
Medical Research Council (see p. 207). Voluntary organisations include
bodies which deal with management problems and provide a service to

subscribing firms, professional associations, linking individuals with a common
interest in particular functions of management, and bodies providing
specialist services, usually on a fee-paying basis.
In addition to the assistance the Ministry of Labour can give where
employees are recruited through employment exchanges, members of the
Ministry’s industrial relations service are available to give advice on personnel
policies, personnel management techniques and problems of human relations
at the workplace, as well as assisting in the formation and support of machinery
for negotiation and settlement of disputes (see below).
The safety, health and welfare of employees in Northern Ireland have been
the subject of legislation which, with certain exceptions, is similar to that in
Great Britain and is embodied in the Factories Act (Northern Ireland) 1965
and the Office and Shop Premises Act (Northern Ireland) 1966. Many firms
voluntarily employ safety officers, and an Industrial Safety Group for the
area, supported by representatives of industry, trade unions, insurance
companies and public authorities, is very active and makes a valuable contri¬
bution in the field of industrial accident prevention on similar lines to what
is done in Great Britain.
The structure of labour relations in Britain is established mainly on a voluntary
basis, and rests on the organisation of employers and workers into employers’
associations and trade unions. These organisations1 * * discuss and negotiate
terms and conditions of employment and other matters affecting the work¬
people at their work. In some industries these negotiations are conducted
simply by ad hoc meetings, which are held when necessary; in others, voluntary
joint machinery has been established on a permanent basis. Normally these
arrangements for collective bargaining suffice to settle all questions which
are raised, but provision is often made for matters not so settled to be referred
for settlement to independent arbitration. The machinery for settlement in
certain trades where wages cannot be effectively controlled by voluntary
agreement has already been described (see p. 439).
The existence of these employers’ and employees’ bodies facilitates liaison
between the Government and industry on labour matters in which they have
a common interest (though it does not preclude individual contact). Standing
arrangements exist for consultation at national level between the Government,
the Confederation of British Industry (CBI), the Trades Union Congress
(TUC) (see pp. 445 and 446) and the nationalised industries through the
National Joint Advisory Council, which was set up in 1939 to advise the
Government on matters in which employers and workers have a common
interest. It meets quarterly under the chairmanship of the Minister of Labour.
Subjects of importance to relations between management and workers
generally throughout industry which it has recently studied include dismissal
procedures and the preservation of occupational pension rights.
In 1965 a Royal Commission was appointed to investigate the whole range
and scope of employers’ and employees’ organisations, and the legal frame¬
work in which they operate.
Many employers in Great Britain are members of employers’ organisations
wholly or partly concerned with labour questions. The primary aims of
1 Some employers, including the central Government and the public corporations
operating the nationalised industries, negotiate directly with the trade unions repre¬
senting their different types of employees.
LABOUR
445
such organisations are to help to establish suitable terms and conditions
of employment, including a sound wage structure and proper standards of
safety, health and welfare; to promote good relations with employees and
the efficient use of manpower; and to provide means of settling any disputes
which may arise. Different employers’ organisations vary in the emphasis
which they put upon these different aims and in the means by which they
try to achieve them. Some concentrate on defensive action, trying by
negotiation and representations to modify proposals of trade unions and
Government in their members’ interests. Others also try to give their
members practical help and advice in developing positive employment
policies and assistance on recruitment, training and further education.
There is diversity of structure as well as function. Generally, however,
employers’ organisations are organised on an industry basis rather than a
product basis. Some are purely local in character and deal with a section
of an industry; others are national in scope and are concerned with the whole
of a particular industry. In some of the chief industries there are local or
regional organisations combined into national federations, while in others,
within which different firms are engaged on making different principal
products, there is a very complex structure with national and regional
federations for these different sections of the industry as well as for the
industry as a whole. Although there are some 1,400 employers’ organisations
dealing with labour matters, about 100 of these are national employers’
associations, many of which are in membership of the CBI and are the ones
that negotiate the important national collective agreements with trade unions.
The final authority of a local or small national organisation may be a meeting
where all member firms are directly represented; but in larger organisations
some form of indirect representation is necessary, either through local
organisations or through the regions or sections into which these are grouped.
The representatives thus chosen, together with a number of office holders,
form a general council, central committee or general committee, which meets
perhaps once a quarter, mainly to make major policy decisions, to elect com¬
mittees and to ratify their work. A small paid staff under a director or
secretary carries out the day-to-day work of the organisation. There is
usually a small working group, consisting of senior officials and committee
chairmen, which meets to deal with urgent questions and co-ordinate the
work of the committees.
The Confederation The central body of employers’ organisations is the CBI, which deals with
of British Industry all matters (not only labour relations) affecting the interests of organised
employers and represents them nationally to the Government and the public
and also internationally, for instance, in the International Labour Organisa¬
tion. CBI representatives sit on various government advisory committees,
on other statutory bodies and on a number of voluntary bodies concerned
with labour matters.
Trade Unions During its long history the British trade union movement has passed through
many changes, and is currently undergoing re-examination within and
without.
In nearly all industries and occupations some workers—and in some indus¬
tries nearly all workers—are organised into trade unions. These have grown up
gradually and independently over a great many years, and consequently, their
form and organisation vary considerably as to their traditions and attitudes,
for example, their degree of concern with political movements. Trade unions
started more than two hundred years ago among the skilled craftsmen and
446
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Trades Union
Congress
spread later to the general labouring and unskilled classes. More recently
trade unionism has increased among clerical, supervisory, technical and
administrative workers. A number of associations of professional workers,
formed primarily for the preservation and improvement of professional
standards, have also come to exercise many of the functions of trade unions,
including negotiations on salary and fee scales, and are legally trade unions.
The qualification for membership of some unions is occupational (for
instance, they may recruit clerks or fitters wherever employed), while in others
the qualification is industrial (that is, they seek to recruit all persons in an
industry, whatever their occupation). In a number of unions recruitment is
based on a combination of these principles. A few large unions recruit members
in a number of different occupations and industries.
At the end of 1965 the total membership of British trade unions was about
10,180,000. There were 580 unions but about two-thirds of all trade unionists
were in the 18 largest unions, while just over a half were in the ten unions
with a membership of over 250,000. The number of trade unionists is
increasing but the number of unions has gone down owing to amalgamations.
The basic unit of organisation in most British trade unions is the local
branch (called a lodge in some trade unions). Every member of the union
belongs to a branch. He may attend its meetings, put forward suggestions
about terms and conditions of employment, discuss the work and policy
of the union, and take part in the election of the union’s officers. The branch
takes action on certain matters considered to be entirely, or mainly, of local
interest and forwards its views on wider issues for action by the union’s
national or regional bodies. Many unions also have shop stewards or other
representatives at the place of work to enrol members and collect dues, to
ensure that local and national agreements operate satisfactorily, to take up
with management the individual problems and grievances that arise and to
keep the union informed of developments at the workplace. Only in a few
trade unions is organisation based primarily on the place of work.
In most large unions the central organisation is along the following lines:
elected officials, including a general secretary assisted by clerical and specialist
staff, are in charge of the work of the head office and are responsible to an
elected national executive council or committee which may be part-time or
full-time, and which is responsible to annual or biennial conferences of
delegates from the branches. Executive committees or councils play an
important part in the government of the unions; between conferences they
are the highest authorities and carry out policy decisions made by delegates.
Most unions also have some regional, district or area organisation.
Trade unions may affiliate to one or more federations or confederations
whose main purpose in most cases is to represent all or most of the trade
unions in an industry in negotiations with employers. The scope and authority
of these federations and confederations vary greatly.
In Britain the national centre of the trade union movement is the TUC which
will celebrate its centenary in June 1968. The TUC’s objects are to promote
the interests of its affiliated organisations and to improve the economic and
social conditions of the workers. Its membership comprises 170 organisations,
of which about a dozen are federations of some 150 separate unions; approxi¬
mately 350 unions in all are affiliated directly or indirectly. These represent
about 8-9 million workpeople. The TUC deals with all general questions
which concern trade unions both nationally and internationally and gives
assistance on questions relating to particular trades or industries at the request
of the trade union concerned.

447
Scottish Trades

Voluntary
Joint
Negotiating
Machinery
At National Level
The congress of delegates, which constitutes the TUC proper, meets for a
week every year to discuss matters of general interest to trade unionists and
to employees generally. It elects annually a General Council which represents
it during the remaining 51 weeks of the year. This is responsible for carrying
out congress decisions, for watching economic and social developments, for
providing educational and advisory services to unions, and for presenting
to the Government the trade union viewpoint on economic, social and indus¬
trial issues. It is also empowered to mediate in inter-union disputes in certain
circumstances and, through the General Council’s Incomes Policy Com¬
mittee, to comment on claims for improvements in wages and working
conditions notified to the TUC by affiliated unions.
The TUC is a non-political body but under the Trade Union Act 1913
individual trade unions can, by a ballot vote of members, decide to set up a
political fund, financed by a separate levy, which any member can refuse to
pay without loss of his normal union rights and benefits. About 100 separate
trade union organisations, including most of the largest trade unions, have
such a fund and, in most cases, it is used to support the Labour Party.
Both the TUC and many unions conduct extensive educational services for
members, mainly concerned with industrial subjects, trade unionism and
industrial relations principles and practice.
Branches of various trade unions in a locality generally affiliate to a local
trades council, which acts as a forum for the discussion of matters of common
interest and as a local agent of the TUC, by which it is registered each year.
There are 500 trades councils in England and Wales alone, grouped together
in 22 federations.
Affiliation to the TUC is open to all trade unions anywhere in the United
Kingdom, but Scottish trade unionists have their own national centre, the
Scottish Trades Union Congress, similar within its objects to the TUC, though
there are some differences of organisation. The Scottish TUC, to which trade
unions may affiliate in respect of their membership in Scotland (a number of
unions are affiliated to both bodies), also accepts affiliation from trade councils
and has an affiliated membership of over 800,000. It holds an annual congress
and has consultations with the Government on issues affecting Scottish
trade unionists.
In most of the main industries there are, at national level, joint committees
(sometimes referred to as joint negotiating machinery) composed of represen¬
tatives of employers and trade unions. There are some 200 in all; about 130
of them are known as Joint Industrial Councils. Their functions vary
considerably, some being simply negotiating bodies, while others deal with
a wide range of subjects affecting the interests of the industry concerned.
Provision is sometimes made in their constitution that a dispute on which it
is not found possible to reach agreement should be referred to some form of
conciliation or arbitration by independent persons, including the means
provided under the Conciliation Act 1896, or the Industrial Courts Act 1919.
Collective agreements between employers’ associations and trade unions
are not civil contracts between particular employers and employees, and are
not in themselves enforceable at law. Observance of agreed terms and
conditions is based mainly on the good faith of employers and the mutual
respect and vigilance of trade unions and employers’ organisations, but can
be secured in particular instances through reference to the Industrial Court
(see p. 448).
448
At District and
Factory Level
State Provision
for Conciliation,
Arbitration and
