BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Arrangements for negotiation and joint consultation also exist at district
and factory level in many industries, where matters are discussed either
between the appropriate representatives of the two sides on an ad hoc basis,
or through regular machinery provided by District Joint Industrial Councils
or similar bodies and Works Councils. Such bodies discuss how agreements
reached at a national level may be applied to their district or factory, but as a
rule have no power to alter the terms of such national agreements. They also
discuss new problems which may arise, and if no solution can be found at
factory or district level, refer them to the national body.
Matters which prove difficult to settle by negotiation are sometimes referred
by agreement to independent conciliators or arbitrators, and one way in which
the parties can find such persons is by invoking the help of the Minister of
Labour. Under authority derived from the Conciliation Act 1896, and the
Industrial Courts Act 1919, the Minister has certain powers to assist industry
to settle disputes which it is not found possible to resolve through an industry’s
own machinery and procedure. These powers are all intended to supplement
and not to supersede the industry’s own machinery. There is no legal
obligation on the parties to a dispute to notify the dispute to the Minister,
nor to place the question before a conciliator.
To assist conciliation in industry the Ministry of Labour has an industrial
relations service, staffed by specially trained officers who keep in touch with
the course of relations between employers and workers at national, district and,
in some cases, factory level and assist them, if requested, to settle their
problems by joint discussion and negotiation. Conciliators have no legal
powers.
Disputes which cannot be settled in this way may, at the request of both
parties, be referred to voluntary arbitration, either by a single arbitrator, or
an ad hoc Board of Arbitration, or by the Industrial Court, a permanent
tribunal established under the Industrial Courts Act. The court normally
consists of three members—the president, one member experienced in
representing employers and one in representing workpeople.
Like collective agreements, arbitration awards are not in themselves
enforceable at law, but under the Terms and Conditions of Employment
Act 1959, reports that a particular employer is not observing the recognised
terms or conditions of employment in his trade or industry may be made to
the Minister of Labour by organisations which are parties to the relevant
agreement or award. If the matter is not otherwise settled, the Minister must
refer it to the Industrial Court which, after hearing the case, may issue an
award requiring the employer to observe the recognised terms or conditions.
Such an award becomes an implied term of the contract of employment of
individual employees and so enforceable at law.
The Minister of Labour is also empowered to appoint a Court of Inquiry
or Committee of Investigation into a dispute, whether existing or apprehended.
These procedures are primarily means of informing public opinion of the
facts of a dispute (the report of a Court of Inquiry has to be laid before
Parliament). Although the recommendations contained in the reports of such
bodies are not binding on the parties, they often provide the basis for further
negotiations leading to a settlement.
Over the past 30 years the number of working days lost each year through
stoppages of work arising from industrial disputes, that is through strikes and
lockouts, has been on an average about 2| million which, taking the working
LABOUR
Communication
and Joint
Consultation
Labour
Relations of
Public
Authorities
Central and Local
Government
449
population as a whole, works out at approximately one hour per worker per
year. These figures, however, only record the time lost at establishments
where strikes actually take place; they take no account of the effect in other
establishments or industries. Nevertheless, the time lost through strikes is very
much less than that lost on account of sickness, accidents and absenteeism
and the United Kingdom’s record over the past ten years or so compares
favourably with that of most other industrial countries.
Strikes in Britain are not in general caused by a breakdown in the collective
bargaining machinery. This on the whole works smoothly and well. In fact
it is estimated that about 95 per cent of all strikes, accounting for between
60 and 70 per cent of the time lost through strikes, are the result of unofficial
(and usually unconstitutional) action.
These unofficial strikes are therefore symptoms of a breakdown in relations
between management and workers at the place of work itself. The problem of
securing a fundamental improvement in relations between employers and
workers and the loyal observance of agreements and constitutional procedures
freely negotiated is currently the subject of public discussion as well as in
industry generally, but it seems likely that there is no single solution.
The concept that workpeople need to have a proper understanding of
management’s aims and plans if they are to co-operate with them has focused
attention on the quality of communication down the chain of responsibility
to workshop level (a matter which depends on personal relations and on the
adequacy of supervisor training) and prompted the establishment, in many
undertakings, of means for joint consultation, such as those provided by a
works council.
A wide range of subjects can be fruitfully discussed by works councils,
including hours of work (within the framework of agreements), safety and
health, productivity, absenteeism, labour turnover, training and education,
and amenities generally. Works councils are usually kept informed about the
state of the firm’s business, and frequently consider problems resulting from
decisions to change production methods. It is, however, usual to exclude
all questions relating to wages and conditions of employment, and other
matters covered by negotiation between organisations of employers and
workers.
Other means of communication in use include posters, wall information
sheets, production charts, house journals, film shows and exhibitions.
The Ministry of Labour’s industrial relations service is ready to assist
these developments by advice on techniques, by the supply of publicity
material and by encouraging and promoting joint consultation.
While labour relations in government service and in the nationalised industries
are, in general, organised on the same principles as in private industry, there
are some special features.
Non-industrial employees in central government service, where salaries and
conditions of service are under the direct control of the Treasury, are per¬
mitted and encouraged to join the appropriate Civil Service staff associations
(trade unions) and there is a highly developed system of negotiation and
joint consultation by means of the National and Departmental Whitley
Councils (see p. 68), corresponding to the Joint Industrial Councils in industry.
If there is failure to reach agreement by negotiation a department or associa¬
tion may, subject to certain limitations, report the dispute to the Minister of
45°
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Nationalised
Industries
Northern
Ireland
Labour for reference to the Civil Service Arbitration Tribunal, an independent
body appointed by the Minister by virtue of his powers under the Industrial
Courts Act 1919.
Industrial employees of the central Government are organised by trades
and not by departments; negotiations regarding their wages and conditions of
employment take place on Trade Joint Councils and unresolved matters are
referred to the Industrial Court for arbitration. In the major employing
departments, Departmental Joint Councils also exist for the discussion of
matters other than trade questions which are of mutual concern to the
department and its industrial employees (and which are domestic to the
department).
In local government service there are separate National Joint Councils
for the main grades of employees (such as manual, clerical and technical
employees) which deal with wages and conditions of service as well as other
matters. There are corresponding regional and district councils.
In the nationalised industries, the main corporations, though not subject to
detailed governmental control, have a statutory duty to establish satisfactory
arrangements for collective bargaining in their industries and for joint con¬
sultation with their employees; but in carrying out these duties they are free
to choose the arrangements that suit them. The main difference from private
industry is that the corporations are not usually members of employers’
associations (although the majority are ‘industrial associates’ of the CBI). In
some industries they are sole or main employers, but even where part of the
industry is in private hands, as for example in road transport, the corporations
are separately and directly represented on wage-negotiating bodies.
Wages and conditions of service in the nationalised industries are generally
settled by negotiation between representatives of managements and trade
unions at the national level; in most cases there are also regional and local
bodies, similarly representative, to deal with local implications. Most of the
industries use the facilities for arbitration offered to industry generally by the
Ministry of Labour, but coalmining and rail transport have their own special
arrangements. Consultations at all levels, including the workplace level, have
been arranged in all the nationalised industries according to the traditions and
needs of each industry.
Some of the nationalised industries have felt that joint consultation was
best carried out by their negotiating bodies; others have established separate
and specially constituted joint committees at all levels.
The system of labour relations in Northern Ireland is based on the same
principles as that of Great Britain and, in these matters, the Minister of
Health and Social Services has powers and duties broadly similar to those
of the Minister of Labour in Great Britain. About 90 per cent of trade
unionists in Northern Ireland are members of trade unions with head¬
quarters in Great Britain.
17 Sound and Television
Broadcasting
Broadcasting
Authorities
Broadcasting of sound and of television in the United Kingdom is regulated
under powers conferred on the Postmaster General by the Wireless Tele¬
graphy Acts 1949-1967, which prohibit the sending or receiving of radio
communications, except under licence. The Marine etc. Broadcasting
(Offences) Act 1967 was passed to suppress unauthorised broadcasting from
commercial (‘pirate’) radio stations at sea.
Sound broadcasting services are provided solely by the British Broadcasting
Corporation (BBC), which was established as a public corporation by Royal
Charter in 1927. Two television services are provided by the British Broad¬
casting Corporation (BBC 1 and BBC 2) and one by the Independent
Television Authority (ITA), which was established by the Television Act
1954-
Users of sound and television receiving sets must obtain an annual licence,
which can be purchased from most post offices. There were more than
17 million receiving licences current in the United Kingdom in June 1967 of
which 14,500,000 were for sound and television combined and 2,550,000
(including 820,000 for sets fitted in cars) for sound only. A combined sound and
television licence costs £5; a licence for sound only costs £ 1 5s. Registered blind
people are entitled to free sound licences or to combined licences for £3 15s.
One licence covers all receiving sets in a household, but a separate licence is
required for a set fitted in a car. A supplementary licence fee of ^5 is required
by owners of television sets equipped to receive colour programmes.
The constitution and finances of the BBC are currently governed by the Royal
Charter of 1964 and the Licence and Agreement with the Postmaster General
of 1963, and those of the ITA by the provisions of the Television Act 1964 and
the Licence issued to it by the Postmaster General in 1964. Both the Royal
Charter and the 1964 Act specifically define the services of the BBC and ITA
as a ‘public service’ with the purpose of disseminating information, education
and entertainment.
The BBC and the ITA are independent authorities in the day-to-day
operations of broadcasting, including programmes and administration. The
Government, however, retains ultimate control, and the Postmaster General,
as the responsible minister, is answerable to Parliament on broad questions
of policy and may issue directions to the BBC and the ITA on a number
of technical and other subjects. The Postmaster General also has powers to
prohibit the broadcasting of any particular matter or class of matter, or to
revoke the licences of the BBC or ITA at any time; these powers, however,
are treated as major reserve powers, and no formal veto has ever been placed
on the broadcasting of a particular item. Both the BBC and the ITA are
required to prepare annual reports and accounts, which are presented by
the Postmaster General to Parliament.
The number of hours of television broadcasting are regulated by the
Postmaster General; he has approved an arrangement which permits any one
452

The British
Broadcasting
Corporation
The Independent

service a maximum of 50 hours a week (30 hours a week for BBC 2), together
with extensions (averaging ten hours a week) for certain stated purposes, such
as religious and educational programmes, schools broadcasts, ministerial and
party political broadcasts, and outside broadcasts. In 1967 the BBC was
broadcasting about 53 hours of programmes from London in its domestic
sound services during a normal weekday.
The Corporation consists of 12 governors (including a chairman, a vice-
chairman and separate national governors for Scotland, Wales and Northern
Ireland), each appointed for a period of not more than five years by the
Queen on the advice of the Government. As a corporate body, the governors
are responsible for the conduct of the whole broadcasting operation, including
the content and presentation of the programmes in sound and television,
and the provision and working of the necessary installations and equipment.
The BBC must refrain from expressing editorial opinion on current affairs
and on matters of public policy and is relied upon to treat controversial subjects
with impartiality.
The governors are advised on all aspects of their work by a number of
councils, established in accordance with the terms of the Charter: for example,
the General Advisory Council; the National Broadcasting Councils for
Scotland and Wales, which are responsible for domestic services in those
countries; and the regional advisory councils for the English regions and for
Northern Ireland. There are also a number of other councils and committees,
not specifically required by the Charter, but established by the BBC to advise
on such matters as religious broadcasting, schools broadcasting, further
education, science and engineering, music and agriculture. For each of the
new experimental local radio stations (see p. 454) there is a broadcasting
council, representative of the local community, appointed by the Postmaster
General.
The chief executive officer of the BBC—the Director-General—is
appointed by the governors and with him they discuss all major matters of
policy and finance. Under the Director-General are six directors (the chief
assistant to the Director-General, and the directors of radio, television, external
broadcasting, engineering, and administration) who, between them, cover the
whole work of the BBC, and who, with the Director-General, constitute its
Board of Management. The number of staff employed is about 22,000.
The services of the BBC are financed from (1) an annual sum, voted by
Parliament, for the domestic services, which is related to revenue derived
from the sale of broadcast receiving licences; (2) an annual grant, voted by
Parliament, for the external services; and (3) profits from BBC publications,
mainly the Radio Times, which has a weekly sale of over 4 million copies and
attracts a large advertising revenue. The net revenue from the sale of licences
for the year which ended on 31st March 1967 amounted to ^71,573,000. In
the same year the surplus on trading, mainly from publications, amounted to
£607,000 and the grant for the external services amounted to £11,611,000.
The cost of providing the local radio services is raised mainly from local
sources.
The Independent Television Authority consists of a chairman, a deputy
chairman and, at present, eleven other members (three of whom have special
responsibility for Scotland, Wales and Monmouthshire, and Northern Ireland
severally) appointed by the Postmaster General. The ITA owns and operates
the transmitting stations, but the production studios and equipment are
owned, and the actual programmes are provided, by programme companies
The Pilkington
Report and later
Developments
SOUND AND TELEVISION BROADCASTING 453
under contract to the ITA. Fourteen programme companies are at present
under contract: ABC Television Limited; Anglia Television Limited;
ATV Network Limited; Border Television Limited; Channel Television
Limited; Grampian Television Limited; Granada TV Network Limited;
Rediffusion Television Limited; Scottish Television Limited; Southern
Independent Television Limited; TWW Limited (Independent Television for
Wales and the West of England); Tyne-Tees Television Limited; Ulster Tele¬
vision Limited; and Westward Television Limited. Under new arrangements
which are to come into force in July 1968 contracts have been awarded to all
the existing companies except TWW Limited. In addition three new com¬
panies, London Weekend Television Limited, Yorkshire Television Limited,
and Harlech Television Limited have won contracts. A common news service
is provided by Independent Television News Limited.
The Authority has controlling and regulatory powers of a wide and
important character over the content and quality of programmes: for
example, it ensures that a ‘proper balance’ of views is expressed and has drawn
up a code on violence stating that special precautions are to be taken when
children are likely to be viewing. There are also safeguards in the Television
Act 1964 to prevent newspaper shareholdings in a programme company
leading to results contrary to the public interest.
In the discharge of its duties the ITA is advised by a General Advisory
Council and by three statutory committees on educational broadcasting,
religious broadcasting and advertising. A specialist panel advises on medical
and allied advertisements.
The chief executive officer of the ITA is the Director-General. There are
also two deputy directors-general, and a headquarters and regional office
staff covering all technical, administrative, clerical, typing and office services,
which numbered 290 in 1967. There were also some 400 engineering staff
serving at the transmitting stations.
A standing committee, composed of four representatives of the ITA and a
representative of each of the programme companies, provides consultative
machinery between the ITA and the companies on matters, other than
programmes, affecting the companies as a whole. There is also an Independent
Television Companies Association, designed to further the collective interests
of the companies with such outside bodies as trade unions and sporting
organisations, and generally to ensure that they speak as far as possible with
one voice on public issues connected with television broadcasting policy.
The ITA receives no payments from licence revenue; the finance for its
operations is drawn from annual rental payments made to it by the programme
companies. In the year ended March 1966 the ITA received about £8-6
million from this source. In return for the valuable public concession enjoyed,
the programme companies also paid to the ITA for transfer to the Exchequer,
a further sum (the levy) related to their advertising revenue; this amounted to
about £21 million during the same period.
The services provided by both broadcasting authorities were reviewed by
the Committee on Broadcasting i960, and subsequently the powers of the
ITA were renewed by the Television Act 1963 (which was incorporated in the
Television Act 1964). This Act also strengthened the Authority’s controlling
and regulatory powers in relation to the independent programme companies
under contract to it to produce the actual programmes. The BBC was con¬
firmed as the sole provider of sound broadcasting services and authorised to
introduce a second television service (BBC 2); this opened in 1964. Colour

television was introduced on BBC 2 in 1967 and by 1970 colour will be

The BBC operates its domestic sound broadcasting services from 59 long¬
wave and medium-wave transmitters at 43 transmitting stations, and from
204 very high frequency (VHF) transmitters at 67 stations. The VHP service
is available to over 99 per cent of the population of the United Kingdom.
Regular stereophonic broadcasts on the BBC’s VHF programmes began in 1966.
In addition there are 69 transmitters for the external broadcasting services,
41 in the United Kingdom and 28 overseas for relay purposes, including a
station on Ascension Island.
There are 143 studios for the domestic sound programmes, of which 63
are in London and 81 at various centres in the regional areas. The external
services use 38 London studios. There are also 39 semi-automatic studios
which can be operated by programme staff without engineering assistance.
The domestic sound services consist of Radio 1 (the Popular Music Service),
Radio 2 (previously the Light Programme), Radio 3 (previously the Third
Network), and Radio 4 (previously the Home Service). These separate, but
inter-related, services enable the BBC to provide a wide range of programmes.
Nine local radio stations, run by the BBC, are to broadcast on an experimental
basis in selected areas of Britain.
Each of the services has its own characteristics: Radio 4 (broadcasting 17
hours a day) is planned as a general service providing the principal news and
information services of the BBC. In addition a wide range of music and drama
is presented; broadcasts for schools are an important feature. The various
regions of Britain have their own version of the service. Radio 3 includes the
Music Programme (broadcasting io|- hours a day), which provides a range of
music during the day, educational sessions, a sports service, and the Third
Programme, which offers works of artistic and intellectual distinction each
evening (and has an estimated regular audience of i| million people). The main
purpose of Radio 2 (broadcasting 2\\ hours a day) is to provide a service of
entertainment and relaxation for the majority including, particularly, light
and popular music. Radio 1, in conjunction with Radio 2, provides a pro¬
gramme of continuous popular music each day. The local radio stations transmit
programmes of particular interest to the local community which they serve.
The external broadcasting services of the BBC are intended to provide a link
of culture, information and entertainment between the peoples of the United
Kingdom and those in other parts of the world; to present events of world¬
wide importance with speed and accuracy; and generally to reflect British
opinion and the British way of life. These services are broadcast in English
and in 39 other languages for some 670 hours a week.
The services are divided into the European Services and the Overseas
Services:
The European Services broadcast over 250 programme hours a week and
are subdivided into four regional groupings: South European (Spain,
Portugal, Italy, Greece, Turkey, Israel), Central European (Czechoslovakia,
Hungary, Poland, Finland), East European (Soviet Union, Rumania,
Bulgaria, Yugoslavia) and German. A French language service provides
programmes for both European and African listeners and there is also
an English service directed to the whole of Europe.
The Overseas Services, which are directed to countries outside Europe,
broadcast over 400 programme hours a week. They comprise the BBC

World Service with its audience of English-speaking listeners, which broad¬

The external services include the Transcription, English by Radio and
Television, Topical Tapes, and Monitoring Services. The Transcription
Service records on disc and tape 750 BBC radio programmes annually,
distributing them to broadcasting organisations in all parts of the world.
The English by Radio and Television service produces English radio lessons
with commentaries in 36 languages, reaching an audience of several millions
by direct transmission from London and by re-broadcasts from some 260 local
stations. The English by Television series have been seen in over 50 countries.
Two television series designed for teachers of English and another for students
of science and technology have been produced in collaboration with the
British Council (see p. 170). BBC English-teaching courses on gramophone
records and tapes are on sale in most countries. The Topical Tapes Service
in English produces 300 hours of topical programmes annually, which are
purchased and re-broadcast by more than 50 subscribing radio organisations.
The Monitoring Service provides news reports from foreign broadcasts; it
has an exchange agreement with its United States counterpart which gives
virtually world-wide coverage.
The government departments concerned with overseas relations prescribe
the languages and hours of external broadcasting, but the content of the
programmes remains the responsibility of the BBC.
The BBC maintains offices in New York, Ottawa, Toronto, Buenos Aires,
Sydney, New Delhi, Singapore, Beirut, Berlin and Paris to encourage local
interest in the BBC, to promote the use of BBC television and radio material
and to provide the BBC with advice and help concerning programmes.
The offices are also responsible for promoting good relations with the local
broadcasting organisations.
In 1936 the BBC launched the world’s first regular public service by high
definition television. Two programmes are now being transmitted: BBCi,
which is available to over 99 per cent of the population of Britain from
87 transmitting stations; and BBC 2, at present from 30 stations, which is
expected to reach some 70 per cent of the population by the end of 1967.
BBC 1 is transmitted on 405 lines on very high frequency (VHF) and BBC 2
on 625 lines on ultra-high frequency (UHF). A duplicate BBC 1 service with
colour is to be introduced on 625 lines on UHF by 1970. In the course of a year,
the BBC television service broadcasts on a national network for 6,150 hours.
BBC studio productions in London come from 17 main studios. The BBC
also has fully equipped regional studio centres at Manchester, Birmingham,
Cardiff, Glasgow, Bristol and Belfast; these centres contribute programmes
to the national network as well as producing others of only local interest.
In addition a number of small interview studios (used mainly for short
insertions into news bulletins) have been established throughout the country.
Outside broadcasting covers most parts of Britain writh its mobile units.
Self-contained television services are available in Wales and Scotland.

BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The first regular independent television (ITV) service was inaugurated in
1955 by a programme transmission from the ITA London station at Croydon.
In 1967 programmes were being transmitted on 405 lines on VHP from 43
stations throughout Britain reaching 97 per cent of the population. By 1970
duplicate ITV programmes with colour will be introduced on 625 lines on
UHF.
Independent television is organised on a regional basis. Programmes are
produced at studio centres in Aberdeen, Belfast, Cardiff, Carlisle, Dover,
Glasgow, Leeds, London, Manchester, Newcastle, Norwich, Plymouth,
St. Helier, and Southampton; they are designed for either local or national
broadcasting. The programme companies broadcast for some 3,500 hours a
year in each region.
Both the BBC and the ITV services include news, talks and documentary
programmes and programmes of music, drama, light entertainment, films,
sport and outside broadcasts. Religious broadcasts, broadcasts for schools
and educational programmes for adults are also features. There are pro¬
grammes designed to stimulate thought and widen people’s horizons, such as
interviews with outstanding personalities, investigations into matters of public
interest, and programmes on the arts; and there are programmes of specialised
interest such as children’s and family programmes, programmes for women
and regional programmes. In addition, there are special series of party
political broadcasts under arrangements agreed between the broadcasting
authorities and the leading political parties. The use of a second BBC channel
offers greater opportunities for the provision of programmes for minority
interests or particular needs such as further education including the proposed
‘open university’ (see p. 167). The Corporation estimates that its average
viewing audience for documentary programmes is some million.
The BBC seeks to avoid giving publicity to any individual firm or organised
interest except when it is necessary to provide effective and informative
programmes under the terms of the Charter. It must not broadcast sponsored
programmes or, without the consent of the Postmaster General, broadcast any
matter for payment. Advertisements are broadcast on independent television
subject to the relevant provisions in the Television Act, namely, that there
should be no sponsoring of programmes by advertisers, that all advertise¬
ments should be clearly distinguishable as such and recognisably separate
from the programme, and the amount of time given to advertising should
not be so great as to detract from the value of the programmes as a medium
of information, education and entertainment. The ITA has drawn up a
Code governing standards and practice in advertising, giving guidance about
the types and methods of advertisement that may not be used. Certain
types of advertising are prohibited, notably that of cigarettes (under a Govern¬
ment ruling of 1965), betting, and ‘cures’ for alcoholism. Advertisements
may not be inserted in certain types of programmes including religious
services and broadcasts to schools. The cost of inserting advertisements in
the ITA service is borne by the advertisers, who pay the programme
companies for advertising time.
Audience research is conducted both by the BBC and ITA. The BBC
measures the size of audiences by interviewing a representative sample of
the population each day about its listening and viewing on the previous day.
Panels of representative listeners and viewers regularly give their opinions
on programmes they have seen or heard. Special investigations are also made.

SOUND AND TELEVISION BROADCASTING 457
The ITA sponsors audience research by an independent research organisa¬
tion Television Audience Measurement (TAM).
Wire relay systems receive programmes at a central point, and from there
distribute them by wire to listeners and viewers. Wire relay companies are
not allowed to originate programmes of their own; their function is to distribute
programmes put out by authorised broadcasting stations. A specified minimum
of their programme material must be taken from BBC sources. At the begin¬
ning of 1967 there were some 796 wire relay services, of which some 626
provided both sound and television. The number of subscribers at that date
was over 1,350,000, about 1,090,000 of whom were receiving television services.
An experiment in pay television is being undertaken by a company, Pay-TV
Ltd., in two areas of Britain. The service is operated over wire relay systems
as an additional programme; subscribers pay for the programmes they choose
to view. The service is subject to the same code of conduct as applies to
existing television services.
The Postmaster General is advised on the technical aspects of television and
VHP sound broadcasting by the Television Advisory Committee, which
consists of an independent chairman, the Director-General of the BBC, the
Director-General of the ITA, representatives from the radio industry,
independent members, and representatives of interested government
departments.
Research into technical problems is carried out by the scientific and
engineering staffs of the BBC, the ITA, the Post Office and the radio industry.
Recent developments by the BBC include: the electronic conversion of mono¬
chrome and colour television pictures between the European and the American
systems; and the reproduction of television pictures in slow motion.
The BBC and the ITA (together with the Independent Television Companies
Association) are active members of the European Broadcasting Union (EBU),
which was established to advance international broadcasting projects. The
union now has 28 full members among the broadcasting organisations in
Western Europe and 40 associate members (mostly from outside Europe,
including the United States of America and many of the nations of the
Commonwealth). It maintains a technical monitoring station, where frequency
measurements and other observations on broadcasting stations are carried out.
The range of inter-Commonwealth broadcasting co-operation is very
wide. The BBC provides a large amount of technical aid, particularly in staff
training to Commonwealth broadcasting organisations. Members of the BBC’s
staff are also seconded for service overseas. The BBC, the Australian Broad¬
casting Commission, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, the New
Zealand Broadcasting Corporation, the Rank Organisation and Reuters have
jointly set up Visnews Ltd., a Commonwealth and international newsfilm
agency which provides a reliable service of international news on film for
subscribers who operate television services, produce cinema newsreels or
acquire newsfilm for any other purposes, including education, anywhere in
the world.
The BBC’s Radio and Television Enterprises undertake the world-wide
sale of BBC sound and television programmes; they also purchase material
for the use of the BBC services. Overseas sales of ITV programmes are
undertaken by the separate programme companies.
458
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Eurovision
Inter-continental
Television
Both the BBC and the independent television companies are associated
with the Centre for Educational Television Overseas (CETO), which assists
the advancement of education in developing countries through television.
The centre received a government grant totalling £70,000 in 1967-68, but
most of its funds come from private sources, including the independent
television companies. The BBC provides free technical and other facilities.
Training in television work is also provided for overseas trainees at the
Thomson Centre, in Glasgow, run by the Thomson Foundation, a charitable
trust. The Ministry of Overseas Development is spending about £100,000
annually on radio and television training for overseas students in Britain.
The BBC and the ITA also participate in the work of the International
Telecommunication Union (ITU)—the United Nations specialised agency
responsible for the regulation and control of all international telecommuni¬
cation services (including sound and television), for the allocation and
registration of all radio frequencies and, through its international consultative
committees, for the promotion and co-ordination of the international study
of technical problems in broadcasting.
The BBC is a regular contributor to the network of European television
(Eurovision). This network now includes 23 organisations in Western Euro¬
pean member countries; the exchange of television programmes between them
is arranged by the EBU, which maintains an International Television
Co-ordination Centre (Eurovision) in Brussels. The range of Eurovision is
steadily increasing as countries expand their networks and facilities, and new
countries participate. Successful programme exchanges have also been made
between Moscow and London by both the BBC and the independent
television companies.
The first inter-continental television relay across the Atlantic by means of
Telstar, the communication satellite, was seen in Britain in 1962; it was
followed by live programme exchanges between Europe and America, and in
1964 between Europe and Japan by Telstar II. In 1965 the Early Bird
synchronous satellite marked a further significant advance in inter-continental
television by the first transatlantic exchange of programmes; simultaneous
two-way live television was achieved for the first time between Europe and
America. Early Bird is stationary relative to the earth over the Atlantic, and
thus permits continuous contact between ground stations on opposite sides
of the North Atlantic. The first exchange of live television between Britain
and Australia took place at the end of 1966 via the Intelsat II satellite while it
was over the Indian Ocean.
18 The Press
Ownership
The British press caters for all political views, different levels of education
and a wide range of interests. It is not subject to State control or censorship.
The number of newspapers per person sold daily in Britain—some 50
copies for every 100 people1 2—is among the highest in the world. The
circulation figures of individual newspapers are correspondingly high. Ten
of the national papers (five dailies and five Sundays) and one London evening
paper have circulations in the millions. The reasons for this are the concen¬
tration of the population in a relatively small area and the highly developed
system of distribution, which means that the national newspapers are
available almost everywhere on the day of publication.
Britain imports just over half its newsprint requirements, about i| million
tons annually, while the rest is made from imported raw materials. The average
size of national morning papers varies between 14 and 32 pages. Prices of
daily newspapers vary from 4d. to 8d. (for the Financial Times). Sunday papers
are considerably larger and prices run up to rod. In addition to their normal
paging some newspapers carry occasional supplements and a few provide
regular weekly colour supplements. The Times issues an entirely separate
Business News section with every edition.
According to The Newspaper Press Directory* 136 daily and Sunday
newspapers and just over 1,200 weekly local papers (dealing mainly with
news of interest to the region where they are sold) are published in Britain.
These figures include certain specialised papers, the circulations of which
are limited not by region, but by interest; for instance, sporting papers,
papers in foreign languages for groups of nationals of other lands resident in
Britain, and religious papers.
Daily national and provincial newspaper ownership is concentrated mainly
in the hands of a comparatively small number of large press groups, most of
which control chains of newspapers in different parts of the country. The
provincial group also own weekly newspapers and weekly newspaper
subsidiaries, but there are still a large number of small enterprises in the
weekly and small daily newspaper field. The six largest newspaper groups
are: International Publishing Corporation Limited; Associated Newspapers
Limited; Beaverbrook Newspapers Limited; the Thomson Organisation
Limited; United Newspapers Publications Limited; and Westminster Press
Provincial Newspapers Limited.
Some newspaper groups have holdings in independent television
contracting companies and extensive interests in periodical publishing which
is being integrated to an increasing extent with newspaper publishing.
The International Publishing Corporation and the Thomson Organisation
Limited also have newspaper interests overseas.
Although pronounced views may be expressed in newspapers and their
political leanings may be obvious, they are financially independent of any
1 According to the United Nations Statistical Yearbook, 1965.
2 Changes in the number of newspapers occur constantly; figures are based on the
1967 edition of The Newspaper Press Directory.

political party and not obliged to follow any specific party line. In order to
preserve their character and traditions, certain newspapers and periodicals
(including 2 he Guardian, The Observer and 'The Economist) are governed by
arrangements which vest ownership of the undertaking in trustees, or operate
it in accordance with a deed of trust, or provide that the transfer of shares be
in the hands of trustees. Others have management arrangements intended
to ensure the authority and independence of the editors.
The trend towards concentration of newspaper ownership, which began in
the early nineteen hundreds and was accentuated after the second world war,
giving rise to some public concern, was studied by two Royal Commissions
on the Press, one of which reported in 1949 and the other in 1962. The first
stage of the latter’s recommendations was carried out by the provision in the
Television Act 1963 which stipulates that, if it appears to the Independent
Television Authority at any time that newspaper shareholdings in television
programme companies have led or are leading to results which are contrary
to the public interest, the Authority may, with the consent of the Postmaster
General, notify the companies that their programmes may cease to be trans¬
mitted. Newspaper take-overs are regulated by the Monopolies and Mergers
Act 1965 which gives the Board of Trade powers to control the transfer of a
newspaper or newspaper assets to a newspaper proprietor whose newspapers
have an average daily circulation amounting, with that of the newspaper to
be taken over, to 500,000 or more copies, after (in some cases) the Board of
Trade has received a report from the Monopolies Commission (see p. 252).
Technological advances in the newspaper industry include the introduction
of web-offset newspaper printing and photo-type setting and developments
in the use of computers and facsimile transmission.

The London local weeklies (nearly 150) include papers for every district in
Greater London.
Scotland has six morning, seven evening and two Sunday newspapers,
excluding the Scottish editions of the Daily Express, Daily Mail and Sunday
Express. The leading morning papers are The Glasgow Herald (circulation
^4>392) and The Scotsman, published in Edinburgh (circulation 73,092).
Others are: the Daily Record and the Noon Record, published in Glasgow;
the Courier and Advertiser, published in Dundee; and the Press and Journal
of Aberdeen. Evening papers include the Edinburgh Evening News and
Dispatch, Glasgow’s Evening Times and Evening Citizen, Dundee’s Evening
Telegraph and Post, Aberdeen’s Evening Express, the Paisley Daily Express
and the Greenock Telegraph and Clyde Shipping Gazette. The Sunday papers
are the Sunday Mail and the Sunday Post.
Weekly newspapers published in Scotland number about 150. The most
widely known are the Weekly Scotsman and the People's Journal.
Northern Ireland has two morning papers, one evening paper and one

and the Irish Nezvs (Nationalist), the evening Belfast Telegraph and the

Periodicals
463
Sunday News. There are over 40 weekly newspapers in Northern Ireland, with
circulations ranging from about 5,000 to over 25,000. The majority are
published by individual companies.
One daily morning newspaper, the Western Mail, published in Cardiff, has a
circulation of 104,351, mainly in southern Wales. In north Wales the
Liverpool Daily Post gives wide coverage to events in the area. Evening
papers published in Wales are the South Wales Echo, Cardiff, the South
Wales Argus, Newport, and the South Wales Evening Post, Swansea. North
Wales is served by the Liverpool Echo and to a smaller extent by the Manchester
Evening News.
The weekly press (some 55 papers) includes the English language papers
(by far the largest category), some of which carry articles in Welsh; three
bilingual papers; and n papers in Welsh, of which five are denominational.
The Channel Islands have two daily (evening) papers (one in Guernsey and
one in Jersey), the Guernsey Star with morning and evening editions, a Sunday
paper {Island Sun), and two weeklies, which also circulate in Alderney and Sark.
The Isle of Man Times is issued from Mondays to Wednesdays with a special
weekly edition which is published on Friday: there are four other weeklies.
There are over 4,600 periodical publications in Britain. They include the
trade and technical press (over 2,000 titles); magazines of general interest;
women’s magazines; publications for children; religious periodicals for all
denominations; fiction magazines; magazines dealing with sport, gardening,
hobbies, and humour; and journals specialising in various subjects such as
politics, finance and economics, science, agriculture, medicine and the arts.
A large part of the periodical press, in particular the business papers
(which include professional and specialised journals as well as those properly
described as ‘trade’ and ‘technical’ and are now one of the leading sections of
Britain’s publishing industry), has a considerable circulation outside the
United Kingdom and are an important export. Some 150 million copies are
distributed annually throughout the world and, apart from earning about
fio million a year, are an important media for selling British goods overseas.
The weekly periodicals with the highest sales in Britain are: Woman
(3,219,362); Woman's Own (2,272,856); Woman's Weekly (1,521,900);
Woman's Realm (1,319,207); Weekend (1,206,308); Reveille (1,264,524);
together with the Radio Times (4,361,387) and TV Times (2,736,538).
The leading weekly journals of opinion are The Economist (circulation
80,671), a politically independent publication covering topics from a wider
angle than its title implies; the New Statesman (circulation 90,282), which
is a review of politics, literature and the arts with an independent socialist
political tendency; the Spectator (31,085), which covers much the same
subjects from an independent conservative standpoint; and Tribune, which
has a strongly left-wing but anti-communist bias. Pm«c/z (114,675), traditionally
the leading humorous periodical, has in recent years devoted increasing
attention to public affairs. New Society, which covers the sociological aspects
of current affairs, has rapidly established its reputation, as has New Scientist,
which reports on the progress of science and technology in terms which the
non-specialist can understand.
Monthly and quarterly journals, particularly the literary and political
journals and those specialising in international and Commonwealth affairs,
generally speaking appeal to the more serious type of reader.

BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
News Agencies
Training for
Journalism
In addition to the circulation of periodicals published in England, a farming
weekly, the Welsh Farm News, and several monthly and quarterly journals
in both Welsh and English are produced in Wales.
Four monthly illustrated periodicals are published in Scotland: Scottish
Field, Scotland's Magazine, Scots Magazine and Scotland', and two weeklies
devoted to farming interests, Farming News and Scottish Farmer. Among
literary journals, probably the most famous is Blackwood's, published in
Edinburgh. Numerous popular magazines are also published in Scotland.
In Northern Ireland, weekly, monthly and quarterly publications cover
farming, the linen industry, building, motoring and politics.
There are three principal British news agencies:
Reuters Ltd. is a world news agency owned by the newspapers of the
United Kingdom, Australia and New Zealand operated on a non-profit-
making basis under the terms of a deed of trust which guarantees the
independence and integrity of the news service and ensures that all profits
are used to develop it. Founded in Aix-la-Chapelle in 1850 and transferred
to London in 1851, Reuters has offices in many countries and maintains
several hundred correspondents throughout the world, supplying a con¬
tinuous report of foreign news to the London newsroom. This is then
distributed to the national newspapers, to the radio and television news services
and, through an extensive private network of communications, to news media
in almost every part of the world.
Press Association Ltd. is a news co-operative supplying the British press,
radio and television, and other publishing media. Since its foundation in
1868 it has been owned collectively by provincial newspapers in the British
Isles outside London. It is also one of the major owners of Reuters (see above).
The Association distributes home news within the British Isles, supplies the
same home news to Reuters and its associated agencies for distribution
abroad and distributes to British newspapers outside London the overseas
news of Reuters and the Associated Press. It also provides wire photo
coverage of the British Isles to the national and provincial press and to
overseas subscribers, and distributes by wire the Associated Press world
photo service to provincial newspapers. All profits are used to develop the
service.
Exchange Telegraph Company Ltd. (Extel) supplies financial and sporting
news to newspapers, the broadcasting organisations, overseas news agencies
and private subscribers; a comprehensive news service to clubs, hotels,
business houses, and similar companies; and, by means of its statistical card
service, the latest information about more than 5,000 companies whose
shares are quoted on the London Stock Exchange, and the principal
European, North American and Australian companies.
Associated Press, which is a branch of the Associated Press of America,
also supplies a general service of overseas news.
A number of other United Kingdom, Commonwealth and foreign agencies
and news services have offices in London, and there are agencies in other
cities, specialising in various aspects of newspaper and periodical requirements.
Syndication of features is not as common in the United Kingdom as in some
countries, but a few agencies specialise in this type of work.
New entrants to journalism are trained under the scheme run by the National
Council for the Training of Journalists, which represents the principal press
organisations. The scheme consists of ‘on-the-job’ experience, supplemented
THE PRESS
Press
Institutions
465
by special courses in relevant subjects. Trainees are apprenticed for three
years after a six-month probationary period, and take a professional
examination at the end of their training. About 600 young reporters and
photographers enter the scheme each year. Jobs as trainee reporters on
newspapers are also found for students who successfully complete experimental
one-year preparatory courses for school-leavers which began in 1967.
The National Council also runs week-long practical courses for young
journalists to supplement experience gained on the job; training courses in
such subjects as science, financial and industrial reporting, and in sub-editing
for senior journalists; intensive courses for graduate entrants—100 graduates,
about ten per cent of the total intake, entered the profession in 1966 and the
number is steadily increasing; and special courses for journalists on periodicals
and for public relations and industrial journalists wanting extended training
in journalist techniques.
A two-year inquiry into the training and education of journalists is being
undertaken by the University of Sussex, with the support of the newspaper
industry and in co-operation with the National Council, to enable a post¬
graduate course in journalism to be designed.
Under the Commonwealth Press Union Travelling Fellowship Scheme for
the training and education of young journalists throughout the Common¬
wealth, each year about ten journalists from overseas spend six months
in the United Kingdom: three months in the offices of newspapers or
periodicals and three months acquiring a general idea of life in Britain.
A limited number of travelling scholarships are also awarded to British
journalists to enable them to visit Commonwealth countries overseas.
The Thomson Foundation provides scholarships and organises training
courses at the Foundation’s Centre in Cardiff for journalists from all parts of
the world.
Both employers and employees in the industry are well organised. On the
employers’ side the most important organisations are the Newspaper
Proprietors Association, whose members are proprietors of the national
daily and Sunday newspapers; the Newspaper Society, which represents
the regional and London suburban press; the Scottish Daily Newspaper
Society, which represents the interests of daily and Sunday newspapers in
Scotland; the Scottish Newspaper Proprietors Association, which represents
the owners of weekly newspapers in Scotland; Associated Northern Ireland
Newspapers, whose members are the proprietors of weekly newspapers
in Northern Ireland; and the Periodical Publishers Association, whose
membership embraces the independent publishers of trade and technical
publications and general magazines. On the employees’ side there are the
Institute of Journalists (loj), founded in 1884 as the National Association
of Journalists, and the National Union of Journalists (NUJ), founded in 1907.
All working journalists (including those engaged in radio, television, public
relations and freelance journalism) are eligible for membership of both these
organisations. To facilitate an eventual merger, an interim arrangement has
been made for dual membership without the payment of extra subscriptions.
The aims of the NUJ and the loj are the improvement of the economic status
of journalists, the promotion of their professional welfare, and the safeguarding
of the status of the press and its editorial staffs. Total membership is nearly
23,000 (NUJ about 20,500, loj about 2,350).
The main aims of the Guild of British Newspaper Editors are to sustain
the dignity of editorship, to raise and safeguard the professional status of
466
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The Press
Council
The Press and
the Law
editors, to protect the rights and freedom of the press, and to improve the
education and training of journalists: the Guild has about 350 members. The
British Association of Industrial Editors is the professional organisation to
which most editors of house journals belong.
The Printing and Kindred Trades Federation is the federation of the
printing trade unions which include the National Graphical Association, the
Society of Graphical and Allied Trades, and the Scottish Typographical
Association.
The Press Council, established in 1953 and reconstituted in 1963, has a lay
chairman and 25 members. Its aims are: to preserve the established freedom
of the British press; to maintain the character of the British press in
accordance with the highest professional and commercial standards; to keep
under review any developments likely to restrict the supply of information of
public interest and importance; to deal with complaints about the conduct of
the press or the conduct of persons and organisations towards the press; to
report on developments in the British press which may tend towards greater
concentration or monopoly; to make representation on appropriate occasions
to the Government, to organs of the United Nations and to press organisations
abroad; to publish its adjudications and periodical reports recording its work
and to review from time to time developments in the British press and the
factors affecting them. Reports, which include statistics of the newspaper and
periodical press and a series of articles examining the structure of the leading
press groups, are published annually.
The press in Britain has the same freedom as the individual to do and say
what it likes provided it does not transgress the law; in general, it is at liberty
to comment on matters of public interest. Apart from enactments relating
directly to such matters as the registration of newspapers for postal purposes,
there are no specific press laws but certain statutes include clauses which
apply, in particular or incidentally, to the press. These relate to such matters
as the extent of newspaper ownership in television companies; the transfer of
newspaper assets (see p. 460); the right of press representatives to be admitted
to meetings of local authorities; restrictions on the publication of (a) divorce
and domestic proceedings in courts of law, (b) advertisement and investment
circulars, which are governed by Acts dealing with fraud, and (c) advertise¬
ments of remedies for certain diseases, which are covered by public health
legislation; agreements between the Post Office and newspaper proprietors
on telegraphic communications, which must comply with telegraphs legis¬
lation; restrictions on certain types of prize competition; and copyrights,
which come under copyright laws.
Of particular relevance to the work of the press are the laws on: libel and
defamation; contempt of court—a newspaper may not publish comments on
the conduct of judicial proceedings which are likely to prejudice their
reputation for fairness before or during the actual proceedings nor may it
publish before or during a trial anything which might tend to influence the
result; and seditious libel, incitement to disaffection and revealing official
secrets.
Legal proceedings against the press are comparatively infrequent; the
majority of actions that do take place are libel actions brought by private
individuals. In such cases, the editor, proprietor, publisher, printer and
distributor of the newspaper, as well as the author of the article, may all be
held responsible.
19 Sport
Central and
Local
Government
Participation
In Britain, the word ‘sport’ is used generally to describe such activities as
organised outdoor games, athletics, field or country sports, indoor games,
aquatic sports, and such popular pursuits as horse-racing, dog-racing, show
jumping, riding, boxing, rock climbing, motor racing, cycling and rifle
shooting as well as those (for instance, archery, fencing, gliding and ice-skating)
which, although less popular judged by the number of participants and
spectators, all have their own devotees. Those who engage in sport may be
professionals (that is, paid players) or amateurs.1 Professionals keep up the
technical standards of the sports in which they take part and spectators make
a vital contribution by their enthusiasm and their financial support; but the
sporting life of Britain derives its character principally from the amateur
element—people who devote time and energy to organising sport and to
teaching and training, as well as the many thousands of all ages who engage
in sport for pleasure alone.
The Government is not directly concerned with the organisation or promotion
of sport in Britain but it has assumed responsibility for providing encourage¬
ment, guidance and help; it gives grant-aid to voluntary bodies towards
approved expenditure on playing fields, swimming baths and other facilities
for physical recreation, and to national voluntary organisations in Great
Britain for various purposes, including the holding of world championships
and events of similar importance in Britain. The Government is advised on
matters relating to the development of amateur sport and physical recreation
by the Sports Council, which also fosters co-operation between the Depart¬
ment of Education and Science and the Scottish Education Department and
the voluntary organisations concerned. The chairman of the Council is the
Parliamentary Under-Secretary for Education and Science, who is the minister
with special responsibility for sport. Nine regional sports councils in England,
one council in Scotland and one in Wales, composed of representatives of local
authorities and sporting organisations, have also been set up. In Northern
Ireland the Ministry of Education is advised by the Youth and Sports Council.
The Council works in close co-operation with the Central Council of
Physical Recreation, the National Playing Fields Association, the Scottish
equivalents of these bodies, and the British Olympic Association.
Direct Exchequer assistance to voluntary sports organisations in Great
Britain amounted to over ^1-5 million in 1966. This assistance takes the form
of capital grants towards the provision of facilities and, in the case of national
organisations, grants towards the costs of administration and coaching
schemes and participation in international events overseas. Specific grants
are not available to local authorities for expenditure on sports facilities, but
such expenditure is taken into account in determining the aggregate amount
of Exchequer grant to local authorities under the rate support grant system
(see p. 76)
1 Some sports, for example, athletics, Rugby Union football, hockey and rowing, are
entirely amateur, but in other sports the distinction between professional and amateur
status is becoming less strictly defined.
468
Facilities for
Sport
Composite
National Bodies
The Central Council
of Physical

BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
In Northern Ireland £212,271 in grants was given to public authorities
and voluntary organisations for sports facilities and coaching schemes in
1966.
The Secretary of State for Education and Science, the Secretary of State for
Scotland and the Ministry of Education for Northern Ireland require that
all publicly maintained schools shall provide for the physical education
(gymnastics, games, athletics, dancing and swimming) of their pupils. Schools
in the national systems (excepting those solely for infants) must have their
own playing field, or the use of one, and most secondary schools have a
gymnasium—local authorities being encouraged to make these facilities avail¬
able also to public organisations. Facilities for, and instruction in, many
kinds of sport are likewise provided at the independent preparatory and public
schools and at the universities (some of which have departments of physical
education). Under the Public Health Acts and the Physical Training and
Recreation Acts local authorities are empowered to provide playing fields.
They also provide gymnasia, tennis courts, golf courses and swimming baths
on an increasing scale. Sports facilities for employees are provided by industrial
and commercial concerns. An appraisal of major sports facilities throughout
the country is being made by the regional sports councils.
The national voluntary organisations most closely concerned with the general
development of sport are the Central Council of Physical Recreation, the
Scottish Council of Physical Recreation, and the National Playing Fields
Association. The British Olympic Association, whose main functions are
connected with the participation of British teams and competitors in the
Olympic Games, is also interested in all matters likely to benefit sport or
physical recreation in Britain as a whole. In addition, each sport has its own
governing body, with, in most cases, entirely separate autonomous governing
bodies in Scotland and Northern Ireland.
The Central Council of Physical Recreation (CCPR), which is an association
of all national bodies in England, Wales and Northern Ireland concerned with
the development of post-school physical recreation, provides the Sports
Council with such services as may be agreed in the administration, technical
and research fields. Its funds are partly raised by voluntary contributions but
it also receives grants from the Department of Education and Science and
from the Ministry of Education for Northern Ireland. Its General Secretary
is also the Director of the Sports Council.
The CCPR consists of about 300 members. Of these over 200 are members
representing national bodies concerned wholly or in part with the development
of some branch of physical recreation—the governing bodies of games and
sport, the national outdoor activity and dance associations, the youth service
organisations, and many others concerned with education, physical education
and health. The Council’s headquarters are in London and it has nine
regional offices in other parts of England. Its activities in Wales are controlled
by a representative Welsh committee, and in Northern Ireland by a separate
section with its own executive committee.
Broadly, the Council’s function is to promote all forms of physical
recreation. Its activities include the organisation of courses for coaches and
instructors, courses in personal performance, lectures, displays and other
publicity events. In 1966—67 over 2,000 such courses, attended by nearly

The Scottish
Council of Physical

The National

Association
National

47,000 people, were organised. Its staff give advisory, technical and adminis¬
trative help wherever required, but particularly to the headquarters, regional,
county and local branches of the constituent organisations and to local
educational authorities and industrial concerns. Its regional officers have been
appointed as secretaries to the newly formed Regional Sports Councils which
aim to promote co-operation and co-ordination in the provision of sports
facilities within their regions.
The Scottish Council of Physical Recreation (SCPR) is the counterpart in
Scotland of the CCPR, and has 140 affiliated organisations, including the
governing bodies of all the Scottish sports; it receives a grant-in-aid from
the Scottish Education Department.
The main aim of the National Playing Fields Association (NPFA) is to
stimulate the provision of playing fields and playgrounds, especially for
children, by publicity and technical and financial assistance. Since its
inception in 1925 it has distributed over £1-7 million in the form of grants
for playing field and playground schemes and about £234,000 in the form of
loans. It assists more than 400 schemes a year.
The NPFA council is composed of representatives of the governing bodies
of various sports organisations, of the British Olympic Association and the
CCPR, and of a number of educational bodies, voluntary youth organisations,
physical education associations and local authorities. The national headquarters
in London employs a small full-time staff, including a technical and
research department which gives advice on all aspects of recreational
planning including the provision and layout of indoor and outdoor sports
facilities. Advice is also given on matters relating to children’s playgrounds,
play leadership schemes, and the play and recreational needs of children from
their earliest years. The Association derives its funds mainly from voluntary
contributions but it also receives a small contribution towards administrative
costs from the Department of Education and Science.
The NPFA has branches in Scotland and Northern Ireland; there are also
branches in nearly every English and Welsh county; administration is carried
out, in the main, on a voluntary basis—in many cases in association with a
local authority or Rural Community Council.
There are five National Recreation Centres in Britain, outside London—two
in England, one in Wales and two in Scotland—administered by the CCPR
and the SCPR. The centres, all but one of which were established by voluntary
funds, provide a wide range of courses for coaches, instructors and per¬
formers in many games, sports and other physical activities. A programme of
improvements, the capital cost of which will be borne by the Department of
Education and Science, and, for Scotland, by the Scottish Education Depart¬
ment, is being carried out and will continue over the next two or three years.
A sailing centre, likewise to be administered by the CCPR, is to be established,
at Cowes, Isle of Wight, to provide courses on sailing, boat handling, cruising,
navigation, racing, boat maintenance and boat building, for school and youth
groups and for adults.
The Crystal Palace National Recreation Centre in London covers 36 acres;
has a main stadium with seating for 12,000 spectators; a sports hall with
seating for 2,000 spectators; a swimming hall with pools of Olympic dimen¬
sions, a teaching pool and a gallery for 2,000 spectators; an indoor cricket
school; practice rooms suitable for all indoor activities; a hostel for 140
residents; and staff housing. The Centre, managed by the CCPR, is designed
